author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: pain in left hip with popping/ dislocating feeling
content: Hello, To evaluate the cause of the hip popping and pain, start with a plain x-ray and consult your local orthopedist. You may also consider pelvic or lower spine problems which can refer pain to the hip. Occasionally, we use an MRI to assess the structure within or around the hip joint. Treatment plan options follow the results of the clinical exam and special tests.   Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Ulnar nerver transposition post-op problems/ questions
content: Hello, Numbness around the incision site is not surprising as some small sensory nerve branches may have be damaged either before or during the surgery.  Time will tell if the sensation will return. Discoloration or bruising of the tissue post operatively is also normal.   Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee pain when bending it
content: Hello, Knee pain - behind the knee may be caused by tendonitis, hamstring sprain or referred pain from within the knee.  Occasionally, in certain patient population - those with a high risk - a thrombosis (blood clot) in the vein or artery is a concern.  At 18 y.o., the most likely cause is in the muscle, tendon or within the knee.  Check with your family physician for an accurate and complete diagnosis and treatment plan.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Ankle Pain - Possible atfl (need advice please)
content: Hello, Thanks for the pictures and inquiry. Sometimes severe ankle sprains can damage the outside ligaments and make the ankle unstable.  Besides the risk of recurrent sprains, an unstable ankle can cause pain and eventual arthritis. I recommend seeing an orthopedist for a clinical examination and x-rays.  Furthermore, an MRI may help view the outside ligament for damage.  In any event, you will need to protect the ankle from further sprains.  For this, perform ankle rehab exercise per your physical therapist.  Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Mon Oct 25, 2010 4:33 pm

author: SurfDesigner  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Jun 25, 2010 10:48 am Gender: Male
title: Possible Forearm Tendon Rupture
content: Last fall, after finally being diagnosed with serious tendonitis in both of my arms and discontinuing work (shipping and receiving), I had an as yet unexplained experience: While tearing the package for a tea bag, I felt a deep "itchy feeling" on the inside of my left forearm, a few inches up from the wrist. I rubbed the area a couple of times and felt a snap - I KNOW something let go, because the tension in my muscles suddenly eased, but the pain was so severe that I almost passed out. I immediately developed a bulge in the muscle just below my elbow, and right after that my entire arm started swelling - from fingers up through shoulder and into my upper left chest area. I took Motrin 800 that had been prescribed for tendonitis pain, and went to see my orthopedic doctor the next day. Swelling in my arm had subsided by then, but I still had a bulge below my elbow. Doc's diagnosis was "I doubt that anything snapped, it just looks like a bruise to me, keep taking the Motrin and you will be fine. 8 months later, I still have an abnormal bulge in my arm below the elbow, occasional pain in my forearm with use, no gripping strength in my left hand, and inability to flex my thumb to my palm. I still believe that a tendon ruptured, but what tests can I request that will prove it?
posted_time: Post  by SurfDesigner » Fri Jun 25, 2010 11:04 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male

content: Hello, Yes, you may have ruptured a tendon.  The best test for diagnosis (apart from clinical exam) is an MRI.  Take care.

author: JERTX  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Jun 29, 2010 1:54 pm Gender: Female
title: Post fasciotomy for CECS--ants crawling sensation, cramping
content: Good afternoon- I am 4 years post fasciotomy for chronic exertional compartment syndrome.  All four compartments in both legs were released. My right leg, has some nerve damage with numb spots--primarily on the outside of my leg and the top of my foot.  I also seem to be prone to posterior tibial tendinitis in that same leg.  Other than that, the surgery was a success.  The past 2-3 months, I have been getting the sensation of ants crawling on my legs.  It is not constant and both legs are affected.  It feels exactly as described and is bothersome, especially when I am sitting outdoors.  I have to look, because sometimes it is, in fact, an ant!  In addition, the outside of my left leg cramps up quite often.  The cramp starts halfway up my leg and goes down into my ankle and the outside of my foot.  This happens at rest and when I am active.  This started about 3-4 months ago.  Could these symptoms be related to my surgery?  I am not sure if it is "just one of those things" that comes along with the surgery or if it could be something more.  Thanks for your time.
posted_time: Post  by JERTX » Tue Jun 29, 2010 2:08 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Post fasciotomy for CECS--ants crawling sensation, cramping
content: Hello, In general, since you had nerve damage in the compartment and have residual sensory changes, you should expect strange sensations e.g. "ants on the legs".    The cramping may be a slightly different story as this could be caused by circulatory or hydration problems and ought to be evaluated by your family physician.  Take care.

title: Re: Shoulder Pain..Help Please
content: Hello, If the upper limb has lost strength due to nerve impingement, it would be worthwhile to find the source and correct any problems.  An MRI of the cervical spine may be in order. author: Moldypeach  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Jul 02, 2010 5:51 am Gender: Female
title: Hard, growing lump in forearm
content: I have had a lump in my left forearm, just below the bend of the elbow since around February of this year. It started out completely under the skin - it was pea sized but could only be felt if specifcally looking for it and was not visible to the eye. I randomly noticed it one day but because I couldn't see anything I sort of forgot about it. About a month and a half later I noticed that it had grown, and was visible to the eye as a small lump protruding from the skin. It didn't really hurt when prodded or squeezed, and felt very hard and didn't move much. I went to the doctor about it, who said that it was not a ganglion and was not really sure what it was so referred me to have an ultrasound scan. I had to wait about a month and a half to get the referral and appointment and in that time the lump has continued to grow - it is now about the size of a grape or almond and is protruding from the skin and is very noticeable when my arm is stretched out. It has also started to become painful when pressing/feeling it. The skin around it is not bruised or different in color to the rest of my arm.  I had the ultrasound scan done a few days ago, and was told that the lump was not connected to the tendon/joint/bone/vein etc, and as such they still weren't sure where it was coming from. I have been referred to have an MRI scan.  What could this be? I am obviously quite concerned that it is continuing to grow and becoming painful, and things like tumours and cancer keep going through my mind though I'm sure there are many other explanations. I am almost 24 years old and female, if this has any bearing on things.  Many thanks.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male

content: Hello, You are doing the right thing in having the lump evaluated.   In the end, the lump will likely be surgically removed since it is growing and causing pain.   Likely the lump is non cancerous but should be sent for analysis once removed to determine definitively if it is cancerous or not.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Tightness in knee when standing
content: Hello, Yes, you may have damaged the lateral collateral ligament and/or the meniscus (padding or extra cartilage inside the knee).   First, x-ray the knee to rule out fractures - even small chipped bone.  If the clinical exam findings are consistent with ligament or meniscal damage, you may either try physical therapy or have an MRI. An orthopedist certainly would be able to address these issues.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Grinding left shoulder cuff pain
content: Hello, X-ray will show arthritis in the shoulder joint.  If present, a cortisone shot may help.  Otherwise, I would evaluate the shoulder for adhesive capsulitis (aka frozen shoulder) and rotator cuff impingement/bursitis/tear.  Both can be assessed clnically and both conditions can occur simultaneously.  Therefore if physio therapy has not helped, consider an MRI to evaluated the soft tissue structures in the shoulder.  Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Sat Oct 09, 2010 12:47 pm

posted_time: Post  by Magick711 » Tue Jul 13, 2010 9:20 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: s/p orif s/p R Clavicle FX
content: Hello, In most cases of clavicle fractures, the treatment of choice is to brace the shoulders for comfort and use analgesics as needed and allow 4-6 weeks for healing.  The definite time to operate occurs when the skin is broken by one of the fractured fragments (open fracture). Otherwise there is no additional benefit from surgically reducing or fixing the fracture. It is hard to determine from your note the source of the pain - the shoulder joint versus the muscles around the shoulder versus the fracture site itself.   Over time the fracture should heal and limitations are minimal. I would suggest having a physician re-evaluate the shoulder to check for other problems or causes of dysfunction.   There may have been other structures damaged during the initial clavicle fracture incident.  Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Sat Oct 09, 2010 12:28 pm

author: hsuga3  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Jul 13, 2010 11:23 pm Gender: Male
title: Continous pain in sternum, sc joint, and chest wall
content: Hi I have experienced an ongoing problem that I first noticed about 3 and a half years ago. I am a 21 year old male who tends to be very physically active as long as my body can keep up. When I was 18 I began to notice what I perceived as chest wall pain. It felt like all around my right chest wall and sternum that the cartilage was more prominent and tender. I saw multiple doctors and had all types of tests and scans and blood work done and the only diagnosis they came up with was costochondritis. I attempted rest and ice along with nsaids, and I have completed that same procedure multiple times throughout these years hoping for anything that will help. Nothing ever helped. I continued to just deal with it and I would go through phases where I would do no physical activity at all, to maybe light activity or just basketball and no weightlifting, to attempting to workout the best I can. It has really come in the way of everything for me since I have a passion for working out and playing basketball. But I have seen all types of doctors from orthopedists, to thoracic doctors to thoracic surgeons to cardiologists to internists. I finally found a doctor last summer who thought he knew what the problem was and said i had abnormal cartilage in my ribs, I had surgery performed and he removed cartilage and some rib under my pec muscle on the right side of my chest. I thought I had a solution but another problem surfaced and the sternum pain and tightness all in my chest never went away. My major pain areas now are going from the midline in my sternum towards my right side (so my ribs and muscles in my right pec) and my right clavicle and sc joint. I have done so much research on all these things for so long and am just hoping for some insight and something to help me get better. My sc joint on my right side and my sternum both crack and click and constantly bother me and always make me feel uncomfortable and in pain, it also feels like all the muscles in my right pec are tighter and I can just tell something wrong is going on.  I am a student in college and I can not even study without being consistently bothered by this pain. It also effects me in so many more ways but I am just hoping for some help, and everything on my left side is completely normal and doesn't bother me at all. I am hoping for any beneficial insight, advice, or opinions on this as it is such a rare case and I am yet to find a doctor or someone who can diagnose my problem and help me move forward. Thank you in advance
posted_time: Post  by hsuga3 » Tue Jul 13, 2010 11:40 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Continous pain in sternum, sc joint, and chest wall
content: Hello, This is a difficult case.   You have had multiple specialists evaluate the rib cage and thoracic cavity and no definitive diagnosis besides costochondritis.  Typically, this condition resolves with NSAIDS and time.  In your case the condition lingers. There may not be a fix per se. But finding activities / exercise you can tolerate and analgesics (creams, tablets etc ) is important.  Other treatment options are acupuncture and chiropractic the first for pain relief and the second to assess and treat any mal positioning of the thoracic spine and rib cage.    Take care.

posted_time: Post  by tinker44 » Fri Jul 16, 2010 3:20 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: cruciate ligament injury
content: Hello, Studies have shown that early surgical intervention of torn ACL (anterior cruciate ligament : stabilizing ligament within the knee) can decrease the risk of developing cartilage damage.  Since conservative treatment with physical therapy has not improved function, pain and swelling or has done so minimally at best, it would be worthwhile seeing the knee specialist for a re-evaluation.  You may agree to opt for ligament reconstruction and meniscus repair.   Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Tue Oct 05, 2010 12:22 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee Cap Dislocation
content: Hello, It sounds like the knee cap is dislocating laterally.  Conservative treatment includes bracing, quadricep muscle strengthening and retraining, stretching and pain control measures.  If conservative measures fail and dislocation becomes chronic and debilitating then surgery is an option.  A lateral reticulum release would likely be done - surgically releasing or cutting the tight fibrous tissue under the skin just to the outside of the knee cap.  Risks and benefits of this procedure should be discussed with an orthopedic surgeon.  Take care.

title: hip joint pain during activity
content: Hi, I have had pain in my left hip joint, which I only feel when I bend my leg or my left leg is put into motion where the hip joint is used. Also, because I only noticed it while exercising, this tells me the pain is only felt when activity forces my leg to bend causing hip joint pain. I am 26 years old, and I can't remember any trauma that may have occurred to cause this pain. I am about 5'10, and I used to weigh close to 300, but now I am close to 200. Would this weight have any impact on why I am having this hip joint pain? Also, I used to have high blood sugar issues (diabetes) because of my weight, but this has also come down as well to regular levels. This pain is felt with motion, I have tried to stretch to perhaps increase the range of motion, but I think this has just caused me to feel more pain. Can anyone please offer insight into this problem? Unfortunately, I am a hypochondriac, and I imagine the worst case scenario which is cancer. However, this pain has not increased or gotten worse since 2007, and I would think that bone cancer would progress. Insight would be highly appreciated.
posted_time: Post  by ezilymed » Sun Jul 18, 2010 1:07 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: hip joint pain during activity
content: Hello, Your hip pain can arise from a number of structures in, around or near the hip.  First, lumbar (lower back) issues can refer pain to the hip.  Second, the  hip joint itself including the cartilage and labrum (padding in the hip joint) can be damaged.  Thirdly, the ligaments and tendon around the joint can be inflamed.  Fourthly, the muscle around the hip can be strained, sore or tight. In essence, have a orthopedist, physical therapist or physiatrist evaluate the hip for proper diagnosis.  Likely, the condition is benign and fixed with conservatie treatment (ice, NSAIDS and theraputic exercise).  Take care.

title: Re: 'High-Grade' ankle ligament injury, w/ MRI results.
content: Hello, The MRI results show the results of a severe lateral ankle sprain.  Surgical repair is not likely needed unless the ankle joint is unstable (from a ligament tear - not reported on MRI).  Be patient with your rehabilitation as several structures were damaged.  Bone bruises or contusion take awhile to heal.  Expect at least 3-4 more weeks of recovery until the ankle starts to feel good.  Take care.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Abnormal Shaped Chest.
content: Hi, Thank you for your post. This condition is known as "Pectus Carinatum" (pigeon chest). (Carina, is a Latin word for the keel of a ship or for its entire hull Carina, in ancient Roman architecture, is the name given to any building resembling a ship. More simply, it means a "ridge").  This condition is one among the several protrusion anomalies of the chest wall. This has been further classified depending upon the site of maximun protrusion as, - manubrial (chondromanubrial), or - at the body of the sternum (chondrogladiolar).  It may be, - congenital, or - aquired (ex., following median sternotomies).  There is a male preponderance. The deformity may be evident at birth or become noticeable during puberty. Some cases may be associated with congenital heart disease. Minimal deformities are usually asymptomatic.  In conditions of normality, as the chest wall moves during the respiratory cycle, both the anteroposterior (A-P) and side-to-side diameters of the chest increase during inspiration.The sternum moves forward to increase the A-P diameter.In severe forms of pectus carinatum, this movement becomes severely restricted causing respiratory difficulties.  Management: Upto the age of 18 years, compression braces have been found to be useful in some cases. These act in a manner similar to the orthodontic braces. In adults (especially who have respiratory compromise),surgery may be the only option. Best wishes!
posted_time: Post  by Dr.M.Aroon kamath » Fri Sep 03, 2010 10:31 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: "cave feet" (too arched)
content: Hello, It sounds like you may have been suffering from chronic plantar fasciitis coupled with a pes cavus foot ...and the rear foot was tilted inward too much (inverted) hence the surgery. With chronic foot problems including pain and abnormally shaped foot, it is important to do a few things for long term health. 1. Have a specialist evaluate the entire leg - biomechanical problems with the feet usually affect the knee and hip and all the soft tissue in between and address deficits  2. Treat the immediate pain and any future flare ups with NSAIDS, hot and cold packs, proper orthotic use and theraputic exercise  3. Proper foot wear.  Specialists include podiatrist and physical therapists.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Repetative joint dislocations in various joints in my body??
content: Hello, There is a condition called hypermobility syndrome which describes general hypermobility of both joints and skin.   Four criteria help define this syndrome: 1. hyperextension the pinky finger at the knuckle to 90 degrees or extend the thumb to touch the forearm - painlessly. 2. extend the elbow 10 degrees beyond neutral 3. extend the knee 10 degrees beyond neutral 4. touch the floor with palms without bending the knees.  Two connective tissue diseases (rare conditions but have some potential serious manifestations) need to be ruled out when general hypermobility exists: 1. Marfan Syndrome  2. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome  For proper evaluation and to rule out the above two conditions, see your family physician.  Take care
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Mon Aug 09, 2010 2:22 pm

title: Subchondral Cyst in left wrist
content: My husband is in the Army and recently had an MRI done on his left wrist and was refered to an orthopedic doctor but the doctor happened to be a Major and military affliliated doctors tend to leave you uninformed with little to no information and I was hoping to lear a little more before his next appointment.   His MRI results were:  There is a 2mm Subchondral cyst along the ulnar aspect of the proximal scaphoid pole. There is a 3cm mutliloculated synovial cyst located along the volar surface of the capitate carpal bone extends distally to the level of the third metacarpal base. Mild subcutaneous adema within the fat adjacent to the scaphoid carpal bone.  I have researched the different cysts on the internet and all the websites I went to were basically saying the subchondral cyst is linked to osteoarthritis, but when my husband asked the Major about it he brushed off the cysts didn't even talk about treatment he just gave him a dex steroid injection and told him it was going to hurt (My husband is 22, no prior injuries in that wrist). He also has tendonitus a few different types actually ( I don't know them). His symptoms are things like pain that increases with use, anti-inflamitories such as naproxen have no effect. His wrist swells with use there is a popping/creaking noise with every movement (different movements produce different noises both his wrist and thumb pop and creak) His pinky and ring finger all the way down to his wrist goes numb, his wrist gets warm to the touch. limited mobility and strength. Pain goes all the way to his shoulder and neck.  Also I read up on the Dex steriod injections and it says multiple injections can break the cartilige and from what I have read about osteoarthritis it basically does the same thing. I am wondering if the Major could have just made my husbands situation worse?  So I guess my question is this, does a subchondral always mean osteoarthritis?  Does his case sound like osteoarthritis? and if not what might it be?
posted_time: Post  by beautifullyimperfect » Thu Jul 29, 2010 1:41 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Subchondral Cyst in left wrist
content: Hello, Not all the research has supported the development of osteoarthritis (OA) from the finding of subchondral cysts.  However, if subchondral cysts do in fact preclude OA, all the more reason to care for the affected area properly - maintain painfree range of motion and strength, use proper analgesia during painful flare ups and protect the joint from trauma and deformity.  Sometimes bracing is needed.  Also, some vitamin C may be in order as some studies have shown this helps in preventing regional pain syndrome (aka reflex sympathic dystrophy) which develops in the limb after trauma or surgery.  A problem with the scaphoid should not cause symptoms in the pinky or ring finger - so the neck and elbow ought to be checked for pinched nerve signs (these fingers are in general innervated by the ulnar nerve and lower levels of the cervical spinal nerve roots.   Otherwise he may benefit from some physical therapy to the wrist and hand to regain function.    Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Mon Aug 09, 2010 1:25 pm

author: wesa0923  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Aug 01, 2010 2:21 pm Gender: Female
title: Do subchondral cysts always mean you have OA?
content: In May 2008 I was throwing a huge trash bag into a dumpster behind where I worked. As I went to toss it in my right shoulder popped really loudly. By the time the District Manager came in my two middle fingers were drawn down into my palm and I couldn't straighten them out. My wrist was swollen to the size of my elbow and my shoulder was in extreme pain. I have had pain for years and have learned to work thru it, so anything that leaves me in tears is REALLY hurting.  The doctor prescribed pain meds, a splint and total rest until the Worker's Comp claim was approved. It took 11 weeks before they finally sent me to an Ortho specialist.  The Ortho gave me an X-ray which showed clear. The strength tests showed that I could not lift with my right arm due to pain in the shoulder and wrist. The middle and first finger of the right hand were numb and tingling.   Nerve tests came back 'normal'. MRI supposedly came back 'normal' or clear. I was then given a shot in the wrist which helped some. Had CT release surgery in July 2009.  I have had trouble ever since. The fingers are still numb and tingle. The wrist and just above it ache when I clap or if I have to drive a car in a wind from the driver's side. The pressure of trying to hold the steering wheel steady puts pressure on my right hand which causes it to ache for a day or two afterward.  I can't even carry a tiny 12" x 12" bag that doesn't even weight 3 lbs in my right hand. When I do the weight causes the hand to go numb and I have pain in the shoulder as if someone is trying to tear my arm off my body.  My attorney has been negotiating with the insurance company for two years now. I was sent in April for an IME with another Ortho. The report I received last week said that the MRI was not clear. It showed the presence of subchondral cysts in my right shoulder.  I had never heard of this type of cyst so I went online to see what I could find out. I too, read the information as basically stating that this type of cyst never shows up unless the person has either Rheumatoid or Osteoarthritis. I too, would like to know if this is correct or can the cysts actually show up by themselves just due to the injury received?  I was fired from my job for "medical  reasons" shortly after the Worker's Comp doctors released me. Medicaid said that I would have to be put on Disability and I have waited 7 months to see if they are going to approve it or not.   I would like to know for sure whether or not the presence of these cysts mean that I do in fact, have OA? I have been told that I have a predisposition to OA due to the fact that I had Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever as a child. I have also been told that if this is, in fact OA, then the disability claim would be automatically approved. So I really need to know whether or not the cysts are indicitive of OA.  Since all of this happened, I have also had problems with my left knee swelling and being extremely painful after I stand for more than a few minutes at a time on it. My left hip has also had periods for several years where it will suddenly 'lock' on me. I can't swing my left leg to take a step and I can't move sideways to even get into a car or sit in a chair. It has gotten worse since this accident at work.   When it locks up on me it will last for up to 10 minutes. However, even after it 'unlocks', my hip will feel as if the femure is out of socket and I don't feel secure taking a step. It gives the feeling that if I put my weight on it, it will give way and I will fall. That lasts for up to 90 minutes before some normalacy returns.  Some days are essentially pain free and I can do almost all of the things I used to. Other days it is all I can do to get out of bed. On those days I feel like the Tin Man on the Wizard Of OZ. It is as if my joints are 'frozen' and I need to have them oiled up so they will work correctly.  So I need to know: does the presence of these subchondral cysts mean definitively that I have OA or could they just show up by themselves due to the injury received at work? With the other things going on in my hip and knee, I have a tendency to think I do have OA. What do you think?  Thanks much for taking the time to answer so we can stop wondering.
posted_time: Post  by wesa0923 » Sun Aug 01, 2010 3:22 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Do subchondral cysts always mean you have OA?
content: Hello, Several studies have shown a relationship between the development of osteoarthritis (OA) (OA is characterized by cartilage damage, osteophytes - bone spurs, and subchondral sclerosis - thickening) and bone activity in the subchondral area (below the cartilage).    There are mixed reports however regarding the prediction or diagnosis of OA in the presence of subchondral cyst without other evidence of OA signs or symptoms.  In essence, without other signs or symptoms of OA, subchondral cysts may or may not predispose to OA.  The evidence seems equivocal.  Damage to the rotator cuff ought to be considered with subchondral cysts - there are on occasion associations between the two.  Take care.

content: Hello, Barefoot running seems fine for some people usually those with a very moderate arch profile or slightly elevated arch but running surface should also be considered. content: Hello, With the pop sound then pain and swelling, some local trauma from normal walking occurred. author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Morning Tender Feet
content: Hello,  Plantar fasciitis ought to be considered as a leading possible diagnosis. The tissue connecting the base of the toes to the heel is called the plantar fascia.   Often this tissue becomes tender and inflamed ...sometimes due to normal stress of daily activities and often certain foot types lend themselves to the problem. One such foot type is a high arch where cumulative chronic stress on the plantar fascia can caused inflammation and pain.  Treatment includes NSAIDs, ice and/or heat packs and specific exercises.  Orthotics (specially made shoe inserts) can help too.  For specific diagnosis and treatment plan, see your family doctor.  Take care.

title: Deformed Left Rib
content: On the left side of my ribs there is a big dent...it does not pain or anything but looks awkward...i am very worried about this. Any help would be appreciated.   This is the picture of my chest.
posted_time: Post  by Hrangwala » Sat Jul 24, 2010 6:00 am

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Deformed Left Rib
content: Hi, Chest wall deformities are mostly  - congenital but  - may be acquired due to trauma(accidental/surgical).  They spectrum of clinical presentations is very wide ranging from a localized simple bulge or a depresion to the extremely severe forms such as the thoracic insufficiency syndrome (TIS).  Thoracic Insufficiency Syndrome (TIS) has been defined by as the inability of the thorax to support normal respiration or lung growth, resulting in respiratory insufficiency.  There are 3 types of the more common congenital chest wall deformities seen in clincal practice;  - pectus excavatum,  - pectus carinatum and  - Poland’s syndrome.   Poland syndrome is a rare birth defect and appears with lateral depression of the ribs most commonly on the right side (75% of patients).The incidence of Poland syndrome is approximately 1 case per 32,000 live births, and  is almost always sporadic or nonfamilial.   It is also called as Poland’s anomaly or Poland’s syndactyly. When the defect occurs on the left side,there are chances of the heart and lungs being vulnerable because they are covered only by a thin layer of skin and tissue.  Poland syndrome is associated with congenital absence or incomplete development of the pectoralis minor muscles and the costal cartilages in relation to this muscle. Hypoplasia of the breast /subcutaneous tissue(on the involved side), lack of axillary hair and hand and upper extremity defects may also be associated.  It is probable that the deformity as seen in the attached photograph may happen to be a feature of underlying poland syndrome.  Surgical treatment for Poland syndrome: Minor defects may not need surgical correction other than for cosmetic reasons.More severe forms may need surgical correction(especially the left sided forms). Reconstruction of the chest wall with autologous rib graft has remained a standard 'open' surgical procedure in most situations. Endoscopically assisted reconstruction has been reported. Tissue expansion with tissue expanders followed by a second-stage endoscopic latissimus dorsi harvest and reconstruction has been reported.  I hope that the deformity in your case is completely asymptomatic. If this is the case, you may choose to leave it alone. It is advisable however, to exclude poland's syndrome by consulting your regular doctor. Best wishes!

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: joint problem, cracking noise/pain in knee-osteochondrosis?
content: Hello, If your school has a physical therapy department, be a subject for one of their teaching labs to have them evaluate the knee.  In the clinic, the ligaments, meniscus, muscles and tendons can be assessed.  Proper exercises can be given too.  If the problem persists, an MRI may be indicated.  MRI would define any structural damage in and around the knee and testing would either precede or coincide with a scheduled visit to the orthopedist.   The crunching often comes from the patellofemoral joint.  Rehab involves specific set of exercises (stretching and strengthening) and avoidance of painful activities. Other noises around the joint can be normal tendon gliding over bone but should be checked as structural instability or muscle imbalances can also cause it.   Take care.

title: Re: Knee pain on driving or bending knee
content: Hello, I like the way you are thinking about this knee pain...ruling out possible causes (bone, muscle, ligament). Particularly in the spine, it is hard to determine the exact structure causing the pain...with the knee however, it is easier (bone vs muscle vs tendon vs ligament vs cartilage vs meniscus or a combination of structures).  After a couple of months of pain with negative x-rays, I might suggest two actions in order. 1. Conservative treatment: NSAIDS and physical therapy (therapeutic exercise, manual treatments, hot/cold modalities).  Both can be prescribed/recommended by your family physician.  2. If no progress or if a complete clinical evaluation shows likely structural damage, do an MRI...and proceed with appropriate care.  All the best to you.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Ace bandage for patella alta?
content: Hi,  Patella alta: is an abnormally high-riding patella and is associated with a long patella tendon.This can be, in exceptionally rare cases congenital but, most cases will be aquired.   In a healthy knee, the height of the patella is roughly equal in length to the patella tendon. In patella alta, the ratio of the tendon length to the patella body length is increased, placing the patella in an elevated position that greatly increases the risk for dislocation of the patella.  There are many kinds of orthoses available for patellofemoral dysfunctions.  Elasto-crepe bandages are indicated in situations wherein one aims to reduce pain and swelling (inflammatory conditions or acute trauma). It may not be much of a help in patella alta, as it may not assist in optimizing patellar tracking. No harm may ensue however, by using this(go in for latex-free versions, to be safer).  A plethora of Knee Supports are available in the market. They come in various designs. Generally in a Closed Patella version and an Open Patella version.The patellar opening is claimed enhance comfort and freedom of movement. Patella tracking support is also a feature in some of them. These may be a better choice for you, rather than the elasto-crepe bandages.  It will be best for you to consult a physiotherapist, who will be able to offer you an individualized plan of therapy. Best wishes!

content: I was jumping around a circle with only one feet(alomost like dancing... ), then suddenly i heard a noise (like 2 pop) from  my knee .. then i felt. Now i stretch it straight but while i was trying to walk, it like slides and then i loss my balance and felt. it feel like something is gliding, but it doesnt hurt that much when i was trying to walk straight.  I use cloth to wrap around it and give it support.. i am a high school swimmer in season. that means i am swimming now in the winter.. author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: 2 poping sound at my knee.. wondering what happen
content: Hi, Thank you for this thought-provoking post.  The "pop", sounds very much like either an ACL tear,or a tear of the patellar tendon (ligamentum patellae).   Most often ACL tears occur when considerable amount of momentum and violent forces are involved. Some of the mechanisms involved are,  - One-step-stop landing with the knee hyperextended:  a situation such as, when a baseball player slides into a base with the knee hyperextended.  - Planting and cutting: here, the foot is planted firmly on the ground followed by a twisting movement of the thigh and trunk. This in effect, causes the femur to twist over a stationary tibia. - straight knee landing:  - Pivoting and sudden deceleration: a situation such as, when a soccer player who is running very fast, slows down suddenly, followed by a quick turn in direction.  During a one-leg hop, some of the forces enumerated above may be active, but not necessarily of the magnitude needed to tear the ACL.    But you did hear a 'pop' and that is what usually happens during most ACL injuries.  The question is, how such seemingly innocuous activity such as a one-leg hop could have lead to an ACL injury?  There is some concern that females may be more prone to ACL injuries.The reason for this is unclear, but some sports medicine experts feel it is primarily due to certain anatomical differences between the sexes.  The intercondylar notch:  a depressed area at the lower end of the femur through which the ACL passes - tends to be smaller in females than in males.The walls of this notch may impinge on the ACL during some of the movements discussed earlier and cause fraying. Any fraying of the ACL would tend to be more serious in females, since the female ACL is a relatively thinner structure.    Bony pelvis: the wider female pelvis tends to exaggerate the angle made at the knee between the femur and tibia (normal adult tibiofemoral angle of 7deg in males and 8 deg in females).when the foot is planted on the ground, thus placing excessive stress on the ACL.   Lax ACL: there is a theory that the ACL is more lax in females than males - and therefore more prone to overstretching. There is evidence that  both estrogen and progesterone receptors exist on the ACL and the theory suggests that increases in one or both of these hormones may slacken the ACL.  Muscle  strength: inherently lower muscle power in  the thigh and leg muscles(especially the hamstrings which prevent hyperextension of the knee) and slower muscle-reaction times compared to males, tend to increase the risk of ACL trauma in females.  The other possibility is a quadriceps tendon or patellar tendon rupture. Typically occurs in middle-aged (30-60 year old) individuals,and part-time athletes (weekend warriors).Landing on a slightly flexed knee is the usual mechanism. Patients usually know that something wrong has happened, but they are often unsure of what happened. A "pop" is fairly common. Some patients may be able to walk following the injury, but many may not.There are many causes. Underlying pathology is believed to be repeated 'microtraumas' to the patellar tendon leading to degenerative changes. Several conditions are known to be associated with patellar tendon tears including, - systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE),  - long term systemic corticosteroid therapy & local steroid injections,  - chronic renal failure, - adverse effects of certain medications (ex; ciprofloxacin)  Only after a detailed examination by an orthopedic surgeon, will it be possible to diagnose your injury. Best wishes!

title: Growing longer limbs
content: Hi,   I'm a 18 year old female who wishes to "grow" longer limbs. I'm 5'6" but disproprtionate because of my long torso. There are many products online that "guarantee" results. Do they really work? Thanks
posted_time: Post  by chrisy » Sun Nov 02, 2003 11:42 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Chrissy, Limbs can be grown longer by a process called distraction histogenesis or the Ilizarov method, which is named for the pioneering work done in the early '60s by the Russian physician. There are three phases to the treatment. First, through a small incision, the bone is cut so it can be lengthened. It is done very carefully so the periosteum, or bone covering, is preserved, since it plays a major role in forming new bone. The surgeon then places a device, known as an external fixator, around the leg. It is comprised of lightweight carbon rings or a carbon bar that is attached to the bone, through the leg, by wires and/or screws. The wires are placed under a predetermined amount of tension. The fixator will be used to slowly pull the bone apart.   About five to 10 days after surgery, the second phase, known as distraction, begins. Each day the patient or a family member turns a small wheel on the fixator a total of 1 millimeter. It is usually done in four installments, once at each meal and again at bedtime. The turn results in a space forming between the two ends of the bone. New bone forms within the space. It takes about one month to gain a centimeter of length.   When the desired length or angle of the bone is achieved, the consolidation phase begins. During this time, which is usually twice that of the lengthening time, the new bone and tissue become solid. The fixator is then removed under general anesthesia, and the patient is fitted with a temporary cast or brace. This is to ensure that the new bone does not get broken. Ongoing physical therapy to maintain joint mobility is essential, as is follow-up care. If a patient is negligent about his after-care, temporary or even permanent loss of function may result.  Its a long and very tedious process, but rewarding if the case warrants it. This method has been used with dwarfism to give them extra height.  Regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: human growth hormone
content: Human growth hormone is the principal hormone responsible for our body growth and maturation during our development from childhood to adulthood. Our height is attributed to growth of our skeletal bones. Each of the 'long bones' as they are called has an area called an epiphysis which represents a loose junction near its ends that allows further bone formation under the effects of growth hormone. However, once the bone epiphyses unite at adulthood no amount of growth hormone can make the bones longer. Length of bone in this cases can be grown using surgical techniques.  These injectable hormones, naturally produced in the pituitary gland, are designed for those with a growth hormone deficiency, or those whose growth has been thwarted as long as their epiphyses has not been united.  Athletes use growth hormone to build muscle mass and bone mass (stronger bones - not longer) , this usually comes at a price. There are complications to the use of growth hormone that include glucose intolerance, carpal tunel syndrome, gross hormonal imbalance.  Cheaper alternatives are on the market. Oral tablets, nasal and rectal sprays, and other products currently on the market claim to stimulate growth hormone production. A person soon builds up tolerance to these compounds so that they do no good. Improvements may one day make these so-called "secretagogues" a viable alternative to injectable growth hormone # but that their safety still needs to be proven.  Hence it should be known that the use of these supplements is not FDA approved at this moment as far as I know.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: The epiphysis takes several years till complete union. Below is a rough outline:  1. Proximal epiphysis, which appears approximately at birth, a. Initial union at 14 in females, 16 to 17 in males b. Complete union not until 23 years 2. Distal epiphysis, appears during the first year of life a. Beginning union at 11 to 13 in females, 14 to 16 in males, b. Complete fusion in females between 13 and 18; in males by age 20.  Unfortunately there is no evidence that oral hgh will work after union of epiphysis.

title: new knee pain month after half marathon
content: Hi,  Thank you in advance for taking the time to review.   I am a 25 year old male in great shape with no prior physical health concerns. On June 6th, I ran a half marathon in 1hr 22 min. (6:18 pace) with minimal prior training.  I am now experiencing discomfort in both knees (primarily left knee) with the feeling of fluid draining internally below the patella.  It also feels that my knees may give out when excess weight is applied (i.e. walking up stairs, bending forward).  There is no swelling, or major pain - just uneasiness and unnatural knee bending movement.  The uneasiness is directly over the patella.  I have full range of motion while seated with no pain.  However, when my knee changes degree of flexion, that's when I feel fluid drainage.    These issues surfaced one week ago and have been persistent for the past 5 days.    I would certainly appreciate any insight or advice you may have on moving forward.    THANKS SO MUCH,  J

title: Re: new knee pain month after half marathon
content: There is the possibility that it is patellofemoral pain syndrome. It is quite common in athletes and is a form of arthritis. Physiotherapy can help by strengthening the ligament. If it gets painful do not exceed the pain threshold as this will only slow down the healing process. Rest and icing it will bring about the speadiest recovery.

title: Round the clock Knee pain and Whenever it wants instability
content: In 2002 I landed hard on my right knee during a football game resulting in instability.  I call it popped out, but I am sure it is not the right term.  After that I had seen 3 different doctors and they all told me to go home and ice it and it would be fine, and then it would pop back out again. In 2007 I found a doctor  that finally took some action.  Unfortunately I can't remember the medical name for the surgery but he said that he basically was going in and shrink wrapping tissue to hold me knee together better, and petellular realignment.   About 5 months after the surgery it happened again, and when I saw my surgeon again he said it might sometimes happen.  I do everything to keep it strenghthened and it still happens.  I find it very serious because I can lose my job from missing work, but if my knee is out then I can't work.   I went to see another surgeon for a second opinion and he explained to me that a surgery cutting a tendon and screwing in place could be an option in fixing the popping out problem. When i went back to my normal surgeon he said that there was nothing surgically he could do and that it was tendonititis.  I have that and brusitis in my shoulder and I know the difference.  My shoulder also doesn't pop out like my knee. I tried to go with the other surgeon since I felt he was trying to help me more but he won't except me as a patient.  I need help.  I am 18, and I already feel like giving up on it, and I have a whole life ahead of me.  Could you explain my options or give me some potentional diagnosises.   I am now moderately obese, but can tell you that weight is not causing instability because I was not obese when these symptoms started occuring.  I can't exercise as I used to because of this problem. Any thoughts, locations to visit, or diagnoses would be more than greatly appreciated. Thank You
posted_time: Post  by zeiglerlinae » Wed Nov 11, 2009 12:26 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Round the clock Knee pain and Whenever it wants instability
content: Hello, It sounds like the patella (kneecap) is dislocating (popping out).  The surgery sounds like a lateral release - easing the tension of the tendons on the outside part of the knee. The goal is to reduce the incidents of dislocations.   You have had surgery and now is the time to rehab the knee. I would recommend a physical therapist who has dedicated considerable time working with patients with the diagnosis: patella femoral syndrome or chronic patella dislocation. Whether you have another surgery, rehab is still needed.  And yes, you can exercise - e.g. swimming.  Take care.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: The left side of my body larger than my right side
content: Hi, It is not possible based on the information provided, to guess the diagnosis.   But, there are a few conditions that may explain such features that you have described, - congenital hemihypertrophy and - congenital hemiatrophy.  As the names imply, one half of the body is either overdeveloped (hypertrophy) or underdeveloped (atrophy).  Both are very rare. But in the medical literature, more cases of congenital hemihypertrophy have been reported than the  congenital hemiatrophy.  Hemiatrophy is known to be associated with - Ollier's disease(chondrodysplasia) and - scleroderma.  A disorder of the sympathetic nervous system during fetal development is suspected to be a major underlying cause of congenital hemiatrophy.The sympathetic nervous system is thought to play a trophic role in the development of all body tissues.A disorder of this is thought to lead to loss of sympathetic trophic control over growth.  Hemihypertrophy has been seen to be associated with - medullary sponge kidney, - wilm's tumors, - recurrent hypoglycemia during infancy,  - a predisposition to the development of tumors affecting embryonic tissue, and - malignant tumors of liver and adrenals.   Hemihypertrophy can also be a feature of a group of conditions known as the "overgrowth syndromes". - Klippel-Trenaunay-Weber syndrome, - Proteus syndrome,and - Macrocephaly-cutis marmorata telangiectatica congenita.  As you can well see, there are very many conditions to be considered in coming to a final diagnosis. As this is such a rare feature, most clinicians will be more than glad to evaluate you. Good luck!
posted_time: Post  by Dr.M.Aroon kamath » Mon Jul 12, 2010 12:32 pm

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male

title: Bilateral Clubfoot- reduced movement?
content: Hi,  My brother is 4.  He was born with bilateral clubbed foot, had casting and surgery.  His feet now look "good" according to his doctor.  He started swim lessons today.  He holds his foot stiffly and at a 90 degree angle.  When you swim they expect a greater amount of movement.  When I show him my foot pointed and ask him to do the same he curls his toes, if I try to gently move it into a point he acts like it hurts.  Is there anyway we can (or should we?) encourage him to move his foot more flexibly?  Is this restricted amount of movement common in corrected feet?  Thanks!
posted_time: Post  by CelticLabyrinth » Mon Jun 28, 2010 8:04 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Bilateral Clubfoot- reduced movement?
content: Hello, The surgery and casting have corrected the abnormal club foot position (excessive ankle plantarflexion and inversion). The position you are trying stretch him into is called plantarflexion.  This position was a part of the club foot and thus corrected.   I would not aggressively stretch back into this position as you will cause pain and may undo some of the surgery. Gentle mobility is fine but do not push it.  The correction has likely caused a contracture or stiffening of the ankles so do range of motion but again...not too aggressive.  Consult the podiatrist or orthopedic doctor for their instructions as well.  Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Fri Jul 09, 2010 1:39 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Hyalgan injections
content: Hi, Osteoarthritis(OA) is a degenerative disorder that results from the biochemical breakdown of articular cartilage (Hyaline cartilage) in the synovial joints. Most workers believe that degenerative changes primarily begin in the articular cartilage.  In health, there is an interplay between the articular cartilage, sub-chondral bone and synovial fluid which maintains the health of the components of the synovial articulations for smooth movements and painless weight bearing.  Traditionally, management of osteoarthritis has centered around management of pain, which is the overriding concern for both the patients & clinicians.  Hyaluronates have taken management of osteoarthritis a step further, using an entirely different approach to address the problem.    This approach involves the injection of gel-like substances (hyaluronates) into a joint to supplement the viscous properties of synovial fluid. Sodium hyaluronate is similar to the synovial fluid that surrounds the synovial joints. Synovial fluid acts as a lubricant as well as a shock absorber. It ha s been speculated that the quantity & quality of hyaluronate in the joint fluid may be deficient in those with OA.   'Sodium hyaluronate' is extracted from rooster combs. Hyaluronic acid is a natural complex sugar of the glycosaminoglycan family. It is available as a sterile,viscous solution consisting of a high molecular weight (500,000–730,000 daltons) fraction of purified natural sodium hyaluronate  in buffered physiological saline, with a pH of 6.8-7.5. It was  approved by FDA in August 1997.Indicated for the treatment of pain in OA of the knee in patients who have failed to respond adequately to conservative non-pharmacologic therapy, and to simple analgesics such as acetaminophen.  Sodium hyaluronate is given as an injection into the knee. This medicine is usually given as one injection per week for a total of 3 weeks (occasionally 5 weeks).Greater clinical benefit has been seen when used earlier in the disease process. Can be administered before, during or after therapy with NSAIDS/acetaminophen.  Contraindications: - Infections of knee joint (present & past) or infection of the skin around the knee. - past history of allergy to sodium hyaluronate. - pregnancy and lactation.  Caution: Before receiving sodium hyaluronate, one should tell their doctor if they have an allergy to eggs, birds, or bird products.  Adverse events: include - gastrointestinal complaints,  - local ecchymosis - headache,    - local joint pain and swelling,&  - local pruritus.  Apart from these relatively minor adverse effects, occasionally, more serious anaphylactoid/anaphylactic reactions may occur.  As it is a relatively recent form of therapy, studies are on-going. Early results appear to show significant benefit.Greater clinical benefit has been seen when used earlier in the disease.  Best wishes!
posted_time: Post  by Dr.M.Aroon kamath » Mon Jun 21, 2010 11:10 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: (OCD) / Cyst in Bone (R. Elbow)
content: HI,  In the past, osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) of the elbow was called as "Little Leaguer's elbow" because it was so commonly seen in baseball pitchers between the ages of 12 and 20. Now it is known that other sports, primarily racket sports & gymnastics impose similar forces on the elbow. These sports can also lead to elbow OCD in adolescent athletes.  Pathogenesis:  The repeated forceful actions of these sports can strain the immature articular cartilage of the outer part of the elbow joint (capitellum of the radio-humeral joint). The bone under the cartilage (sub-chondral bone) weakens and becomes traumatized, which damages the blood vessels supplying this area of bone. Due to ischemia, this small section of bone dies. The weakened bone cracks & It may actually break off.  Symptomatology: In the early stages, Pain is the main presenting complaint, and restriction of extension is seen in almost all cases. Locking and clicking of the elbow may be seen in more advanced cases.  Management: Depends on the stage.For early stages plan is to rest the elbow until the symptoms regress. This may take up to a few weeks. Application of ice to the elbow periodically may help. NSAIDs may be needed for the pain.  For the more severe cases, some surgical option becomes necessary, such as -  Retroarticular drilling without bone grafting. -  Arthroscopy to remove loose bodies. -  Bone-peg grafting (graft taken from the proximal part of the ulna) to the prepared osteochondral defect. -  Autologous osteochondral mosaicplasty---obtaining small-sized cylindrical osteochondral grafts from the lateral periphery of the femoral condyle at the level of the patellofemoral joint and transplanting them to the prepared defects.  Unfortunately, I am not aware of any alternative medicines with proven benefit which may help you.Sorry, i can't help you there. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Nocturnal Hamstring Cramps & Spasms
content: Hi, A lot of discussion goes on about muscle cramps in general, but,the actual cause remains elusive.Research has so far not been able to determine whether the cause lies in the brain or at the peripheral level (nerves/muscles).  Lack of water (dehydration), low levels of minerals such as potassium,magnesium, sodium and calcium as well as drugs such as diuretics- have long been linked to leg cramps. It may be associated with diabetes and certain other endocrinological conditions. A familial tendency is seen in some cases.  A muscle 'cramp' is one in which a muscle goes into contraction involuntarily and remains so for a while.During this time,the affected person feels excruciating pain.This situation may last for a few minutes at a time.Cramps commonly affect  - the calf muscles, - the muscles in the sole of the foot or - the hamstrings.  The description that you have given about your boy friend's illness does not sound like either typical muscle cramps or the 'restless legs' syndrome.I suggest that he consults a neurologist initially to sort out his symptoms. Good luck!

title: Re: Genu Varum treatments
content: Hi,  Firstly one has to decide if indeed you have true bow legs.Some persons have what is known as 'apparent bow legs', wherein,  externally rotated hip joints & slightly flexed knees lead to an appearance of bowed legs.Simply by internally totating the hips and extending the knee joints, this appearance goes away.  In the new borns & infants, bow legs are commonly seen and are considered normal. This is attributed to the fetal position in utero.T hereafter, gradual straightening occurs and by the time the child starts to walk (18 months of age), the limb becomes straight(zero tibiofemoral angle).Between 2-3 years of age, gradual development of genu valgum occurs to the extent of 12 degrees.This knock knee situation corrects itself by age 7 to the adult tibiofemoral angle of 7deg in males and 8 deg in females.  Persistent genu varum in adolescents may be corrected by surgery (osteotomies/hemiepiphysiodesis).  Apart from cosmetic concerns, adults with uncorrected genu varum are at an increased risk of osteoarthritis as age progresses. Physical therapy & orthoses are unlikely to be benificial at this stage.Minimal genu varum may be perhaps observed. If person develops osteoarthritis of the knee(usually in the medial compartment) or severe pain in the luter aspect of the knee(ligamentous stretch),surgery may be the sole option.  In young adult patients, valgus producing high tibial osteotomy (HTO) is an effective surgical option for medial compartment osteoarthrosis with varus deformity . This could be - the conventional high tibial osteotomy techniques or  - an osteotomy at the distal border of the tibial tuberosity coupled with a gradual correction of the varus deformity using an Ilizarov external fixator. Good luck!

author: awassom  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Jun 17, 2010 3:38 pm Gender: Female
title: Fell on knees 6 mos ago, still having pain, Dr's unsure
content: Six months ago, my right leg got caught on a table leg at my work. My leg was wrenched sideways, and then I fell on my knees. I was unable to catch myself, so my knees recieved my full body weight. I immediately got a bruise on my tibia right underneath my patella. My knee became very swollen and it was uncomfortable to walk, sit , or stand. I went to the Dr. and he took X-rays. They did not find anything in the X-rays, but decided to start me in phsycial therapy. During physical therapy they focused on strengthing the muscles around  my knee. I continued my regular work duty which involves standing for 8 hours a day. After 12 weeks of physical therapy, I was still having pain, and my knee was still swelling. They decided to do an MRI. I then went to see an Orthopedic specialist. While reviewing the MRI, the doctor thought he saw a small fracture on the tibia near the iliotibial band insertion. He called the radiologist, and they both decided that it was just a blood vessel instead of a fracture. He did mentoin that the MRI quality was poor however. I was given 8 more weeks of physical therapy due to IT band tendonitis. It has now been 6 months since my injury. I am still doing physical therapy. I still have pain specifically where the IT band inserts into the tibia, and also patellar tendon pain(I am guessing from my fall). The Dr. has decided to complete another MRI. He says that tendonitis should have started to resolve itself by now, so he is worried that something else might be wrong.  I am very frustrated with the situation. It has been 6 months since my injury, and it seems that they still don't know what is wrong. Any ideas??? Additional info: No clicking or catching of the knee joint Any help would be greatly appreciated.
posted_time: Post  by awassom » Thu Jun 17, 2010 3:55 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Fell on knees 6 mos ago, still having pain, Dr's unsure
content: Hi, It appears that due to persistence of your symptoms, a fairly rare injury known as "The Segond fracture" needs to be excluded. The Segond fracture is a small vertical avulsion injury of the lateral aspect of the proximal tibia just distal to the plateau (about 2-10mms distal).   It usually results from an excessive internal rotation and varus stress.  The iliotibial band is lies superficial to the lateral capsular ligament and is an extracapsular structure & inserts proximally on the epicondylar tubercle of the femur and distally on 'Gerdy tubercle' of the tibia.  Segond fracture is seen in 6-13% of patients with anterolateral rotational instability of the knee. Diagnosing a Segond fracture may not be straightforward as the fracture fragment may be tiny.   Segond fracture is best detected on the anteroposterior projection. In some cases, the frature may be seen only only on the tunnel projection.MRI offers additional help. The Segond fracture may be associated with injuries to other ligamentous structures and menisci.These must be carefully looked for. Best wishes!

title: Big Toe Pain
content: about a month ago, i frozen bottle of water fell from the top freezer onto my big toe hitting the "metatarsophalangeal joint" to be specific.  the pain was unique and severe but i didn't think it was broken (having broken my fingers a few times).  i couldn't bend or lift my toe even with the use of my hand and there was also a weird, shooting sensation up my shin.    the next night i went to the urgent care, since the pain/swelling got worse and it was very difficult to walk.  the doctor did *not* physically examine my toe, he took an x-ray (which i never saw), told me it wasn't broken and that i was "going to make it".  i spent 2 weeks walking on the side of my foot, unable to move it.  it has now been a month and i am still unable to move my toe. there is a weird lump on the bottom of the toe and it's still swollen, despite the ironic use of ice.  it still hurts to touch it, but it's not numb anymore. i'm not sure if there is something wrong because of the lump or if i should continue to wait it out.    any advice?

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Big Toe Pain
content: HI, It is well known that at times, initial X-rays (standard views) prerformed in an emergency setting may not reveal certain fractures. These become radiologically apparent sometime later.In some of these cases, special radiological views or even imaging techniques(CT, MRI etc) may be needed to detect these fractures.  As the mechanism of injury had been fairly significant in your case, and the fact that you are having persisting symptoms, you should consult an orthopedic surgeon for a re-assessment. Good luck!

title: Something "popped" in my calf
content: A couple weeks ago, I was walking down the stairs and something "popped" in the middle of my calf. I had immediate severe pain. It has now been 2 weeks, I still have pain in my calf, and it throbs. When I stand I feel as though my leg is swelling, and I start to lose feeling of my leg muscles. My leg and my heel go numb and feel hot. The pain radiates above my knee into my hamstrings and down into my heel. I can only move around for about 15-30 minutes before I need to rest, by elevating my leg. I also can't put my leg at a 90 degree angle or completely straighten it without pain.   Did I possibly rupture a tendon? What is the best course of action for me? I am not working right now, so should I be 100% resting for a week or so to let it heal?  If it doesn't get any better, is it necessary to see a doctor?

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: ACL tear
content: Hi, Causes of graft failure in Surgery for a ruptured ACLcan be broadly divided into three categories: - external    - technical,and   - biologic.  External refers to causes such as trauma(as in your case).Technical refers to the intricacies of the surgical technique and biologic refers to factors related to the graft that is used.  Plain X-Rays can detect some of these causes(ex; integrity of the screws,tunnel placement,bony parts of the graft, and size of the screw tunnels).MRI may be needed  to evaluate graft integrity,tunnel position,& the other soft tissues of the knee joint.  Even if there is the slightest doubt, i urge you to consult your orthopedic surgeon and get evaluated. Best wishes!

author: sweetsugrbriches  Guest Posts: 12 Joined: Mon May 30, 2005 7:31 pm Location: Texas
title: unexplained ankle swelling and pain
content: Hi - I am a 29 yr. old female who is at the end of my rope with my newly acquired "injury".  For about the past four weeks, my ankles have been hurting and swelling for no obvious reason.  By this I mean that I haven't injured them nor has anything in my life really changed recently.  I have a follow-up appt. with an ortho specialist tomorrow afternoon but I am so confused by my symptoms and I want to make sure I cover everything with my doc.  Hopefully there is someone else out there who has my same issues and can help put my mind at ease.    First, let me give you some background on me - I am 29 and work as a secretary.  I have had a "desk job" most of the time since graduation from high school and therefore have been pretty inactive most of my adult life.  I didn't play sports in high school (I was a band geek!) which probably helped me escape any major injury to any parts of my body.  I've never had any broken bones - - not even stitches!  Medications:  The only medications I am on are over-the-counter Naproxen for headaches and PMS as needed, 1 mg Xanax nightly, 37.5 mg Pentermine daily for weight loss and Desogen for birth control.  My new "injury" -  Around the beginning of May, I noticed that my ankles kind of hurt.  Anyone who wears heels all the time, has twisted an ankle at least once before in their lives.  It kind of reminded me of that but not too painful.  Just a little sore.  But I can't remember injuring my ankles in anyway.  About a week later I noticed slight swelling on the inside of my left ankle.  Although both ankles hurt, it was the left that hurt the most.  The right ankle didn't appear swollen but could have been just a little bit and I just couldn't tell because I was looking so hard.  A few days later, I noticed significant swelling in the left ankle (inside only) and it was starting to turn a little pink and it felt warm to the touch.  A week into this, my right ankle appeared obviously swollen but not as bad as the left.  Again, only the inside of the ankle.  The pain was getting worse and the swelling wouldn't stop so I started putting ice on them at night and elevating them.  No help.     Labs - After 2 weeks of swelling, I went to my primary care doc and he told me to ice the swelling, elevate them and take some Naproxen for the pain.  He also did the usual labwork.  He said everything came back normal and referred me to an ortho doc.  I got a copy of that labwork just the other day and everything was within normal ranges except two things under my white blood cell count.  But apparently, it wasn't abnormal enough to alert the doc.  Neutrophils were 40 (range 42-77) and Lymphocytes were 46 (range 16-43).    Tailbone - To make matters worse, my ankles hurt so bad one morning that I fell on my tailbone in the bathroom and I think I bruised it.  Now that hurts!!  My ankle pain is the worst in the mornings and starts to feel better throughout the day but still hurts all day to the point that I limp and have to walk slowly and carefully.  On the day I fell on my tailbone, I noticed more swelling in my feet by late afternoon.  Not only were my ankles swollen, but now the whole foot was swelling on both feet.  Everything except my toes.  So that evening, I got some Ace bandages and wrapped my ankles.  I can't sleep in them cuz they drive me crazy at night but I do wear them to work.  I still have to dress up for work so I've been wearing slacks and stuffing my fat feet into the only two pair of low heels I have that I can with Ace bandages on them.  Again, I sit most of the day so I can kick my shoes off.  However, it is rather difficult to elevate my feet while at work.  Ortho doc - I got in to see the ortho doc about a week later and his inital impression was some sort of arthritis of unknown origin.  He took x-rays and said they were normal.  He also ordered more labwork and I go back tomorrow.  He ordered RH factor, ANA test, C-reactive protien, Sed rate and uric acid level.  Now here is where I start getting paranoid.  It's been almost a month and my ankles still hurt and they are still swollen.  The Ace bandages seem to control it somewhat but I need to know why they are doing this and how to stop it, as I can't wear Ace bandages every day of my life!  Starting the morning after I went to the ortho doc (this past Friday), I woke up in severe pain - everywhere!  My left hip hurt, my left knee hurt, both my ankles hurt so bad and even my right elbow hurt!  I almost didn't get out of bed because it hurt so much to move.  Thank God that was my last day at work for the week.  This weekend has been pretty bad.  The pain has pretty bad in my hip, knee and ankles.  The pain in the elbows comes and goes as does other pains.  Like in my shoulder, wrist and thumb once.  Today was the first day that I haven't hurt like hell.  My ankles are still swollen and still hurt, though not as bad as they have all month long.  I've read about all the types of arthritis, lupus and fibromyalgia and I have some of the symptoms of each but they could all be because of other minor things too.  My mom has multiple sclerosis and I've read that some doctors think some of the auto immune things are hereditary.  The biggest symptom, other than joint pain, of all these auto immune things is fatigue which I don't really think I have.  Because I sit all day, I am always kind of sleepy but I don't really think that is fatigue.  On the weekends, I prefer to be a homebody most of the time, but I don't think that is fatigue either.  I think I am just lazy actually.  I haven't had any rashes as with lupus nor any increased hair loss.  I do get ulcers in my nose but I just thought they were cold sores since I get those on my lips all the time!  I keep telling myself that I am making too much out of this but I don't know how to explain why so many different parts of my body hurt all of the sudden.  Every morning I wake up wondering what is going to hurt today and how long is it going to last.  I can't wait to go to the doc tomorrow!  On one hand, I hope he finds something in my lab work so I'll have a definite answer, but on the other hand, I don't want anything to seriously be wrong with me.    Sorry this is so long but even if no one reads it or responds to it - - at least I feel better now for getting it off my chest!    Thanks in advance for anyone who takes the time to read this long sob story!!
posted_time: Post  by sweetsugrbriches » Mon May 30, 2005 9:30 pm

author: sweetsugrbriches  Guest Posts: 12 Joined: Mon May 30, 2005 7:31 pm Location: Texas
title: more lab results
content: Just thought I'd share my new lab results that the ortho specialist ordered: ANA - Negative Uric acid - I can't read the number on my copy but it's within normal limits RF - 25 CRP - 15.40 ESR - 29  My doctor wasn't available Friday when my lab results came in so I haven't talked to him yet to get his interpretation of them, but I can read... so according to the reference ranges, the only elevated levels were the CRP and the ESR.  The ESR was slightly elevated (should have been between 0 and 20) and the CRP is elevated.  I probably shouldn't have had the results faxed to me before I could talk to the doc but I was going crazy waiting.  Based on what I've read, I guess I have some sort of infection or immflamation in my body.  I bet the next step is going to be more tests to try to figure out what kind of infection or immflamation.    So I feel like this is good and bad news.  Good because I probably don't have lupus or rheumatoid arthritis but bad because who knows what kind of infection I could have!  My ortho doc will be in the office on Monday afternoon and I expect to hear from him then, but in the meantime, this waiting is DRIVING ME CRAZY!  And the joint stiffness isn't getting any better.  Actually, my ankles hurt MORE now than they did last week.  And the migrating joint pain elsewhere in my body is really getting annoying and more intense.  It's been one month now since this all startd, and I am really getting worried!  Any responses would be appreciated!

content: after (another) bad night with virtually no sleep, i decided to see if i could find out the cause of my ankle,knee pain for myself, when i stumbled on your posting it was like reading about myself, with the exception of my age -55yrs. i have had arthritis in spine for many years now but always managed to keep reasonably active, but, since the appearance of sore/swollen ankles 4 months ago, i am struggling with my mobility,i am on weight loss programme to try and ease the load on my joints, i lost 5st but this has slowed down dramatically now, because -i think- of the lack of mobility, i try and get outdoors for a walk each day regardless of weather but by the time i get home i am totally drained because of pain. my ankles are only moderately swollen in morning, but by the time i am up and dressed and start going about my daily chores, they have swollen up and turned red. i have appointment with my practioner later in the week and expect to be told when i lose weight things will improve, as i am within 2stones of my target weight, i thought improvement would be evident by now. i am very interested in the outcome of your problem and if you can recommend any exercises or drugs that have helped your case, i live in uk and realise things might be different regarding drugs but it would give me an idea of what course to take to alleviate this debilitating pain, i thank you in advance for your reply[/list][/i][/b]
