author: sweetsugrbriches  Guest Posts: 12 Joined: Mon May 30, 2005 7:31 pm Location: Texas
title: Hi jaki
content: Hi jaki!  I'm so sorry you are in pain.  I'm not sure how much help I can be of but I'll tell you my story.  I am a 29 yr old female and have been in relatively good health most of my life.  I wasn't very active in high school (i.e. sports) but I was in band.  After graduation, my activity level decreased A LOT!  I gained so much weight over the next ten years after graduation.  I was probably about 110 when I graduated from high school in 1994 and by 2004, I was 190!  I didn't have children to blame the weight gain on and I didn't think I ate a lot but something had to change.  It's hard to change your lifestyle when it's been the same for 10 years!  I never had any major health problems except for a cyst on my right ovary.  I had surgery to have my right ovary taken out just before my senior year of high school.  Other than that, I never had anything really wrong with me.  I don't exercise and since I never really have, it's kind of hard to make myself stick to an exercise routine.  I am a legal secretary and I work a lot - mostly sitting at my computer - so just thinking of exercise exhausts me!  When I hit 190 pounds, I decided to go to my primary care doctor and ask for diet pills.  I had some problems with depression and anxiety over the past 10 years, but nothing too serious.  I had been on anitdepressants but decided to get off of them hoping that would help stop some of the weight gain.  I was doing pretty good except my weight was out of control and that started depressing me again.  Mostly it was anxiety.  So when I went to my primary care doc for the diet pills, I decided to ask for Xanax again.  I had been on it previously and loved it!  I didn't abuse it or take it during the day all the time.  I only take it at night to help me sleep throughout the night.  My mind starts working overtime once it's time to go to sleep so the Xanax allows me to relax, stop thinking about things, and go to sleep.  My doc gave me Phenteramine for weight loss too.  I love it!  I'm down to 147 and my goal is 130.  I started the Phenteramine in Dec. 2004.  Well, that's my background.    As far as my family is concerned, my mom has multiple sclerosis and I have a second cousin or maybe third cousin or something like that that has MG.  I have one cousin with Downs and high blood pressure seems to run in my family.  I don't know my father or anyone on his side of the family so I don't know about their medical history.  Obesity seems to run in the family too!  Since MS and MG are auto immune disorders, I know I am sort of predisposed or something, but I've never had any problems to warrant going to the doctor for lots of tests - - until recently!  In March of 2005, I went for an eye exam and decided to switch to contacts.  In May 2005, while I was fully frustrated with getting used to contacts, I went for a follow up with my primary care doc.  Everything was going good with me, the weight was slowly coming off and I was feeling pretty good - with the exception of not being able to find any brand of contacts that were comfortable!  My eyes were always so dry with every brand I tried.  I never really noticed that I had dry eye before but now, in trying to wear contacts, my eyes were always dry.  Even on the days I didn't wear them!  Then, not two days after my doctor appointment, my ankles started bothering me.  They just felt a little achey.  About a week or so later, I notice that my left ankle seemed a little swollen.  Another week later, I noticed that it was started to turn a little red and sometimes kind of blue and purple, like a bruise.  Then my right ankle started swelling and they felt very warm.  After several weeks of this and taking 400 to 600 mg of Naproxen two to three times a day, I decided to go back to the doctor.  While he was mashing around on my ankles I sort of felt some muscle pain.  Kind of like a sore muscle and when he would hit just the right spot, it felt pretty good.  Like when you rub a sore muscle.  The joint pain was puzzling though.  It wasn't a distinct joint pain either.  It was hard to explain.  It felt sort of like I had sprained my ankles but I knew I hadn't.  Primary Doc ordered labwork but it all came back mostly normal.  He ordered a CBC, Chemistry and Thyroid tests.  The only abnormality was in my white blood cell count.  Lmyphocytes came back slightly elevated and Neutrophils came back slightly lowered.  Otherwise, everything was normal.    Primary Doc referred me to an orthopedic doctor.  Ortho Doc took x-rays and said they looked ok.  I didn't have any pain anywhere else except in my right elbow and I thought I had just slept on it funny the night before.  Ortho Doc didn't have a clue so he ordered more labwork.  He did a complete arthritis panel and tested for lupus and rheumatoid arthritis.  The very next day, I woke up with joint pain all over my body!  Hips, knees, ankles, elbows!  I was miserable for the next few weeks!  The pain would migrate.  One day it was my left hip, then the next it was my right knee.  Everyday a different combination of joints would hurt.  My ankles got so bad that I almost couldn't walk because they hurt so bad!  I had to keep them wrapped with Ace bandages all day just to make it through work.  My labs finally came back and my CRP was elevated and so was my Sed rate.  Rheumatoid factor came back normal and ANA screening was negative.  So infllamation of some sort was present but none of that gave him a real answer.  He prescribed me a one-week packet of steroids, Prednisolone I think, and I felt better in only three days!  It was great!  Steroids work wonders!  It was only a one-week prescription, thank God!  I only gained two pounds while on them so it wasn't too hard to drop it again!  Ortho decided that neither my diet, my other prescriptions, nor my lack of exercise had anything to do with my pain.  He said it was something systemic but he couldn't pinpoint it.  He told me to take Mobic (an anti-inflammatory) daily and see if that kept everything in check.  If not, he could refer me to a Rheumatologist for further workup.  I tried the Mobic but a few days later, my ankles started swelling again.  None of the other joint pain came back and my ankles didn't hurt near as bad but I was worried that they would.  Ortho Doc told me to switch back to Naproxen as anti-inflammatories tend to increase water retention and maybe I would do better with Naproxen.  Then again, it might not be water retention.  I switched back to Naproxen and it didn't really help but the swelling and pain didn't get worse do I just left it at that.  I took the Naproxen, about 400 mg twice daily, for the next several weeks.  Slowly but surely the swelling and discoloration started to go away.   As of now, my ankles hurt everyday but it is minor.  No more swelling or discoloration and no more joint pain anywhere else.  They really bother me if I am on my feet a lot.  I forgot to mention that when they first started hurting, before I went to the doctor, I tried elevation and ice but nothing helped.  Now, if I am on my feet too much, I just put them up when I get home, keep them warm and take some extra Naproxen and they are usually okay in a few days.  That's the other strange thing.  My feet are always cold.  They never really used to be but since I work in an office all day and sit at a desk all day and since I live in Texas and it's so hot all the time, I wear sandles A LOT!  So when I'm at my desk all day, my feet got cold.  But over the past year, I've noticed that I can't even get them warm at home.  I'll have socks on and be sitting on my feet and still they are freezing!  Unless I'm active and on my feet, they get soooooo cold soooooooo fast!  And the coldness seems to make them hurt more too.  My dry eye is what is bothering me the most now.  I went to an opthomologist and was able to get him to prescribe me Restasis.  My left eye tested somewhat dry so he said I could try the Restasis and see if it helps.  I was told that it usually takes a full 6 o 8 weeks before the Restasis really starts to work so I am still waiting for it to work.  I've been on it for about a month now and I can't wait for it to start working!  I'd really like to wear my contacts again!  That is if I can find a brand that won't dry my eyes out so bad!  Hopefully the Restasis will help that but I'm sure I'll have to find a good contact too.  Other than a very strange lack of sex drive, I don't think I have any other symptoms.  It's not normal for a 29 year old to have absolutely NO sex drive!  But that doctor's appointment is on August 30th and we'll deal with that when we get there.  I am thinking that I probably have some sort of autoimmune disorder but it is probably so borderline right now that it would be impossible to diagnose.  I could probably go to a rheumatologist and have more labwork done and possibly narrow it down to something, maybe, but until I have a "flare-up", I guess I'll just keep taking my Naproxen.  I probably don't want to know what's wrong with me anyways!  So, that's my story.  I know it's long but hopefully it's of some help to you.  Good luck and I wish you well!

content: Iam a 30yr old female..i was shocked to come across this page because i had assumed my problem was unheard of..my symptoms are similar to most and exactly the same as sweetsugrbriches. Basically it was on may 31st, 2005 ( i was 25 yrs old then) when i felt pain in my right ankle my was also red hard and a throbbing, numbness feelinwg to it. I quickly consulted an orthopedic specialist as a matter of fact i went to two different one ( so i could have a second opinion) the orthopedist had me wear uno booth & the other big black boot for my foot for a few weeks which didn't help at all. He ordered i had x-ray, ct-scan, and finally MRI but no fractures were present just an unexplained fluid build up on my right ankle he then referred me to a rheumatologist..i was tested for lupus, rheumathoid arthritis & a few other things but all was ruled out the rheumatologist stated that if it was a rheumathoid arthritis issue then the pain would be symmetrical my situation was unique i had pain & swelling in my right ankle only and it only worsens throughout the day when im walking too much or sitting for longer periods..but not bad in the mornings so he then referred me to a lymphedema clinic they did a lymphosynthigraphy test where they (inserted a clear dye in both my foot & view my lymphatic system via gamma rays) that also came back with no results there was no circulation problem they had me work with a PT which showed me how to minimize swelling by using bandages, wraps, compression socks etc. i admitt this helps only to minimize swelling but doesn't cure it. They ruled out lymphedema and told me basically there was nothing else to be done i had come to the end of the road so disheartened and upset i stopped being active. oh i forgot to mention i was eating healthy, working out didn't injure myself besides sprain from heels or fall which healed a year before even my symptoms started. I stopped working out because my foot and ankle swoll up more when i walked/ran on treadmill, when i went to the mall with my girls after walking 30 mins i had to stop and sit for a while becaue i couldn't walk any further ...i've also had the cortison shot injected on my ankle area twice which helped with alleviating pain and swelling for a few days but then it returns...i decided after taking some time off on investigating this issue since i had given up to consult another rhumathoid specialist i just felt i was young and symptoms weren't really precise and presenting themselves for a proper diagnose but it seemed that might be it...anyway this doctor looked at my profile and decided to have me do a bone scan test i don't remember why but that also came back fine...he also had another round of extensive blood work done on me nothing at all..then he referred me to a vein specialist...he said basically there is nothing at this point if i have had the swelling this long it is hear to stay no cure to just start working out and eathing healthy etc. which by the way i was never overweight just wasn't working out like i used to ...so i really decided to come to terms with it.. i love heels so much i gave them up until last year i decided i will wear them again but always have a flat shoe as a back up...i suffered last year as a bridesmaid heels all day i had no choice my feet swell up i had so much pain could barely stand & ended up with lots of blister but right now im at a point where i've to terms with it aslong as it doesn't turn to something else/worse..i elevate it when i have a chance which always helps reduce swelling... i hate the compression sock but i use them sometimes...recently i also decided to test for lyme disease just incase but that was negative as well the only thing is my vitamin d came back at level 10 which is supposed to be very low so my primary doc has me on 50,000 iu once a week taking it with calcium im supposed to go in 6mons for a follow up...she has suggested taking aspirin 3times a week and working out more to build leg muscles so there is more circulation going on there bcuz the doplar test showed a slight lower amount of vessels or ciruclation i believe is what she said...Also i had a reunion with my cousins last year i hadn't seen them in ages and my female cousin has the same issue as me so we we're starting to think could it be genetics related? But then again after looking at this site i see so many women around my age range with this issue oh and my type of employment was customer service ( 10 years) im not working currently though just in school. One last thing i also HAVE A VERY LOW SEX DRIVE which is strange for my age? i wonder if its all related...i blamed it on depression because iam prone to that..i also realize this is a very old forum but one that fits my criteria so if anyone still checks back and wants to update me on their story i'd appreciate...sorry for the detailed long story but had to get it out..thanks for reading

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: Re: Nerve removal sugery
content: Neurolysis is a way of pain control when the cause of the pain can not be treated.  It destroys the nerve that takes the pain signals to the brain.  Before this procedure, it is reasonable t is reasonable, as your doctor has done, to see if numbing the nerve with a local anaesthetic addresses the issue.  Side effects are few.  Numbness is a risk, and is the development of a neuroma, which is a painful lump at the site of procedure.  The pain can come back.  The thing to remember of course, it does not necessarily eliminate the cause of the pain, just the symptom of pain.  It is possible that the mechanical cause of the pain will persist and progress.

title: Congenital Radial Head Dislocation
content: Looking for some feedback about my condition.  Both my elbows are pretty messed up and hurt most of every day. The symptoms I have are los of ROM in both elbows. My right I think is about a loss of 15 degrees in straightening out, as well as loss when contracting. The left elbow is not quite as bad, the Dr. told me it was about 5 degrees lost. But that was last year, and I can tell it's gotten worse.  I had a scope surgery on my right elbow about 6 or 7 years back to clean out floating pieces as well as relieve pain. It did work a bit, no re-gaining of ROM, but pain was relieved some. It wasn't long once I resumed my activities that my elbow started to hurt again.  Fast forward to early last year, April when I decide to have another surgery on my right elbow. This time the surgeon was going to attempt to regain ROM as well as relief from pain. Not sure what the surgery was called, but he said something about releasing "capsule" pressure or something like that. The surgery was much more extreme than my last one that I was back and up to normal activities within a few days.  This time I was to keep an arm brace on all day every day and night for over a month, as well as use an otto-bock machine that I sat in about 6 hours a day to regain ROM. I was also attending therapy twice a week for 2 months.  Therapy and progress went well from what I was told, regained some ROM within a month and it pretty much stopped progressing. Pain was more sore after that, not overall too bad.  After the second month I finished therapy as well as received the go-ahead to resume my activities. I let my Dr. know that I wanted to lift weights again and play basketball, which he seemed ok with. I was also told I could order an Otto bock static immobilzer (Not sure if this is the right name) to aid in regaining more ROM.  This is where it pretty much starts my issues into today.  I began using the immobilizer as instructed, resumed playing basketball and lifting weights. At first I wasn't really in all that much pain playing basketball or lifting weights, but then I remember pains starting up in both elbows that wasn't going away.  I wasn't sure then or now if this pain is just normal due to the surgery or to my server arthritis. Every day my elbows, both of them, just ach all day as if the bones are just grinding against each other.  It's been about 7-8 months since my surgery, and the pain doesn't seem to be going always like I expected it to. My ROM is slightly better than before the surgery, but I don't know if it is getting worse again either.  Due to my condition as well as from what I was told by my Dr. very bad arthritis am I just causing my issue to be worse by lifting weights? Or does it not matter really, and I just have to live with this.  I'm 35 now.  And yes I've been doing as much as I can think of to relieve/reduce pain and swelling. Heating pads, ice packs, resting ibuprofin, Glucosomin and Chondroitin..  I'm just at my wit's end on what to do and if I should just give up again doing anything remotely physical in my life.  Any thoughts or opinions are greatly appreciated.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Congenital Radial Head Dislocation
content: Hi, You have not given any details about the radial dysplasia that you seem to have.  Osteoarthritis usually affects the weight-bearing joints(ex, the hip and knee). The elbow is one of the least affected joints due to osteoarthritis on account of its well matched joint surfaces and strong stabilizing ligaments. As a result, the elbow joint can tolerate large forces across it without becoming unstable.  Elbow osteoarthritis could be - primary (idiopathic - can not be attributed to some specific     circumstance) or - secondary (cause is known).  Symptomatic 'primary' OA of the elbow particularly affects middle aged men (but some patients can have symptoms earlier), especially those who engage in strenuous manual activity. Commonly associated with metacarpophalangeal OA ('Missouri metacarpal syndrome'), and has a favourable outcome.  Primary osteoarthritis of the elbow is characterized by painful stiffness, mechanical symptoms(restriction of joint movements), and the presence of hypertrophic osteophytes. Preservation of the joint space is common and may account for the good results that are usually achieved with nonoperative treatment and nonprosthetic arthroplasty.  Arthroscopic or open  capsular release and removal of impinging osteophytes are the primary surgical modality in the management (osteocapsular arthroplasty, débridement arthroplasty).    The major changes are hypertrophic osteophyte (bone spur) formation and capsular contracture.The relative sparing of joint cartilage is unique to 'primary' elbow osteoarthritis and thus makes it amenable to this modality.   Arthroplasty is rarely indicated for primary osteoarthritis of the elbow and is generally reserved for elderly individuals with low physical demands, for whom other treatment options have failed.  For advanced 'secondary' osteoarthritis of the elbow, some other types of surgery may be needed, such as... - distraction interposition arthroplasty - elbow joint replacement or total elbow arthroplasty (TEA) or - elbow arthrodesis.  In the absence of details,regarding the radial dysplasia and its severity, only general information has been offered. Best wishes!

title: Pain in the left medial malleolus without trauma
content: Brief history: -23 year old female -5'3" -122lbs -17 years as a gymnast -born with total flat feet -bunion on left foot (big toe) -coach gymnastics 2x a week (and still tumble some) -work at a hospital where I walk 3x a week, 12hr shifts  On Thursday (the 5th of November), I did an advanced 1.5hr aerobics class and the class went well. The day after the aerobics class, my ankle started hurting (left). The pain is pretty much centered around my medial ankle bone and when I do a lot of walking (at work) it extends up my tibia a little. It is also really sore and stiff when I wake up in the mornings.  It has moderate swelling and it is very sore to touch on the ankle bone, but no bruising. I've been taking 800mg if Ibuprofen every 6-8 hours or so and I iced it for the first few days on and off. Walking, the pain isn't bad unless I let my foot evert. When sitting, it hurts to invert my foot.  I would rate the pain about a 6/10 and I have a pretty high pain tolerance from my history as a gymnast.  I modified my work schedule so I had 5 days off in a row to rest, ice, elevate, etc.  It did not make any impact in pain or swelling.  I've had inserts made for my shoes by professionals. I don't wear them on a daily basis, but I do where them whenever I am at work or at the gym working out.  My insurance will only pay for 50% of any doctor visit to a specialist until the new year starts (for us, February) and I simply cannot afford that right now.  I'm barely making above minimum wage and I'm a full time student.  Before I take out more loans to pay for a huge doctor visit, I'm hoping to receive some insight on this forum.  It would be great if I could figure out what is going on or at least make the pain go away without throwing out a few thousand dollars I don't have.  Any help would be greatly appreciated!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Pain in the left medial malleolus without trauma
content: Hi, Considering your profile and the history, a few conditions need to be considered in the differential diagnosis.  a) A 'stress fracture' of the medial malleolus: Stress fractures of the medial malleolus are known to occur very rarely. Usual symptoms are pain over the medial malleolus which is made worse by activity (running and jumping etc), tenderness over the medial malleolus and sometimes an associated swelling. In the early stages it may not beseen on X-rays but a bone scan, CT scan or MRI may confirm the diagnosis.  Treatment: rest from weight bearing activities for around 6 weeks. An 'aircast ankle brace' may be useful to protect/ support the joint & to relieve the pain. In case the injury  progresses to a complete fracture then surgery will be usually required.  b) Symptomatic 'medial malleolar bursitis':  popularity of athletic activities requiring tight-fitting shoes and boots has increased the  prevalence of this condition which is an inflammed 'Adventitial bursa' .  Congenital bursae develop in utero. They are fairly constant in location, usually deep-seated,and may communicate with the adjacent joint. Anatomic bursae in childhood develop at sites where normal friction is expected to occur.Adventitial bursae develop in adults as a result of chronic, excessive friction between soft-tissue and underlying bony prominences. The adventitial bursae are frequently subcutaneous & are not true synovial-lined potential spaces like congenital bursae.  c) one of the most common causes of medial ankle pain is ''tibialis posterior tendinopathy'. Here,the pain is just behind the medial malleolus & may radiate ti the food in the vicinity of the navicular bone.   d) in patients with a rupture of one or more of the lateral (outer) ankle ligaments following an ankle inversion injury, an impingement is said to occur between the medial malleolus and the medial facet of the talus resulting in pain that is felt on the medial (inner) side of the ankle.  Many of the injuries outlined above commonly occur in sports persons (figure skaters, gymnasts,runners etc).  In your case, you will surely need an orthopedic consult, perhaps an X-ray to exclude a  'stress fracture' of the medial malleolus. If fracture is excluded, then, it may turn out to be a case of symptomatic 'medial malleolar bursitis'. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: What can I do for my bruised tailbone
content: Hi, Coccyx (tail bone) is usually made of 4 coccygeal vertebrae(this number is variable, 1-4). It may be prominenty felt in some individuals than others.The more prominent ones are more prone to trauma.This feature depends on a number of factors - overall shape/tilt of the pelvis, - males vs females, - its angulation with the sacrum, - racial/familial factors, etc.  Minor trauma usually results in bruising at the tail bone (coccyx)and severe trauma can produce a hairline crack fracture. Hairline cracks can appear either at the coccyx tip(common), at the lines of fusion of the coccygeal vertebrae or through the vertebral segments.  Paradoxically,natural coccygeal segmentation seen on a plain film in trauma cases may be mistaken for simple fractures!.  Coccygeal injuries generally are quite painful & can take months (even up an year) to heal.Most coccygeal fractures do heal on their own, although this generally is slow. Even actual simple fractures are generally treated conservatively,  Occasionally, a manipulative closed fracture reduction may be done if the displacement is major and is impinging on some neighbouring structures.  As i have already indicated, the prominence of the coccyx varies.In those, in whom it is more prominently palpable, the pain(presumably) will be expected to be more while lying in bed(supine).It is likely that in your instance, this may be the case.  I suggest that you should consult an experienced physiotherapist(in consultation with your regular doctor) who may be able to suggest/modify/design something suitable('tailor-made') for you. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Thigh Pain and Pulling after THR
content: Hi, Sir John Charnley (1911–1982), Founding Father of the total hip surgery said famously: "Over-lengthening of up to 1 cm can be justified because ....it permits active rehabilitation ...and patients very soon become adjusted to 1 cm of over-lengthening. Since men nowadays wear raised shoes for cosmetics, slight lengthening is less important."  Postoperative leg length disparity after total hip arthroplasty frequently leads to medical liability issues. No standard exists as of now regarding the 'acceptable' disparity. How much disparity is preventable is not clear.  The 'total hip' prosthesis has two components - the acetabular component and  - the femoral component. Both of these together contribute to the length of the limb (after removal of the diseased parts). Lengthening more oftren occurs due to the femoral component.   Even patients with 'equally long' limbs(after a total hip replacement) may perceive that their operated leg is longer immediately after the operation. This is called 'apparent leg length difference' ('Real, anatomic leg length discrepancy' is where there is a 'real' or measurable leg length discrepancy).   Usually,this perception gradually disappears  (approximately within three months) with physiotherapy. If there is 'Real, anatomic leg length discrepancy',the patients continue to complain more often about this(even after 3 months).  If the operated limb became shorter after surgery,this difference is less disturbing to most patients.The shortening is usually tolerated better as no soft tissues are strained. When compensated by appropriate shoe lift, there is no undue strain on their soft tissues and the spine is well balanced.  Measuring the limb length can be done by various ways (with or without the aid of X-rays).This needs expertise.  In some patients the operated leg may have been shorter already (before the surgery) because of prior deformity (ex, congenital dislocation of the hip) or trauma. If such a patient 'desires' correction of this, then this is a 'desired leg  lengthening'.  Studies have shown that the real leg length discrepancy does not cause problem in itself but, It is the increased painful tension in muscles and nerves that sorround the total hip joint and strain in the spine caused by the longer leg that causes pain.  I note that you have not indicated - the indication for the THR in your case or - which limb is either longer or shorter.  Therefore, my answer can't be more specific. Best wishes!

author: mahalo12  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Dec 02, 2009 9:26 pm Gender: Female
title: Ankle sprain or maybe a hairline fracture
content: 2 weeks ago I fell down a few stairs first twisting my ankle inward then tumbling and hitting outside of ankle pretty hard on the banister.  Pain was intense for about 10 minutes but subsided.  I was able to bear weight with some pain. I had swelling and bruising almost immedietly to the area.  I went to the ER and about an hour after the accident they did ankle xrays which they said were normal and it was just a sprain.  2 days later I followed up with PMD and she saw my big toe area was pretty bruised and swollen so she got xrays on my foot.  Those were negative.  She said I'd be fine in a week no problem.  Well, it's been two weeks.  I can walk but my ankle (lateral, posterior) is constantly hurting, like an almost pulsating aching.  It was better for a couple daysbut has been getting worse.  I've been off work, resting, icing, elevating, and wearing an ACE when up and about.  I used crutches for 4 days as well.  Also taking NSAIDS every 6 hours and Norco every other day or so when I just cant deal with the pain anymore.  I can't sleep well and constantly wake up moaning out in pain. I went back to my PMD today telling her about the paina nd that I still cant work.  Asked her if I should get a second set of xrays, since fractures can be missed or not even visible for 2 weeks.  She told me no and that I should have healed by now and she doesn't understand what's wrong with me.  She ordered PT and sent me on my way.  I have a stupid HMO and can't go to an ortho doc without her approval (switching to PPO in January thank God).  The pain is getting so intense I'm half tempted to go to ER.  Any thoughts, suggestions?  Is it possible there is a fracture that just wasn't visible only an hour after the injury when my entire ankle was 3 times its size?  If the pain does continue, at about how many weeks after the injury should I contact my PMD again and suggest she give me a referral to an ortho?  Thanks!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Ankle sprain or maybe a hairline fracture
content: Hi,  Missed fractures (occult fractures) around the ankle do occur from time to time.  The most commonly missed fractures are of the talus, the bone that articulates with the lower ends tibia and fibula, forming the ankle joint proper.  Other fractures that are known to be missed are... - fracture of the base of the fifth metatarsal bone, - calcaneal stress fracture ,and  - tibiofibular syndesmotic injuries.  Fractures of the talar dome (the most commonly missed), are usually the result of inversion injuries of the ankle. They are located medially or laterally on the talar dome with equal frequency and occasionally through both. Lateral talar dome fractures are almost always associated with trauma, while medial talar dome fractures can be traumatic or atraumatic.  These fractures present like ankle sprains and can be missed on routine plain X-ray projections.They tend to show up on plain films weeks after the injury (variable).   Efforts are on to improve the diagnostic accuracy for these fractures.It has been suggested by some that a modified search pattern may result in improved accuracy of radiographic interpretation.  A twostep 'gold standard' interpretation, has been suggested. - an initial interpretation by the clinician or the regular radiologist, followed by - reinterpretation by a 'musculoskeletal radiologist' with the patient's medical and imaging records, with review of discrepancies(if any) by a consensus panel. MRI or CT scanning may be needed in diagnosing these occult fractures.  As you continue to be symptomatic you certainly deserve an ortho consult immediatly. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Wrist sprain post 12 months. Still feels discomfort
content: Hi, Since you seem to be having continuing pain in your 'sprained' wrist, certain other possibilities have to be thought of...  a) a missed fracture (especially of one of the carpal bones) b) post-traumatic synovitis at the wrist joint.  A fracture of the scaphoid bone (one of the carpal bones) is missed at times as the fracture-line may not be visibile in the X-ray plain films at the first presentation. X-rays repeated a week or two later may reveal the fracture.That is why, if a scaphoid fracture is suspected, it is generally treated as such, even if X-rays are negative.  Synovitis is an inflammation of the tendon sheaths as they course through the carpal tunnel. The tendon sheath (tenosynovium), becomes thickened and constricts the gliding motion of the tendons.Pain and difficulty in finger and wrist movements are usual with or without swelling at the wrist.  It will be advisable for you to consult your orthopedic surgeon who, after examining you will be in a position to decide if an MRI of your wrist is necessary to exclude these possibilities. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Middle Finger pain running down side of finger to hand.
content: Hi, The symptoms that you describe indicate that you probably have a neuritis affecting the 'Proper digital nerve' which supplies the adjoining sides of the index and middle fingers.  As you have not mentioned any injury, past surgery or swelling in the affected area,this could be something akin to the well known 'Morton's metatarsalgia' in the case of the foot, which is thought to be a degenerative process of the nerve characterised by epineural,perineural and endoneural fibrosis; hyalinisation of the walls of the endoneural vessels & endarteritis; demyelination and degeneration of the surrounding adipose tissue.  Various theories regarding its aetiology have been suggested. These include  - ischaemia , - enlarged bursa,    - repetitive micro trauma to the nerve and  - entrapment neuropathy.   You need to consult your doctor and get investigated (plain radiography, ultrasonography, electromyography etc) to exclude other causes of nerve compression (tumors, AV malformations etc).  Treatment will depend upon what cause is found.If it is only a neuritis,treatment would be most likely non-surgical, centering around physical therapy. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: sudden tearing/buring pain in my side with a very hard sneez
content: Hi, Severe cough is known to cause the following.... - simple fracture of the rib/ribs, - fractures of a rib with associated rupture an intercostal artery, - a ruptured diaphragm (with or without fractured ribs), - chest wall hematoma, - abdominal wall hernias etc.  Fracture of the ribs occuring as a result of cough is called "cough fracture" of the ribs.  Whether this can produce any serious problem or not depends upon which rib is involved, how many ribs are involved, condition of the underlying lung, co-morbid conditions etc.  But one needs to remember that severe cough is capable of producing life-threatening conditions (ruptured diaphragm with herniation of abdominal contents into the chest) as well.  So, the best for you would be to consult your doctor. Best wishes!

author: Daniel  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Tue Jul 24, 2007 12:58 pm
title: Left Tarsal Coalition
content: Hello, when I was 9 I was diagnosed with left tarsal coalition and I was told that I could either take steroids or have an operation involving some sort of fusion that would make my left foot very stiff with reduced mobility. My mother chose not to have surgery or steroids and I was fitted with an orthotic device for my shoe instead.  I'm now 20 and enjoy playing basketball and jogging but find that after 15 minutes of activity, I develop a lot of pain around the heel of the foot and some pain around the metatarsal bones. Additionally, my foot will automatically curve outwards at an angle and I begin to limp.  My question is, if I were to have the fusion surgery now, how stiff will my foot become? Will I have any mobility in the foot at all?  Additionally, is there an alternative treatment that would allow me to enjoy my activities with less pain?  Thank you very much for your time.
posted_time: Post  by Daniel » Mon Nov 30, 2009 12:34 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Left Tarsal Coalition
content: Hi Daniel ,  The prevalence of tarsal coalition is probably <1%. The two most common sites affected are the  calcaneonavicular joint and the mid facet of the talocalcaneal joint.   Diagnosis is usually suspected in the preteen or teenage individual with insidious or sudden onset of pain in the midfoot to hindfoot associated with a lack of motion in the subtalar joint.   Initial treatment is by immobilization or an orthosis(an orthotic implement) may relieve symptoms, but most patients will have persistent symptoms that warrant surgical correction ('excision' of the coalition rather than 'fusion' as you have mentioned.   Long-term results show that excision of the coalition is moderately successful in relieving symptoms in the calcaneonavicular bar. Long-term success with excision of subtalar bars is not clear, although early relief of symptoms is usually seen.  You say "my foot will automatically curve outwards at an angle and I begin to limp".This indicates spasms of the peroneal group of muscles which are known to go into intermittent spasms in tarsal coalition (an indication of a spastic flat foot).  As you have not mentioned what is the exact type of coalition that you have, it is difficult to be more precise.  I hope this information clarifies some of your doubts. Best wishes!

author: Dr. mnermis  Medical Doctor Posts: 8 Joined: Fri Jan 09, 2009 4:15 pm Gender: Male
title: Re: elbow, and hand pain
content: pain and numbness in the hand and fingers and only pain from wrist to elbow at night seems like carpal tunnel syndome.  In this syndrome, median nerve closely pressed in the carpal tunnel at wrist and numbness will occur wrist distal (palm and fingers especially first three fingers), pain occur at the forearm.  EMG shows the level of pressure to the nerve, according to  this EMG result, you may need surgical decompression or steroid injection to tunnel or only wrist splint. your doctor decide the treatment option.  It is not a difficult problem, but treatment will take 3 to 6 months maybe.  Take care, do not lift so heavy boxes more

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: elbow, and hand pain
content: Hello, I agree that carpal tunnel syndrome should be the first consideration.  Wearing wrist splints at night and perhaps at work should help.  Also, strengthen the wrist extensor muscles and stretch wrist flexors.  Avoid any ball squeezing type exercise as this will worsen the symptoms.   Carpal tunnel problems usually occur with repetitive motions like typing or grasping and handling jobs.   Also, try ice packs on the wrist after work.   Let us know how it goes.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Decadron Injection For Gout & Knee Pain Relief?
content: Hello, Corticosteroid injections are indicated for arthritic knees.  Duration of relief lasts from several days to several months - depends on the individual.  Decadron has many uses - to suppress the immune system and to decrease inflammation.   Speak to you physician about possible side effects and risk of knee injection as well as benefits including expected length of efficacy.  Take care.

author: Rudexvirus  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Oct 30, 2009 11:38 am Gender: Female
title: Knee joint - Popping, grinding, Knee cap not in place.
content: I have seen two different doctors and do not believe that I have had this correctly diagnosed, I do plan on getting another opinion however I want to be as well researched as possible before I go into the inital meeting.    Background information : My knee pops or grinds when I extend it to full length, The knee cap slides out of place frequently whether I am active or not. the pain gets worse with activity, sitting in the same position for long periods of time, and wet or bad weather.   The first doctor I went to took an X-ray, and told me I had simply strained a ligament. I was informed to take ibuprofen, and it would go away in 4-8 weeks. Over the counter pain medication does not touch the pain in my knee, and the 2 month mark came and went while my knee pain got worse.   The second doctor physically felt me knee more, Took an mri, gave me a perscription for a pain medication and told me that I had a cyst. He then told me to get physical therapy and that was it. After extensive research on the types of cysts that can occur in knees I have found that my symptoms do not match any of them, nor has it reduced or gone away with the remedys perscribed for any of them.   I have tried ace bandages as well as knee braces, and they do nothing except to make the pain worse, the joint can not handle the pressure from them. I have also tried both heat and ice, they work only while the object in question is applied, however as soon as it is removed the pain comes back.   I would really appreciate any insight before I go  to another doctor for this. Thank you in advance.
posted_time: Post  by Rudexvirus » Fri Oct 30, 2009 11:50 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee joint - Popping, grinding, Knee cap not in place.
content: Hello, You have all the symptoms of patellafemoral syndrome.  Rehab includes painfree leg strengthening, stretching and taping or the patellafemoral joint (McConnell taping technique). Avoid leg kicks and bicycle.  If no improvement or recurrent dislocations of the knee cap, see a sports orthopedist who has done lots of lateral release of the extensor retinaculum.  Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Tue Nov 24, 2009 10:02 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: Re: Decadron For Knee Pain
content: Hi baja38, Decadron is used to treat many disorders and is sometimes used in rheumatic disorders too, for example, gouty arthritis. Decadron (dexamethasone) is a corticosteroid medication that works by reducing inflammation. Since individuals metabolize and react to medications differently it would be almost impossible to give a time frame as to how long relief will last. Hopefully in your case it will be an extended amount of time. Best wishes! Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: leg pain only at night
content: Hello, If there is a specific pattern of pain down the leg and the character of the pain is numbness, pins and needles, or tingling, consider neurology. If the pain seems deep in the bone without the above symptoms, I would see your family physician for a thorough history and physical including any cancer risks.  Bone pain occurring at night in someone over 50 years old unrelated to injury, arthritis or obvious skeletal condition raises concern about a bone tumor or cancer. So good time to see your family physician for a check up.  Take care.

title: DeQuervains or something more complicated?
content: Nine months ago I experienced my thumb locking up and severe pain when I attempted to release it. I tried NSAIDS and ice for a few weeks, but it continued to worsen. I finally went to the Dr at week six and he sent me for x-rays. The films showed a radial fracture that had healed. Based on the physical exam and the x-rays, he put a splint on my wrist and prescribed ultrasound therapy, diagnosing DeQuervains tenosynovitis. After two months of this and no improvement, he gave me steroid injections. They worked wonderfully for about a month and then the pain slowly returned, along with some other strange things. When I wake up each morning my wrist and hand is in spasm, requiring me to massage it until I can move it. It is quite painful. I have tried sleeping with the splint on, but it makes very little difference. There are several swollen areas on my wrist, about two to three inches below the site of the injections, and they feel almost like bands of some sort. I have developed similar areas around my carpal bones. It is becoming progressively more painful The swelling is worse at night. Along with that, I have developed tendonitis in my hip and both heels. I am starting to wonder if all of this has some systemic cause, or if the wrist issue is seperate from the rest. I have no health insurance, so I have to be careful what tests I have run due to the cost. I would appreciate any suggestions as to what diagnostics would be prudent at this point, and what potentially could be causing all of this.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Lower back sports trauma
content: Hello, Improving pain and range of motion are good signs.  Lack of redness, swelling and palpable tenderness are also good signs and speaks against hematoma. Exercises include supine trunk rotation, single and double knees to chest, hamstring and quadricep stretching. Another good exercise (back stretching) is to position yourself on hands and knees (like a cat or dog) then move buttocks back toward heels while dropping chin and stretching hands forward.  You can find back home exercises at http://northviewmedgroup.wordpress.com/ ... exercises/.    Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Sun Nov 01, 2009 6:43 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Swollen Knuckles, Pain in Forearm
content: Hello, It sounds like the arms and hands are suffering from arthritis and/or myositis and/or tendonitis.  Basically, inflammation in the joints and soft tissue from repetitive overuse. Here are some idea for pain and inflammation relief. 1. Use liniment containing methyl salicylate or salicylic acid (e.g. Aspercreme) and a liniment with menthol (e.g. Icy/Hot).  Combine the two, apply to the arms and cover with moist heat pack for 20 minutes - use ACE wrap to secure hot pack. 2. Add Tylenol to Naproxen 3. If all else fails, see a physician for a tapering dose of corticosteroids.  Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Fri Oct 30, 2009 2:27 pm

author: iskyfly  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Oct 26, 2009 12:09 pm Gender: Male
title: left knee pain when climbing steps after banging knee
content: 35 yo Male. 5ft 9, 170lbs. 4 day a week gym workout over the past 5 years. Mainly alternate between upper body free weights, legs and 45 minute cardio elliptical. No surgery history.  I seem to remember approximately 6 weeks ago, when working around the house, lifting my left leg and banging the top part of my knee cap into something. 10 / 10 pain at that moment. Walked it off and all seemed fine for the rest of the day.   Went to the gym the next day and warmed up with jumping jacks, squats (no weight) and treadmill. Went on to leg presses and dumbbell step ups. Noticed some pain / discomfort in my left knee. Stopped and continued with upper body.   Next day, left knee pain when walking steps, getting in or out of car, bringing leg from extended straight position to a retracted position and vice versa when sitting in car or laying in bed.   At its worst pain seems to be run a vertical straight line under the knee cap. At best it is a minor ache that also seems to be under the knee cap.  Definitely anything to do with steps either going up or down makes it worse. Leg presses also makes it worse.   Took a weeks off from the gym and things started to feel better. Took another week off, *felt* 100% fixed and slowly went back to a regular gym workout but the pain came back. I'm now favoring the leg by using the other leg first when getting up from a seated position. I'm also restricting how much the knew bends when walking.   I am concerned about repeatedly injuring what ever it is I injured. I would like to maintain my workout regiment, or at least my upper body work out, but lately anything involving weights where I use my legs for support aggravates my knee.  Pain / discomfort when; -Getting in out of car -Going up or down steps -Leg presses -Bringing leg from extended (straight) to bent position (in car or when laying in bed)  Priority #1; Resolving the problem in time for a month long vacation (first in a couple of years)  around Xmas. I'd like to be active and mobile for that.   Priority #2; Maintain cardio fitness. Would elliptical be ok? Or is there something better?  Thank you very much, -Giles
posted_time: Post  by iskyfly » Mon Oct 26, 2009 12:56 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: left knee pain when climbing steps after banging knee
content: Hello, With trauma to the kneecap and persistent pain, I would call your condition patellafemoral syndrome. Care must be taken to avoid irritation the kneecap joint.  So modify the exercise program to painfree activities. Also, use NSAIDS, ice or heat packs and hamstring stretching (decreases pressure on kneecap joint).   If no changes after 2-3 weeks have an x-ray and/or MRI. Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Fri Oct 30, 2009 1:28 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Pain in right hip, radiating to groin and lower back
content: Hi, From your description one would first think of a gynecological cause,among other causes, as the pain radiates to the thigh.Also you say that the pain is very severe. One of the causes of such severe pain is a twisted ovarian cyst (intermittent torsion and detorsion can occur). Other possibilities include urological causes such as urinary stones (renal colics)  and orthopedic causes such as an acute arthritis of the hip joint. Finally, one rarer possibility..... Extra-uterine endometriosis. I hope this information may be useful to you.Good luck!

title: Re: Lower Left Calf Muscle Spasms (9 hours and counting)
content: Hello, Of additional concern is deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Diagnosis is made by history and physical and special tests.  Testing depends on probability of DVT but generally doppler US and sometimes D-dimer (blood test) are used. So, see your physician who will evaluate the calf and order appropriate tests and/or treatment.  General info: women who smoke and take contraceptive medicine (oral or patch) are at 8.8 fold increase risk of DVT.  Take care.

title: Re: wrist fusion is cracked
content: Hello, Your option for surgical correction vs non surgery seem limited due to your history and the current pain and dysfunction levels. I think the concern is about the possibility of infection with surgery or failed fusion after surgery. The bones may require fixed hardware to maintain the fusion - that is plate and screws which may need to remain in the wrist or hand to maintain stability. author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Severe Knock Knee Treatment for adults
content: Hello, Unfortunately the growth plates in the bones have bridged and therefore "set".  Unless you undergo a radical surgery to correct the genu valgum, the legs will remain as they are. With that said, it will be important to focus on maintenance strengthening and stretching of the lower extremities and lumbar/sacral area. You will also need to maintain a good weight as obesity will make the condition worse. Take care.

title: Knee popped during Basketball - Can't straighten knee
content: In August of 2008 I had a bicycle accident which sprained both my ankle and knee on my right leg. It put me on crutches for about three days. I ended up being able to ski that winter with only mild stiffness. During the spring, I was playing basketball and got hit in mid air, falling over and severely twisting same knee and ankle, again injuring them to a point where I was on crutches for another 3 days. In both cases, I probably tore stuff in me knee and ankle, they have mostly healed by I have had stiffness in both the ankle and knee.  Two days ago I was playing basketball, I just made a small turn to catch the ball and I heard and felt me right knee POP... It wasn't a severe turn and at first it didn't seem like it was very severe, but when I tried to put weight on my right leg, I couldn't... as long as I kept my knee bent, I could put a small amount of pressure on that leg, but I could not and still cannot completely straighten my knee. I feel some resistance and pain on the left bottom portion of my knee cap when I try to straighten my knee.  When I mentioned it to a friend, he initially suggested it might be a torn ACL, but I think I would have been in a lot more pain and not able to put any kind of pressure at all on that knee. But also, it didn't seem like anything tore like when I've sprained my ankle and knee before, it just went POP.  If it was simply my knee popping out, should it be somehow "popped back in", or did I tear something and need to give it time to heal before rehabilitating it?

Pl see your orthopedic surgeon.Good Luck!

author: BertieZilla  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Thu Oct 15, 2009 5:04 pm Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee popped during Basketball - Can't straighten knee
content: Thanks very much for the reply. I looked up the symptoms of both ACL tear and subluxation of the patella, the latter didn't really seem to match what it felt like or the placement... but the ACL tear... Symptoms of an ACL Tear wrote:The knee is a hinged joint allowing for flexion and extension only.  The ligaments of the knee help to prevent any movement that the knee is not designed for. The muscles above and below the knee joint are the prime movers.  These muscles are what allow us to walk, run, jump, climb, etc.  If you injure your knee, you lose the ability to perform these activities.   An ACL injury normally occurs from some type of rotational stress applied to the knee.  Remember it is only made to bend and straighten.  When this injury occurs, the athlete may feel a pop with in the knee.  They will also experience a feeling of the knee “giving out”.  The phrase “Trick knee” has long been associated with an ACL injury.  Other symptoms may include immediate swelling, an inability to fully straighten or bend the knee.  The most common symptom is the feeling of the knee “giving out” or feeling unstable.   It is not uncommon for other structures in the knee to be damaged at the same time that one injures their ACL.That seems to pretty well describe what happened.. Heard a pop and the knee gave out, and I have an inability to full straighten the knee, restricted bending, and most certainly feels unstable.  What would be your suggestion for treatment and rehab? Thanks again!!

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee popped during Basketball - Can't straighten knee
content: Hello, I agree with Dr Kamath's words.  Regarding rehabilitation of an injured knee suspected of having ACL tear, here are some measures to take.  Immobilize the knee initially; use compression (ACE wrap) to control swelling; non weight bearing initially. Over time, as the pain and swelling go down, start range of motion exercises without putting weight on the leg.  For instance, lie supine: bend and straighten knee using long belt around ball of foot for assistance.  Motion should be painfree.  Any increased pain and swelling means too much exercise intensity.  Over time as pain and swelling decrease and range of motion becomes normal, start straight leg raising strengthening using cuff weights around the ankle.  Lastly, do lunges or mini squats for quad, hamstring and glute strengthening.  Use caution throughout exercise program to avoid increase pain or swelling.  Restoring full range of motion and strength is vital in order to return to regular activiities.    If in doubt about any rehab measures or any increasing problems with the knee, see a physical therapist or talk to your orthopedist.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Fri Oct 16, 2009 1:17 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Left thigh pain-2 years after surgery
content: Hello, It would be important to assess the prognosis of the painful thigh by first reviewing the tumor characteristics and the extent of surgery done and discussing the expected outcome with the surgeon.  I would think that 6 months post op would be enough time to see some pain relief.  Other questions include, was there a certain pain level before surgery and did that level change?  Was there an expectation of worsening pain levels after surgery?  Finally, is there another potential source of the pain. sometime the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve can be traumatized and cause burning and pain in the thigh.  Treatment includes steroid injection.  Take care.

I'm not sure how long my knees have been misaligned but my patellas point distally and not forward the way they're supposed to. The points of my lateral/medial epicondyles are always quite sensitive and when my knees are having their bad days I can feel a lot of tension. They become most irritated while they're extended and there's weight upon them. Me being overweight right now or being far more sedentary than I'm used to isn't helping either but those are more obvious issues.  I had a bad habit when I was younger of splaying my legs out wide and my feet followed. My inner thigh muscles seem to be elongated and weak (anytime I attempt to hold my legs together for too long they start to become quite fatigued) and the outer shortened and tense. I'm not sure if this has anything to do with it but I know that my misalignment is quite considerable in my knees and it seems like all my muscles from the knee up contain chronic muscle tension.  I'm actually a graduated and soon to be licensed Massage Therapist and observed a lot of these problems while in massage school and started practicing a lot better posture and it helped my lower back a lot and my upper back considerably as well. However, once the every other day massages stopped I gained a lot of tension back obviously lol. I can't diagnose myself 'cause..well..me being a doctor is still a ways down the road lol. I just need some help with this and want to know what my options are. Does this technically classify me as Genu Verum since my patella deviates from it's sagittal plane, or is it something else? What can I do about it? Surgery? Maybe some other method?  Thank you, I appreciate your time.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee pain, Misalignment
content: Hello, Muscle length and strength imbalances in the lower extremity can have a profound affect on the patellafemoral (PF) joint. Obesity is also a risk factor for PF syndrome. I would recommend seeing a physical therapist to help work through the rehab. You may also benefit from bracing or taping of the patella to better position it during activity.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Shooting pain near groin area below the hip joint
content: Hello, I applaud you for taking on the habit of exercise in particular running.  Running can be an enjoyable sport however it does carry risks for lower extremity injuries.  Since the pain is localized to the anterior proximal hip, a number of structures are likely to be inflamed and causing the pain: iliopsoas muscle, rectus femoris muscle or lateral femoral cutaneous nerve.   Treatment involves ice or heat, NSAIDS, stretching and strengthening program.  If no improvement after 2-3 weeks then see a physician who may order physical therapy.  Also, the progression of the running program may be too aggressive.  In other words, when you increase mileage, it should be done so gradually...no more than 10% increase per week.  Since running is repetitive and using only certain muscles, it is important to do other types of exercise to balance the muscles groups.  This would include swimming, biking, eliptical machine as well as weight training, core strengthening and leg stretching.  The non running program is vital to long term running health.  Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Sun Sep 27, 2009 8:39 pm

posted_time: Post  by education23 » Tue Sep 22, 2009 7:24 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Chronic pain-middle of left thigh-occured after surgery
content: Hello, I am sorry to hear about the persistent thigh pain.  I can not explain the pain and from the sounds of it - nor has any of the multiple surgeons that you have visited.  My first thought was about retained foreign body from surgery but this would have likely shown up on imaging tests.    The lipoma itself is an easy removal and should not have affected the thigh to this extent.  The only other thought would be to examine the tissue with an open procedure (another surgery) and take a muscle biopsy.  This assumes that the muscle or deep tissue of the thigh is causing the pain and assumes that there is some "thing" in the tissue causing the pain.  Finally, a bone scan would be in order since most of the tests and treatments have focused on the soft tissue of the thigh.  Examine the bone.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Limited Elbow Extension/Unable to lock Elbows
content: Hello, The first step in finding out what is wrong with the elbow is to do an x-ray and have a physician examine the elbow. The examination will quickly determine if this is or is not tennis or golfers elbow (lateral or medial epicondylitis respectively).   The real issue is making sure there is no abnormality in the elbow joint which restricts motion.  If no joint defect, then resting the elbows and perhaps some rehabilitation would be in order especially as you are looking to start rigorous training which requires arm and elbow use.   Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Severe right leg pain after spinal fusion
content: Hello, Because of the leg numbness continuing after surgery it will be important to follow up with your neuro surgeon for re evaluation.    Regarding the muscle pain and dark urine, you may be suffering from rhabdomyolysis in which the muscle tissue is breaking down (perhaps from the myopathy).  This breakdown of muscle tissue would cause pain and dark colored urine.  You will need to see a physician who will run some lab work (CPK, myoglobin, UA, chem panel) to look for signs of rhabdomyolysis.  Take care.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  It would have bean easier if you could inform us more about the character of this pain, like the onset, the course, if it is related to certain movement or at rest, what aggravates, what help alleviate and any associated symptoms or signs.  Do you have any other medical problems or systemic diseases? Any recent viral infection or drug intake?  From this description it sound to be of myoskeletal origin, most probably a muscle pain. Muscle pain and spasm occur due to muscle injury.  Causes of muscle injury include: Traumatic Muscle fatigue , wrong posture Heavy exercise  Flu Metabolic abnormalities like low Magnesium level and Hypocalcemia Thyroid disease The last three causes result usually in multiple muscle affections.  - Any causes of pinched nerve should be investigated too, including: Spinal problems like vertebral discs prolapse,  Arthritis , shoulder joint problems etc Brachial plexus injuries.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Complications from cortisone injection in SI joint
content: Hello, With steroid shots into joints, there is a possibility of a steroid flare which includes symptoms of increased pain, swelling, redness for 24-48 hours after the injection.  The flare is treated with ice and ibuprofen.  If the pain persists beyond a couple days, see your physician. If the steroid shots have not helped in the past and continue to give you more problems than benefits, it is worth considering another treatment option. Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Finger locks straight and won't bend.
content: Hello, At times the tendons which work the fingers (either flexion or extension) become inflamed and cause mobility problems. When examining the finger, it is important to attempt both active and passive motion of the digit.  If both are limited then the joint itself may be sprained but if just active movement is limited the tendon is more likely the problem. Inflamed finger tendon can be injected with steroids to reduce inflammation and improve mobility. Take care.

content: Hello, Sometimes an orthopedic surgeon will manipulate a "frozen" joint with the patient under general anesthesia.  Results are mixed however some patients get good results. author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee pain like small pins... im 24
content: Hello, I am not sure what part of the knee is cracking - the knee joint itself or the patellafemoral (PF) joint.  An exam by your family physician would help determine if the knee cap is in good alignment or if there is crepitus (crunching sound) in the knee. With the regular x-ray, obtain a sunrise view of the patella to check the alignment.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Extreme nerve-type pain on outside of feet only?
content: Hello, Thanks for writing in.  The question is: Is the nerve type pain originating from the foot or from the lumbar spine.   To help differentiate the two, a physician would do some further testing.   For example, to test for lumbar etiology, check the tendon reflexes, leg strength and stretching the sciatic nerve.  Furthermore, an MRI or EMG may show some deficits.  I would start there.  Other possible causes are diabetes or localized nerve impingement.  But again, I would look at the lumbar spine first.   Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Chronic Hamstring Tendonitis - what are my options?
content: Hello, For chronic hamstring tendonitis, I would do 6 things:  1. some sort of heat modality followed by gentle stretching.   2. General closed chain strengthening of quads and hamstrings (e.g. mini squats, full squats and bridging on therapy ball).   3. Open chain exercises: easy leg kicks and swimming 4. Plyometric training. 5. Long distance running 6. ice   I think the most helpful activities would be the running (long distance at an easy pace - no sprinting!) and swimming.    Take care and let us know how it goes.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Exposed jaw bone thru gum
content: Hello, Either the gum line is receding to expose the bone or the bone is growing.  I would think the gum line would have to recede in order to expose the bone. title: runners knee.
content: Hi. Im a 17yr old male.. 6ft and weigh 78kg.         and recently and currently going through a very quick growth spurt..  ive recently been going to physio..   ive been diagnosed with runners knee and have now been doing exercises for it for the past 12weeks.    a lot of pain has gone and it feels better but it is still very creaky and grindy and is so bad other people can hear it in the room..    also when i extend and flex my knee and feel it with my hand the patella moves smoothly until about a 60degree angle then it suddenly moves as if its jumping over a loose bit of cartilidge but have been told by my physio there is no loose cartilidge in there..    (just to let you know.. my knee doesnt lock at all")  any ideas??.. your help would be really appreciated.  the one question i need answering is 'would this stop me joining the army'  p.s my other knee is creaky as well but have no pain what so ever in this one..  cheers. :)
posted_time: Post  by watson » Sun Jul 12, 2009 4:07 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: runners knee.
content: Hello, The movement of the patella is influenced by shape of the distal femur, the contours of the patella itself and the pulling forces from various muscles and tendons around the knee.   Without changing bone, the muscles and tendons are what is left to change.  This is where physical therapy helps. Stretching hamstrings and IT band while strengthening quadriceps including VMO (vastus medialis oblique) helps. Taping is another option for the knee especially if the patella seems to abnormally adjust at 60 degrees.   Usually the painful arc in runners knee is 30-60 degrees of flexion.  If you manage the knee well and no complications, you should be able to run and do boot camp.  Take care.

author: STARSHOWER  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sun May 31, 2009 12:48 pm Gender: Female
title: My rib cage has lowered drastically
content: Dear Doctors, please could anybody help?  My rib cage has lowered drastically in a very short space of time. I am desperate to know if a procedure exists to correct this. The weight is taking its toll on my shoulders, neck and jaw. My jaw has receded significantly and I have limited mouth opening. The weight feels like constantly being on a really fast ride, with the g-force pulling my neck and head back all the time. It’s a nightmare.  When walking there is significantly more weight being placed on my hips, knees, and ankles. My back doesn’t feel able to support its own weight any more, and this seems to be taking its toll everywhere else. Not to sound too dramatic, but if I carry on like this I’m likely to need hip and knee replacements pretty early on as I can tell I’m wearing them out. I have loose, weak joints anyway. Not to mention a jaw replacement, as the whole weight of my rib cage feels like its hanging onto my jaw. I have friction and some crepitus in the jaw joints already.  My lower spinal joints also feel like they’re being compressed under the weight, so I’m probably looking at arthritis there too. I don’t mean to sound dramatic or overly pessimistic, but I have pretty good foresight and a sense of cause and effect, and I know that these things will definitely happen in time, and can be prevented if there is some way of surgically aligning the rib cage and spine into a more desirable relative position. I should also mention I have scoliosis (relatively mild) and so already had rib asymmetry and a hump, which means the right side, which sank first, is weighing down quite a bit heavier than the left. The uneven weight means that my neck is being pulled into a curve. The neck-to-head joint is also under a lot of strain and feels like it’s being pulled out of its socket. It is all extremely uncomfortable and worrying, and I am desperate to find out if there is any hope at all of having this corrected. Also if anyone knows what may have caused this in the first place, I would be extremely grateful. My NHS doctors are telling me I must be mistaken as it can’t happen, but there is absolutely no way I am mistaken, it is such a huge and drastic shift. The weight of it seems to be getting heavier by the day, and I really have to clench my stomach muscles to support myself when sitting upright, standing, or walking. I am only 24 years old and feel like I have succumbed to the perils of old age already. Please please please please please can somebody out there help?!??!!  Thank you.
posted_time: Post  by STARSHOWER » Sun May 31, 2009 12:59 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: My rib cage has lowered drastically
content: Hello, The lowering of the rib cage sounds fairly drastic to cause so many symptoms.  I am trying to imagine how or why the rib cage would or could do this and feel so heavy.    I would want to see some x-rays or better yet a CT scan of the chest and abdomen to see if there are any masses in the thoracic cavity causing your symptoms.  Other considerations include overall weight (any obesity?) or large breast tissue?    In the spine, it would be important to strengthen the entire back musculature as this would add stability to the entire spine.  From the spine hangs the shoulders, arms and chest.  Your family physician can evaluate your situation fully and order CT scan and physical therapy.  Take care.

Wish me luck!  Thanks again.

author: manwithdog  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sat May 30, 2009 7:41 pm Gender: Male
title: Severe knee and hip pain 13 months after DHS
content: 13 Months after a DHS, I am encountering intermittent but severe knee and hip pain.  The History:   I presented to a hospital with pain ++ in  April 08, five hours after completing the London Marathon and with a three week history of increasing hip and leg pain.  I underwent open reduction and internal fixation for a fractured neck of femur. The Dynamic Hip Screw method of fixation was used.  The fracture appears to have united and mended very well (and the DHS appeared to be in place)  based on radiographs in February and I was delighted to be discharged as a result.  The issue:  I have encountered knee  pain since the operation - but frankly I thought it  normal. Since roughly Christmas time, the knee pain comes and goes and has become more severe. I walk a good few miles on a daily basis and can go days with very minimal twinges. Sometimes however, very severe knee pain can come on incredibly suddenly and then most of the time is accompanied by hip pain shortly after.  The pain is usually extreme. Sometimes it is limited to the knee and hurts when I move it - but not at rest. More often when it is hurting, I feel pain along the front of my leg about half way up, and pain on the side of my leg / hip. On a few occasions, my entire hip on the left side has felt so fatigued that I have had to stop and rest. I know it is not normal  Can you venture any opinion on what may be causing the pain and why it could possibly be occurring on some days but not others? The inconsistency is driving me insane and have been unable to find any similar stories online . Could the DHS be rubbing? Thanks
posted_time: Post  by manwithdog » Sat May 30, 2009 8:17 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Severe knee and hip pain 13 months after DHS
content: Hello, I doubt that the screw is causing the pain as the pain starts at the knee and travels up toward the hip.  I would suggest evaluating the knee: internal ligaments, cartilage, tendons - "the whole nine yards" and include a measurement of leg length.    Any time the hip is fixed for fracture it is important to check leg lengths if the distal joints are becoming painful without reason.  Take care.

title: Should a high school volleyball player wear ankle braces?
content: The coaches seem to disagree on this topic.  Some say it causes weaker ankles over time, others say it protects the ankles from future sprains.  Our daughter has already had a slight sprain, so we want to do what's best for her for the future.  She hopes to continue playing through college.  Thanks in advance.
posted_time: Post  by kree8tif » Tue Jun 16, 2009 11:09 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Should a high school volleyball player wear ankle braces?
content: Hello, For athletes who have recurrent ankle sprains, I recommend bracing.  The duration of bracing is the other question.  The ankle should be fully rehabilitated and no incidents of pain and swelling in the foot, knee or hip for an entire season before considering going without the brace.  There will be trainers who may have their own protocol and of course each athlete is unique.    My view is that bracing can prevent ankle sprains but bracing is not the end of the story.  Exercise must be done regularly to retrain the proprioceptors in the ankle and to regain normal strength, mobility and functional activity with and without the brace.  The best time to go without the brace initially is during controlled settings - exercise or rehab sessions then progress to practices and then competition.   Again each athlete is different and should receive their own treatment plan for rehabilitating that injury.  Take care and all the best to you.
