author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: back of knee pain after sitting on feet
content: Hello, It is hard to tell what exactly caused the pain.  The posterior knee contains mostly tendons, some bursa, skin, some deep blood vessels and nerves then the knee joint.  Sometimes a baker's cyst develops in the back of the knee and this would be palpable.  If present have the knee examine for internal damage.  This is not to say the sitting position would cause these conditions but may have been enough to make you aware of them.  For the most part, the sensation probably meant the knee was in a stressed position too long and it let you know it when you stood.  If there is no pain, swelling or loss of motion or function (stairs, walking etc) then there probably is no damage.  Take care and let us know how it turns out.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Carpal Tunnel? Inflamed Joints? Help...
content: Hello, Carpal tunnel syndrome occurs from compression of the median nerve of the wrist.  It can cause local pain, numbness in the fingers, hand weakness, and loss of motion.  Treatment is conservative (ice, heat, NSAIDS, exercise) unless symptoms worsen or nerve damage is found with EMG then decompression surgery.  Osteoarthritis is joint inflammation.  It commonly occurs in the wrist, base of the thumb, DIP and PIP joints of the hand.  Treatment is conservative.  Sometimes injecting the base of the thumb joint with corticosteroids relieves the inflammation.    A physiatrist may help differentiate the two and can do an EMG for carpal tunnel symptoms.    Occupational therapy may assist in restoring normal hand function with either carpal tunnel or osteoarthritis.  To me, this sounds more like osteoarthritis vs carpal tunnel.  Let us know how it goes.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: severed nerve in index finger
content: Hello, The fingers are innervated by small nerves which transmit signals from the finger to the brain so cutting this nerve will cause numbness.  The nerves supplying the muscles are more proximal and should not be damaged by finger laceration.  The numbness may not resolve if the nerve is completely cut but the other nerves (on the other side of the finger) should be preserved.  Take care.

title: Re: Increasing leg pain on the heels of lower back pain
content: Hello, There are two issues here: what to do about the pain in the legs and back from the falls and why the balance problems and falls.  First, since the back is causing back down into the legs it is important to have the legs and spine assessed for neurological integrity. title: Re: bottom left rib movement and discomfort
content: Hello, The first order of business will be to x-ray the rib cage looking for fractures.  If no fractures you may need to see a chiropractor or osteopathic doctor who can assess the ribs for mal-alignment and make any needed adjustments. According to a child specialist I have taken few test which are all normal But the CPK in blood raised at 4500. The doctor said that there are no treatment for high CPK. I am afraid that my baby's growth is very slow. Can anybody suggest me what can I do ? Is the high CPK will create any problem in future ?
posted_time: Post  by Hasnain » Sun May 24, 2009 9:32 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: High CPK 4500
content: Hello, My first concern with the symptoms you describe and elevated CPK is Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.  Muscular dystrophy causes muscle weakness which often is realized by episodes of falling or regression of gait.  Intellectual impairment can occur as a co-factor.   This possible diagnosis should be discussed with your son's physician and may schedule an EMG and muscle biopsy.  Take care and let us know how it goes.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Fri May 29, 2009 10:04 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Clicking weak ankles
content: Hello, I would start by looking at the foot structure (rigidity, flexibility, deformity, weaknesses, walking pattern, arch height) and any acute symptoms (swelling, tenderness, etc).  Orthotics may be in order depending on physical exam of the foot and certainly treating any acute symptoms is needed.   The knee and hip pain are likely secondary to the foot problems but worthwhile examining first hand.   You may find face to face help from a podiatrist or physical therapist who specializes in feet and lower extremity biomechanics.   Take care and let us know how it goes.

author: oldtennisnut  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu May 21, 2009 3:45 pm Gender: Male
title: Pain and very old rotator cuff injury
content: Four years ago I started experiencing right shoulder and arm pain while playing tennis.  This winter, for the first time, the pain persisted after the season was over.  An ultrasound scan in February indicated complete atrophy of the supraspinatus and inflamation of the biceps tendon tendons.  I suspect the complete tear and retraction of the superspinatus occurred 20 to 30 years ago and that I can regain service capabilities if physiotherapy can relax the biceps and restore arm strength and movements.  Is this a reasonable expectation?  I am still rallying and returning service.
posted_time: Post  by oldtennisnut » Thu May 21, 2009 4:53 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Pain and very old rotator cuff injury
content: Hello,  I applaud you for staying active.   Regarding the supraspinatus,  if it is not torn then strength can be restored otherwise you will need to rely on compensatory muscles (eg lateral deltoid and other rotator cuff muscles) for the complex motion of the overhead serve.    The risk of repetitive overhead motion with abnormal rotator cuff is impingement, pain, inflammation, and secondary frozen shoulder.  The last being worse case scenario.  I think it is reasonable to expect improved function with P.T. and since you sound like an experienced tennis player muscle memory should not be a problem (vs a newbie to the sport).    Take care and let us know how it goes.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Fri May 29, 2009 9:50 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: flat feet, knee pain started after playing badminton
content: Hello, Yes, flat feet can cause knee pain especially medial knee pain and patella femoral dysfunction.  It is positive that the orthotics are helping. author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Constant non-painful cracking noise in neck.
content: Hello,  Certainly, increased tension in the neck can elicit popping or crackling noises.  Without pain, swelling or trauma, crackling noises in joints are commonplace.  Rotating neck to the right with crackling noises (but not to the left) may be telling of some asymmetries in the neck or shoulder muscles or extra tension on the right side but again nothing alarming.  I would recommend 10 reps of shoulder shrugs (squeezing shoulders up tightly toward the ears and hold 5 seconds then relax).  In the least, this will ease muscle tension and may relieve the sounds in the neck.  Take care and let us know how it goes.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Dislocated shoulder - aftermath diagnosis
content: Hello, Even with the detailed description, it is hard to tell what extent of damage was done to the shoulder without a clinical exam.  Sometimes the rotator cuff muscle can be torn and the shoulder have full range of motion - due to compensatory muscle use.  I test the rotator cuff with the drop arm test, empty can test, and lift off test (place the back of hand on the low back and try to lift off the back).   With dislocation there is concern about the superior labrum which can tear along with the biceps tendon.  With this said, it is important to have a clinical diagnosis via the primary physician or orthopedist.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: MRI shows no herniated disk, but symptoms persist?
content: Hello, With hyperextension injuries to the spine from rear end collision the facet joints are compressed which can cause local spinal inflammation.  The joints themselves can refer pain into the legs. Also the nerve roots in proximity to the facet joints can become inflamed independent of disc problems.  If the leg symptoms continue or worsen, an EMG and nerve conduction velocity test can determine if the nerves from the low back are being affected.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Chronic Neck spasm
content: Hello, Chronic narcotic pain med use can develop into a tolerance which requires more medicine which can lead to dependence (psychological need for drug) and then addiction which involves redraw symptoms when the drug is removed.   It is hard to say how long these stages take.  Usually, a few months on narcotic pain meds is not a problem but remember you will likely need some pain meds post op too.  Other options are Ultram which can be added to your regimen.  It may take the burden off the need for too many Lortab.  It sounds like you are well aware of the potential problems with narcotic meds but also are getting some benefit.    Obviously, discussing this with your primary physician is the best route to take.  Take care and all the best to you.

author: Brownie  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed May 20, 2009 11:17 pm Gender: Female
title: Possible fracture turn break
content: I have a nephew who fell at 7 months.  Is it possible to not notice any pain until a few days later?  Also, could a fracture turn into a break?  I understand a fracture is a break, could it turn into a more complicated break? Thanks.
posted_time: Post  by Brownie » Wed May 20, 2009 11:30 pm

author: Debra Van Ness RN  Nurse Posts: 79 Joined: Mon Feb 02, 2009 9:58 pm Gender: Female
title: Re: Possible fracture turn break
content: It is possible to feel more pain a few hours later.  Sometimes our bodies do not hurt nearly as bad until several hours or even a day after the injury.  Many times the pain is worse later because of the compression of nerves around the area from the swelling that occurs. Also, IF it were a fracture, yes it could get worse.  You need to send this kid to the doctor.  He needs an x/ray if not already done.  The usual symptoms of a fracture are extreme swelling, bruising and the inability to move the limb.  Many times you will see an abnormal alignment of the bone or joint.  Excruciating pain is common of course with a fracture.   But yes, if it is a fracture and one continues to use or put weight on that area, it can become more injured.  Another concern would be that if a fracture occured and he did not get medical attention right away, the bone will try to heal in the abnormal state of alignment and hinder use of that area.  It is more difficult to do align the bone or joint after it has already began to heal the way it is.    Debra Van Ness RN
posted_time: Post  by Debra Van Ness RN » Wed May 27, 2009 10:56 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Persistant Upper Ankle/Lower Leg Sprain/Torn Muscle?
content: Hello, A torn interosseous muscle or tendon would be considered a high ankle sprain and take longer to heal than a lateral ankle sprain.  With a high level of pain and normal scan, I wonder if you are putting too much weight on the limb not allowing enough time for healing.   Bracing and crutches at this point may be in order.  Take care and let us know if we can answer any further questions.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee numbness, Swelling & Soreness
content: Hello, It is important to x-ray the knee to rule out a fracture of the patella (kneecap).  Have the radiologist include a "sunrise" view of the patella.   Otherwise, you'll need to have a physician check the integrity of the internal knee ligaments, the other knee ligaments and the quadriceps ligament and patellar tendon.   Take care and let us know how it goes.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee numbness, Swelling & Soreness
content: Hello, Often with internal knee derangement (torn ligaments or cartilage), a Baker's cyst develops.  This is a collection of swelling in the back of the knee.  When the knee is repaired the Bakers cyst should resolve.  No treatment is needed at this time besides the routine for protecting the knee from further damage.  Take care.

author: RedFirePhoenix  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Wed Apr 29, 2009 8:47 pm Gender: Female
title: Re: Knee dislocation problems
content: Hello,  I am not a doctor, but saw your post and familiar bells went off. This started happening with me when I was 16, and they diagnosed me with patellofemoral syndrome. Essentially the tendons on the inside curve of your knee are too loose and the ones on the outside are too tight, as the knee cap does not track correctly. The key is to strengthen the quads and hamstrings so that the muscles guide the kneecap properly. So any exercises which allow this, along with stretching of these muscles, will help stabilize.   Again, I'm just an average Joe, and please see a doctor if you're concerned. Just relating my personal experience. It's actually called 'subluxation' with what you're experiencing, since the kneecap goes right back into place. If it ever does NOT go back into place and stays dislocated, see a doc immediately. Let me know if you have any more questions on my experience, I'd be happy to tell you what I can.
posted_time: Post  by RedFirePhoenix » Tue May 12, 2009 9:43 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee dislocation problems
content: Hello, RedFirePhoenix was right on the money.  Strengthen the medial quadricep muscle particularly the VMO.  Stretch the lateral band of the knee extensors by passive patella mobilization medially.  Brace as needed.  Taping sometimes helps.  Surgical release may be needed if the lateral fibers continue to pull the patella out of place.    Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Tue May 19, 2009 9:37 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Bone Swelling in Knees
content: Hello, It is hard to tell exactly what is happening with the knees.    The MRI reported no ligament or cartilage damage just some swelling in the bone?  Perhaps bone bruise is the right term.  It sounds like the condition is in the quadricep mechanism (quad muscle, tendon, bursa, and patella).    Treatment is conservative and usually consists of physical therapy, avoidance of aggravating activities, NSAIDS and time.   I would expect 4-6 months healing time depending on the extent of the condition.  Take care.

My left sided ache under ribs can be initiated by mental activity- yes- reading a magazine or doing computer work or driving the car. author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Left sided ache under ribs
content: Hello, For left sided abdominal pain,  anatomically, there are considerations of the ribs, the lung tissue, the spleen, the pancreas, the colon, the kidney, and the diaphram, and the abdominal aorta. Therefore the differential diagnosis is broad.    A thorough history and physical exam is warranted for persistent symptoms.  Imaging study like CT and some basics labs (CBC, amylase, lipase, and basic metabolic panel) usually are ordered.   One of the many diagnoses is pleuritic pain or pleurisy.  Pain increases with forced inspiration/expiration and located in the chest more than the belly (can locate under the ribs)  The causes of pleurisy forms a long list including viral or bacterial infection, inflammation, auto immune disorders, cardiac problems, etc.   Again, this is just one of many considerations which can be teased out from a history and physical exam by your family physician.  Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Tue May 19, 2009 9:28 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Bursitis Surgery
content: Hello, Chronic hip bursitis can be aggravating.  I would look at an underlying cause of the bursitis - walking mechanics, leg lengths, muscle tightness, strength testing, shoe wear, excessive genu valgum, etc.  If you can remedy any underlying cause, all the better.    I am not familiar with excision of bursa sac in the hip -- this would be considered as a last resort.  Take care.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Fri May 15, 2009 3:37 pm

title: Teenage Middle & Lower Back Pain In Morning
content: I am 15 years old and I keep getting really bad backache when I wake up in the morning. It tends to be in the center to lower area of my back. My back feels really inflamed and painful when I wake up. I also need to click my back a lot and is tends to get really stiff if I stand for a while or if i'm sitting down in a lesson. I did go to the doctors about it, but my GP suggested it was due to inactivity (as I went during half term). She told me to do exercises, like touching my toes, etc. I have tried these things, but none are working. I have considered it being due to being overweight, as I am a UK Size 16 or possibly I might have a curved spine which I have heard people can get which causes back problems. I also thought it may have been due to having an unsuitable mattress, so my parents went out and brought me a special orthopedic mattress, but it hasn't made a difference. A few years ago I went on a bouncy castle at a party and I jumped really awkwardly into the side and I felt and even heard my spine move. It moved outwards and then moved back into place, if that makes any sense. My back felt sore for a day or two afterwards, but was ok'ish afterwards. But ever since then, my back has never been 100% ok. I'm really starting to get worried because i've been getting pain in my back for well over a year now, possibly two. I feel as if i'm being a hypercondriact by going back to my doctors, but I know something isn't right. My mum keeps saying take tablets to releave the pain, but I just want find out what's causing my back to hurt so much. Please, please could someone give me advice on what to do. I would be most greatful.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Teenage Middle & Lower Back Pain In Morning
content: Hello, The physician may be correct to say to increase the activity level however more than just toe touches would be in order.  I would recommend a physiotherapist to instruct you in the proper mechanics of spine exercises.  Walking should also be a component of most back pain sufferers regimen.    Taking some NSAIDS for 3-4 weeks should be ok in addition to hot and cold packs.  You may also consider having an x-ray of the spine to make sure there are no displacements or small fractures or scoliosis.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Chronic but not constant calf pain -- no idea where to turn
content: Hello, The gastroc-soleus complex (calf muscle) runs the length of the posterior lower leg behind the knee to the heel so yes this pain could be from one specific muscle.  You may also look at the type of feet you have in terms of pes planus (flat) vs pes cavus (arched).  This may have an impact on the leg muscles.  A physical therapist may be suitable to assess your condition and help with your rehab.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Plantar Fasciitis- steroid not working
content: Hello, The steroid shot may not have hit the correct location or not enough steroid.  The plantar fascia sometimes is hard to inject accurately - its a long broad fibrous band with multiple potential points of inflammation.  So unlike a joint injection, you have to find the right spot. I would give this a few weeks and consider another injection. Some physical therapy may also help where they can do ultrasound or iontophoresis with a steroid cream. Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Raised Lump in Wrist
content: Hello, I am not sure exactly what is going on with the pisiform bone.   I would use a lot of caution when considering removing the pisiform.  The ulnar ligament and ulnar nerve travel in a groove (tunnel of Guyon) creating in part by the pisiform. Sometime the lateral wrist flexor tendon causes calcium buildup at its pisiform attachment site.   This may be what the bump is.  I would try conservative treatment first and use surgical as a last resort.   Take care.

title: Ankle Injury/Medial Mallelous
content: Recently I have had an injury to my right ankle due to either squats or jogging. The pain is at the medial mallelous. Originally, if you could visably see the pain it would have been, upon standing, in the shape of a cresant moon around the medial mallelous nearest the achilles tendon, near the area where the posterior tibial tendon is in relation to the medial mallelous. The pain is constant and moderate with occasional stinging pain. There is no increase of pain with eversion or inversion of the foot. However, there is an increase of pain with both extreme dorisflexion and plantor flexion. It hurts to walk on the foot/ankle but is not yet unbearable. The area of pain around the medial mallelous has increased and is now most prominent near the top of the medial mallelous but still present around the side. There is no pain in the front/top of the ankle, where the foot meets the leg, even nearest the medial mallelous. There is now moderate pain that extends a couple inches above the ankle into the leg on the medial side. Pain is present when inactive.
posted_time: Post  by Sc00byd0obyd » Fri Apr 24, 2009 7:29 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Ankle Injury/Medial Mallelous
content: Hello, I applaud you for your description - well done. This pain could be caused by a number of things. I would palpate the medial tibia from the proximal shaft all the way to the medial malleoli looking for tender spots.  The posterior tibialis may be inflamed along this route and most severe around the malleoli.  Running may worsen this condition.  Without traumatic event, an ankle medical ankle sprain is unlikely especially with painless inversion/eversion.  The question is : is the pain in the joint itself or in the tendon.  The reason for thinking about the joint itself is the onset of lateral pain.  I would do an xray to look at the joint; if negative then I would assess the tendons, bones, joints for range of motion, strength, tenderness etc. and also look at the feet (flat feet vs high arches).  Flat feet and running can cause medial knee and ankle pain.  Take care and let us know how it goes.

The injury was not something that happened immediately following some activity, it appeared gradually with no known cause although the pain started a couple days after I lifted a heavy net over the boards.  The pain originally started in my upper back and neck with radiating pain into my left elbow.   It was quite severe and constant. I do not have any tingling, numbness or weakness at all and the pain is lessened if I lay down with my head propped up and arms straight out and flat.  Standing and sitting for moderate periods of time increases the pain.  Also tilting my head upwards increases the radiating pain to my elbow.  I am able to turn my head either direction to look over my shoulders.  I have had an X-Ray of my C-Spine which came back normal and also an X-Ray of my left shoulder which originally came back normal, but I received a call from the hospital stating they thought it might be a slightly seperated shoulder.  I am not entirely convinced of this as it has not healed after almost 8 weeks and with pain appearing in new locations.    The pain is now not as sever as before but still there.  I have taken numerous drugs for the pain.  Ibuprofen, Tylenol, Tylenol #1, Arthrotec all did not work.  I was given Naprosyn and I am not sure if that helped or not.  I was also given Percocet, that was the only drug that helped with the pain, I only took it for two days as it is highly addictive.  Luckily after the 2 days the pain was manageable without medication.  I am scheduled to see a Physiatrist in 6 days and I am also supposed to be getting scheduled an MRI, but the wait time for MRI's is 1 year.  I'm mostly worried that it may be something permanent or serious.  I have already seen at 3 or 4 different doctors about it but they are unable to give me any reassurance or good information.  Any thoughts or advice?

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Upper Back/Neck/Left Shoulder/Left Armpit/Left Arm Pain.
content: Hello --  One question: in the course of all the exams and rule-outs, have you by any chance had even a cursory cardiological workup? It's a stretch, I realize, but the symptoms do follow a certain fairly typical nerve pathway and the orthopedic tests haven't yielded much. While there are other possibilities for sure, I always like to remove the big, ugly ones first. A resting 12-lead EKG and a listen via stethescope, at least, would seem in order.   Assuming that's either been done or will turn out negative, you must have somehow compressed or at least irritated a nerve somewhere along that pathway from your neck/shoulder down your arm. It could be either of the major nerves serving the arm and hand, but you don't mention any numbness or tingling in the hand on the affected side. You do, though, have pain in the elbow. The ulnar nerve (which also carries much coronary pain) passes across the elbow (your "funny bone", one end of the humerus) and the pain could culminate there. The question remains, if this is so, where the nerve has been compromised. If there's no cervical injury, it's still entirely possible you disturbed the brachial plexus/thoracic outlet, where the ulnar nerve and the blood vessels serving the upper extremities pass through on each side. Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) can cause the symptoms you describe and can  be caused by trauma, postural faults, heavy lifting or be congenital. What happens is the already narrow space between the collar bone and the first rib becomes more narrowed due to one of the above causes and sometimes compresses the ulnar nerve.  This is only a couple of suggestions. I seriously doubt the "slight shoulder separation." The symptoms don't suggest shoulder separation and it's hard to have one's shoulder be "slightly" separated. It's a pretty traumatic situation and painful and again it isn't consistent with things you've reported here. It's not impossible, but it's extremely unlikely.   Hopefully this will be of some help in narrowing the field of possibilities as to what's going on. The fact that opiods are effective on the pain and anti-inlammatories do not suggests it's not an inflammatory problem but a mechanical one. This could include TOS.   Good luck toyou. Please follow up with us as needed.

It is about 2 inches up from the elbow close to or on my tricep and also about 2 inches down from the elbow on my forearm flexors/brachioradialis (sorry i don't know the muscle anatomy of the arms too well)  If I tilt my head up and look at the ceiling the worst pain that radiates is 2 inches up from the elbow close to or on my tricep. author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Upper Back/Neck/Left Shoulder/Left Armpit/Left Arm Pain.
content: After reading this and re-reading the original post, I think there must be some cervical hyperflexion (overextension) that isn't normal and that causes the ulnar nerve outlet to be placed under pressure. It almost always will refer further downstream, in the area of the elbow or outside of the left hand (down as far as the  pinkie). If this is so, even though imaging doesn't seem to disclose it, this may be because it looks relatively normal unless the neck is flexed the way it is when you're able to reproduce the symptoms. Also, since flexing your neck forward and keeping your arm in a certain position seems to relieve it, this is my best guess. However, since we now have on board someone  with a good deal of expertise in this area, I'm going to refer this to him and see if he can offer a better explanation. Please check back here in a day or so to see what turns up.

author: Kim S. RN, COHN  Nurse Posts: 4 Joined: Tue Feb 17, 2009 9:50 am Gender: Female
title: Re: Upper Back/Neck/Left Shoulder/Left Armpit/Left Arm Pain.
content: Hello,       I am so sorry this is happening to you. I can say as nurse who has taken care of many people with work related neck injuries that I believe this is all related to your original complaint when you lifted that heavy object. It is not unusual that you might have pain that radiates down the arm or to another place on the arm even if you injured your neck. You mention that when you move your neck a certain way it intensives your problem. This is most likely because when you do this you are pinching the nerve that supplies that part of the arm. The nerves that supply our arms with sensation and movement all go through the neck (cervical region) There are several vertebrae that the nerves can move through. Depending on which area of the neck you injured or caused a herniation is where you get the pain.   From my own experience I had an injury in which I picked up a large carpet and inititally only my shoulder hurt then slowly I began to get increasing (as the swelling of the disc herniation increased) pain in my right forearm that was severe, deep and even extended to my right thumb. Xrays were inconclusive, I had an MRI that showed "bulgling discs, but no herniation", so they thought my injury wasn't "that bad" I was lucky to have a doctor who believed I was in severe pain and prescribed pain medicine, but the pain never went away, even with PT, traction or anything I tried.   I finally went to see a neurosurgeon who was concerned because I had no bicep reflex on the right arm. They did a myelogram, which is an xray with dye put in your spine, and they found out that my C-6 (sixth cervical vertebrae nerve) did not fill with dye which meant I had a completely compressed nerve at that point which is why my forearm, shoulder and finally my neck hurt so bad. I ended up having surgery to repair it and now it is fine and I have only minimal decrease in sensation because of the wait for the diagnosis.   I was wondering if you would have as long a wait for a myelogram as it is a series of regular xrays done with dye placed in the spinal column. It only requires a normal xray room and can give the same kind of information as an MRI, Just wondering. I hope things go well and that they find the cause of your pain.
posted_time: Post  by Kim S. RN, COHN » Mon Mar 30, 2009 7:09 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Upper Back/Neck/Left Shoulder/Left Armpit/Left Arm Pain.
content: Hello, I wanted to add to what you and John discussed.  Pain just above the elbow which increases with cervical extenstion (looking up) may be caused by a cervical vertebrae problem. This is where I would start investigating.  Look at neurological status: deep tendon reflexes, sensation and muscle strength in the arms.  Then asses the neck with variety of movements including a Spurling test of the neck.  The physiatrist may do a nerve conduction velocity test in the office to check nerve status.   Secondarily, look at the shoulder range of motion, strength and joint integrity and special tests for rotator cuff, impingement or subluxation problems.   If both of these areas are negative and normal then do general rehab on the shoulder, neck, and arm and symptopms should resolve with time and rehab.   Let me know how it goes and if you have any further questions.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Upper Back/Neck/Left Shoulder/Left Armpit/Left Arm Pain.
content: Hello, Since the EMG and NCV was normal, nerve damage is not a concern.  From your original description, this sounds like it is coming from the neck or even the thoracic spine.   You may try some cervical traction for a couple weeks and see how the referred pain does.  If this helps then continue for a few more weeks and add some neck range of motion exercises (rotation, side bending, and chin tucks).  You may also try scapular squeezes.   Of course, any exercise which worsens pain or symptoms should be stopped.  Take care and keep us posted.

author: bocephus48017  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Apr 09, 2009 7:24 pm Gender: Male
title: Re: Upper Back/Neck/Left Shoulder/Left Armpit/Left Arm Pain.
content: First of all I am not a doctor, but I have had similar symptoms in my right arm, shoulder, & neck.  I am a male, 56 years young.  My problem started when I was age 39.  I am a former 1 year, beginning adult hockey player who finished that season with low back surgery (not related to the arm pain). I too had EMG, MRI, X-RAYs, etc. with no significant problems being found.  During peak periods, when I would look down and/or to the left I could turn the pain on like a light switch.  People in the same room could sometimes hear my neck "pop" as I turned my head.   It usually starts in August as a stiff neck-shoulder in an area 2 inches down from that large bone at the base of our neck and 2 or 3 inches to the right.  If left untreated, by Christmas I am crippled to the point of looking like I am 90 years old.   Like you, because of the arm pain, coupled with the numbness, twitching, and pain in my left leg from the inadequate back surgery, I imagined all kinds of diseases that I thought I had, MS, etc.  When I had the MRI, even though I called ahead of time to let them know that I could not lay flat on a hard surface without my right arm going numb and hurting beyond description, they attempted the procedure anyway without treating the pain.  Needless to say, I had to reschedule for a time when they could knock me out.  The results?  NEGATIVE!  All that was found was some arthritis in my neck.  So, I said to the doc.; "How about we treat the arthritis?"  He put me on a drug called Daypro and I swear that within two weeks I was pain free!  A problem that had dogged me for eight years was gone within 2 weeks of taking the Daypro.  I would do a TV commercial about that drug for free!  Now, I only need to take it when I feel an episode coming on. The only problem that I have now is the insurance company of course only wants to pay for the generic drug which is called Oxaprozin (may be a bit mispelled).  It absolutely does not work on me.  I have to get the doc. to insist on the script that I only get Daypro.  Best of Luck to You!

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: CALCIUM DEPOSITS IN ELBOW?
content: Hello, It is hard to tell what is causing the pain in the elbow without examining it and see the xrays. It is good that you have an orthopedic referral.    Tendonitis in the elbow can occur without playing sports.  It can be caused by any repetitive motion including a variety of jobs.  Also new activities may cause the pain e.g. raking or snow shoveling....or gardening.   Depending on the location and specific diagnosis, a cortisone injection may help.  It is also important to consider infection in the elbow joint.  Signs and symptoms include pain, swelling, warmth, redness, loss of motion.  The ER docs should have picked up on this if there were an infection.  Take care and let us know how it goes.

posted_time: Post  by Meshach » Mon Apr 20, 2009 12:21 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: What age to start Weightlifting?
content: Hello, Weight lifting can begin during the adolescent years however caution against heavy weight lifting must be used until after the growth plates are fused to avoid bone injury.    I recommend light weights for 3 sets of 10 reps 3 x a week.  Take it easy for the first 6-8 weeks.  It takes at least 6 weeks to build muscle.  Also combine strengthening with a good stretching program.  Lastly, remember cardiovascular - swimming, cycling, jogging of soft surfaces.  Take care and let us know how it goes.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Tailbone pain - but not when sitting down
content: Hello, One of the best test to diagnose tailbone injury is the simplest test - push on it.  If it hurts, your tailbone is injury.  Other possible causing are the sacrum, SI joint, and lumbar area sprain/strain.  I would bet the sacrum is the bothersome part since jogging hurts.  The SI joint transmits the load and force from the ground through the legs and into the back during running and walking.  For confirmation, see your family physician.  Take care.

title: Re: one positive one negative ANA poss Lupus or RA?
content: Hello, Fatigue, joint pain, rash and photosensitivity are all part of the lupus criteria for diagnosis. ANA over 1:320- is suggestive of lupus and anti smith antibodies will help confirm this.   Re checking the ANA is a good idea.  Treating the trochanteric bursitis seems tough since the steroid injections have not helped.  I would start looking at the muscles aroung the hip for tightness and weakness and look at the pelvic and leg alignment - anything which may contributer to the bursitis...even shoe wear and the feet themselves.   Take care and let us know how it goes.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Rolled Ankle - Question Regarding Swelling
content: Hello, With a lower limb injury including sprained ankles, swelling is the last symptom to resolve. I recommend compression (e.g. neoprene ankle sleeve), ankle pumps, mini squats, heel cord stretching, ice and NSAIDS for most people.  Double check with your family physician before starting any medication.  Otherwise this ankle will most likely continue to improve over the next 2-4 weeks.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Cervical Spine Epidural Injections
content: Hello, The bone spurs may be causing the pinched nerves.  In general, we try conservative treatment as much as possible before surgery. Take care.

title: Re: Pain and Swelling in Foot - X-ray shows no fracture
content: Hello, A thorough evaluation of your legs and low back are in order as well as a good history.   With problems like this, we look for any likely causes from your history.  For example, I saw a young women who developed bilateral foot and ankle swelling.  No history of cardiac or peripheral vascular problems. Turns out she has been vacationing on the beach (walking on the beach barefoot) for a week and because of the structure of her feet (high arches) and tight heel cords, she developed posterior tib tendonitis bilaterally causing ankle pain and swelling.  I say this to make the point that a good history may bring to light the cause.  This may be something simple as tendonitis or arthritis both of which would not show up on xray.  You may need to see a physical therapist who can take some time with you to perhaps find a cause and certainly help rehab the injury.  Take care.

author: Serenity-hime  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Apr 12, 2009 12:28 pm Gender: Female
title: Tenderness to touch and pain in shins
content: I am female, 22, diagnosed with Hypertension (taking 10mg Ziac once per day for it), and a 4L-5L Spondylolisthesis (diagnosed after severe back pain when I was 15).  The Spondy has caused me a lot of back pain (for which I was seeing a chiropractor to my relief but can no longer afford), and I have noticed poor circulation in my legs and feet as well.  For at least several (maybe 7 or more) years, I have had very tender shins.  It isn't the muscle surrounding the bone but the actual bone itself - if I bang my shins against anything it causes intense pain enough to take my breath away, and I cannot stand for even a 10-pound cat to climb up onto my legs.  Someone lightly squeezing that area causes sharp and significant pain (less pressure than you would receive from a massage).  My husband noticed today that it seems like the "knobbiness" of my tibia was far more pronounced than it should be - not noticeable through the skin but it can be felt clearly, and I have always noticed that about my legs.    Also, I experience occasional pain with no pressure at all - laying in bed before sleeping sometimes they will hurt, although not nearly so bad as with contact.  I have no pains like this in my thighs, knees, ankles, feet, calves, even the tops of my legs closer down to my ankles.  I have had no luck finding any information on this and was wondering if someone could help me with at least a rough diagnosis.  This pain doesn't interfere with my everyday life but if it's something more serious I'd like to know, and I cannot find more information.  Thank you for your time and consideration.
posted_time: Post  by Serenity-hime » Sun Apr 12, 2009 12:57 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Tenderness to touch and pain in shins
content: Hello, The differential diagnosis for shin pain includes shin splints, stress fractures, compartment syndrome, muscle strain, deep vein thrombosis, tumor, and popliteal artery entrapment, sciatica.  What interests me in this list and from your history of poor circulation in the legs is the possibility of popliteal artery entrapment or one of it's branches e.g anterior tibial artery.  This may cause bone pain from poor blood supply. It is worth considering doing an arterial doppler to check the arteries in the legs.   It may turn out to be nothing more than shin splints from flat feet but worthwhile seeing a physician for examination and appropriate testing.  Take care and let us know how it goes.

title: ruptured bakers cyst
content: cyst ruptured 3 days ago and i still can't stand on it, is this normal i have no bruising or swelling i did hear  a pop and felt it cannot stand  or put anypressure   it feelsa little better then it did but still can't walk with out crutches  any ideas

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: ruptured bakers cyst
content: Hello, Baker's cyst is either a communication between normal bursa behind the knee or is a pocket of fluid from the knee joint itself.   In the latter case, a Baker's cyst often indicates internal knee damage.  So I would have the knee examined and perhaps an MRI. Surgery if indicated is aimed at correcting any knee derangement causing the Bakers cyst rather than removing the cyst itself.   Take care and let us know hot it goes.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Foot Pain/Worse when standing up/finger tingling
content: Hello, The pain that you describe sounds like a form of arthritis.  The bulging disc in the low back would not cause all the the multiple joint symptoms.   You may re test the rheumatoid factor and add anti-CCP for better sensitivity and specificity to see if rheumatoid arthritis is involved.  Also checking inflammatory markers like sed rate and CRP add information for diagnosis.  I usually add ANA in the rheumatology panel too as lupus can cause arthritic pain.  Xrays of the painful joints may help with diagnosis.  If normal, then you at least have a baseline radiograph in case the joints worsen over time.   Has any anti inflammatory medication help relieve symptoms? Take care and keep us updated on how things go.

title: Will lengthening my shin bone lengthen my achilles tendon?
content: I would like to get a doctors perspective on doing a shin bone routine to lengthen my Achilles tendon. A shin bone routine is where you jog with ankle weights to create micro-fractures in them and you then weight them down while sitting on your bed for about 1-2 hours, this stretches the bone and you then go to sleep and wait for them to heal up. Most people can lengthen their shins up to 3 inches.  Will doing this routine lengthen my Achilles tendon along with the shin?  Basically I would like to do this to run faster...From my understanding the longer your Achilles tendon the faster you run.  Thanks for any responses!
posted_time: Post  by speedy09 » Thu Apr 09, 2009 5:35 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Will lengthening my shin bone lengthen my achilles tendon?
content: Hello, I would not recommend jogging with ankle weights.  Furthermore, I have not read any research or witnessed any change in tibia length with traction forces of ankle weights.   Unwanted problems are likely to occur using this routine. For faster running speed, I recommend practice running fast.  Elongating the achilles (if it were possible) may give some extra height to a vertical jump but not any speed to running.   Type of muscle in the legs may determine amount of speed and muscle composition can be changed with conditioning (long distance running - aerobic vs sprinting anaerobic).   Take care and let us know how it goes.

author: avatar7  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Apr 08, 2009 10:53 pm Gender: Male
title: Displaced and underdeveloped Sternocleidomastoid muscle
content: Hello,  First of all because of the individual nature of my problem it was difficult to categorize it, so my apologies if this is not the right section to post at. Also, I'm lacking the knowledge of the actual medical terms for some of the things that are involved, but I'll try my best to explain. First, some history that leads to my current state:  Soon after my birth I've been diagnosed with Torticollis on the left side. I'm not aware of the procedures that took place at the time as all medical records of that have been lost, but in my parents memory there wasn't any physical therapy applied. Soon after I aged 2 years a surgeon's advice was listened to - to have the problem corrected surgically. I have no information of what was done to it, but apparently it only did damage as later when I was 7 years old another surgeon (who my parents led me to because the position of my head was still not straight up) said there's need to do another surgical intervention. No record of that exists either, but since I have memory of the time and I can see evidence of the intervention even now, I know they've treated both the base of the left hand side of the neck and also the muscle area that is right under the left ear.  My head's position has been fixed with the latter and for about 10 years I didn't have any noticeable problems, except the numb feeling under and at my left ear (damaged nerves I assume) and the underdevelopment of my left Sternocleidomastoid muscle in comparison to the right one. Generally I was a very skinny person with not much muscle mass so there was not much stress exercised at my upper body in those years. That was until I started doing some bodybuilding in my 18s and then joined the army when I was 19.  Of course there was a lot of physical stress and constant exercising there, so my muscles reacted quickly. It was then that I noticed that while my right side of the neck is starting to develop further in both elasticity, strength and muscle mass, the left side was as if being pulled inward, stiff and shorter. The side effect was that my left shoulder, in mine and my body's attempt to keep a straight pose, would go up and forward a bit to compensate for that difference. I felt quite a discomfort from that so I began wondering what's causing it and also seek medical advice from different hospitals. Unfortunately nobody was noticing that something was wrong and on the outside I suppose the difference was too small to notice.  Since then a lot of events cascaded over time. It didn't take me long to discover that my left Sternocleidomastoid muscle was twisted and displaced in such way that it went somewhere behind the right Clavicle (I can easily trace it with my finger), so I realized that any physical exercise or effort was putting unequal pressure over the whole area on the left side in comparison to the right side. Because of the necessity of doing physical work (in my job at the time) the differences from the normally developed right side and the displaced and underdeveloped left side of my neck muscles began to cause overall lack of balance as the left shoulder along with the Clavicle and the shoulder blade moved their position to compensate.  The first side effect of the disturbed balance appeared as continually growing deformation angle under my knees as the weight of my body was not being distributed evenly over my legs. Then I noticed a rotation in the left side of my chest due to the left arm and shoulder tendency to return to their normal position (partially a conscious effort I suppose) all the time yet being limited and pulled in and forward by the problematic neck muscle thus restricting their range of movement. Of course all that happened over the span of a few years and was very difficult to monitor and notice, let alone explain to doctors who just couldn't see it.  I have went through various physical therapy programs during those years under the advice of some doctors, but since the neck muscle was not attached properly the difference always remained in the end. As time passed my right hand side really began doing part of the work of the left side while the latter kept becoming more and more underdeveloped.  All of that didn't come without effects on the spine. It both became bent and twisted to the right thus enforcing the process of increasing the disbalance. It sort of became like a closed circle at one point, with each area adding to the overall damage.  To save time, I'll skip to present days and my current state - nearly completely disfunctional left side neck muscles, both front and rear, left Clavical severely turned inward and forward onto the chest wall, along with the shoulder and arm, size and elasticity of pectoral and shoulder muscles reduced, left half of my chest tilted backwards, doing no function, very small in size, my pelvis rotated to follow all twist that with the left leg pelvis joint at an angle up and left and the bone running from the knee down bent at quite a noticeable angle to support the shifted weight. At the same time the right hand side being forced to take on the work and weight of the left side is beyond normal size, muscles very elastic and strong but also stressed all the time, the size of the right half of the chest almost completely taking up the whole chest size and doing all the breathing processes, my right leg just about supporting the majority of the weight, with its pelvis joint tucked in and behind the pelvis. The spine is twisted around itself, to the right and bent forward at its base and the pelvis pushed at an angle (it's what keeps the legs in their abnormal position).  It's quite a cascading effect of forces being applied to different parts of the body as a compensation or result of the asymmetry at the neck and the differences in muscles development and weight distribution. When I apply conscious effort to straighten up all that I can see how most problems disappear (except the permanent deformations in the bones like under my left knee and the chest) but the neck remains as it is due to the disfunction left Sternocleidomastoid muscle.  I don't see how any physical therapy can help correct this to a point that it would cause the opposite order of events to occur as to correct all those issues, unless the neck muscle position (if not size and functionality) is corrected first. The problem is I have totally no idea what kind of help to look for as I have gone through many doctors and nobody was able to give an advice or help, and many say it's not possible to treat it surgically at all. I strongly believe that if the neck muscle functionality and position (and thus the left clavicle position along with the shoulder and arm) is restored, at least partially, the rest is largely reversible through physical therapy alone.  I would appreciate any advice and expert opinion on this because it's totally ruining my life at the moment and it keeps worsening day by day. Especially during my sleep when I have no control over my position the disbalance just takes place completely and the bending and twisting are just reinforced on its own by natural forces. I wish I could have explained it in shorter manner, but it's very difficult without actually being able to show it visually.
posted_time: Post  by avatar7 » Thu Apr 09, 2009 12:14 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Displaced and underdeveloped Sternocleidomastoid muscle
content: Hello, i am not sure what kind of assistance to give you.  It is somewhat difficult to imagine all the intricate changes the SCOM has caused.  It is had to imagine the SCOM starting behind the left ear and attaching to the right clavicle.  This would cause problems with the trachea and esophagus.   Exercise may not correct all the deformities but may prevent further deformity.   Surgically, I would think an orthopedist would at least consider reattaching the SCOM to a better place on the left clavicle - the problem is the risk of damaging vital neurovascular structures proximal to SCOM.   An MRI may be needed to define the anatomy before any surgical considerations. Let us know how it goes and if we can answer any further questions.

title: Right knee pain after car accident
content: I was in a car accident two months ago, only going about 30-35 mph. No serious bumps or bruises except my right knee, which hit under side of dashboard. There was some pretty serious bruising, at one point covering the entire top half of my knee and lasting 6 weeks. At the time of the accident, it was obviously very sore. There was also some sensitivity when you touched it, particularly in the soft spot in the middle of the knee, between the bone and toward the inside of my leg. It felt like the skin had been rubbed raw and stung/tingled when you touched it. I had trouble bending the knee for a couple of days due to the swelling and associated pain. However, I didn't think it was anything more than bruising.  Now that the bruise has gone away, though, I'm still having pain. It is sore to the touch, and I can't put pressure on the knee (such as kneeling down) without it hurting. If I touch my knee in the right place, or if it even lightly bumps anything, I experience tingling and stinging, again in that soft spot between the bone on the inside of my leg. The tingling and stinging can persist 5-10 minutes.  When I've compared knees, it feels like the topmost bone on the right knee (the one that hit the dash) is a little bit softer than the other. My boyfriend did the same and said my right knee feels "mushy." I'm not sure if this is just because I'm moving to a funny angle when anyone touches it, or if this might mean something.   Just kind of curious is this is normal relating to bruising and if it will get better on its own, or if it's something I should have checked out. Thanks.
posted_time: Post  by katebot » Mon Apr 06, 2009 11:55 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Right knee pain after car accident
content: Hello, Yes, you should have the knee and knee cap checked out.  X-rays are important to look for fractures especially in the patella since this bone probably hit the dash. If no fracture, then the retinaculum from the medical quadriceps may have been damaged.  If the knee cap is unstable and pops out of place the tissue supporting the knee cap may need to be repaired surgically...not likely though from the sound of your description. Let us know how it turns out.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Broken Tailbone?
content: Hello, The tailbone can be palpated easily.  If it is fractured, you will experience great pain with palpation.  The area of your pain is near the tailbone but may be a bit higher up toward the sacrum.  Without trauma, I would doubt any fracture.    Sometimes a cyst develops in this area and is very painful.  The skin itself will be tender with some redness.    Regardless of the cause, you may try some moist heat on the area with analgesics (acetaminophen or ibuprofen) for a few days to see it will resolve.  Otherwise, a trip to your physician will be in order.  All the best to you.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Bruising and pain on leg after physical therepy
content: Hello, This sounds like you were treated for trochanteric bursitis.  The deep electrical machine in physical therapy was probably an ultrasound machine.   Did they put a gel on the skin and rub an flat applicator (hand held device) over the area for 5-10 minutes? If it was an ultrasound machine, yes it can cause tissue damage if not used properly.  You should discuss this with the physical therapist who treated you. Another concern with pain, swelling, and discoloration is localized infection.   Risks with cortisone injections include infection, discoloration of the skin (increased or decreased), pain, redness and swelling.  Sometimes a steroid flare occurs with the onset of redness and swelling however this resolves in 24 - 48 hours. Hope this gives you some direction.  Keep us posted.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: discomfort in right shoulder
content: Hello, Without examining the shoulder it is hard to tell if the joint is loose.  Anterior dislocations are more common than posterior dislocation; either way trauma is the most common mechanism.  Turning during sleep would not qualify as trauma unless of course you're playing ball or wrestling "Andrae the Giant" in your dreams.  All kidding aside, the bone sticking out is probably the scapula and not the humerus.  This may be the result of weakness in the upper back muscles or may simply be just the way you are made.  Checking the opposite shoulder for comparison is important. Best bet if this is bothersome is to have your family physician evaluate the shoulder. Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: "Pop" heard from Knee
content: Hello, You certainly may have strained or sprained the lateral collateral ligament and the loss of range of motion is due to swelling.  Of other concern is the lateral meniscus.   The goal at this point is to reduce the swelling and regain range of motion over the next 2-3 weeks.   Bracing the knee is important since it feels unstable.   If the unstable feeling persists despite range of motion exercise, bracing, and controlling the swelling, then you will need an MRI. Take care and let us know how it goes.

author: Footisahurtin  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Mar 31, 2009 6:05 pm Gender: Female
title: Right Heel Hurts
content: I am a 27 year old female that has had pain in my right heel for about two months. I am 5'7, 215 pounds. I noticed that the pain is very strong when I sit for more than an hour at a time or stand for more than an hour at a time. When I wake up in the morning I have to massage my foot and stretch it so I can walk. My bones in my ankles have started getting achy from babying my heel. I have been to the doctor and had an X-Ray done and the doctor said,"Well you don't have spurs but here is some anti-inflammatory medicine. I took that for five days and nothing happened, I am still in pain. Do you have any suggestions on what I should do? Thank you for your time.
posted_time: Post  by Footisahurtin » Tue Mar 31, 2009 6:22 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Right Heel Hurts
content: Hello, This sounds like inflammation of the heel where the plantar fascia attaches to the calcaneus.  You may call this plantar fasciitis.  Treatment for plantar fasciitis: 1. anti inflammatory medication 2. In the morning, before you put weight on the foot, apply a moist heating pad for 20 minutes. Afterwards place a rolling pin on the floor and roll the foot over the pin back and forth for 5-10minutes.  This massages the tendon on the bottom of the foot and promotes circulation.  Do this every morning for 7-10 days. 3.  The heal may also benefit from a steroid injection if #1 and #2 do not help or do not help enough.  The injection should be given with a lateral heel approach directing the needle toward the source of pain.  Some physician insert the needle directly through the bottom of the heel.  This approach is too painful for most folks.  4.  Night splints help with chronic plantar fasciitis.  They place a prolonged stretch on the tendon. 5. Some people require orthotics (molded shoe inserts).  If all else fails consult a podiatrist or see a physical therapist.  Take care.

title: Posterior interosseous nerve palsy(I think)
content: I'm 6 weeks post-op from a Type 2 Slap tear(reattachment at the bicep tendon) with extensive debridement(mainly supraspinatus).  Around the 5th week I had adhesion around the head of the bicep.  Once the adhesion was released, I had extensive pain in my forearm.  Once the pain subsided(from an 8 to 2), I lost motor function of my thumb at the knuckle.  I am still sore/tight at the forearm.  An ultra-sound of my arm showed nothing abnormal.    Dr. Chan Lowe opined on Mr. Mech's case on Mar 20, 2007.  Thank God I found this thread because I had no idea what was wrong with me.  My Doctors are not drawing correlation from the bicep reattachment but the motor function of my thumb.  Does my self diagnosis seem feasible?  What can I do? posted_time: Post  by dscholl » Sat Mar 28, 2009 11:45 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Posterior interosseous nerve palsy(I think)
content: Hello, I do not think the PIN is the culprit.  First, PIN is injured with trauma to the elbow or distal humerus.  The bicep repair on your shoulder was done proximally rather than distally.  Furthermore, the PIN innervates the wrist extensors muscles and not the thumb. The median nerve is responsible for the thumb.  So I would consider carpal tunnel problems before looking at the shoulder. Also, an EMG and nerve conduction velocity test would help with diagnosis. Take care and keep us posted.

posted_time: Post  by Kitkat101 » Fri Mar 27, 2009 2:12 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: left arm/hand numbness interrupting my sleep
content: Hello, You can do a test at home called the Phalen's Test to check for carpal tunnel problems.  Simply place the back of the hands together with fingers pointing toward the floor and bring hands toward chest.  Hold for 30 seconds.  If this position reproduces the symptoms, it is carpal tunnel. Otherwise, the condition is probably coming from the neck and may be related to your work posture.  In this case, do posture exercises and correct the ergonomics at work. Lastly, for accurate diagnosis see your family physician. Let us know how it goes and if we can answer any further questions.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: left shoulder and arm pains
content: Hello, Thanks for writing in. You know at first, I thought this might be a cervical spine problem and it still may be.  But a cortisone shot in the shoulder area would not relieve symptoms if they stemmed from the neck...but the neurological signs sounds a like lower cervical problems or perhaps ulnar nerve entrapment in the elbow.  However the EMG was negative. So back and forth we go...maybe this or maybe that.  There is another consideration: thoracic outlet syndrome.  This is where the nerves and blood vessels leaving the neck and entering the arm become compressed causing pain, numbness and tingling.  Often this occurs in overweight women or in women with an aberrant first rib development.  Your physician can do the Adson and Allen test in the office to help diagnose.  May have to review them online as the tests are not commonly done.  It is also important to check your posture and the muscle length/strength relationship in the shoulder; in other words are the shoulders too rounded with tight anterior structures and weakened elongated posterior shoulder and scapular muscles.  This might lead to shoulder, neck, and arm symptoms  Lastly, an MRI of the cervical spine may be in order to may sure the nerves in the neck are not involved.  All the best to you and let us know how it goes.

posted_time: Post  by mr. noname » Wed Mar 25, 2009 1:01 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: hamstring or gluteus maximus strain? help?
content: Hello, This is an interesting injury.  In football and sometimes in basketball, players get hit hard in the thigh and suffer a deep thigh bruise.  In your case, this sounds like a deep gluteus muscle bruise.   Since this occurred two weeks ago, start with heating pad 20 minutes on and then stretch the gluteal area.  Check the web for "gluteal stretch" or "piriformis stretch".  To strengthen the muscle do deep squats.  Of course, use caution not to aggravate the area.  If it seems to flare up with pain, use ice packs and NSAIDS (eg ibuprofen). Perhaps the best exercise is walking... or swimming. Avoid deep massage as this might aggravate the tissue. Let us know how it goes and if you have further questions. Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: ankle pain thats got to much!!! 15 months ive had it :(
content: Thanks for posting your case. Thanks for the picture too. It appears the pain is located in the ankle joint itself more anterior (front) and lateral (to the outside) where the ankle bends or flexes.   You say that orthotics helped but still get some pain. I suppose that you are a runner.  Before the pain started how many miles did you run per week? And was there any increase in mileage?  In other words, was this an injury related to running? Also, have you had any xrays or MRI done? Also, what type of foot do you have - is it rigid with a high arch or is it very flat with very little arch? Was the orthotic made by a professional or bought at the store?  The pain with calf stretch makes sense.  It would be better to do the calf stretch without weight on the foot to take pressure off the anterior cartiledge of the talus.  Structurely speaking, the anterior lateral talus may have a bone bruise from repetitive trauma of running.   Did the physio therapist assess the stability of the ankle?  Are the ligaments snug and not loose. With the morning stiffness in the ankle, the problem is likely to be in the ankle joint itself.   The solution is not easy.  Rest, acetominophen or ibuprofen, gentle stretching and strengthening.  The hard part will be returning to running as this will probably aggravate the injury.  Try pool running first to take weight off the ankle and progress slowly to land.  Some gyms have an apparatus / harness which you can strap yourself into in order to take weight off the feet and do walking or running.    Give me a bit more info... may have a few more ideas.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: ankle pain thats got to much!!! 15 months ive had it :(
content: Hello, I understand now that the symptoms are on the inside (medial) part of the foot.  Makes sense.  Regarding the soleus stretch, with your kind of foot (tends to roll in), the soleus may be overstretched and indeed the stopping point then becomes bone on bone.  Instead focus the exercise on strengthening the soleus thus shortening it a bit.  Heel raises in weight bearing (standing) or toe presses against resistance will strengthen gastroc-soleus.    It is also important to strengthening the ankle inverters (muscle that turn the foot in).  Lastly, proprioceptive training is vital.  Exercise such as standing on one foot with eyes closed or sitting on exercise ball supported by only one foot on the ground (eyes open and eyes closed - but don't fall!).  Keep me posted on your progress.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: ankle pain thats got to much!!! 15 months ive had it :(
content: Hello, The rehab exercises should not cause sharp pain.  Mild achiness for 24 hours is expected but not sharp pain or any increase in swelling.    Any running or hopping or jumping may aggravate the ankle until the foot is properly conditioned.  If brisk walking for 30-40 minutes is painless and no swelling then progress to jogging.  For your type of foot sprinting may be better tolerated than jogging.  With sprinting, the foot is positioned more on the toes/forefoot during weight bearing so less of a chance to roll inward.    Keep us posted.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: torn cartilage in wrist
content: Hello --  Now that  we know the cartilege is separated in one  place and torn in another,  PT would likely be less than a good idea for now. It won't help the tear to heal. In fact, what likely will help is either immobilization (via an elastic brace or soft cast) or, quite possibly, minimally-invasive surgery to repair the major tear, followed by immobilization while it heals. However, it is conceivable proper immobilization might  allow it to heal. Whether it would heal properly or not would depend.   This is important, because as long as it's being used and even pushed beyond its normal limits,  it's not likely to heal, let alone properly, and pain and even disability could result from this in time.  Please have the ortho eval and I'm  betting you'll at least come away with a brace for a while,  which could, with luck, be all you'll need.  I hope this is helfpul to you. Good luck with this. Please follow up with us as needed, and for sure update us after you've seen the ortho doctor.

content: Back in May 2008, I fell in the shower and injured both my left and right wrist. I fell on my outstretched hands. author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Right wrist Injury
content: Hello, Clicking in the wrist can be caused by tendons rubbing over bone, if the tendon is inflamed then clicking will produce pain.  Also, clicking can be caused by loose joints - perhaps secondary to a sprain or damage to the joint - pain is elicited from inflamed tissue in and around the joint or from normal tissue being pinched or overstretched.   Clicking with pain is a concerning symptom and should be evaluated.  In the meantime, immobilize the joint with a splint or an ACE wrap and avoid painful movements.  Hope this helps.  Keep us posted.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: severe pain in left wrist
content: Hello, Thanks for writing in.  This could be tendonitis, overuse syndrome, acute arthritis, flare-up of old stress fracture.  There are several factors to consider regarding the wrist pain.  First, consider taking an xray of the wrist to rule out stress fracture and to get a inside view of the joints and joint spaces.  Second, consider asking your physician to examine the wrist.  He can test range of motion, palpate tendons, and assess for infection.  Third, consider a wrist brace, hot or cold pack and NSAIDS to relieve pain.  Fourth, if pain continues, ask for a referral to see an occupational therapist.  Generally, they do a good job at rehabilitating hand dysfunction.  Take care and keep us posted.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: left shoulder pain/cracking with neck pain
content: Hello,  Thanks for writing in.  At 5 ft 85lbs, you have a small frame and probably not much bulk in the shoulders and neck.    The problem with chronic shoulder and neck pain is weakness can develop.  Weakness then can lead to more pain..and so on.  A physical exam and history would be in order to rule out any neurological problem in the neck.  A testing of reflexes, sensation, muscle strength and special neck test should be done to screen and rule out nerve involvement in the neck.    You may also consider a neck xray to rule out bony spurs and abnormal curvature and dislocation of the spine - the general term would be spondylosis (abnormal formation of the spine).    Next step would be some physical therapy to condition the muscles and joints.  This may take some time and certainly would involve exercises at home.  Also, your family physician can recommend appropriate analgesics.  As to the exact cause of your pain, it is hard to tell without an exam, history, and proper imaging tests.  And, a clinician's hands are valuable tools when assessing conditions like yours.    Let us know how it goes.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Mon Feb 16, 2009 2:23 pm

author: Debra Van Ness RN  Nurse Posts: 79 Joined: Mon Feb 02, 2009 9:58 pm Gender: Female
title: Re: are stairs bad for your knees?
content: If your knees hurt when climbing stairs, there is likely some underlying condition there more related to the knee joints or connective tissues surrounding the knees. I would think it highly unlikely that it has anything to do with any of the female problems going on.   I don' t believe it is an age related issue.    So, yes, I suppose that if the stairs are aggravating the condition and causing pain, then stairs could cause some further damage in the long run.  Please be sure to check with your doctor on this issue.  You may need some tests run such as some blood tests or x-rays to find out what is going on.  Stiffness is typical in diseases such as arthritis (many different types) and some other diseases such as fibromyalgia.  I am not diagnosing here by any means.  However, it is likey not due to an injury because both knees are affected.    Try to keep the stair climbing to a minimum if possible until you get some testing to find out what the cause is.  Debra Van Ness RN
posted_time: Post  by Debra Van Ness RN » Mon Feb 16, 2009 10:22 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: are stairs bad for your knees?
content: Hello,  Morning stiffness can be a sign of arthritis.  Weight bearing joints like the hips and knees are prone to osteoarthritis.    It is important to maintain range of motion and strength in the legs and continue activity as tolerated.  Low impact activities like walking, swimming, and cycling are best.    If stairs are a must to maintain the activities of daily living, by all means continue.  Unless you bound up and down the steps two at a time several times a day, it is doubtful much damage will occur.    There was a study done recently on older individual runners to see if the repetitive pounding of regular jogging increased the incidence of osteoarthritis.  The results were inconclusive.    So, common sense is the key to exercise and activity.  If it hurts avoid it; if no pain or swelling then continue as a gradual easy pace.  Also, double check with your family physician before starting any exercise program.  Take care and keep us posted.

Had Xrays, MRI and Bone Scan that clearly showed a lesion (Osteochondritis Dissecans). Has arthoscopy done this past Sept. Am now 3 months post scope and still have constant aching pain (it never goes away). I mentioned before the scope that the pain was lateral behind ankle bone but was told I shouldn't have pain there because that's not near where the lesion is. No harm done and fully respect Dr. since lesion was clearly shown and had to be cleaned anyway. My dilema now is this. Is it possible that the lesion was noticed but wasn't the source of original pain to begin with and something is being missed? I'm scheduled for a cortisone shot next week as a last ditch effort to get rid of pain. Would I be offending to the Dr. for me to ask him to take another quick look at my MRI since they have it readily available and only need to pull it up on the computer? After much research myself and at a loss as to why I still have chronic ankle pain, I have found my symptoms to be very much in line with a Peroneal Tendon problem. Pain is a constant ache even more so at rest and is located laterally behind ankle bone. Does this make sense? Any input would be appreciated much! Thanks

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Persistant Ankle Pain
content: Was the lesion on the talus?  If so which part?  The talus extends from the posterior aspect of the distal fibula ("ankle bone") forward to the mid foot.  In fact, two of the three main lateral ligaments which support the ankle attach to the talus (one in front and one in rear).  The peroneus tendons run over top of these lateral ligaments and could be a source of pain.  If so, then cortisone injection should help.   Also, it is not unusual to have a different loci of pain relative to a bony lesion.   Keep us posted.
