title: Knee Cracking
content: I have a quick question about knee cracking. For many years whenever I bend down, and often when I straighten my knees they crack. I understand that this is normal if it isn't accompanied by any pain or negative symptoms (occasionally there is discomfort but it lasts for a second or two and is the same type of feeling that is often felt with finger cracking, though it's more frequent).  Eventually I started intentionally cracking my knees because I enjoyed the feeling, even when it hurts I actually find it enjoyable. The way I induce it is by planting my foot on the floor and twisting my body back and forth until a pop is heard and felt.  I'm just wondering if I can expect any truly negative results from this with regards to soft tissue damage or issues with my knee joints. My knees aren't more likely to pop out when engaging in sports or the like?  I'm guessing no but I felt it was worth asking because my knees oddly enough are quite important to me.  Also, if I'm asking about my knees, I might as well ask about my back.  In the last few months I've developed a habit of cracking my back and neck over and over repeatedly throughout the day. I don't just mean occasionally I mean ever 30 seconds to a minute.  When I really overdo this I do feel quite a bit of discomfort (a clear sign), but for the most part I don't overdo it to much.   Is this likely to lead to any issues with my back?   If the answer is yes I doubt I would have any problem at all breaking the habit.  I wouldn't still crack my knuckles if I didn't understand that it isn't bad for the joints, and isn't too too bad for the tissues. (I think)  Thanks for taking to time to read this.
posted_time: Post  by HubbaBubba » Sun Feb 08, 2009 4:12 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee Cracking
content: Hello, Thanks for writing in.  Your question is about the detrimental impact of repetitive cracking of joints (knees, neck, back).  For the most part, cracking joints will not cause damage however (there's always a however), the manuever of planting the foot and twisting can cause some meniscal and cartilage damage over time.    The neck and back vertebrae are often cracked (self induced or by chiroprators).  I have not read of any detrimental long terms effects of this on a healthy spine.    The frequencey of popping your neck however is too much.  Although I have no research in front of me, I can not help to believe this is not good for your spine especially considering there is pain after the crack.  Keep us posted.  ps.  Your comment "Also, if I'm asking about my knees, I might as well ask about my back" reminds me of the enjoyable children books - If You Give a Moose a Muffin or If You Give a Mouse a Cookie.

content: Hello, Yes, I agree an evaluation by your ob/gyn would be prudent to make sure the pelvic organs are healthy. author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Left hand swelling and numbness in full right arm
content: Hello, Thanks for writing in.  You have reported: over the past two months left hand swelling, darkening yellow urine, and heaviness in right arm.  RA workup was negative (labs should include rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP, CBC, sed rate, and CRP).    Causes of darkening urine include increases concentration of urine (e.g. loss of fluids), bilirubin or myoglobin in the urine.  A urine analysis will reveal these.   One of the causes of myoglobin in the urine is a condition called polymyositis.  Criteria for diagnosis includes proximal muscle weakness (shoulders, trunk), arthralgias, elevated CPK (blood test), elevated inflamatory markers (sed rate and CRP), muscle pain, and EMG changes.    It may be worthwhile to have an EMG done, some muscle enzyme tests, and specific anti body tests to add to the RA workup to formulate a working diagnosis and appropriate management.    And of course your symptoms could be as simple as a bit of arthritis in the left hand, some numbness in the right arm from overcompensating and the urine is darker from decrease hydration.  Hope this helps and keep us posted.

title: Leg/Hip pain with no back trouble?
content: OK. My wife, child, and I were in a friends car (Friend was driving) after picking me up from work and on our way home. Over half way there a van strikes us from behind. The driver and child on the left side of the car was fine. The trunk caved in and split the seat I was in, it did a number on my back and hit my head a few times but, I suffered with Sciatic nerve pain for three months and got better after 6 months of over walking/moving, and lots of resting. However. My wife (who was front passenger) turned slightly back instinctively looking at our daughter to make sure she was not getting harmed in the middle of the slam. Over the past 7 months my wife has seen many doctors who have been nothing but rude, mean, and very quick with her without taking the time and take all measures to see what her problem could be. MRI and X-RAYS indicate that her lower lumbar is fine. Everyone looks at these and says they can't do anything for her since her spine is clean and one doctor even said she has Sciatica. Every time she see's a doctor she says her back does not hurt at all but her hip all through her left leg hurts severely. Her symptoms include: *Severe pain all throughout her left hip down to her back thigh. * Left foot sticks out causing unbalanced walk/limp.   I've been doing tons of medical research to back up my claim and many notes that indicate a dislocation or trauma of some kind at the "Femur" or somewhere around that region. She has tried hot baths, over the counter meds, Heating pad/ ice pack, a numbing patch, and nothing seems to work. She's been prescribed Mobic and Scelaxin which she found not only not work but ended up allergic to them. Vicoden  which sorta kinda helps but nothing relieving her pain. I constantly rub her and sometimes it puts her at ease  if she does not move for 15 mins but does not make the pain go away.  Seriously we are at the end of our rope here. She's been in and out of hospitals and doctors offices who seem to not even bother trying to dig further into whats wrong. Visible problems are her limp, foot pointing other way, Sacral bone area is no longer inflamed but still seems bumpier than usual and slight touch kills her and yet the x-rays only went as far as her Sacral bone and higher, MRI for lower lumbar. We don't know what to do anymore or who to turn to. Way too many doctors looking away and not taking the in depth time to look further. If you have anything suggestions that would be greatly appreciated.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Leg/Hip pain with no back trouble?
content: Hello, Thanks for writing in.  You report your wife has left hip and posterior left thigh pain.  History of MVA rear end collision with your wife turned to the left to look at daughter in rear drivers side (wife was in front passenger seat).  MRI and xray of lumbar spine are negative.  Chronic pain.  Foot is turned outward.    I agree that investigating hip pathology is right.  When she was turned to the left to look at her daughter, she would shift weight slightly to the left hip and rotate the trunk slightly left.  A force from the rear would compress the facet joint in the lumbar spine, compress the SI joint.  Some points on normal body mechanics, when we look to the left in a seated position with both feet on the floor, the left pelvis retracts and the femur internally rotates and adducts (toward to midline).  The rear end collision would have accentuated this posture and perhaps caused a stress/overstretch of the internal rotators and anterior joint capsule of the hip.  When assuming a normal stance, the toes would then tend to point outward.    Some imaging of the hip and pelvis would be prudent and if no fracture or structural damage then seek a referral to an orthopedic physical therapist.   Another area to consider is the facet joints in the spine,  arthritis in these joints could cause the same kind of pain (but does not account for the change in foot position).  Sometimes corticosteroid injection into the facet joints alleviates symptoms.    Let us know how it goes.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Fluid in hip after having baby
content: Hello, Thanks for writing in.  You have reported left hip occasional achiness and lopsidedness of hips. Xrays are negative and steroid shot of no help. What to do?  The swelling is not from bursitis if the steroid shot did not help.  If the hip is not red, warm, and swollen and no pain with weight bearing, it is likely not infected.  So, there may be arthritis in the hip... or the pelvis may be mal-aligned from having a baby.  Loosened ligaments in the pelvis can allow a change in the alignment of the pelvis and throw the hips off.   It may help to see a chiropractor or physical therapist to asses the bony structures of the hip and pelvis and perform any needed mobilizations/manipulations indicated.    I would not aspirate (withdraw fluid) the joint unless it is obviously swollen and possibly infected.   Take care and keep us posted.

posted_time: Post  by tina_psm3@yahoo.com » Sat Jan 24, 2009 4:09 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Torn tendon from the bone.
content: Hello, Thank you for writing in.  You reported a fall and asking about signs and symptoms of a torn tendon in a lower limb.  Torn tendons (tendons are fibrous tissue that connect muscle to bone) are uncommon.  Typically locations are achilles and biceps tendon (arm).  Usually these occur in athletes - football players, weight lifters, ballerinas.   Signs and symptoms include popping sound, lump in the muscle belly, inability to move the joint associated with the tendon, pain, swelling, bruising.  More commonly tendons are strained and ligaments/joints are sprained.  These can cause pain, bruising, swelling, and pain with weight bearing.  A physician can quickly and accurately diagnose a torn ligament with history and physical exam.  Take care and keep us posted.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Spinal Injury & Fentanyl TD
content: Hello, Thanks for writing in.  You have reported that your daughter suffered a spine injury 9 years ago and is currently taking Lortab, Fentanyl, and tramadol.  Her pain medicine strength has increased over the years and in the past year Fentanyl was started and seemingly is causing dramatic weight loss.  This is an important topic because many people take narcotic pain medicine for non malignant chronic pain.  Research studies show conflicting reports on the efficacy of opioids for chronic pain.  Furlan et al 2006 found opioids were more effective than placebo for chronic pain relief while Martell et al 2007 found no change in pain levels.  Both researchers report a 16 week duration of study. Since most chronic pain sufferers use opioids for longer than 16 weeks, this information is of limited use.   General medical practice uses pain medicine in a step fashion: eg NSAIDS, then non narcotic meds (tramadol), low strength opioids,  high strength opioids, combinations of opioids.  Over time people develop tolerance to opioids and require stronger dosages.    The problem with developing tolerance is the potential for drug dependence (physical dependance) and addiction (psychological dependence).  When a person reaches this stage, removing the drug will cause withdrawal symptoms (agitation, anxiety, mood swings, hypertension, racing heart, sweating).  Weight loss may occur with Fentanyl and may be caused by other adverse effects (nausea and constipation).  Usually death from opioids are caused by overdose.  The signs of overdose are slow heart rate, low blood pressure, and respiratory distress and failure.    For withdrawal, a tapering dose can be used with adjunct medicine for withdrawal syptoms.  Buprenorphine and naloxone can also be prescribed.  This medicine binds to the opioid receptors in the brain...thus replacing the opioid without withdrawal.      For more information consult your pain management specialist or family physician.  Take care and keep us posted.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: severe muscle pain in forearms and legs after light activity
content: Hello, Thanks for writing in.  You have reported that your brother is experiencing bilateral elbow pain after light work and history of bilateral thigh pain last year.  History of chronic abdominal pain. Question of muscular dystrophy.    As a painter, your brother will be prone to tendonitis the arms.  It is therefore likely that the pain is from tendonitis (eg tennis elbow).  The stomach and thigh muscle issues are probable not related.    To be for certain, consult a physiatrist who can test the muscle strength, deep tendon reflexes, sensation of the arms and evaluate for tennis elbow or other tendonitis etiology.    Muscular dystrophy would likely present with muscle weakness with/without pain.  Again physiatrist can do the muscle testing (no biopsy or needles needed).  Take care and keep us posted.

title: Knee pain on impact while running

There is very little or no pain except at impact (running or jumping).  I will occasionally feel an aching pain after a long run. The orthopedist that I saw said that my patella was in the right place, and appeared to be tracking properly, but then told me that he still thought that that was the problem (and was unable to tell me how or why).    Some additional information:  About five months before the knee pain started, I was in a car accident where my knee was jammed when I slammed on the brakes.  Between the accident and when the pain started, I was doing primarily biking, and no running, and the pain began shortly/immediately after I began running again.  I also have very loose joints and my knees hyperextend  >10 degrees, and have always been that way.  I am a very active person and have run extensively in the past with no issues.  What are the possibly injuries that I may have?  Thanks!

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee pain on impact while running
content: Hello, Usually patella femoral joint problems will present with pain in, under or around the kneecap including the patella tendon.  The pain you described is along the joint line of the anterior medial knee which leads me to think about meniscus, knee cartilage, or plica problems.    The car accident mechanism makes sense with the patella femoral problem.  An MRI may shed light on a more accurate diagnosis.    Biking sometimes makes patella femoral problems worse.  Running can cause any and all sorts of knee pain.  Hope this helps.  Keep us posted.

title: Re: Knee pain on impact while running
content: Hello, Sorry about the delay.  Osteoporosis usually occurs in older women after menopause after a drop in estrogen.  Many other medical conditions can cause secondary osteoporosis (eg hyperparathyroidism, cushings disease).  So a review of history and any signs and symptoms will be appropriate.    In an otherwise healthy and assymptomatic young women osteoporosis would not be my first suspicion however it would be wise to discuss this in detail with your physician.  Keep us posted.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Thumb pain
content: Hello, I am sorry to hear about your thumb.  Is there any pain or difficulty holding, grasping, or pinching objects using the thumb.  Sometimes the ligament on the inside of the thumb gets sprained (gamekeepers thumb). Treatment involves avoiding painful movements, ice or heat packs, NSAIDS, and time for healing.  The joint at the base of the thumb is also prone to osteoarthitis (OA).  Treatment includes acetaminophen, hot packs, and gentle range of motion.  You may find wrapping the thumb with self adhesive wrap (looks like a small ACE wrap but adheres to itself - stretchy too) helpful.    Let us know if you have any more questions and if in doubt about the diagnosis, see your family physician.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Thumb pain
content: Hello, Compression of nerves will cause numbness or tingling in the hand and compression of blood vessels (arterioles) will cause some pain and coldness in the hands.  The radial artery dives deep on the opposite side of the meaty part of the thumb and probably not affected and the median nerve is deep in the wrist and should be fine.  Compression like neoprene wrist/hand brace may help with the swelling (along with rest, ice,and NSAID)  Keep us posted.

title: Chronic Rib pain 3 years
content: My names is Megan Garrison I am 18 I graduated from a town in alaska that did not have very good medical care, so i was forced to seek care eleswere for this problem, which started 3 years ago. I was a cheerleader in my highschool until a girl fell on me in a stunt and i was the only one who caught her, causing me to get slammed inbetween her body and the hard wood floor. at first i just thought it just knocked the wind out of me i sat down for a couple minutes caught my breathe and i was fine but the next day i started getting this severe pain in the upper left side of my rib cage (three ribs underneath my left breast) they also seemed to be inflamed, so i took some asprine to relieve the pain and help reduce the swelling well..8 months later this pain was getting worse, causing me to miss school, get very sick vomiting wise becuase of being in so much pain which is how my body respondes to pain is by puking. So we decided to go to Anchorage to seek treatment..bad idea as much as i told this doctor it was my ribs he was set that it was my stomach or pancreas. So he did an edoscopy.results turned up very little it just showed that i had sever allergies to god knows what (haha) and that what do you know i had acid reflux which ive had since i was 8 years old the doctor insisted on puting me on steriods which seemed to do nothing, and told me it was acid reflux which i was 17 at the time i knew it was not that. So we came down to washington and went to childrens hospital it took them all of 3 seconds to realize this was not a G.I. problem, but they still can not seem to figure out what is wrong with me!! im sure you could imagin this frustration, since this pain very much limits me in what i can do. i cant carry heavy things, cant work out or do yoga, anything strenuise basicly and me being a very active 18 year old this is horrible! all the doctors say they can do is keep prescribing me vicoden which never takes the pain away. im just getting extremly frustrated with this whole situation and im looking for any advice at all. I have had bone scans, cat scans mass amounts of blood work and X-rays done and i have had an MRI but it was of my stomach Soon i will be going to ANOTHER orthepidic doctor but my health insurance doesnt kick in till the end of the month which seems like years away for me. so PLEASE if you can help me AT ALL just let me know id REALY apriciate it. thank you so much!  ~Megan
posted_time: Post  by solos_bud » Thu Jan 22, 2009 2:24 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Chronic Rib pain 3 years
content: Hello, With your history of blunt trauma, thorax pain, and vomiting, it sounds like the physicians have been ordering test to rule out internal organ problems.  It also sounds like the tests have come back negative.  If indeed the vomiting is from the thoracic pain, then relieving the pain should decrease the vomiting.  So, when you have little or no pain, is there any vomiting?  If this is a musculoskeltal problem and since you have not listed any reports of fracture then the rib cage and thoracic spine can be mobilized or manupulated. A chiropractor, osteopath, or orthopedic physical therapist may evaluate the rib cage and thoracic spine.  They will look for mal rotation of the spine or a rib being out of place...treatment will focus proper alignment, pain control, and exercise.    Hope this gives some help.  Let me know if you have any questions.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Mon Jan 26, 2009 2:09 pm

title: Re: Chronic Rib pain 3 years
content: Hi,  yes once my pain is under control, there is no vomiting, but the doctors told me if it is the ""slipping ribs syndrome"" not to go to a chyropracter for it  could further injure me.. so im not sure with that, i have another doctors apt for thursday with a different doctor becuase we talked to him and he said that if theres little swelling ( no previouse fractures or anything like that.) and there is not an indentation, then the slipping ribs should be completly aliminated from the possibilities. So im not completly sure. I think that it may be tissue damage, but then again the tissue around my ribs doesnt hurt, its when they are pushed on directly if like a doctor is trying to feel around it just to get an idea, that is extremly painful but x-rays and such don't show that there has been a fracture or anything of the sort so honesltly im not to sure. thank you so much!!!

title: Pain in Lower Leg (tibia region)
content: Currently have pain in my right lower leg around the tibia. Noticed a little swelling and a little bruising. Unable to dorsiflex without pain, when dorsiflex there is a cracking/popping sound as i move my foot towards my leg and back down. I do not remember any recent trauma to the region, besides playing basketball over three weeks ago and walking. The foot has swollen but has since subsided. Tried a mobic, aspirin, ice, and wrapping it to no avail.
posted_time: Post  by Scorpion044 » Thu Jan 15, 2009 5:32 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Pain in Lower Leg (tibia region)
content: Hello, The anterior tibialis is primarily responsible for dorsiflexing the foot.  More importantly is the area of bruising and pain near the ankle.  You may have suffered a high ankle sprain.  It would be good to have the ortho doc or family physician check the ankle stability (anterior drawer of the ankle: test anterior talo fibular ligament), and assess for sprain.    Your treatment thus far has been right on.    I suppose a strain to the anterior tib could explain the pain and swelling.  It would be quite a case to have a sprained anterior tibialis.  Sometimes this muscle gets sore especially with its microattachments to the tibia (shin splints).    Grasping at straws...may need to see ortho if it doesn't heal on its own over the next 1-2 weeks.   Let us know how it goes.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Mon Jan 26, 2009 2:58 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: severe pain in left shoulder after a road accident
content: Hello, I am sorry about your accident.  Treatment of landing on the shoulder while bike riding injury includes: - ruling out fractures with xrays. - Ice packs: on for 10-15 minutes, off for 30 minutes for the first 72 hours.  Then switch to hot packs. - Immobilizing the shoulder for 72 hours then gentle range of motion exercise only to painfree limits.   - NSAIDS. e.g ibuprofen or diclofenac - time  If no change in status in 7-10 post injury then follow up with family physician for further evaluation or consult to orthopedist.   Take care and let us know how things turn out.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Mon Jan 26, 2009 2:29 pm

author: GriffinsMom  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Jan 22, 2009 5:31 pm Gender: Female
title: Severe Whole Left Arm Pain Onset 2 months ago
content: Hi, I'm just hoping for advice/input on my situation. I woke up one morning in early November with arm pain, I thought I had just slept on it wrong and I figured I could just "walk" it off and be ok. Ten days later I couldn't take it anymore and went to my Dr. he thought I probably sprain it somehow and put me on Flector patches, in a sling and resting it. I went back a week later worse yet and was given a coprtisporin injection which didn't help at all. I was referred to an Ortho Surg who after waiting 3 weeks to get in to see him in 4 minutes said he wanted an MRI and it may be rotator degeneration. With insurance drama I will finally have my MRI on Monday (1-26). But, I'm worried what if it doesnt show anything? I am in such constant pain I don't know what to do! I was given the chioce to continue wearing my sling or not and I chose not because of the fear of atrophy or frozen shoulder. Any advice or idea would be truly appriciated! Thank you for your time.
posted_time: Post  by GriffinsMom » Thu Jan 22, 2009 5:44 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Severe Whole Left Arm Pain Onset 2 months ago
content: Hello, Possible causes of worsening shoulder pain include: - rotator cuff tear or impingement - sub acromial bursitis - shoulder arthritis - frozen shoulder (adhesive capsulitis) - generalized shoulder strain. - AC joint sprain - shoulder dislocation - labral tear (internal shoulder damage) - referred pain from the heart (ischemia)...unlikely - diaphram disease (the phrenic nerve innervates the diaphram.  Irritation of the diaphram can refer pain to the ipsilateral shoulder)  MRI is a good choice because, the pictures will help the physician detect if any of the above are causing the pain (with exception of the last two items).    In the meantime, continue ice/ heat and analgesics.  You are correct in your concern over frozen shoulder due to prolonged immobilization.  Also, some visits to the physical therapist may help with the pain and mobillity.  Keep us posted.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Mon Jan 26, 2009 2:21 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Ankle/foot pain when pointing toes
content: Hello, This sounds like a lateral ankle sprain.  When you point the toes (like a ballerina), the ankle will naturally invert.  Since severe ankle inversion from a fall or twisted foot causes lateral ankle sprain, then pointing toes will hurt.    Treatment for acute lateral ankle sprain includes ice, ibuprofen, compression (neoprene or ACE) and elevation.  If painful to bear weight, an xray is used to rule out fractures.    At this point, alternating hot and cold packs, weight bearing exercise (e.g mini squats), dorsiflexion stretches, neoprene sleeve (or aircast brace), crutches if painful to walk, and analgesics.  But first things first, have the foot xray'd to rule out fracture.  Take care and let us know how it goes.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Mon Jan 19, 2009 12:09 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Ankle/foot pain when pointing toes
content: Hello, Thanks for the description. With a lateral ankle sprain, we make a decision to xray the ankle based on: Does it hurt to bear weight. Is there pain when the distal tibial/fibula area is sqeezed. Is the 5th metatarsal painful. Is the distal fibula painful.  If a fracture is not displaced or angulated no reductions are needed.  The area is casted or splinted and left to heal.    If the ankle is improving with time and no swelling or pain with weight bearing, this ankle probably was just sprained.    In general the longer you wait for treating a fracture, the outcome again depends on the bone and the severity.  Big long bones like the femur need immediate attention because of the blood supply  and potential nerve damage.  Displaced and angulated bones do not heal well if at all unless they are approxamated and straightened...plus risk of infection especially if the skin is broken (open fracture).  Hope this helps.  Keep us posted.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Wed Jan 21, 2009 12:01 pm

author: misterj1080  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Jan 18, 2009 4:46 pm Gender: Male
title: Lump on ankle
content: I am a 25 year old healthy, fit (not overweight) electrician.  I have very dense bones amd have never broken anything, nor have I ever suffered anything more than a minor sprain.  I have very developed legs which can take just about anything.  I suppose I had a sense of invincibility of sorts.  Last summer, I got into the habit of leaping off my boss's 3-foot deck onto asphalt on the way to the work van.  This was done in constrictive high-top flat-soled work boots with no support whatsoever.  After a couple months I noticed instability in my right ankle.  So, I bought supportive insoles and stopped jumping.  When it got worse, I switched to tennis shoes and concentrated on training the specific weak point little by little.  Now after more than 6 months, the strength is back but I have a noticeable lump (no longer swelling) over the outside of the ankle bone (tallus?).  Is it possible that a bone spur could be cutting into the muscle or tendon?  My mother has heel spurs.  I currently don't have health insurance, although I can afford it now.  Is this worth insurance and a trip to a specialist, or should I just exercise it?  Thank you.
posted_time: Post  by misterj1080 » Sun Jan 18, 2009 5:26 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Lump on ankle
content: Hello,  It is hard to get a clear idea where the lump in the ankle is.  The normal bump on the outside part of the ankle is the distal fibula.   The ankle joint is made of the tibia/fibula communication with the talus.  A bone spur on the lateral ankle is uncommon and would need to be rather large and pointy to cut a tendon - very very unlikely.   The pain and swelling in the ankle may have been from repetitive jumping onto hard concrete.   The fact that the pain and swelling are gone is reassuring.  As long as the ankle and foot and knee (yes - always consider the joints above the injured area) are functioning properly without pain then the structures are probably sound.   If in doubt, have the ankle and foot xray'd and see your family physcian for accurate diagnosis.  Take care and let us know if we can answer any more questions.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Wed Jan 21, 2009 11:45 am

title: Broken Finger?  Do I need more then a splint?
content: Got back from the doctor and they recommended I see a Orthopedic Surgeon about my finger.  Here are some pictures from the x-rays.    Is an orthopedic surgeon really necessary?  This happened while playing flag football if that matters...haha
posted_time: Post  by rodvang » Tue Jan 13, 2009 11:56 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Broken Finger?  Do I need more then a splint?
content: Hello, Thanks for the pictures.  It is difficult to see the distal end of the proximal phalanx clearly but there may be a oblique fracture there with minimal displacement and some angulation.  If so, then yes see an orthopedist.    Did the radiologist report a fracture?  Looks like the PIP (proximal interphalangeal joint) may be hyperextended or dislocated.  Was this reported?  In general, a non displaced, non angulated finger fracture without neurovascular compromise (no numbness, tingling, or diminished pulses) can be splinted or buddy taped without an orthopedic consult.    Again, from this distance it is hard to read the radiograph clearly.  Let us know how things turn out.  What you do will depend on what you and your family  physician decide and based on the radiology report.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Fri Jan 16, 2009 10:21 am

author: Dr. mnermis  Medical Doctor Posts: 8 Joined: Fri Jan 09, 2009 4:15 pm Gender: Male
title: Re: Broken Finger?  Do I need more then a splint?
content: Trauma that cause hyperflexion of the distal phalanx ruptured the extensor tendon ( Mallet finger)  sometimes the end of the tendon may  have a bony fragment.  this is a Bony Mallet finger   It means that extensor tendon of the fourth finger ruptured from its insertion point with a bony fragment, ( avulsion fracture)  Bony Mallet finger healing time is earlier than the Mallet finger. Bone to bone healing is better, and earlier than bone to tendon healing.  this radiographs were taken with splint, and spints tries to hyperextend the proximal and distal interfalangeal joints to shorten the distance between the avulsed bony fragment to distal phalanx. if avulsed bone don't have any gap with distal phalanx and touch it, it will heal more rapidly with full range of motion without pain.  general information for phalanx fracture, if the fractured bone is not larger than the 30% of the joint surface it does not need any surgery.  Your fracture is small than the 30% of the joint surface, there is not any gap at the fracture site, so i think you will use your finger after 6 weeks splint treatment.  don't worry,  But don't remove your splint before 6 weeks  Take care

title: 28 year old female-knee pain from exercise
content: Hi, I'm a 28 year old female. In the past year, I began working out and dieting to lose weight following the birth of my 1st child. While happy to report that I've lost 40 pounds and reached my goal weight, I now have knee pain in both knees after doing squats, lunges, or running on the treadmill. I can't even do the elliptical or stair-stepper due to the pain. The pain is mostly under and right below my knee caps. Usually ibuprofen will help, but I'd like to be able to do the elliptical machine and add weight to my squats/lunges to improve muscle definition, but it seems impossible. I tried taking a break from doing any weight bearing exercise, but we have stairs in our house and I have to carry our 30 pound son down the stairs occassionally and this causes pain. Are supplements such as Osteo Bi-Flex worth the money or does this sound like something more serious that I should have a doctor investigate? Thanks so much for your help!
posted_time: Post  by nettyandrenata » Wed Jan 14, 2009 8:31 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: 28 year old female-knee pain from exercise
content: Hello, Congratulations on your new son.  30lb boy is good weight within the first year!  Your knee pain sounds like patellar tendonitis.  Treatment includes ice packs; stretching quads,hamstings, and groin; exercise as tolerated (walking, swimming), and NSAIDS.  This can be a nagging recurrent injury and it is indeed a training injury.    Use of patella straps may help.  For linament, I like 50% salicylate cream / 50% menthol cream mixed and massaged into the tendon and topped with moist heat pack for 20 minutes.  Use 1-2 x a day for 1-2 weeks.    Gradually, return to squats, lunges, running, etc.  All exercise should be painfree both during and 24 hours after exercise.    If needed, see a physical therapist for supervised rehab.  Let us know how it goes.

title: Anterior Cruciate Ligament Injury
content: I have recently just had a knee arthroscopy to repair damaged cartilage from a hockey injury a few months ago. After surgery the surgeon informed me that I had only 50% of my anterior cruciate ligament left. I return in 6 weeks to have another check up but was wondering if you could tell me if it is possible that a person having only 50% of this ligament left would be able to return to play sport again without having surgery to repair the ligament? If so is there anything I can do to strengthen the knee?  Many Thanks
posted_time: Post  by hockeymad » Wed Jan 14, 2009 4:34 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Anterior Cruciate Ligament Injury
content: Hello, I am sorry to hear about your knee.  Having 50% of an ACL in itself does not prevent participation in sports.  What matters is: 1. The stability of the knee.  Is there to much anterior translation or laxity in the knee.  Too much "sloppiness" in the knee can worsen the cartilage damage and cause problems with the meniscus.  However, some surgeons recommend opting out of ACL repair if the hamstrings and quadriceps are significantly strong and flexible and can handle the load and jarring of the sport.   2. How the knee responds to rehab including back to sport training.  Significant swelling, pain, weakness, instability, or locking sensation in or around the knee may be warning signs that the ACL needs repair.    Hope this helps. Keep us posted and let us know how things turn out.

author: cmasse  Guest Posts: 40 Joined: Thu Dec 27, 2007 7:14 pm
title: Wrist Surgery
content: I have a question.  I got wrist surgery on Dec. 17, 2008 and I decided to use the Total Gym on January 9, 2009, Firday evening, for a little for my wrist even though I wasn't supposed to but wanted to try it anyway.  Five minutes later I got really dizzy and I could not see straight and things were turning around in circles and I felt nauseous that evening for an hour.  Then it got better and then I woke up in the middle of the night with it again and then all day Saturday, I still felt dizzy and nauseous, with still a little dizzy on Tuesday, January 13, 2009.  Can using my surgically repaired wrist too soon make me dizzy?  Maybe a drop or rise in blood pressure could have caused this?  Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated.  Thank You.  Cassie
posted_time: Post  by cmasse » Tue Jan 13, 2009 10:34 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Wrist Surgery
content: Hello, Consult with the surgeon before starting any exercise.  Yes, a drop in blood pressure could have caused the dizziness and nausea. Pain or fear can trigger a vasovagal response.  The blood pressure drops and the person passes out...or close to it.  Essentially the head (including the brain) does not get enough blood.  This is why before passing out people are described as turning pale.  ie "Their face turned white as a ghost"  If the nausea and dizziness continue despite stoppng the exercise and increasing fluids, consult a physician for evaluation of your symptoms.   Take care and keep us posted.

author: AthleteInPain  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Jan 15, 2009 7:53 am Gender: Male
title: Pain in Knee from jogging
content: Hello. I am an on again/off again jogger who recently started a new jogging program. After a week or so I've developed a lot of pain in and around my left knee. The knee is very sore on the inside part and I can feel a small pocket of fluid on each side of the knee cap. It's very sore and painful when I extend the knee. Aside from not jogging, what is the best way to treat this condition?  Thank you.
posted_time: Post  by AthleteInPain » Thu Jan 15, 2009 8:09 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Pain in Knee from jogging
content: Hello, Treat acute inflammation with ice, rest, elevation and compression (ACE wrap or neoprene sleeve).  Maintain range of motion in the knee.   Before returning to running, ask a physician to examine the knee for meniscal problems, pes anserine bursitis, patella femoral pain, ACL laxity, medial collateral laxity or inflammation.  If you have a flat feet, leg tightness (hamstrings, quadriceps, achilles, groin muscles or hip flexors), leg weakness or fatigue then you will be prone to knee injury with running.  Use orthotics in shoes if you have flat feet.   In general, new runners or on-again/off-again runners should prepare the leg muscles for jogging with 4-6 weeks of leg strengthening exercise, stretching, and brisk walking (up to 30 min) before starting a running program.  This helps prevent injury and makes running more enjoyable and long lasting.  Take care and keep us posted.

author: nmguy  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Jan 13, 2009 4:12 am Gender: Male
title: Recurring but random Severe Hip Pain
content: Two months ago I attended a political rally and was on my feet for about 6 hours, standing, with only a couple of short walks from the location I was standing. That night, I experienced severe hip pain in my left hip. On a 1-10 scale it was 9. The pain was reduced by movement, walking, stretching, but returned within a couple of hours if I went back to bed. This continued for several days, it improved day to day and was no longer an issue.  Since then I have had several incidents of a similar nature, but without the extended period of standing. Currently I have experienced this again. I was fine, no unusual activities, and woke up during the night with pain in my left hip joint. The pain, on a 1-10 scale was 9-10. It was difficult to get out of bed, walk, or stand. I did get up, walked around the house for about 10 minutes, put a heating pad on my hip while sitting in an desk chair for about 20 minutes, and the pain went away.  I went back to bed, and slept for about 3 hours. I woke up, with the same pain. Again I walked for a few minutes, then a heating pad, and the pain went away. About every 2-3 hours this continued, until I was up for the day. This same pattern has continued for 3 days. During the day, if I am active, walk, and do normal activities there is no pain, only some soreness in my hip.  I had a complete physical in October, about a month prior to the 1st incident. I talked to my doctor about it after the first incident in November. He said it was nothing to worry about, and was likely due to the extended standing, imobility. I've called him since when it reoccurred, and he said to come in if it didn't improve, that it was likely bursitis.  I have no numbness, no other pain, anywhere. I have no other health issues, other than my blood pressure, which I take Altace, and nothing else.   I'm not quite sure what to think, about what may be causing the hip pain. My Doctor didin't seem concerned the 1st time, or since when I've talked to him. This current incident is worse than any prior, and has lasted longer.  Should I be more concernded? See a different doctor. Does this fit with bursitis? or could it be something else more serious ???
posted_time: Post  by nmguy » Tue Jan 13, 2009 4:33 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Recurring but random Severe Hip Pain
content: Hello, A few conditions could cause this pain: trochanteric bursitis hip arthritis muscular strain / pain referred pain from back  Bursitis is easy to diagnose because the bursa sits directly over the greater trochanter of the proximal femur and is easily palpated.  If inflamed, it will be tender to touch. Hip arthritis is diagnosed with history and physical exam and xray.  Treatment includes heat and/or ice packs, NSAIDS for bursitis or acetaminophen for arthritis, and maintaining strength and motion.  For definite diagnosis see your family physician for examination and xray.  Let us know how it goes.

content: Hello, Grinding sensation is more concerning than the typically snapping or popping that many normal joints do...especially considering loss of function and pain. author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: SEVERE LOWER BACK AND LEG PAIN
content: Hello, Thank you for your questions.  Regarding the MUGA scan: the benefit of this test is to determine how well the heart is pumping blood either toward the lungs or toward the body (aka ejection fraction - this is expressed in percentages...which you gave).  The only bearing on the lumbar spine and legs would be a one of blood supply.  An ejection fraction of 50% in itself should not increase low back pain.  I agree that the CRP is a general marker for inflammation and high concentrations in the blood may be caused from a variety of conditions...so in isolation, not helpful in specific diagnosis.  The MRI was normal two years ago. Certainly, if low back symptoms with pain radiating down the legs has developed or worsened since that time, a repeat MRI is reasonable.    The bone scan scheduled is a good test considering recent history of stage III breast cancer.  It should be determined that the cancer has not progressed to stage IV which may include bone involvement and a potential cause for your back pain.    Lastly, since you have a mild neuropathy, have you been screened for diabetes?  Let us know how things go.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Radial dysplasia (elbows)
content: Hello,  To improve ROM and strength, some general principles for exercise are as follows: - apply heating pad before and ice pack after - use NSAIDS for inflammation control  - use supportive brace (neoprene sleeve) during activities like basketball for warmth and support. - focus on elbow flexion and extension gentle stretching without resistance ie weights until full painfree motion.  Also practice forearm pronation and supination. - gentle progress to weights.  Avoid bending and turning (forearm pronation and supination) in combination as this will place more stress on the radial head area.   - Let pain and inflammation be the guide.  Pain means stop the exercise.  Regarding more treatment options, I have not seen any further specific treatment in the medical literature.  Perhaps, you could describe the dysplasia in more detail.  I assume this involves the radial head.   Any some point, a second debridement may be in order.  In the meantime, conservative treatment is to be optimized.    Let me know how it goes.   Take care.

posted_time: Post  by jynx » Sun Jan 11, 2009 10:58 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: shoulder injury& interpreting MRI results/serious?
content: Hello, The MRI reports partial tears in the glenoid labrum (padding in the socket part of the shoulder which helps stabilize the joint), the rotator cuff, biceps tendon, and the teres minor (one of four muscles comprising the rotator cuff).    With failed or failing physical therapy, there is enough pathology (via MRI report) here to consider surgical repair... so a discussion with an orthopedist would be prudent.  The enchondroma is benign but some medical literature reports a slight risk of pathological fracture in which case a malignant transformation would be suspected.  In other words, if it starts hurting, have it evaluated otherwise it is non cancerous and no worry.   Let us know how things turn out.

author: MWise  Nurse Posts: 3 Joined: Thu Jan 08, 2009 8:34 am Gender: Female
title: Re: sudden unexplainable big toe pain
content: I would recommend that you ask your Family Practitioner to make sure it is not symptom of gouty arthritis. He can run a simple blood test called a Uric Acid Level to determine if this may be the cause. Your pain is a frequent symptom of this kind of arthritis. MWise RN

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: sudden unexplainable big toe pain
content: Soretoe, The pain is not phantom pain from the other foot's big toe although it is a novel idea.    I agree that a uric acid level would be in order to determine if this is gout.  Gout typically affects the great toe - causing pain, redness, and swelling.  It may affect other joints as well including the knee.  Treatment consists of rest, elevation, and NSAIDS.  Keep us posted.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Unexplained Swelling of Left Knee
content: Hello, Structures that can swell in the knee are of course the knee joint itself but there is also a small bursa above the knee cap call the supra patellar bursa which can swell.   The main question to answer is whether this is caused by some damage inside the knee or outside the knee.    An MRI may help rule out cartilage, meniscus (padding inside the knee), bone bruising, and tendonities/bursitis.  A plain xray will not show these defects.  Treatment for pain and swelling are ice, rest, compression and elevation.  Keep us updated.  Write again if you have any questions. Take care.

author: Meekus24  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Jan 08, 2009 7:02 pm Gender: Male
title: Lacerated Thumb Question
content: On Christmas, I cut my left thumb right underneath the knuckle on the finger to the bone.  Did not cut any tendons and the cut is about an inch long.  I had 5 stitches put in and kept them in for 10 days.  When I had them removed on Monday, it seemed that the stitch closest to the knuckle hadn't completely healed.  I have been trying to not use the thumb and the gap seems to be closing slowly over the last four days.  I have been trying to immobilize it at night so I don't do any further damage.  I have a couple of questions:  1. Am I doing the correct thing by keeping it immobilized at night and letting the cut completely heal or am I doing damage by keep it rigid like that?  2. When should I start trying to move the thumb and see if there is any permanent damage (the ER doc told me the tendon wasn't cut or partially cut)?  3. Is there anything I should be doing specifically to try to make sure I have full range of motion with my thumb?  Thanks.
posted_time: Post  by Meekus24 » Thu Jan 08, 2009 7:10 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Lacerated Thumb Question
content: Hello, Which surface of the thumb did you cut?  On the palm side or back side?  As long as the skin edges of the wound are closing and no signs of infection, this should heal well.    You can start gentle motion at any time as long as it doesn't place too much tension on the skin causing the small opening to enlarge.  Just do not overdo it.  The opening can worsen and cause a non healed laceration repair (aka dehiscence)...and then healing takes longer.  You will not hurt the thumb by immobilizing it at night.  You will be able to regain motion after another week or so.  If in doubt, check in with your physician to have a look at it.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: shooting pain in hands and legs
content: Hello, Since the pain is in both arms and both legs, I wonder about systemic problems like auto immune disorders (e.g. lupus, RA), metabolic problems (like diabetes or thyroid issues), or neurological problems.   Of course there can be spinal issues referring pain to the limbs or generalized muscle or bone pain both of which we would still want to know about other symptoms (eg fatigue, weakness, change in reflexes, racing heart, weight loss or gain, illnessess).  Also, it is important to probe her history both personal and family as well as social history (what kind of work does she do, hobbbies, activities).  More information needs to be gathered so it will be important for her to see her family physician who can take her history and do a physical exam and any needed testing.    Keep us posted.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Injured Knee playing Wii?
content: PC  This sounds like a either suprapatellar bursitis or acute knee strain/sprain.  I am not that familiar with Wii but I understand that the player mimics the real sport action.  Given that there was no trauma, or impact, or sudden sharp pain/pop incident, the condition should respond to rest, ice, compression (ACE wrap or neoprene sleeve with open patella), and elevation.   The sharp twinges of pain should subside and full range of motion return.  If any problems with worsening pain, swelling, or loss of motion have a physician evaluate the ligament and meniscus in the office.   No need for xray or MRI at this time.  Let us know how things turn out.

title: Re: reduced range of motion and other hip issues
content: Hello,  In general, sudden bone pain in an adult which wakes a person at night should be evaluated by a physician.  Xrays should be taken and a thorough history and focused physical done.  Several conditions could be causing this pain: inflamation in the bursa (tenderness on the outside part of the upper femur) hip arthritis stress fracture (seen on MRI) groin pull muscle strain/sprain labral tear in the acetabulum (hip socket)  less likely causes: cancer gout referred from the spine  Loss of external rotation of the hip confirms the need to have it evaluated by a physician. author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: 28 male with knee pain and stiffness other symptoms
content: This sounds like a patella-femoral problem.  Popping or crunching sounds (aka crepitus) are common reports.  Pain and stiffness may indicate arthritis under the knee cap.     Osgood Schlatter disease is actually is a condition where the cartiledge detaches from the tibial tuberosity (the attachment site of the patellar ligament - just below the kneecap) and causes localized pain and tenderness.  From the location of your pain, it doesn't sound like Osgood Schlatters.   It would be good to see a physical therapist who will prescribe specific patella-femoral exercises.  These should include straight leg raises, mini squats, and stretching (hip flexors, hamstrings, quadriceps, and IT band).  Avoid stationary bike and leg kicks and no deep knee bends or squats until painfree. Use acetaminophen or ibuprofen; ice or heat as needed.  Sometimes a patellafemoral brace helps.   All the best to you.   Let us know how it goes.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Hip Pain..could it be from Strep infection?
content: Yes, strep bacteria can and do cauce infection in children's hips.  One source quotes the source of infection from the ears but I suppose any respiratory tract infection could cause it.    Although rare, septic arthritis must be considered since it is a serious condition. Infections in the joint can destroy the entire joint, enter the circulation, and may lead to serious sequelae like sepsis and death.     Ask a physician evaluate the hip for signs of infection (warmth, swelling, pain, and redness; and fever and overall health status).  Xray and CBC (blood counts) may be needed.    Septic arthritis is an orthopedic emergency so make sure the hip is not infected.    Non threatening conditions likely to cause this include tendonitis bursitis (inflamation of bursa on the outside part of the hip) musclar strain or sprain radiating pain from the back.   If a septic (infected) joint is suspected, see a physician right away.   Keep us posted.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: A continuning ankle strong ankle pain
content: A high ankle sprain (stretch or tear in the ligaments holding the distal end of the tibia and fibula together) takes twice as long to heal as a regular lateral ankle sprain.  In your case, three years post injury, it is important to check the strength and stability of the ankle because this pain may be from a re-injury or a poorly healed original injury.  Either way, have a stress xray image of the ankle to see if the bones (tibia and fibula) stay together or separate (unstable) with weight bearing.  If the ankle is unstable, then surgery may be required to fix the bones with screw(s).    Let us know how things turn out or if you have any questions.

title: Re: severe pain in feet, not heel, after resting
content: The cortisone injection was probably for a Mortons neuroma (pinched or inflamed nerve between the toes).  This probably has nothing to do with the radiating ankle pain.  It would be helpful to have family physician evaluate your feet and take your history and take some xrays and perhaps some lab work.  The differential diagnosis for bilateral ankle pain radiating to the toes includes: osteoarthritis rheumatoid arthritis gout tendonitis idiopathic foot pain  (Least likely) plantar fasciitis: based on the location.  PF usually hurts on the plantar surface of the foot but does hurt more after resting or first thing in the morning.  occult ankle fracture spinal stenosis  Let us know how things turn out or if you have any more questions.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: pain in the patella
content: This is a classic patellafemoral problem.   The patella (kneecap) is a bone within the quadriceps tendon.  The quadricep is the large front thigh muscle that extends the foot (kicking motion) and provides power and stability during squatting and climbing.   Sometimes the tendons around the kneecap become too tight (in your case on the ouside).   Avoid knee extension exercises and deep squats until painfree.  Focus on stretching quadriceps, hip flexors, and IT band.  Strengthen the quads with straight leg raises and mini squats (less than 60 degrees knee flexion ... and light weight - either dumb bells or squat bar on shoulders) Remember to ice.   If this fails, see a physical therapist via your family physician. All the best to you. Keep us posted.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Been having ankle pain for years
content: Thanks for your patience. This sounds like a chronic lateral ankle sprain.  With an ankle sprain, the ligaments supporting the ankle joint over stretch.  Since the ligaments are non contractile tissue they do not rebound easily (unlike a rubber band or muscle tissue).  Therefore the ankle is prone to further injury - even stepping on smal objects or uneven terrain aggravates the ankle.   Some simple measures to help the ankle: 1. When it hurts, apply bag of ice (10 minutes each application) - pearl: place a warm wet cloth on the skin before applying ice bag. 2. Do mini squats: stand with your back against the wall and slide down the wall under knee in flexed about 60 degrees.  Using a ball behind the back make sliding easier but watch your balance. 3. Advanced strengthening exercise: walk on heels and walk on toes.  Do not do if painful.   4. Practice walking up stairs leading with affected foot.  Advance to two steps at a time.   5.  Stand on a straight line.  Close eyes.  Maintain balance.  (Try with affected foot either in front or in back of other foot.)  Before you start these exercises, have the ankle xray'd to rule out fracture.   Any exercise which hurts stop.  Keep us posted.

I haven't hit my leg or injured it in any way. I do not know what i've done to cause such pain? What should i do? or do you have any idea what it might be?
posted_time: Post  by wlt4ever » Mon Nov 03, 2008 1:43 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Severe Thigh and Hip Pain/ Going on for FIVE Months
content: Thanks for your patience. With most limb pain especially pain without a cause, it is important to check the part of the spine that sends nerves to that limb.  In this case, have a physician exam the lumbar spine - range of motion, tender areas, deep tendon reflexes, nerve stretching manuevers (straight leg raise), sensory check.  If all is well here then move on to examine the hip joint and entire leg. In general, it is important to not only evaluate the portion that hurts but also the joints above and below.   In short, have a physician evaluate the back, hip, thigh, and knee.   Xray of the hip may be indicated too.   Have you tried any heat or ice or over the counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen? Keep us posted.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Mon Dec 29, 2008 7:38 pm

title: Flake Fracture Tallus - Problems after surgery
content: In June 2007 I tripped down a step at work and sustained a avulsion fracture of my right ankle pulling a tendon from the bone. In May 2008 following many months of discomfort & physio therapy an anteria lateral arthrotomy/arthroscopy was carried out to remove the bone fragment. This was then followed by physiotherapy for 3 mths. I continue to experience numbness in my toes, sharp electric pain in the top of my foot & toes, burning sensation in the top of the foot, stiffness and annoying/aggrevating discomfort when laying in bed at night. My two outside toes have dropped and are now curling under my foot. My last visit to the specialist voiced that there is no further treatment and that there could be permanent nerve damage. I am currently back at work full time, however after a couple of hours, pain sets in. At the moment, I am on alternative duties but don't know how long my employer will provide this option. Have one month before work cover will do a final assessment for permanent impairment. Can you suggest any further treatment options and advise what I can expect in the future (worst case cenario, arthritis etc).

This could cause a deformity and may affect the foot's function...and more pain too.  It would be worthwhile to have a orthotist fabricate an orthotic to prevent the toes from curling under.   Keeping the foot's range of motion and strength in good condtion will help in the long run. Keep us posted.

author: teachersb  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Oct 28, 2008 7:01 pm Gender: Female
title: Osteoarthritis and Lyme's Disease
content: I had Lyme's disease in 1989.  Now, when I have had X-rays, CT Scans, and MRIs of either my spine and/or knee, the doctors say I have some Arthritis in both those areas.  Is it possible that there could be a connection between my Lyme's Disease and me having the Arthritis?
posted_time: Post  by teachersb » Tue Oct 28, 2008 7:12 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Osteoarthritis and Lyme's Disease
content: Thanks for your patience. Yes, one of the late manifestations of Lyme disease is arthralgias (painful joints) and arthritis (joint inflammation).  The joint problems may start from weeks to months after the infection itself starts.  Usually the symptoms resolve within a 30 day course of antibiotics.   If any joint would continue to be painful, it would be the knee.  The bones in general may also become osteopenic and some specific joint erosions may occur.  In fact, before Lyme disease was discovered, affected children were thought to have juvenile rheumatoid arthritis. In short, Lyme can cause some lasting joint problems especially in the knee.  Less common in the back. Have you had a bone mineral density test?
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Mon Dec 29, 2008 6:57 pm

author: ecater  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Sep 22, 2008 3:19 pm Gender: Male
title: Chronic Hip Pain
content: I am a 24 year old, otherwise healthy male.  While involved in intensive military training in November of 2006, I fell from a top bunk onto a hard floor.  Susbsequently, I began to notice a moderate pain in my left hip while I was running.  I went to the doctor and was told I had a muscle strain, given 800 mg motrin and sent home with a running exemption.    The pain progressed over the following days, significantly impairing my ability to walk at all.  I was precribed narcotic pain killers and was given a referral to orthopedics.  I was seen by an orthopedist who took an MRI and diagnosed me with a stress fracture on my femoral neck.  I was given crutches and told to stay off it for 6 weeks.  After 9 months of no change in my pain, my stumped orthopedist sent me out for a second opinion.  That orthopedist discovered a bone mass on my femoral head and three seperate tears in my labrum.  He removed the bone mass, repaired what he could of the labrum, removed the rest and inserted micro-fractures where he removed it, all arthroscopically.  I was told to stay on crutches for 8 week.  2 days later, I fell down a flight of stairs.    Six months later, I was still experiencing severe pain.  Having no explaination for it, my orthopedist referred me to a pain management doc.  About this time the military moved me.    The pain management doc I saw here referred me to a physical therapist.  After two sessions, the physical therapist sent me to an orthopedist, who sent me back to the same pain management doc, who sent me back to the same physical therapist, who has now sent me to an orthopedist.  Please, please, please... if there is anybody out there who might have an idea as to what the problem might be, I am begging for you to just throw out some ideas.    Thanks in advance.
posted_time: Post  by ecater » Mon Sep 22, 2008 3:45 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Chronic Hip Pain
content: Thanks for your patience. I gasped when I read that you fell down the stairs 2 days after arthroscopic hip surgery.   Any testing after the fall?  You may consider doing a repeat MRI or to do a bone scan looking for soft tissue damage or fractures.   If everything is sound structurally, then the process begins to rehab the hip.  With lots of pain this may take some time but I would think a combination of pain management and therapy would suffice.  Consider doing the rehab in a pool at first to take weight off the hip and progress to land activities. Keep us posted.

author: rabidmiacid  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Sat Sep 20, 2008 9:42 pm Gender: Female
title: Severe Shoulder pain for 3 years, spreading down right side
content: I am a 21 year old female who smokes less than half a pack a week and has only smoked for 2 years.  After a car accident in late '05 I noticed my right shoulder hurting, especially at work (at the time I was making pizzas at a large franchise).  The pain radiated between the shoulder blade and the spine, heading up towards my neck and into the groove between shoulder and collar bone.  After a month, it spread to my bicep, and I began having numbness and tingling in my hand.  Sometimes I would loose circulation entirely.  I went to my primary care physician, who sent me to an orthopedic specialist, who sent me to a spine specialist, who sent me to a neurologist, who sent me back to my primary care, who sent me to PT, at which point I was out 1000$ and could no longer afford my co-pay and still had no answers.  I controlled it with medication as long as I could, but after a few months each type would stop working and I would have to switch.  Due to financial issues I am now taking over the counter only and my kindeys hurt.  I was given multiple inconclusive diagnosis'.  First was repetitive motion injury or a rotator cuff injury.  The MRI (right shoulder only - no neck, no chest) showed fluid, but no noticeable injury. The orthopedic specialist thought I had Thoracic Outlet - I loose pulse on my right side only when my arm is at chest level or higher.  X-Rays showed no extra ribs or spurs.  The neurologist did an EMG - which aside from being horrible came back normal.  I did physical therapy for 3 months - which made the pain much worse and my arm felt even weaker afterward.  I have continued doing the exercises and have not been able to gain any muscle mass in my arm and the pain and weakness continue to this day.  The pain is much like a knife lodged between the blade - I am unable to move my head when it gets bad. It has been bad enough recently to make me cry.  (I have a very high tolerance - when it's bad it's *bad*)    Shortly after the pains in my shoulder started, I began getting sharp pains on the right side of my stomach, nausea and weight gain (20lbs in last 10 months - my diet has not changed).  Blood work was run  and came back inconclusive.  Recently there have been pains in my chest - just to the right of my heart or down the whole right side - and severe headaches from the base of my skull or my right temple.  The pain in my chest is not so much sharp as it is more like the sort of tight squeeze your heart feeling you get when you are incredibly nervous.  Occasionally I have difficulty breathing.  (I have had these before, but they have been worse last 6 months).  When I cough and sometimes when I swallow, it feels as if there is a lump in my neck, just to the right of my trachea.  A month ago I became suddenly extremely lightheaded, could not breathe, and felt as if the blood in the veins on the right side of my neck had turned to sludge - I could feel it slowly moving through the side of my neck like thick mud.  I managed to grab my inhaler and took some antihistamines - which helped - but when my head cleared my shoulder was in agony and I could not move my arm.  I was not allergic to anything near me when this happened.    Is all of this related, or just horrible coincidence?  I have little money right now and can't spend too much on tests and false diagnosis - but I know I need to go back in for this pain.  What should I request done?  Does anyone know what these doctors have missed?  Please, if anyone can give me any answers, suggestions on what to look for, or general advice I haven't tried yet, it would be incredibly appreciated.  I can't live like this anymore.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Severe Shoulder pain for 3 years, spreading down right side
content: Thanks for your patience.  It sounds like the chest pain and difficulty breathing may have been a panic attack.  However, talking to your physician would help shed some more light on the etiology of the chest symptoms which sound unrelated to the neck and shoulder pain.    Regarding the neck and shoulder problem, it seems that the motor vehicle accident started the problem.  This mechanism of injury can cause all sorts of pain patterns and dysfunction throughout the spine and shoulder girdle. Were you wearing a seat belt and was this across the affected shoulder? Although not too reassuring, It is not surprising or unusual that you are having this much trouble.  From what I read in your account, the only other test I would recommend is an MRI of the neck to rule out disc herniation.  Since the EMG was normal, an alternate route is to do a series of neck xrays to rule out spondylosis ("disease of the spine" like bone spurs or decreased disk height) especially spondylolithesis (slipping forward of a vertebrae).  If xrays are normal then you could proceed with confidence that the structures of the neck are fine.   You could start addressing the shoulder and neck in one of two ways: 1: on your own, start gentle range of motion with the neck and shoulder.  The initial goal or phase is to achieve and maintain full range of motion (ROM).  This should be done gradually and slowly with the use of heat before exercise and ice afterward.  It may take 3 months to achieve this goal and hopefully be painfree.  Again the exercises should be easy and within a painfree limit and slowly increase limit over time. (Your therapist should have given some simple ROM exercises to do at home)  Afterward start a easy does it strengthening program.  Take 6 months for this phase.   2: See a chiropractor who also does a preceeding massage treatment.  Then do phase one and two above (time frames will be shorter if chiropractor helps).  Keep us posted

author: tj_rabbitt  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Sep 19, 2008 12:14 pm Gender: Male
title: Sciatica, stenosis, or zaspopathy?
content: Severe pain down my left leg put me out of commission for about 2 months recently.  It was diagnosed as sciatica (had the same happen 2 years ago) due to a combination of a herniated disc and a stenosis of the nerve canal.  Unlike the incident 2 years ago, this time I had great pain in the upper frontal muscle of the left leg, having to constantly massage and apply heat/cold to it for relief.  Now that the spinal issue seems to have resolved again (including 2 cortisone injections), my left leg is still weak.  That is no particular surprise, except that it appears noticeably smaller than my right leg - but only the upper front muscle - the one that was in so much pain.  It is weak to the point that stairs are an effort, I cannot squat down on the left leg only (it is unable to support my weight), and I cannot push up from a squating position (knee more than 45 degrees bent).  Until this episode, I had no weakness in the left leg.  I am beginning to become concerned that this was not, at least solely, a herniated disc/stenosis problem.  I've not heard of anything that could cause a muscle weakening like this other than zaspopathy, but there is very little information available on it or it's symptoms.  It has been 5 months since the onset of the problem, and I see no change in the left leg.  In fact, exercise seems to aggravate the situation much more than strengthen the leg.  After even brief exercise I have to be particularly careful about attempting to walk down stairs for most of the day, as the leg has a tendency to "give out" much more easily and unexpectedly.  So I'm wondering, is this typical from sciatica/stenosis, or is there something else going on?  And if it's something else, how do I proceed to have it investigated effectively?  Do I need to find a specialist - and what kind?
posted_time: Post  by tj_rabbitt » Fri Sep 19, 2008 1:04 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Sciatica, stenosis, or zaspopathy?
content: Thanks for you patience. Zaspopathy is a form of muscular dystrophy which affects the distal leg muscle more that the proximal leg muscle.  Diagnosis is made with history and physical, EMG, and muscle biopsy.  However, your case does not appear to be zaspopathy. The leg problem seems related to the nerve impingement and herniated disk.  An EMG and CPK (test for muscle enzyme in the blood) would help know the extent of muscle and nerve impairment.   A physiatrist can evaluate you thigh problem and do the EMG. Keep us posted.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Sat Dec 27, 2008 8:48 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: top of foot pain
content: Often bone spurs themselves are not the source of pain but the inflamed tissue around them is responsible.  Spurs develop from excessive pressure over time.   So perhaps there is a way to change the way you walk or change foot wear in order to change distribution of pressure in the foot.  It would be helpful to know exactly where the spurs are.  Inflamation can be treated with NSAIDS, ice and heat (if chronic).  Having a physical therapist evaluate your foot and gait may help find out why there is too much pressure in the foot causing the spur. Have you gained any weight lately? Keep us posted.

posted_time: Post  by poldy » Thu Sep 18, 2008 3:43 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Enlarged and longer collarbone
content: Cervical spondylosis is a general term which literally means "disease of the vertebrae".  Specifically, the spine may show: narrowing of the disc space (between the vertebrae),  spurs or osteophytes which protrude out from the spine and may pinch a nerve including the spinal cord  Usually, these changes in the vertebrae are advanced by age and are found in older individuals.    MRI will show any nerve impingement or spurring or disc protrusions/herniations.  I would investigate the exact findings on the MRI and see why the dx of spondylosis was made.  Although one can affect the other, from what you have written, I do not see the relationship between the clavicle and ther cervical spine.       Certainly, neck and shoulder pain can be caused by a problem in the clavicle but I would make a closer examination of the entire shoulder complex including the AC (acromioclavicular), SC (sternoclavicular) and glenohumeral joint.  Also, since the shoulder blade muscles are weak, it is important to rehab this part of the shoulder as well.  Perhaps some physical therapy is in order.  Any scoliosis or kyphosis in the spine?  Mechanically, this would affect the shoulder and clavicle more that cervical spondylosis.    Keep us posted.

author: kcnix  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Sep 15, 2008 1:05 pm Gender: Female
title: Ruptured Posterior Tibial Tendon
content: I am a 39 year old female and have had rheumatoid arthritis for 14 years. I have a ruptured posterior tibial tendon  as well as 3 or 4 spurs in dorsal margin (whatever that means) and have seen an orthopedist and he suggests surgery to replace tendon and remove spurs. Most of the pain in my foot is on the opposite (outside) of my foot and ankle and I guess that is from the spurs. I can barely walk by the time I get home from work and I have a desk job. What are the dangers from not having the surgery ASAP, as my insurance carries a high deductible and have to pay all that up front first and don't have right now? I have tried braces, but they do not offer much help with the pain and my foot is beginning to feel very stiff, and can not turn it inward.
posted_time: Post  by kcnix » Mon Sep 15, 2008 2:44 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Ruptured Posterior Tibial Tendon
content: Thanks for you patience. The posterior tibialis (post tib) muscle originates from the posterior (rear) portion of the lower leg deep to the gastrocsoleus (big thick calf muscles).  The muscle's tendon wraps around the ankle medially (inside portion of the ankle) and attaches to a couple midfoot bones (eg navicular and cuneiform).  I assume the bone spurs are located at the attachment of the post tib muscle.   The lateral ankle (outside ankle) pain is from compensation.  Your foot probably doesn't like weight on the inside aspect so more weight is born laterally. Plus, since the post tib helps with pushing off during gait, you are probably changing the way you walk causing unusual stress on the foot.   Surgery is certainly a good option especially if the tear is causing more problems with the foot and an inability to walk.   May want to try some crutches or a cane (in the hand opposite to the painful foot) to take some weight off the foot.    Does the other foot hurt or the small joints in the hands?  In other words, could some of the foot pain be from an exacerbation of RA.  Keep us posted.
