title: Severe hip pain that numbs leg/foot from limping!
content: If I posted in the wrong forum I apologize, its my first time here seeking help.  I'm 32,6ft 450 pounds,..sounds like a lot but my Nutritionist I was seeing said if i were 0% bodyfat I'd still weigh 250-260 based on muscle and structure.I have good blood pressure and "healthy" for someone of my size.  My problem is I dislocated my left knee in January of '07 slipping on ice, I lost my job of 13 years due to severe Depression after losing my Gramma who raised me since I was 8, so obviously have no insurance ( funny thing of having the same job of 13 years making almost 6 figures with great medical insurance the only thing I saw my Doc for was the occasional tonsilitus and check ups,now that I don't have insurance hell broke loose with one problem after the next,.. story of my life)  so with dealing with the LCL injury on my own ( dislocated my right knee a few years prior and figured I could get myself through this one alone) well from limping I'm getting a severe pain in my right hip area ( left knee is now the problem knee) the pain makes it hard to stand and walk,it starts to shoot out a "numbing" feeling that runs down my right leg on the outside and around to my shin area to my foot.it starts to feel like my foot gets heavy and feel I'm ready to collapse, it comes and goes when it gets really bad,to the point I cant stand for more than 5 minutes without having to hold on to something to prop me up and a sharp pain as I walk in my hip.its to the point I have severe Anxiety (sp?) and feel theres no hope for me to ever being back to a productive human being...and sometimes triggers off thoughts of losing hope and suicide.  I don't know what to do anymore, I just need some kind of idea of what it could be and what to do to make things better,I cant take the pain anymore,I'm currently on Disability,I barely make enough to get by, I lost everything I had due to depression ( I know this has nothing to do with my problem,but I just wanna be back on my feet again;literally)  I never went to rehab for my knee because the lack of insurance, I thought by taking day by day and feeling comfortable walking without a cane would help help my LCL get stronger but doesn't seem to help. I go for walks around the block and theres been times I would seriously think of calling a cab to get me home because I felt so unstable and in pain to make it back, but stayed strong and did it.  I used to work out 5-6 times a week, lost 70 pounds in 6 months trying to turn my life around using the gym as my "drug" and not Depression medication,it worked til all of this happened, I went from walking miles a day to barely being able to walk from one end of a grocery store to the other without being in extreme pain trying to hold myself up...its taking over my life,.. I just need some kind info on what it could be ( I assume something to do with a nerve) I miss the joys of walking and working out,..in High School I was into hard weight training and power lifting and when starting it again in '06 I really felt great about my life and now feel hopeless with feeling I have limited mobility.  I wanted to throw that out there that I was on the road to getting back in shape and losing weight because I know the weight thing will be an issue off the bat,.."blah blah blah,.. you should start by losing weight" and when I hear that I go insane inside because if people only knew how hard I fought to lose the weight I did when I was getting back into it, I was at 440 pounds when I started seeing a Nutritionist and working out, and got down to 370 in 6 months and my target weight was 300.  I apologize for rambling so much, but I have a habit of of soing that to explain myself and I thank anyone who can guide me in the right direction as to what the problem sounds like and treatment. I wanna be me again,..I'm 32 feeling like I'm going on 82.  thank you for your time!

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Severe hip pain that numbs leg/foot from limping!
content: Sorry about the delay response Hang in there and don't give up. This condition is understandable and perhaps fixable. Experiencing right thigh or hip pain that travels down and around to the shin sounds like it is referred from either the hip or the lumbar spine.   What's probably happened is that you have been shifting more weight to the right lower extremity (and thus through the hip and lumbar area) to ease the pressure from the injured left knee. I would recommend getting into a pool to work on some leg range of motion, pool walking, and general conditioning.  The water provides buoyancy and will ease the pressure on your spine and lower limbs.   Keep us posted.

title: Peroneal brevis tear

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Peroneal brevis tear
content: Hope all is going well with the ankle.  Sorry about the delayed response.  Lots of changes including prospects of pain and inflamation in areas surrounding an injuried joint.  Therefore, not only is treating and protecting the involved joint important but also the joints above and below it.   Could the intensity of the physical therapy be too great?   Also, does the ortho doctor have you on crutches or partial weight bearing.   Certainly "difficulty with the boot" may have contributed to the symptoms. For certain, follow up with physician is indicated for re evaluation.  Keep us posted.

author: RS2  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Sep 02, 2008 12:31 pm Gender: Male
title: Electric Shock to lower leg...
content: I wasn't sure what board this was best suited for. This past Saturday morning I was shocked by an extension chord that touched the trailer frame or the boat I was climbing into in my driveway. My immediate reaction was that somebody had struck my right calf with a heavy object like a baseball bat. I'm not sure how or why it concentrated in my calf but this was where the immediate shock took place. I had a lot of trouble walking for the rest of the day. My calf was clearly swollen but did not show any external signs of trauma. By Sunday evening I was able to actually flex my leg and walk with a severe limp. Monday I trudged along at a normal pace and my leg seemed to be doing better. What was notable last night is that I have edema....if you were to push into my skin of the front of my shin the indentation would stay for several seconds. This morning the swelling was going down but it is still sore and starting to "tighten up again" as I've been using my leg relatively normally.   I did not go the emergency room nor did I call the doctor for this accident. I checked online and everything I read suggestiong medical attention when there are burns or potential cardiac issues or if it was a high voltage shock. At this point I feel "ok" but I'm a bit paranoid. My wife and mother are begging me to go the doctor. I have been taking 800 mgs of Ibuprofen twice a day and I would assume this has helped with the inflamation. I do not have a regular doctor. Now my wife and mother are suggesting that I could have a blood clot and that I need to go.   Based on what I've stated....would it be prudent to seek medical attention? I feel pretty good and I hate going to the doctor.
posted_time: Post  by RS2 » Tue Sep 02, 2008 12:46 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Electric Shock to lower leg...
content: Sorry about the delayed response. I hope all is well with you.  Indeed, all the advice (including wife and mother) to seek medical help after an electrical shock is correct.  There was probably un-seen deep tissue injury which was causing the swelling.  DVT (deep vein thrombosis...aka blood clot) usually results from prolonged inactivity, circulatory deficiencies or predispostion to blood clotting (like cancer or inherited disorder) but could occur following trauma. Obviously, problems with the heart can arise with electrical shock. So indeed seek medical care.  p.s. How did things turn out with your leg.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Wed Dec 24, 2008 11:35 am

author: Pictureman  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Aug 30, 2008 4:33 pm Gender: Male
title: Many joints have suddenly started clicking
content: I’m a 41-year-old male and about four months ago some of my joints started to click frequently and audibly. Although it was not too painful, it was uncomfortable. After a few weeks my right elbow became quite sore and I suspected tennis elbow. However I had not been placing any particular stress on that joint.   My job takes me abroad and this summer I spent several weeks in Asia.  Whilst there my left elbow became equally sore and so did my right knee joint.  I also noticed that many other joints in my body started clicking, e.g. my neck, wrists, forearm, ankles and shoulders.  On my return from Asia I visited my doctor.  I explained the problem and history and consequently he carried out a blood test.  I’m not exactly sure what the test was meant to identify, but apparently it came back negative.    My doctor feels that the clicking is just a symptom of old age and inactivity.  Perhaps he is right however the frequency of the clicking has amazed me and perhaps I did not explain this too clearly to him.  Currently I would estimate that the total number of clicks (across all joints) that I 'notice' is between 150 to 200 times a day. Also I can make some of the joints click continuously by repeating the same movement.  Six months ago there was only an occasional click from my knees if I bent down and that was pretty much it.    To provide a little more relevant background my employment circumstances changed about 18 months ago.  Previously I was in a job where I would walk between 2 to 3 miles per day and be constantly in and out of chairs.  My current employment involves sitting at a desk about 90% of the time.  I weigh 103 kg and do not exercise that regularly, I realise I am overweight and do want to address this.  Apart from the clicking and 3 sore joints I feel as normal as I ever did.   Some days the clicking and the sore joints seem slightly worse than others.  Overall it does appear to be getting progressively worse as the weeks roll on.  My doctor instructed me to go back to him if it all became too painful and he would give me some pain relief.  However I find it hard to accept that this is the only option and I still wonder if there is something he has missed.  Thank you in advance of your time and advice on this matter.  Nigel.
posted_time: Post  by Pictureman » Sun Aug 31, 2008 6:33 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Many joints have suddenly started clicking
content: Thanks for your patience.  A few other questions: Are there any skin rashes or sores on the skin? Are there any painful, warm, or swollen joints? Any weakness in the muscles? Any pain in the muscles? Any diarrhea? Any fatigue? Any fever?  Most of these questions are aimed at the possibility of an infectious cause.   Otherwise this may simply be resultant from weight gain, inactivity, or mild osteoarthritis.   Keep us posted.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Foot swelling and pain
content: My apology for the delay in response.  With unexplained weight gain and swelling, it would be prudent to have the thyroid checked (physical exam and lab work).  Also consider arthritis in the lower extremities or poor circulation (poor venous return).  Other causes of foot swelling include heart failure, cellulitis.  It would be good to follow up with family physician to do a thorough history and physical. The foot pain can be from the swelling itself or from underlying arthritis.   Again, see a doctor for a complete examination.  Your ob/gyn may shed some light on any correlation between the hysterectomy and leg swelling.  Any history of pelvic congestion syndrome?    Keep us posted.

author: Attacus  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Nov 06, 2008 4:01 pm Gender: Male
title: 1-2 ribs "jammed" into sternum?
content: I have quite a noticeable bump at the top of my sternum, and it seems like 1 or 2 of my ribs are overlapped on top of the sternum and sort of "jammed" in place. I am a waterpolo player, and when doing any form of throwing motion, it puts incredible strain on the area, to the point where I have to stop playing. I have done physio and osteopathy (my osteopath confirms there is tightness of the ribs). An orthopedic surgeon and a radiologist said my x-rays seemed normal. I think the problem originates from doing dips at the gym. Any form of dipping motion or lateral pulldown exercise will leave me with tenderness and pain in the sternum for a day or two. Oddly enough, pressing and flyes do not seem to aggravate it.  The left side of my sternum seems to be worse off than the right, and when I press on it, I can feel tension in my back, along the same rib.   Trying to play "around" this injury has lead me to a shoulder injury that has put me off season for at least 2 months, I am looking to try and fix this sternum problem before I get back.  What gives? Do I just keep going to the osteo and hope it gets better? Because that's my plan right now. I'd give anything to be able to do dips again in the gym.  Thanks
posted_time: Post  by Attacus » Thu Nov 06, 2008 4:14 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: 1-2 ribs "jammed" into sternum?
content: Thanks for your patience.  The difference between flys/presses and lat pulldown or dips is the plane of motion.  The former is in the horizontal plane whereas the latter is more in the vertical plane.  Since the ribs during respiration move in a "bucket handle" fashion, it seems the vertical plane exercise would be more aggravating to a rib problem.   Since there are no fractures or dislocation, continuing with osteopathy or physical therapy would be fine.  There are physical therapists who specialize in rib mobilization and treatment - it requires special training and practice to fix rib problems.    As you can tell, I do agree that thoracic cage is the culprit to your pain and dysfunction. Let us know how things turn out.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: What is this severe pain in both heels when walking?
content: Hello, I would recommend arch supporting shoe inserts you can buy over-the-counter such as Dr. Scholl's.  These have been shown in many cases to be just as effective as specially made shoe inserts costing hundreds of dollars.  There are some specially made ones now being sold for under $100.  The inserts take a while to get used to but eventually they can help.  You may also benefit from changing shoes to be sure you have one that will accommodate the insert.    If you are able to tolerate anti-inflammatory medication such as ibuprofen you may find this to be helpful over time as well.    Best wishes

title: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
content: Hello,  At around 12 years of age I had a slipped capital femoral epiphysis in my right hip which was fixed with was fixed with some pins. Now at the age of 43 I am experiencing the same type of pain in my left hip, along with an out-turned left leg when walking. Is this unusual? From what I've read this is a juvenile condition.  Thanks in advance, Rob
posted_time: Post  by rbmcal » Thu Nov 06, 2008 10:53 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
content: Thanks for your patience. With slipped capital femoral epiphysis, the leg tends to turn outward and away from the body - similar to its tendency now.   Since the initial problem with the grow plate was fixed, the external rotation may be caused from shortened external rotator muscles and/or weak internal rotators.  The position of the leg may have been slowly changing over time and suddenly noticed it - don't know for sure.   An xray and a physical exam of the hip would be helpful and if no instability or dislocation then a few weeks in rehab should help.   Also have your doctor measure the leg lengths - a discrepancy can cause abnormal rotation in either leg.   Keep us updated.

author: 022827  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Thu Aug 28, 2008 1:51 pm Gender: Female
title: Unexplained Leg Weakness
content: In December 2007 I began experiencing left hip, groin and knee pain and leg weakness. Until then, I was an avid exerciser - running, weights etc. No specific injury, and a gradual onset- first with thigh weakness when running. After a month or so, I started to experience severe knee pain for a day or so after a run. Within the next month, the pain spread to my hip and groin, and was so severe that I could not bend my knee after being still for any length of time, sitting was painful, and I walked with a limp and dragged my foot. I went to an Orthopaedic doc for treatment - MRIs of knee, hip and spine negative, as was an EMG/NCS. I stopped all forms of exercise in early March, and the pain subsided in about a month but I was left with residual weakness, a limp, and the pain would return if I tried the least bit of weight bearing activity (walking, etc.).  In June the Ortho referred me to a Physical Medicine doctor for rehabilitation. After 8 weeks of PT and a gradual return to mild exercise, the limp is gone and I can tolerate moderate walking. However I still have weakness in my leg, stairs and hills are difficult, balance is a bit off and I have trouble finding a comfortable sleeping position (lower back pain). I've resigned myself to "this is how it is" and will continue with strengthening exercises on my own (stopped PT with concurrence of doctor). The Physical Med doctor working with me is excellent and he is stumped and can't find a cause - although we both agreed to stop looking at this point, further work-up seems pointless for the time being. I seem to be at a plateau and I would love to get back to my prior physical shape, but I don’t want to waste any more time or medical resources. Out of curiosity, - has anyone ever seen anything like this?
posted_time: Post  by 022827 » Thu Aug 28, 2008 2:00 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Unexplained Leg Weakness
content: Hello -  What you're describing, while somewhat outside the scope of my expertise, sounds like a syndrome I've come across once or twice, which involves the lateral  myofacia of the thigh, and apparently often mimics both lower back spasm and sciatica, but is felt more on the lateral aspect of the leg. It can be quite painful and sometimes disabling, resembling compartment syndrome. It seems to respond well to intramuscular injection of a steroid combined with another anti-inflammatory drug, the name of which escapes me at the moment. At any rate, the "cocktail" is injected into the lateral aspect of the upper thigh and is  often produces relief within minutes -- assuming this is the problem.   The  syndrome I refer to can seem to start in the lower back, radiate  and eventually travel to the groin, and eventually affects the left left lateral thigh between the hip and knee.   I wish I knew the proper name of the syndrome, the anatomy and the drugs used to treat it, but they escape me. It is,  apparently, an often-overlooked condition that can be fairly easily treated if the orthopedist is familiar with it.   I hope that perhaps this will give you at least something to work with. Best of luck to you and please follow up with us and let us know if anything changes.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: knee pain when bending
content: Hi again -  You're very welcome.   While arthritis can develop in only one joint it's more likely to be bilateral. It would seem most likely this is either due to an injury that went unnoticed at the time or has been caused by an intrinsic weakness in some part of the structure of the knee. The popping sound suggests you may have an inflamed bursa, so this may be simple bursitis. In any case it will need to be evaluated by an orthopedist to determine the true problem, and that will guide the treatment for it. While bursitis often resolves on its own, if it hasn't by now it's probably not going to (assuming that is the problem), so it would probably be wise to have an imaging study done of the knee (either CT scan or, preferably, MRI). However, sometimes a good orthopedist can tell just by feeling and moving the joint.   Non-steroidal anti-inflamatory meds like ibuprofin or naproxyn may help in the meantime, but if this continues you really should have it evaluated, because there is always the danger of making it worse. With three small children to handle you need your agility and range of motion to be at the top of its form.  Best of luck to you. Thanks for your followup, and please keep us updated.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Pins and needles / numbness in thumb and index finger
content: Hi there -  You've somehow got your median nerve compressed or entrapped. It may well be due to the sleeping posture you've described, or it could as easily be due to repetitive motion  injury or could, at any rate, lie somewhere other than the shoulder. It's important to have this problem medically evaluated first, to be certain there's no mechanical cause that might require physical therapy or surgical release. A neurologist would probably be best to evaluate this, probably by performing a nerve conduction study to locate the actual location of the compression or entrapment. Once the location is known the nerve can often be released by manual manipulation or physical therapy, or sometimes even by home exercises and therapies, but while massage is sometimes helpful once the locus is established, the usual rest and icing are unlikely to help since this is primarily a problem of putting something back into its correct  position (either the nerve itself or the body part pressing upon it). There is a significant risk of loss of function if the problem isn't isolated and addressed medically early on, so I'd strongly suggest seeing a neurologist (or perhaps an orthopedist or even sports medicine specialist) sooner  than later.   I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you. Please keep us updated.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Mon Dec 08, 2008 9:24 pm

author: sunnyd  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Nov 06, 2008 9:44 pm Gender: Female
title: facial deformity - underdevelopment of one side
content: Hi Doctor,  I'm a female in my late 20s and at the age of about 13 I developed an asymmetry in my face (and body) that had not been present previously. It looks almost as though the right side of my face stopped developing prematurely, while the left side continued onward.  My left side looks more mature and is characterized by stronger cheekbones, higher eyebrow arch and more defined, forward placed jaw (amongst other things) than the right side. The right side seems to be smaller in three planes (height, width and depth/density). As a result, my face looks almost deformed on the right side - it looks like I lack a cheekbone (or it is very low and flat and the orbital doesn't frame my eye the way it does on the other side), and my nose twists toward in the more developed side. It is highly noticeable, particularly when I speak, as my jaw pulls toward the underdeveloped side.  Is there something that can be done to correct this? What could have caused this to develop suddenly during my growth spurt (no one else in my family shows similar abnormalities)? Is this something that I should be concerned about?  I would not ordinary concern myself with some asymmetry, as most people experience some, but this seems to be pervasive throughout my body and significant enough to make me self-conscious about the aesthetic differences. I'm also worried that there may be some kind of underlying condition that may cause further problems down the road.
posted_time: Post  by sunnyd » Thu Nov 06, 2008 10:01 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: facial deformity - underdevelopment of one side
content: Hello -  What you've described sounds like hemihypertrophy (sometimes classified as semi hemihypertrophy), which may actually be a misnomer, but describes the condition well enough. It is a relatively rare birth defect which doesn't usually become apparent until adolescence. It's caused by a mutation, so that it usually won't show up in the family history anywhere, and it appears to rarely,  if ever, have any significant effect on the general health of the subject, but can be, for some, a significant source of self consciousness. I'm  unaware of any specific long-term problems, although I can conceive of some that could happen in some specific instances. I'm also not aware of any specific corrective measures, although I would think there should be some, again, in certain cases.   While I have known of one person who actually has this problem, I  learned very little from her, as the condition was poorly understood. I can tell you, however, that had the condition not been pointed out to me specifically I might never have noticed it. These things are almost always more evident to the subject than to others, although some people are  bound to notice some discrepancy.   I've already done an internet search for more information (again, years after having met the one person I knew who had this "problem") and still can't seem to find anything pertinent. Perhaps discussing this with a specialist in genetic disorders could help shed some light on it. I may also try and locate the subject I'd been acquainted with previously (it's been a long time, but I'm  sure she'd be happy to share any new information -- if I can find her after all this time). Other than that, I've pretty much exhausted my very small knowlege base on this rare variant. I hope this is at least somewhat helpful.   Please stay in touch, follow up with us here as needed, and please update us if you learn anything more about this. In the meantime I'll try and locate the person I'd met a good while ago and if I can, I'll bring back  any additional information she may have accrued in the interim. Best of luck to you.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Fri Dec 05, 2008 10:45 pm

title: Giant swollen ball on elbow
content: Hello,   3 weeks ago, my husband had this giant ball on his elbow that was swollen and red. He said it hurt to touch it and when he did it felt as though it was filled with fluid. After a week it went away, but it has come back again only larger and more painful.  He doesn't have health care as he is immigrating to canada from the USA and until his papers are processed in full he has to pay for any medical care. What could be wrong with him? Should he seek treatment immediately or will it go away again?
posted_time: Post  by Omegastring » Sat Nov 15, 2008 8:37 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Giant swollen ball on elbow
content: If this "ball" is directly over the posterior aspect of the elbow, he probably has olecranon bursitis.    Causes (my list of causes from most to least likely):  1. inflammation from trauma (blunt or repetitive - like rubbing the elbow constantly on the table) 2. infection (particularly if the elbow is red and warm along with the swelling) 3. inflammation from rheumatoid arthritis or gout  What to do: If any reduced range of motion, may suspect fracture especially with trauma.  Xray it.   Besides the swelling, any additional sign of redness, warmth, tenderness, or fever; the fluid should be aspirated by a physician to check for infection.  Plain uninfected olecranon bursitis may respond to RICE (rest, ice, compression, elevation).  Beyond this, having a physician aspirate the fluid and injecting with corticosteroid may bring complete resolution.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Left Shoulder Blade Pain
content: I would look at the mid back muscles (rhomboids and middle traps) for weakness.   I would also look for winging of the scapula.  The serratus anterior muscle stabilizes the scapula and prevents it from winging (tested with a push up against floor or wall). author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee Pain
content: Specific location of knee pain, aggravating manuevers, swelling, giving way sensation, hx of trauma or injury, a person's sex, weight, previous surgeries, length of symptoms, duration of symptoms, any treatments attempted are all important bits of information in diagnosing knee pain.    Even when we know what is structurally wrong, especially patellafemoral problems, we may struggle to remedy the ailment.  Regarding anterior knee pain under or around the knee cap,  certainly this could be caused by a mal aligned or poorly tracking kneecap.  The best remedy for this is proper stretching and strengthening - usually strengthening the inner quadricep and stretching the IT band (lateral leg muscle).  Women tend to have this problem more because their hips are wider and the femur(thigh bone) angles inward creating more valgus of the knee (inward angulation of the knee).  Sometimes the knee cap can suffer from inflammation...or the bursa (slippery fluid filled sac that help tendons glide smoothly) are inflamed or the tendons or ligaments around the knee cap are inflamed.  All of these structures cause pain.  Certain movements cause pain: going down stairs, going up stairs, standing from a chair, sitting down from standing, reaching forward for an object on the floor (this manuever can be worse of all because a lot of stress is placed on the patella femoral joint).    Other problems of the knee can cause pain with the above mentioned movements - namely bone bruises of the tibia, femur or patella; meniscus tears; internal ligament tears; arthritis of the knee; tendontitis; or fracture.    It is important to treat symptoms.  Avoid aggravating motions.  Maintain the range of motion and strength of the leg (consult a physical therapist for this).  Use NSAIDS per physician.  Use ice/heat.  Remember Ace wraps for support (never met an ACE I didn't like...unless it's applied wrong)  For patella femoral problems, I like to strengthen the inner thigh muscles including the medial quad and the hip adductor muscles (which provide some support for the medial quad).  Do mini squats less than 60 degrees of knee flexion.  Avoid bicycle and leg extension machine.  Straight leg raises may help too.  Lots of quad, hamstring, IT band, and hip flexor stretching.    Again, your family physician can write for physical therapy and recommend NSAIDS (as indicated) and make any other necessary tests (MRI etc)

author: babycanoe  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sun Sep 14, 2008 10:02 am Gender: Female
title: Un-even Rib Cage
content: My rib cage pops out higher on my left side.  It's gotten to where I can't even sleep on my left side, because it becomes painful after a while. Is this something I should be concerned about? and if so, What type of doctor should I see for this?
posted_time: Post  by babycanoe » Sun Sep 14, 2008 10:19 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Un-even Rib Cage
content: Hi there -  While it's possible you could have some sort of disease process going on that's causing this, it is really unlikely, and it is very common (even normal) for the left side of the ribcage to be somewhat more pronounced and, in some people, more noticeable than in others. The pain or soreness upon lying on it can  usually be attributed to the fact that the cartilage between the ribs and where they attach to the breastbone can be irritated and become inflamed, sometimes quite easily. When  this happens, pressure on the ribs on the affected side can cause significant discomfort,  but it's not anything serious and, in fact, usually will respond to over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatories like ibuprofin (Advil) or naproxyn (Aleve). If the problem continues despite home treatment with OTC pain meds, or if it becomes more severe, a doctor should probably be consulted, as it could be arthritic in nature,  although again, this is unlikely and fairly rare, especially in young,otherwise healthy people.  In short, the "uneven" ribcage is pretty common and usually normal, and the pain upon lying on one's side, especially the left, is not at all uncommon.   I hope this eases your mind and is helpful as well. Best of luck to you.

title: recovery from mini lumbar discectomy
content: I had mini lumbar discectomy March of this year due to floppy foot said to be caused by nerve being pinched. I am still experiencing some numbness and floppiness in foot after walking for several miles. Surgeon said could be up to a year for full recovery, if it happens.   Also have some swelling of the ankle and foot of affected leg.  Is this usual? And can I do anything to increase chance of full recovery? Thanks
posted_time: Post  by floppy foot » Fri Nov 07, 2008 8:25 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: recovery from mini lumbar discectomy
content: Foot flopping aka foot drop is caused by weakness of the anterior tibialis muscle which is runs just lateral (to the outside) of the shin bone below the knee. In your case, the weakness was apparently caused by a pinched nerve in the back.  Makes sense.  Practice feeling the anterior tibialis with your fingertips while working your ankle forward and backward (like pressing and depressing the car's gas pedal).  As the foot and ankle moves toward you (dorsiflexion) this muscle contracts.  Moving the ankle forward and backward with the leg elevated helps with the swelling.   Another simple exercise is walking on your heels or if this is not possible, stand at the side of bed and do toe tapping to a favorite song or beat - try to lift the toes fully off the ground.    Of course if the swelling and weakness are worsening follow up with the neurosurgeon who will probably do a repeat MRI of the spine.   All the best.

title: Knee/Quadricep pain
content: While on a training run this morning I had a sharp pain on the inside of my right knee at the end of my quadricep muscle. This hot me at mile 6 and I took it as a cramp. posted_time: Post  by Tracy37923 » Sun Nov 02, 2008 2:52 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Knee/Quadricep pain
content: First, congratulations on running sixteen miles.  I gather from this information that you are an avid runner and log many miles each week. Has there been an increase in mileage more than 10% per week?  Intensity increases above this increase risk of injury. Second, it sounds like the extensor mechanism in the knee has been injured.  The extensor mechanism includes the quadriceps muscle, the quad tendon, patella, the patella ligament, and their respective bursa and the patellafemoral joint structures.   To me, it sounds like the quad tendon or the patellafemoral joint is inflamed.  Not surprising for a runner.  Up and down stairs stresses these structures so if they're inflamed....ouch.  Usually going down stairs is worse than up stairs. The treatment is ice, NSAIDS, rest, and avoidance of aggravating manuevers (this last point must be emphasized).  This is not an injury that you can "run through".  After 1-2 weeks, start gradual return to painfree activities; include painfree strengthening (e.g. straight leg raises, mini squats - 30 degrees knee flexion and progress to 60 degrees, and lateral step ups/downs); and plenty of stretching hamstrings, quadriceps and hip flexors.  Don't forget medial and lateral thigh muscle stretching and strengthening.   Some sessions with an orthopedic Physical Therapist will be helpful.  Pearl: many patellafemoral and extensor tendonitis problems worsen with cycling so use caution with stationary bike.  Remember, this recovery takes patience.   All the best.

posted_time: Post  by shamrock147 » Tue Nov 04, 2008 4:06 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Pregnancy and Arthritis
content: Hello, Because medication is not tested in pregnant women in the usual way, our information is limited to what we learn after many women have used particular drugs while pregnant.  Then the teratology services evaluate whether or not there is any increased incident of birth defects associated with women who have used the drugs.  In this way we get a pretty good idea of what is safe.  NSAIDs can affect the blood clotting so doctors are reluctant to prescribe these in pregnancy.   However, risks and benefits are evaluated in forming the right treatment plan.  There are medications that are considered safe in pregnancy but each doctor must give the go-ahead based on the patient history and the doctor's knowledge of her case.  You should have your wife discuss the situation with the doctor taking care of her.  The Tylenol is considered safe in the meantime but better treatment options are probably available to her as well.  Good luck.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: repairing a torn rotator cuff
content: The rotator cuff is a set of four shoulder muscles which attach to the upper part of the humerus (upper arm bone).  A torn rotator cuff means a tear in the tendon or tendons of those four muscles close to where they attach to the bone.  With a complete tear, the tendon is re attached to the bone with sutures (stitches) and allowed to heal.  Bone removal or shaving is frequently done at the acromion (the outer and upper part of the shoulder blade).  When this bone is shaved (acromioplasty), it allows more room for the rotator cuff tendon to glide during motion of the shoulder.  In fact, after doing the acromioplasty the surgeon should feel between the acromion and the upper end of the humerus for adequate spacing.  Acromioplasty is standard procedure for rotator cuff tears.  Post operatively, caution must be used to protect the repair.  Gradual return to full motion begins before strengthening.  Strengthening is the last step of rehabilitation.  Depending on your occupation and the success of the repair, return to normal duties should be expected.

posted_time: Post  by swimmy » Tue Sep 23, 2008 12:59 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Subchondral bone cyst
content: Hello Kim -  A subchondral cyst is a cyst that forms after traumatic twisting of the lower body (or sometimes also due to degenerative collagen disease), and is found on the  pubic symphysis. It is extremely common among football players because of the specific contortions  involved in that game, and can cause sometimes exquisite pain. It  may be treated by steroids (oral of injected) and sometimes corrected surgically.   I hope this answers your question. Best of luck to you and please follow up with us as needed.

author: Meshach  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Sat Sep 13, 2008 11:42 am Gender: Male
title: How come my ankles pop/crack?
content: How come my ankles always pop or crack when I walk and is there a cure for it?  Thanks, Meshach
posted_time: Post  by Meshach » Mon Sep 22, 2008 11:11 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: How come my ankles pop/crack?
content: Hi Meshach -   Some people, for reasons that aren't entirely clear, have this happen because of the placement of the little fluid filled sacs (bursae) that are present in most all our joints. The mechanics of how it happens are complex to explain, but is a lot like popping the bubbles in bubble wrap, except that the fluid in the bursae is reabsorbed back into the sacs in our bodies (generally -- unless there is bursitis, an inflammation of the sac). Many people have this happen in various joints. There's not much  that can be done to prevent it, and sometimes it is actually due to something else, some anatomical oddity, but in any case it's rarely any cause for concern. If pain should develop over time, then a doctor should be consulted. Otherwise, it should be ignored.   I hope  this is helpful.

A week after, most of the pain subsided, but my hip (feels like right inside the joint) still burned. I've done no stenuous excersizes since...none what so ever infact. And it still hurts like crazy.  Also, of note, when i squat down and stand up i still have the pop...but its not the actual joint...it feels like somethings grinding against the bone and i can even feel the band of muscle (or whatever it is slip) which i don't feel even remotely on the right side.  i've got a little over a week until i leave for boot camp and i have to admit i'm a bit paniced.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: strained hip exercising. 3 weeks and it still hurts.
content: Hi there -  It's difficult, of course, to guess with great accuracy without being able to do a hands-on exam (which means you should see a sports medicine doctor soon as possible), but it sounds as though you may have torn a muscle or ligament high in the quad area, which may now be pressing upon a nerve, causing the burning sensation. The fascia may be injured, affecting the nerve serving the thigh.   Usually these injuries are amenable to physical therapy and sometimes one or more steroid injections can bring rapid pain relief and aid in healing as well, so long as the muscle isn't overworked prematurely. It sounds as though you've done everything right so far, including resting the leg, but it's now time to get a professional  working on this,  especially if you're to report for duty on time.  I hope this is helpful. I wish I could give you a more specfic answer, but this area of the hip and leg is complex and requires a specialist. Good luck with this. Please let us know how things work out.

title: Burning knee pain
content: Why does my left knee burn on the left side when I kneel on it?  Have not had any surgeries or injuries.  I do have arthritis.
posted_time: Post  by D. Witham » Thu Oct 30, 2008 1:26 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Burning knee pain
content: Hi there -  Burning pain, especially when it seems to be close to the surface, is usually caused by an inflamed or irritated nerve. Arthritis can of course also cause pain both within the knee joint and by acretion of cacium and/or debris caused by inflammation and also by this junk pressing on sensitive structures which by nature involve nerves. It's not an unusual symptom with arthritic knee changes nor with pressure on a nerve almost anywhere between the base of the spine and on down to the foot.   If the pain should become constant there are medications to help block it if it is, in fact, nerve pain. If it's simple mechanical arthritic pain, there are cheaper, simple anti-inflammatory meds for this.   Hope this  is helpful. Best of luck to you.

title: Re: swollen ankles! Please guide

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: Re: swollen ankles! Please guide
content: Hello, I agree with Shelly.  As Shelly said, edema occurs primarily when the body retain and accumulate water, a condition caused by either a systemic illness (involving organs like the heart, kidney and the liver) or a local problem affecting the extremities.  Individuals present with peripheral edema (e.g. ankle swelling) should be checked for their liver, kidney and cardiac functions to exclude serious systemic causes.  The most common local problems causing edema are venous insufficiency causes by varicose veins or inflammation of the veins (thrombophlebitis). In these conditions the pump system that forces the fluids to move away from the extremities fails to do so, resulting in accumulation of fluids and edema. As you can imagine, veins in the legs and feet are more commonly affected.  Females and those who stand for long time are at high risk for varicose veins.  Some medications especially hormone containing (e.g. steroid, oral contraceptives) are known to cause fluid retention.  A thorough history and direct clinical examination is essential to reach the possible diagnosis and guide for subsequent investigations.  I would advise you also to follow up with her doctor who may recommend liver, kidney function tests and an EKG. Radiological investigations like Echocardiography and Doppler US on the lower limb are requested as needed.  Please keep us updated. Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Fri Oct 31, 2008 7:43 am

author: jademarie23  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Mar 02, 2008 11:39 pm Gender: Female
title: Clicking Lump Under Rib on right side
content: I am a 23 year old girl. For the past 6 months or so I have noticed a clicking lump just under my rib on the right side about 5 cm out from my sternum and a bit lower. It is not near my floating ribs and is not as hard as my ribs. I can push on it along a length of about 2cm and it will slip under my rib and pop straight back up again like a spring, other times I can't find it at all. I can rarely feel it when lying flat on my back but if I bend forward or change positions it clicks over my rib again. It doesn't hurt to press on it and I don't have any rib pain or pain when I breathe. Occasionally I have noticed that if I am sitting in a position where I'm leaning to the right for a while, that when I move again it hurts. And I occasionally get upper abdomen pain, but I have assumed that is from the gallstones that I know that I have. The only thing my doctor can suggest is that it is a glob of fat or a piece of loose cartilage, but I work with physiotherapists and they've looked at it and don't think it's cartilage. I'm worried about it but don't know whether I should be. I just want to know what it might be and whether I can do anything to get rid of the annoying clicking feeling. Jade  Australia
posted_time: Post  by jademarie23 » Sun Mar 02, 2008 11:55 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: Re: Clicking Lump Under Rib on right side
content: Hello,  A swelling can be easier diagnosed if any associated symptoms exist. Your description is very suggestive of an extramuscular, subcutaneous mass mostly lipoma.    Lipoma is a benign tumor of the fat tissue. It usually affects the trunk and the thigh.   Lipomas is usually a soft swelling, painless and freely mobile (sliding). Lipomas are painful when they get infected or when they are big enough to cause compression on underneath neurovascular structures.  The condition does not usually need intervention unless reaches a large size or in a critical site causing mechanical compression.  Follow up with your doctor is essential especially if it enlarges or causes significant discomfort.  Please keep us updated. Best regards.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Trampolining injury
content: Hello -  It sounds as though you've pulled the tendons on the top of your foot, which can be really painful. You would probably do better with a crutch or crutches, especially if your ankle is already weakened by a previous injury. Go back and let the facility where you were treated and request a pair of crutches (and make sure they fit you for them before you leave). This will allow the foot to rest, take pressure off the ankle,  and will allow things to heal a whole lot faster, while avoiding favoring the foot, which can cause other problems from walking funny (which is the only thing you can do right now, without those crutches).  Hope this is helpful. Best of luck  to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Trampolining injury
content: Hi again -  This certainly has taken some odd twists (no pun intended). If you do have a stress fracture, those are generally more painful that anything else, and can be managed a number of different ways, essentially based on the location and what works best for the patient. These measures can range from a walking or soft cast to something as inobtrusive as an orthotic to be placed inside your shoe (or shoes, if balancing the effect is necessary). Generally it is more of a nuisance than anything else, but whatever device is used tends to make walking more easy or at least less painful, with the added benefit of helping the fracture to heal.   It's a pretty common finding, especially in sports medicine, so don't be too surprised if this turns up positive. It could be a lot less complicated than some other things. Good luck to you. Please let us know how things work out.

author: Navy Girl  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Thu Sep 18, 2008 5:33 pm Gender: Female
title: Recurrent Shoulder Subluxations, Instability, Spurs
content: I am a 33 year old female, no other health issues, no medications (except for Mirena IUS).  I have had recurrent trouble with my right shoulder for about 10 years now. The initial injury was a subluxation, the shoulder stayed out for approximately 1-2 minutes and then popped back in on its own as soon as I tried to move.  I was in physio for a couple months and eventually gained full mobility and was pain free.   Over the last 10 years I have noticed however, that the shoulder pops and cracks on almost every movement especially overhead, and sometimes feel likes it catches on the way up.  These sensations were not really associated with pain but if it happened too much would cause a vague aching that would radiate down my arm.  Last year, I was firefighting climbing down a ladder and got caught up, and my arm got pulled on.  I subluxated it again.  This time, I was sent to physiotherapy for a consult, and given exercises to do at home, but could not attend regular appointments because I was being deployed and they felt it was not serious enough to keep me at home. After a few weeks I was pretty much pain free and had full movement but my shoulder never felt quite right after that.. like it felt kind of out of alignment if that makes sense. I also had regular bouts of vague aching pain right down the outside of my arm, sometimes to my pinky finger.  These bouts of aching would happen with no apparent trigger that I could pin point.    A couple months ago, I once again injured the same shoulder.  It came out and went back in very quickly (within seconds).  This time they did x-rays.  They found a "small spur on the anterior lip of the glenoid"  and I was told this was more likely a result of a past injury and not from the most recent one (or the cause of it).  I am also back in physiotherapy and the physiotherapist mentioned 'instability'  I am awaiting a consult with an orthopedic surgeon, but in the mean time would like to know what will most likely happen from here and what is most likely going on with this shoulder?

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Ankle Sprain Recovery
content: Hi there -  Swelling from a significant sprain can last up to a week. It should start to diminish by now, but may take another day or so, depending upon how much time the leg is vertical vs. horizontal and elevated. Icing probably isn't wise beyond the first few days, but ibuprofin for pain, and elevating to reduce the swelling are still appropriate. If things aren't better within a week, follow up with your doctor, but some sprains can cause residual soreness and muscle weakness for some time afterward.   I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Tenosynovitis in left ankle
content: Hello -  Tenosynovitis is usually more or less a chronic problem (although it can go away entirely for long periods and sometimes forever), and some people are prone to it. It tends to run in families,  as does the tendency to form excess scar tissue, which in your case seems to have aggravated the problem.   Has your doctor attempted to drain the synovial space and treat the problem with anti-inflammatories? This could possibly be a workable alternative to repeated surgeries, which would likely only cause additional scarring and continue the cycle of irritation and new problems.   I wish I could give you something more to work with, but this can be an ongoing and pretty uncomfortable problem, but anti-inflammatory drugs can often help get you a little bit ahead of the problem.  Best of luck to you. Please keep us updated.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Tenosynovitis in left ankle
content: Hello Jenna -  I'm sorry to hear you're now having this problem. It is possible (I'm somewhat out of my depth wth this) that the recurrence of tenosynovitis is either a) the result of unconscious favoring of the foot due to previous injuries and surgery or b) that you have some sort of autoimmune problem that's been aggravated by all the injury and intrusion into the area. Then again, I've just recently learned, some of this is considered a "variant of normal" for some patients. I'm not sure how that could be, but it's what I've been able to pick up in my researching this.  Plantar fasciitis will cause sometimes excruciating pain, but is treatable. It's probably also related to slightly abnormal adjustments to your gait because of the earlier injuries and surgeries. This is likely the greater part of your problem right now, and the long term outlook for it is good, but it can take months to fully correct, even with the full battery of treatments available (including physical therapy, supportive shoes, resting of the foot whenever possible, corticosteroid injections, use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatories, etc.). Then the small effusion in the ankle and subtalor joint is just an accumulation of fluid in the ankle mechanism, usually not too big of a problem in itself, and probably secondary to all the other stuff going on in there.   Because of the plantar fasciitis alone, you may possibly be looking at a period of disability or reduced ability, so you may as well explore your options regarding this, in order to protect your job or at least your income. A lot will depend on how the treatment of that goes as well as the visit with the ankle specialist. The plantar fasciitis should be treated aggressively, though, so that it begins to resolve as soon as possible. The tenosynovitis will have to be evaluated in light of the overall foot/ankle problem, to determine whether or not you're going to need addtitional surgery. It may be avoidable if the other problems can be stabilized.  I wish I could give you a better answer than this, but for some people,once a jointed area of the body has been insulted, things become chronic, since each part is load bearing both separately and jointly. I'd go with getting the worst things better first, and I think right now probably the fasciitis is going to be your most disabling problem, but also the most readily treatable. Healing time will be the main concern.  Best of luck to you with this. I hope this answers some of your questions and concerns. Please stay in touch and let us know how things go.

author: enc74  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Thu Sep 04, 2008 10:50 am Gender: Female
title: Type 2 slap repair/posterior plication
content: I am a 32 yo female, 7/08 I had a type 2 slap repair and posterior plication along with rc debridement. 11/07 I dislocated my r. shoulder that resulted in multidirectional instability, physical therapy held no benefit. After the above surgery was performed, within two days I noted a very anterior shift of my right shoulder, I remained pain free and very numb until day 8- then unbearable pain set in, not only in the shoulder but to the finger tips. I began pt in the 2nd week, at first prom was going well then it began to regress quickly, I began having severe skin sensitivity along my forearm and upper arm, no medication cut the pain, my right shoulder began to shift forward even farther, and I lost my posture, with my shoulder now sagging downward about 4 inches or so, my shoulder blade has no independent movement from my upper arm. I have no external rotation. I have the ability to elevate my arm about 25 degrees but nothing more if it my arm is not assisted. My arm does not even sway when I walk. The pain is intense into the bone, with severe joint tenderness in all jointed areas to the finger tips. Intermittent swelling in my hand also. I have a swollen lump that has developed below the ac fossa, and a tendon that snaps when I turn my hand (snap is in the area between lateral side of wrist and elbow). My surgeon did not address these issues other than the possibility of RSD, and maybe going in later and doing an arthroscopic release. This is under worker's comp. the situation is so bad, the surgeon would not communicate with my physical therapist after at least 9 calls to him, I never seen him after surgery until a demand to see him at 6 weeks because I was so miserable. WC intervened in this matter due to the rapid deterioration of my condition, I was sent to another orthopedist, at first he didn't want to give much of an opinion because he works out of the same network as the initial surgeon, he said all surgeons have work they are sometimes not proud of. He did at least note that there is very marked atrophy of my upper shoulder in the rc area, and it appears that my deltoid does not fire ( it is actually a painful knot in the middle of my arm.) He wanted me to go back to the first surgeon to see what he may have to say at this point, and I did (note: that I have an r.n. case manager that assists me to these visits now since I have received such substandard care) The original surgeon felt there was no problem other than possible rsd and to set me up for scalene blocks. My work place was so ticked off- they put their foot down so I did not have to go back to that surgeon since I have been treated so poorly. I then returned to the new orthopedist- he ordered for me to have an emg and to begin ganglion blockers- in which that appointment is still 3 weeks away. I am in so much misery I don't know what to do. My neck is starting to bother me, it feels like it is strained, and I now hear and feel slight crunching from time to time when I move my head. I would like to have some direction from a very honest ethical doctor that cares. They tried to now refer me to another orthopedic doctor but he felt the case was too complicated. Now they are talking with another orthopedic surgeon that is looking at my case to see if he will accept it. I don't want pills. They don't work. I want this repaired as much as possible, I want pain relief. I want to enjoy daily living. I feel very alone in this situation, I don't know if it's time to get a lawyer to help me. But dealing with worker's comp. is such a miserably slow process. This is jeopardizing my job. It is killing my livelihood. Please, some good hearted ethical doctor out there, give me advice of what to do. I just want to have my life back.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Type 2 slap repair/posterior plication
content: Hello -  I'm not a doctor, but I  can certainly understand your very clearly described problem. First, yes, you've received substandard care. I've seen this happen before, and these things can be repaired, but sometimes the process is far too slow, as you're discovering. I think, given the incredibly inept surgery (and I gather that worker's comp is also involved), along with the deteriorating situation -- which almost sounds as though the clavicle was somehow displaced, which may be causing gross thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), that if you are unable to get anyone to act in a timely manner then an attorney is your next stop. The original repair sounds as though it was completely incompetent,  and while the legal process could also be quite slow, it should at least get some of the hired help moving, including the pain management specialist. It may not happen over night, but if you know things are starting to move you'll feel better even if you're still in pain.  Please follow up with us here as needed. I know of no specific medical advice that will help, but certainly you need a game plan.  The attorney is not usually a part of that, but in  cases like this (and they do happen) sometimes an attorney is an essential part of the team.  Best of luck to you, and please stay in touch.

author: tinyangel  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Sep 25, 2008 8:34 am Gender: Female
title: Have you heard of SuperGrowth?
content: Supergrowth is a herbal height increase supplement that is applied on the knee. The ingredients consist of herbs. Do you think this is effective in really increasing height? Is this supplement reliable in the way that there are no side effects?
posted_time: Post  by tinyangel » Thu Sep 25, 2008 10:06 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Have you heard of SuperGrowth?
content: Hello -  While I haven't heard of this supplement specifically, and while it would seem unlikely to cause any harm, I can tell you with reasonable certainty that it won't yield the desired result, either. Growth, especially vertical growth, is determined partially by genetics and partly by the workings of the pituitary gland. Nothing you can apply externally is going to cause any change in your height with the possible exception of platform shoes (not a permanent solution).   I hope this is helpful to you. If you really feel you suffer from an abnormally short height and are still in a stage of life where you might be able to grow, seeing an endocrinologist would be your single best bet, but if you are out of your early teens you're probably fixed at your current height. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, either.   I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Increasing Height
content: Hello, It is unusual to gain height at this point in your life but some men have done it, though not through any external means, pills, powders, potions or exercises.  For some reason they have a sudden growth spurt, even at age 19.  I know of nothing to help this condition beyond painful and minimally effective bone-lengthening surgery.  I do NOT recommend this.    It is more important that you come to terms with the body you have, take good care of it and work on your strength and overall health.  Eating a good, healthy diet is your best defense against growth restriction but as you know, genetics do play a role. There are many cases where a child ate very healthy food with lots of vegetables and then he surpasses his parents by several inches.  There is no way to know if you are one of the exceptions to the rule of growth patterns in humans.    I hope you will come to feel good about yourself.  Building body strength can be very good for the self-esteem.  Your body becomes healthy, strong and attractive in ways that are not related to height.  I know this is not the answer you were hoping to find.  Best wishes.

title: Re: Cannot bend my wrist down for 2 months!
content: Hello I'm not a medical person, but I do have a similar injury. There is a small bone at the base of the thumb called a scaphoid. It is a common fracture when one falls on an outstretched hand. Yes, go get it examined! It has a poor blood supply and may begin to heal & feel better only to give loose latter. I had a bone graft taken from my left hip in an attempt to mend it Oct.'07. Unfortunately there was too much necrosis of the one (and only) vein that suppies the scaphoid and the boneis now dying. I now face further sugery in the winter when my Dr. will take another graft from a more veinious bone. Get this taken care of before your in my shoes. I'm 41 with 2yr. old twins and having a bum wrist sucks!

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: tenosynovitis surgery recovery time.
content: Hello -  It's unfortunate you had to have such a painful negative experience with the original tendon repair, but after three cortisone injections having not resolved the problem in your hand, surgery is probably the only good approach to making this right. It is impossible to know for certain whether the tendons will rupture in time or not, but if that were to happen it would only force the issue of surgery and make it more difficult since by then there will likely be some sclerosing of the inflamed tendons. Surgery for this is generally very simple and the recovery time relatively quick. Complications are not common. If it were me, I'd go for the fix now, while the odds still favor a fairly easy repair.   I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Collarbone Knobs
content: Hello -  The short answer to your question is "No." Our bodies are actually rarely very symetrical, especially in features such as the one you're concerned about. Sometimes it is difficult to notice our inequities because, for one thing, we're not looking for them.  Unless there is a gross difference between bilateral body parts there is almost never anything to be concerned about, and when there are gross differences there are usually other symptoms as  well.   I hope this helps.

author: Noendinsight  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Fri Aug 29, 2008 9:15 am Gender: Male
title: SEVERE JOIN PAIN (toe, ankle, knee, shoulder)
content: About 3 years ago the joint of my big toe on my left foot became VERY sore. It swelled, turned red and I couldn't even lift it. I didn't go to the doctor until the second time it happened which was about 5 months later. At that time I was diagnosed with possible Gout. I now have an episode every couple months which started in my left toe but now is in my right toe, both ankles, my knees and now my should. I was told I may not have Gout because each episode lasts anywhere from 5 to 14 days and no medication as of yet has helped. I was also diagnosed with a form of Psuedo Gout (doctors actual term) and they wanted to start giving me horse tranquilizers. My family doctor is great for treating a cold and giving physicals, but I need some help because the pain is just too unbareable. When the probem moved to my right knee, it swelled up to the size of a cantelope and I had to have it drained twice. My current situation today is that now my left knee has swelled up and very painfull (can't walk), I had it drained two days ago but it's getting large again. Also I know have a severe pain in my right shoulder. There is a bone on the top of my shoulder about 4 fingers length away from my neck that is swollen and I can't raise or move my arm. The best way to describe the pain is that gravity even hurts. I have even went to the emergency room a couple times because I couldn't stand the pain. I feel that only someone with the same problem can understand how bad it gets, because it's just unexplainable. I can't move when this happens. I am at my wits end and don't know what else to do. I can't believe that a doctor would tell me that this is just something I have to live with, which is what I have been told. Can someone please direct me to a diagnosis or at least the correct doctor/specialty to seek?
posted_time: Post  by Noendinsight » Fri Aug 29, 2008 9:42 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: SEVERE JOIN PAIN (toe, ankle, knee, shoulder)
content: Hello -  It certainly sounds like what you're describing is widespread gout. While  gout almost always starts in the big toe, it can spread to other joints, and is often accompanied by hyperuricemia, which is diagnostic when present (it doesn't always show up, however). Gout can also be a misdiagnosis for chondrocalcinosis, which presents in a very similar fashion.  "You're just going to have to live with it" is rarely an acceptable response to a severe medical problem, and if you have gout or a similar, related disease there are treatments for it. While colchicene used to be the drug of first choice, now indomethicin and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatories are preferred because the are more effective with far less potential side effects. Another  family of drugs with even less side effects are the glutocoticoids. There are, in other words, plenty of medications besides horse tranquilizers which work well with this family of diseases and should be tried before you're told to "just live with it."   You need to have your uric acid levels checked (I'm sure this has been done), and you may need to be followed by a rheumatologist to be sure this is treated properly.   I hope this is helpful. Best of luck to you, and please follow up with us as needed.

title: Severe Pain and numbness localized in r hand
content: Hi!  I am a 32 year old female. 9 Days ago, my hand started *falling asleep* even when doing the most menial of tasks (IE talking on the phone, typing an email, sitting on the couch, driving) .. then 6 days ago it started to hurt, I lost my ability to grip anything.  Then 4 days ago, I woke in the middle of the night (usually within an hour of falling asleep) in severe pain, there is numbness, burning, tingling, cramping and shooting pain that will eventually lead to my elbow.  There is a consistent throb in my thumb. My hand can be numb for hours. They (the fingers) feel swollen but they aren't. Massage, Nsaids, Ice and rest are not helping. I don't have medical insurance, being a single mom, and I am about ready to head to the ER. However,  if there is a possible home remedy for this, I would love to hear it. I have read about arthritis, carpal tunnel and trauma.. there was not injury, no repetitive movement and It is only one hand.  I am right handed and an artist, so this is affecting my work ... aand IT HURTS!!! (sorry for the caps, but I have an exceptionally high pain threshold and if it hurts me, it REALLY HURTS!)  Thanks for your time, any advice will be heeded and appreciated!

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Severe Pain and numbness localized in r hand
content: Hi there -  What you describe certainly sounds like nerve pain. It could be carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS), especially since you are an artist and since this is affecting your work and involves your dominant hand. It could, however, also be ulnar neuropathy, which can be a part of CTS, of the more controversial thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), or be due to a nerve entrapment that can happen sometimes without any obvious trauma.   CTS is worth consideration because it can cause compression of the ulnar nerve and cause the same symptoms (plus,somtimes,  swelling or puffiness of the hand). CTS is due to a traumatic, postural or congenital narrow outlet between the collar bone and the first rib, where the ulnar nerve (which serves the 4th and 5th fingers, the thumb, and the outer (pinkie) aspect of the hand.   Pain and numbness from ulnar neuropathy of any origin can sometimes be retrograde back to the elbow, and this is often the location of the nerve entrapment.   An  orthopedist or neuroligist (preferably the latter) can usually sort this out and, often with the help of a nerve conduction  study, determine the location of the entrapment. It then can often be resolved via physical therapy or minor surgery.   Carpal tunnel syndrome can cause similar symptoms, but is often erroniously diagnosed in place of CTS or ulnar neuropathy/ TOS.   I hope this is helpful, and I actually have known at least one artist who developed this problem as a result of unwitting faulty posturing during her work. Just a thought.  If ulnar neuropathy is the diagnosis and no medical therapy is helpful there are some home exercises that can be done which sometimes can ease the discomfort, especially if the impingement is located in or near the cervical spine. Unfortunately, it is impossible to show you diagrams of these exercises here on the site. A doctor could provide these, however.  Best of luck to you. Please follow up with  us as needed.
