author: cybrwolf  Guest Posts: 14 Joined: Wed Jan 18, 2006 10:51 am Location: colorado
title: Medial Meniscus Tear
content: I am a 40 year old, fairly active female.  5'5" and 140 lbs.  A few months ago I twisted my knee or something, no actual 'accident', and awoke the next morning to excruciating pain and difficulty to walk.  There was never any bruising or swelling, and ibuprofen and icing helped.  I have also bought a neoprene brace for when I'm hiking etc.  I exercise quite frequently, usually 4 - 5 times per week, cardio and weight lifting, and have made a point to be more cautious with any activities that are taxing on the knees.  And I started taking glucosamine, which truly does seem to help.  I am no longer in the pain I was before, but do have days where I just seem stiff, others where I have pain, sometimes if I sit or stand too long, doing the opposite will cause a bit of stiff pain or feel like the knee might give out, but it never has.   I have done quite a bit of research and had decided that its the medial meniscus which is probably bothering me and went to see an orthopedic surgeon a couple of weeks ago to get his impression and find out options.  I must note that I don't have insurance, so I pay my own way on everything, but often facilities will give me a 10% or so discount for paying cash at time of service.  The ortho suggested after doing some rotations with my leg that he thinks I have some tears on the medial meniscus cartilage, and that he would suggest that I get an MRI, and that the course would be to have arthroscopic surgery.  I am wondering if there is any way a regular knee x-ray can show such tears, cause as one compares $80 vs $600+, it becomes a bit harder to swallow.  I also understand that it will be about $3,000 for the surgeon's fees, but nearly $7,000 for the facility, even though it's outpatient.  I am somewhat accepting of the surgeon's fees, but think the facility is exorbitant... I am also wondering what alternatives there are instead of actually going through arthroscopic surgery... are there other ways of working to heal this sort of injury? and what types of exercise and activities are ok to pursue?
posted_time: Post  by cybrwolf » Tue Sep 09, 2008 5:32 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Medial Meniscus Tear
content: Hello -  I certainly can sympathize with your concern over the costs involved in treating this problem without insurance. It then becomes a personal decision based on what is feasible for you vs. being able to function over the long haul.   The problem with x-ray of the knee is that while it is sometimes possible to visualize some gross injury to the meniscus, it's not really worth the trouble and expense to do it, since it won't yield the specific imagery required to arthroscopically repair the injury if you decide on that. MRI will yield very accurate imaging and allow for a precise surgical approach.   There's not too much you can do to make the thing heal on its own, which is why surgery is usually the preferred route. You may be able, via use of a brace, to keep it from getting worse, and usually the limiting factor is pain and/or completion of the tear (rendering the knee not only very painful but unable to function).   I would suggest using pain as a guideline for limiting yourself as far as activity goes, assuming you keep it braced and don't try anything overly demanding, but still it is likely to remain painful and will probably get worse. You don't want to make the surgery an emergency affair for sure.   Continue to take the glucosamine if it seems to help (and a lot of people swear by it), but don't depend on it to cause proper healing (or any healing at all). Hopefully you'll find a way to finance the repair. It's a shame things have come to this, but it's all too common nowadays, and we have to weigh the possible risks vs. benefits of paying what seem like outrageous costs for healthcare that too often can become unavoidable.   Best of luck to you. Please do follow up with us here.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Tue Sep 09, 2008 11:00 pm

author: 022827  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Thu Aug 28, 2008 1:51 pm Gender: Female
title: Unexplained Leg Weakness
content: In December 2007 I began experiencing left hip, groin and knee pain and leg weakness. Until then, I was an avid exerciser - running, weights etc. No specific injury, and a gradual onset- first with thigh weakness when running. After a month or so, I started to experience severe knee pain for a day or so after a run. Within the next month, the pain spread to my hip and groin, and was so severe that I could not bend my knee after being still for any length of time, sitting was painful, and I walked with a limp and dragged my foot. I went to an Orthopaedic doc for treatment - MRIs of knee, hip and spine negative, as was an EMG/NCS. I stopped all forms of exercise in early March, and the pain subsided in about a month but I was left with residual weakness, a limp, and the pain would return if I tried the least bit of weight bearing activity (walking, etc.). In June the Ortho referred me to a Physical Medicine doctor for rehabilitation. After 8 weeks of PT and a gradual return to mild exercise, the limp is gone and I can tolerate moderate walking. However I still have weakness in my leg, stairs and hills are difficult, balance is a bit off and I have trouble finding a comfortable sleeping position (lower back pain). I've resigned myself to "this is how it is" and will continue with strengthening exercises on my own (stopped PT with concurrence of doctor). The Physical Med doctor working with me is excellent and he is stumped and can't find a cause - although we both agreed to stop looking at this point, further work-up seems pointless for the time being. I seem to be at a plateau and I would love to get back to my prior physical shape, but I don’t want to waste any more time or medical resources. Out of curiosity, - has anyone ever seen anything like this?
posted_time: Post  by 022827 » Fri Aug 29, 2008 3:49 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Unexplained Leg Weakness
content: Hello -  You may have a problem with a nerve being compressed, pinched or entrapped. Although no one has found any lower back problem on imaging, I can't help but feel there is something either involving the lower back or, perhaps, the sciatic nerve itself, which could  be caused by a non-orthopedic problem. This is unusual, but it can happen. Perhaps a neurologist could be consulted and might run a nerve conduction test to see if the muscles in your leg are even getting the message or if it's being short-circuited somewhere along the way. Sometimes we can develop peripheral neuropathy (inflammation of one or more peripheral nerves) for no apparent reason, too. An electromyelogran might help pinpoint  the source of the problem and then the appropriate steps could be taken to correct the situation.  I hope this is of some  help to you. Best of luck and please do follow up with us.

posted_time: Post  by srg717 » Tue Apr 22, 2008 7:29 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Finger swelling during swimming?
content: Hello -  While I can think of no disorder that would cause this only under the conditions described, there is a phenomenon, usually seen when walking or in tennis players, where the fingers and sometimes the backs of the hands, become puffy and uncomfortable during and immediately after exercise involving the repeated use of force and/or dependency of the  arms (them hanging and swinging as happens when  walking). There is a theory which makes some sense to me, that the activity involves a certain amount of centrifugal force, pushing more blood into the hands. The same would hold true for exercise involving the upper body and arms,  since swimming involves these (and pretty much all the voluntary muscles). Since it resolves after you're done swimming and causes you no other problems,  it would seem to be a benign change related to the activity, same as "walker's hands."   Hopefully this is helpful to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Pain Near Shoulder Blade - Feels Like Open Wound
content: Hello -  What you describe sounds very much like nerve pain. Sometimes a superficial nerve can become irritated or inflamed (peripheral neuropathy, shingles, etc.) and will be sensitive to touch, to clothing, and will often just be sore, exactly as you describe. Other than shingles, which has skin lesions at first, causes of this problem often have no visible signs.   My main concern here is the fact that there are moles in the general area of the pain, and because of this the area should be examined by a doctor to be certain the moles haven't caused any problems with nerves in the skin or underlying tissues. If not, then there are medications to treat this sort of discomfort, depending on how bothersome it is. But first you need to see a doctor and find out exactly what, if anything, is going on (sometimes these nerve pains have no traceable cause).   Good luck to you, and please do follow up with us here.

content: Hi, sorry if this is not in the correct sub forum, this is the closest section I could find that deals with my sort of problem.  My problem is, after walking a very short distance, say 100 metres or so, my shins give me a lot of pain, and I can't bend my foot up or down to continue to walk, I'm not sure I explained that bit very well about the foot, what I mean is, I can sit here now, lift my foot and tap the floor with no problem, but when walking, my feet seem to seize up at the same time as my shins, so that there is no upwards or downward movement, so I wouldn't even be able to tap my foot for example, due to not being able to move my feet very much.  I have had this problem for many years now, I think it might be a result of my something I did years ago, which was walking about 36 miles in 10 hours, at that time, after walking all that way, the next day when I woke up, I could not walk or bend my feet for nearly a week, could that walk have caused some permanent damage to my legs?  Something else you should be aware of, I suffer from, severe social phobia, which I understand is now also called, social anxiety disorder, this means I do not go outside very much, I have not actually been outside my home since November 4th 2005, which means I get very little excercise, which will probably make my problem worre through lack of excercise I would think?  But during my life, my social phobia has affected me to varying degrees, sometimes not leaving my home for a year or more at a time, other times managing to get out and about when I used alcohol as self medication to cope with people around me.  So although I do very little in the way of exercise, this shin/foot problem has been with me for years, even through periods when I was quite active, any ideas what the problem could be? Thanks in advance for any replies, much appreciated!
posted_time: Post  by dghjgdhj » Sun Jan 06, 2008 9:05 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Shin and foot pain when walking
content: Hello -  It sounds as though  you have thought through your problem very well and probably have hit the nail on the head. Over work of an underused part of the body (in this case probably the group of muscles and tendons involved in walking -- shin and instep) can cause inflammation, chronic tendinitis, even some mild correctable deformity.   What makes this a problem likely to repeat itself is the social phobia (or even agoraphobia -- it is sometimes difficult to separate the two). As you've mentioned, this can keep you inside (and so largely inactive or at least preventing regular dynamic exercises like walking). There are also, as you've implied has happened for you, periods of remission when the sufferer is able to "break out" for a while and do certain things, which are then often done in excess, such as your 36 mile walk. While an admirable accomplishment (a very impressive), if this is done without the appropriate and regular warming up and cooling down involved in regular daily exercise, it can cause some pretty traumatic irritation to the musculature and connective tissue in the area now affected.   Physical therapy would, of course, be part of a comprehensive program to correct this, you may need first to resolve the social phobia or anxiety disorder (it is actually both; the  terms are interchangeable). This would be a valuable challenge to undertake,  and the sooner you do, the sooner you can reclaim your life full time and begin to enjoy it a lot more, while also avoiding the associated physical problems it often incurs.  Best of luck to  you with all of this. Start with over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatories, taking them not only when you have problems with walking,  but also before you anticipate doing any significant walking. Then tackle the anxiety problem and associated agoraphobia, which may involve cognitive therapy. All of this will work together for good. Please let  us know how things work out.

title: bruised or cracked rib symptoms
content: Two days ago I fell heavily against the back of my mini-van and doubled over with pain in the area just below my left breast. I have since experienced pain in the area, most noticibly when I cough or sneeze or turn my body (in bed and otherwise.) I'm starting to wonder if I might have cracked or buised a rib...but I also wonder if such an occurrance would elicit more severs symptoms than what I have noted. There is no mark on my skin. I have looked in your archives but did not see anything relevant to my question. Thank you Miller
posted_time: Post  by miller » Wed Feb 13, 2008 7:48 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: bruised or cracked rib symptoms
content: Hello -  Depending on the angle, pressures, etc., involved, you could bruise or even crack a rib without sustaining a visible bruise. More likely, though, you strained muscle or connective tissue on or between ribs, which can be quite painful and rarely shows any discoloration at all. Anti-inflammtory pain meds like ibuprofin or naprosyn for a day or two will usually help a lot, and even if you had bruised or actually cracked a rib there is rarely anything more to do for it than treat the discomfort and try to not repeat the offending maneuver.   I hope this is helpful. Good luck to you.

author: santa  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Dec 27, 2007 5:56 pm
title: Pain in right lower leg and swelling
content: I am 28 yr old male from LA ,California .For last 2 months I am suffering from some pain and inflammation in my right leg .Initialy the pain started in`my right calf muscle under my knee and there was redness and swelling with warmth .My family doctor prescribe Advil and also Cephalexin for 10 days .I was suggested to have complete blood profile checked .Reports were normal .I went to another doctor since things was not improving and the pain went towards my ankle region and my right feet was getting swelled .My doctor suggested to have a Doppler USG and have Uric acid checked.This agin came normal .I was put on a dose of antibiotics again (doxycycline for 10 days and levofloxacin for 10 days )along with Naproxene.I was also given 2 shots of Cortisone injections.This  releived the pain and inflammation .However the eantibiotics caused some intestinal disturbance and dry moth.I had full course of the antibiotics as doctors said i may be having cellulitis...After one month passed still I am having little pain and occasional swelling around my right ankle .I cannot walk long distance as earlier .I consulted one Rheumatologist who suggested to keep the feet at rest but still things are same as before .I am at my wits end as my normal life is getting affected .Some friend of ine suggested to g oto a Podiatrist ..Will this help??please advise..  SM

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Pain in right lower leg and swelling
content: Hello -  Based on your description of the problem my first concern would be to rule out a clot in your leg (deep vein thrombosis or DVT). While it seems unlikely a clot would remain fixed in one location and not cause more problem,  they have been known to stay put (if they don't stay put there is a risk of one  traveling to the lungs, a potentially life-threatening condition). If a clot has been ruled out by D-dimer blood test and doppler ultrasound testing,  then cellulitis is also possible, but two months is a long time for it to remain in a stable state. I would think it would have improved or gotten a lot worse during that period of time.  Other  possibilities are compartment syndrome, which can  cause similar symptoms but can become chronic. It is rarely life-threatening but can injure the leg muscle if left untreated. Finally, a disorder of the lymph glands in the leg can cause similar symptoms also.  Having been through  a course of antibiotics I would think a lymph node problem or cellulitis would have gotten better at least for a while.   Are you athletic? A runner? Compartment syndrome occurs most often in athletic people,  but can also occur in non-athletes. An orthopedist who specializes in sports medicine might be your best bet if internal medicine hasn't produced any signifcant improvement.    I hope this is helpful to you. Good luck and please follow up with us here.

title: Leg aching/twitching
content: Hello, I am a fit individual who works out about 4 times a week ( weights, cardio, aerobics classes) and also I have had 2 reoccuring stress fractures in my left tibia in the last 6 years ( due to running) Since then I have cut out almost all running ( maybe 2-4 minutes at the most in a workout), but I still work out my legs. Just 2 days ago I performed a leg workout, and came home with a dull ache and stiffness in my left inner calf/ inner lower knee part as well, Not excruciating pain or anything, just a dull pain, also some stifness. My left hamstring is pretty sore too. The next day, different parts of my left calf, and hamstring have been twitching all day, when I am just sitting or laying. My right leg has also been a little bit too, but not near as much as my left leg. Finally I feel like the whole medisl part of my left lower leg has given out and when I stand and walk, my weight on my left leg caves inward.   I have also been diagnosed with a mal-tracking problem with my left knee. This has caused me some minor knee pain sometimes, however it's not prominant right now. Any suggestions of what it might be? I am trying to rule out the stress fracture so I can at least not worry about that again. Can overloading the legs with weights cause stress fractures? I always wondered about that.
posted_time: Post  by BIBNR4L » Thu Apr 24, 2008 8:51 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Leg aching/twitching
content: Hello -   To get to the bottom of your post, yes, loading the legs during weight training can cause stress fractures. It sounds as though you may have done it  again, but it also could be the knee problem manifesting as an alignment problem. There's no way to be certain from a distance (actually without a hands-on exam and maybe imaging) but it sounds very likely one of the two has happened. Please do get this checked ASAP. You might also, if you haven't already, have a bone density study done. This is a lot to go wrong without some underlying problem.   Good luck to you and please do follow up with us.

author: Befallingdusk  Guest Posts: 20 Joined: Tue May 17, 2005 2:08 am Location: Raleigh, NC
title: Baker's Cyst or Sarcoma?  MRI Report - Help
content: Hi.  I've been living a nightmare for 3 years thanks to unusual signs and symptoms.  I've yet to recieve a diagnosis and just recently obtained a firm assessment of generalized lymphadenopathy.  A node biopsy was delayed due node location and nature of the procedure.   Meanwhile, I developed a firm lump deep beside my knee, preceded by tenderness and swelling.  The lump itself did not hurt.  Over the course of 7 months, other small lumps and nodules formed in/near my feet, and in my palms. Dr. finally ordered knee MRI with contrast.    After endless hours of research, I've been suspecting a sarcoma as these can have significant delays in diagnosis.  My Dr. felt it was a baker's cyst, but I thought these originated from behind the knee, not beside it.  A brief version of the radiologist's report:  MRI of knee no contrast. Marked device is at medial aspect of knee at the level of the distal femoral metadiaphysis delineating location of patient's palpable abnormality.  In the general vicinity of this marker, is the most cranial extent of a multilobular, multiseptated Baker's Cyst which dissects to the level of the distal femoral metadiaphysis.  Measures up to approximately 1.7 x 1.6 cm (AP by transverse dimension) at the most cranial extent and roughly 3 cm craniocaudal dimension with a thin neck extending back to the origin between the medial head of the gastrocnemius and semimembraneous.  Regional musculature is normal. There is a small amount of residual hematopoietic marrow within the distal femoral diaphysis/metaphysis.  Impression: Multilobular, multiseptated Baker's Cyst with cranial extension as described above.  My questions, remarks:  This doesn't strike me as a simple Baker's Cyst.  All I've read states that it's common for a sarcoma to be misdiagnosed by MRI, appearing very similar to what this radiologist just discribed: multispeptated, multilobular, cranial extension, etc.  Now that I have this report, I'm even more concerned.  So, do you think I should let this go and accept that it's a cyst?  DO Baker's cysts form on the side of the knee?  In light of my other symptoms, lumps, nodules, lymphadenopathy, should I insist on seeing an ortho specialist?  Too, since all of this began 3 years ago, I've developed cysts on my ovaries, cysts in my breasts, cysts in my skin, and now this in my knee.  Is this common?  I've read that multiple cysts can herald or accompany malignancy.  Do you know if that's true?  Any response, insight, or advice would be much appreciated!  Thanks so much!
posted_time: Post  by Befallingdusk » Wed Apr 30, 2008 4:10 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Baker's Cyst or Sarcoma?  MRI Report - Help
content: Hello -  While I am inclined to accept the radiologist's  reading of the MRI, and Baker's cysts do, indeed, form on the side of the knee on occasion (although the most common presentation is on the back), you have such a history of cyst formation that  I think a second  opinion is probably warranted, especially for the sake of your own peace of mind. Many people  do have a history of cysts  everywhere, for reasons that aren't  always clear, and yet never develop any malignancy. Others do, of course, but this is  an odd area. I don't know that an orthopedist would be of special help with this,  but perhaps an internist who, if any doubt arises, could refer you to someone who specializes in this  sort of thing -- even an oncologist would  be able to rule out (or, less likely, in) potentially malignancy. You might even try asking about this under the  oncology subject here at The Doctors Lounge.    I hope this is helpful. It seems you are destined to have an ongoing problem with these things, so you may as well clear the air with a proper consult. Good luck to you.

author: gdawz  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Wed Aug 03, 2005 11:27 pm Location: ny
title: Proper foot posture / knee pain
content: I am a 25 year old bodybuilding enthusiast of about 8 years with no past injuries.  About a week ago, I started to get a continual pain in my right knee, whether sitting, standing, bent or straight-legged.  My father has arthritis and several knee problems, but I've always been rather strict with my posture with working out and felt that, by keeping the joint healthily active, I might avoid some of the problems my father has.  Recently, though, after receiving my personal trainer certifications, I began reading about proper posture - specifically in regard to foot alignment.  Most texts seem to state the our feet should both be pointing straight forward.  As one of my feet tends to point about 15 degrees out if the other one is straight, I made a conscious effort to correct the stance.  This was also the case during potentially hazardous exercises such as the squat - normally I would keep both of my feet pointed out to allow for range of motion, but I've begun pointing them straight forward (and lowering the weight) to perform what I thought was the "correct" method for squatting.  I cannot find too many references to proper foot position aside from a casual mention during posture articles - which mostly focus on back and shoulders. I cannot help but feel that keeping my feet pointed straight is actually harming my posture a tad, first being displayed by this knee pain.  Even though many articles state feet straight forward, I'll then see example pictures where toes are pointed slightly outward.  Is this just an acceptable natural deviation, as long as the knees are aligned and the outward rotation of the foot is not too extreme?  Long question, sort of vague.  Thanks for your time.
posted_time: Post  by gdawz » Fri Jul 04, 2008 12:50 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Proper foot posture / knee pain
content: Hello -   There are sometimes slight natural deviations from the classic alignment, usually due to positioning in infancy or delivery of a breech birth, which will cause usually one or sometimes both feet to naturally point outward ("slewfoot"). Attempting to correct this through sheer will can sometimes be quite painful, and the most vulnerable joint between the hip and ankle is, naturally, the knee. The ankle and hip will not give nor correct by age 25, so attempting to keep the foot straight would potentially be very irritating to the knee. Unless the angle of the foot actually interferes with function or is so far out of alignment as to cause a problem with gait, etc., it's best to just work with it as it is. Hopefully this will allow the knee to recover from the strain and  15 degrees isn't really much of a deviation (i think my right foot is off by about that much, in fact).   I hope this is helpful and that the knee starts to feel better shortly.

title: Severe Neck and Arm Pain

Sometimes the pain does radiates under the left breast as well. I have had an MRI and have seen a neuro surgeon who immediately states that I have a pinched nerve and will need surgery. States that injections will not be a long term solution. I might add I have has some physical therapy that simply did not work. posted_time: Post  by lmj4302 » Sat Mar 01, 2008 11:04 am

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Severe Neck and Arm Pain
content: Hello -   The  short answer to your post is yes. Yes, a pinched nerve could cause precisely these symptoms. Most likely culprit areas would be C-4, 5 and C-7,  T-1 (disks). Even a slight bulge or nerve root compression in these areas can cause disproportionate pain which can appear in areas continguous to or served by these nerves, sometimes at a distance from the site of the pinch/compression.  They can also be difficult to locate at times.   Epidural steroid injections can sometimes shrink a bulging disk and relieve the pain, but results vary. Physical therapy also can sometimes correct the problem, at least for periods of time. Surgery is probably the best long-term bet, but of course is not without its own risks in terms of solving one problem and creating a new one. This does not happen very often, but these risks do need to be fully explored. A really good surgeon of course reduces the risk automatically be many degrees.   I hope you find a satisfying solution to this problem, and I do believe, given your detailed description, that this is being caused by a pinched or compressed nerve.  Best of luck to you and please do follow up with us.

title: Is it Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome?
content: I have been reading information from the internet on hypermobility syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. I was born with congenital dislocation of the hips and didn't walk til i was 20 months old. I have had a broken wrist at the age of 6 and a dislocated elbow at the age of 9. There is hypermobility of some of my joints, especially both my knees. They can bend back quite a way from the straight position. The fingers on both my hands have extra bone growth at the knuckles, a bump can be seen on every knuckle apart from my thumbs and they too can bend farther than the straight position. I was told that as a child my fingers could have been operated on to file down the extra bone but was decided against it thinking it wouldn't course me any problems. About 7-8 years ago my hands started to lock if my fingers are straightened for a short time are very painful to get them to unlock. At present i am experiencing alot of pain in my hips, especially lying in bed which i making sleeping difficult. Other symptons i have which were on the Ehlers-Danlos site are IBS, easy bruising, gum recession and depression. Can you tell me if this is Ehlers-Danlos or hypermobility syndrome and if i need to see my doctor about it. Thank you.
posted_time: Post  by Susanne74 » Sun Apr 20, 2008 4:41 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Is it Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome?
content: Hi Suzanne74 -  What you describe sounds very much like it could be E-D type 3. It also could be Marfan's syndrome, but you have extra details in your excellent description of the abnormalities which make me think it is probably E-D. It would be very helpful to you to know if this is the case (and if not, just what it is) so that you could find the proper specialists to help you manage the problem.   To put this in a somewhat better light, while  E-D (and other connective tissue diseases) is no picnic, the type you would probably have (type 3) is a lot less dangerous than the vascular type, and the types rarely overlap. While the loose joints may be very annoying and painful, you should be able to live out a productive, fairly normal life, setting aside the occasional orthopedic problems you may endure.   If you have, instead, Marfan's syndrome, which I am doubting, but which is possible, you would actually need to be followed more regularly and not just when there is a specific problem. Some E-D/3 patients manage to go for long periods  without any disabling or extremely painful problems. Knowing how to head these off helps a lot.   One thing you didn't mention, which is usually seen in this form of E-D is very soft, pliable, stretchable skin.  This is sometimes overlooked, since it's not especially bothersome and may even be seen as an advantage by some.   Please do follow up with us and by all means do have yourself evaluated for connective tissue disease, with an eye toward E-D. Good  luck to you.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi tiredmom82, There are several forms of Ehlers Danlos Syndrome each with a varying array of symptoms. The symptoms that you have described are quite disconcerting. There are several diagnostic studies that can be performed along with a clinical evaluation. I would also encourage you to print off some information regarding this syndrome to take with you. If another health professional takes your symptoms lightly and suggests that you "join the circus" which is appalling in itself provide them with the information. This syndrome must be appropriatly treated and due to the genetic factor testing for other family members would be warranted. I would strongly encourage you to seek the medical evaluation of both an Orthopedic and Rheumatology specialist. Best wishes. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: tiredmom82  Guest Posts: 19 Joined: Sat May 19, 2007 7:19 am
title: Re: ehlers-danlos possibility?
content: Since my Previous post i have been formally diagnosed with Ehlers Danlos Syndrome Classic Type. Its amaising how much a person thinks is normal about ones self when indeed it the opposite. I am very happy to have been diagnosed and to have answers to my issues.  Life with the diagnoses has been more difficult then thought, its very difficult to find physicians who are aware fully of the syndrome. Everything that i am afflicted with has been linked to EDS but no one knows how to treat the syndrome. Currently i am having issues with my shoulders subluxing and am no longer allowed to carrry even in a gallon of milk with out losing it. The orthopedics in my area don't know how to treat the severe instability, the physical therapist are also not trained for such a thing. In physical therapy being that was my only option i lost my right wrist and elbow to the exercises. Its hard not to cause harm to other areas while treating the current problems. I am learning new ways to do things from support groups but changing your everyday habits is more difficult then i thought. I do know understand why mentally and phyiscally i feel the way that i do. Pain is something that i am trying to over come and have some what over come. It has its prices you can only ignore so much of it before you effect your emotional well being so i am trying to work on both.  Its very alarming how much of my health issues are due to the EDS and im left having to deal with them because there no help for what i have. Currently i suffer from insane diarrhea that i need to get checked but collagen is everywhere in the body and my digestive trac is most likely effected and theres nothing i can do about it. Theres no plus to having an invisable disorder but i am trying to make the best of what i have. I don't appear to be afflicted with vascular EDS but i am going through routine testing on my heart and major arteries. I would much rather not know.  If you know something wrong it probably is....Trust your body and fight for the answers you deserve. So much has to go right in your body for you to function the human body is amaizing.  Rachael

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Chronic Sprained Ankle
content: Hi Cmasse,  I would suggest you see your doctor again to have the area reevaluated since your pain is worsening and you have one particular area that is worst.  You may have a fracture that was not initially seen on the first images.  Sometimes these fractures are not able to be seen for a few days. author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Funny bone smashed
content: Hi Mike,  From the description you've given it sounds like you have done some damage to the nerve that runs near the elbow (the so called "funny bone").  Initially, unless there is numbness, it is generally safe to watch these injuries and see if they improve.  If the tingling/pain is not getting better over the next few days you should have it checked out.  If it gets better the nerve may simply be bruised or "stunned" from the injury and needed some time to get better.  If it is not getting better, there is the possibility that there is some external compression of the nerve such as from swelling or actual damage to the nerve.  Any injury with actual numb areas should be evaluated right away because of the possible damage to the nerve that may need intervention to help preserve or restore nerve function.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Mon Apr 28, 2008 12:15 am

title: DeQuervain's tenosynovitis
content: Hi, My Mom was diagnosed with this condition last year (left wrist).  It's work related.  she got a cortisone shot but it didn't  help.  she continues to do the same job (packaging) and is afraid of doing a surgery.  Would it make sense to get another shot of cortisone?  what are the risks of delaying the surgery?  is it an easy surgery?  how long the recovery is and how painful is it?  I just wan to know the pros and cons of doing the surgery and if there's anything else her doctor may not tell her about this condition.  I really appreciate any advice or shared experience!
posted_time: Post  by bratt » Fri Mar 14, 2008 9:46 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: DeQuervain's tenosynovitis
content: Hello, I assume your mom's doctor has made other recommendations beyond the cortisone injections such as immobilizing the thumb and wrist, keeping them straight with a splint or brace to help rest your tendons.  She should also avoid repetitive thumb movements as much as she can and avoid pinching with her thumb when moving the wrist from side to side.  Heat and NSAIDs such as ibuprofen and naproxen can help reduce the swelling.  These are the conservative treatments which can be very effective if started early on.  Physical therapy and/or chiropractic care may also help but if the repetitive activity that caused the problem is not discontinued, the pain will likely return. I am not sure of the appropriate amount of cortisone by injection but some doctors don't like to do more than two or three of these.    I would recommend the combination of conservative treatments in conjunction with alterations in wrist/hand use before moving to surgery but it will take a while to see improvement.  My best to you and your mother.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Mon Mar 31, 2008 1:16 pm

content: Hello PK,  Generally, after the growth plate closes, growth hormone really does not result in any significant growth and is unlikely to help your condition. author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Treatment for HLAB-27 positive
content: Hello Saurabh.120182,  The HLA-B27 status is a genetic condition that cannot be changed.  This, in itself, is NOT a cause of illness.  It does, however, predispose to a number of various condition, including many rheumatological illnesses that can cause joint pain.  Making the diagnosis of what is actually going on is crucial to being able to treat it effectively.  I would recommend you see a rheumatologist for further evaluation to try and make a diagnosis and get you on a proper treatment plan.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Slip and Fell on Ice = Sharp Hip Pain
content: Hello Sixtysix,  Falls onto the hip can cause a variety of injuries.  These range from mild bruises to fractures of the hip or leg bone (the femur).  Given your symptoms it is hard to say for sure that there is not a fracture present.  Since your pain is not getting better I would recommend you see your doctor for an evaluation to determine if any x-rays are needed.  At the least, I suspect you have a very severe bruise that is going to take some time to heal but determining if there is a fracture is important to be sure that things heal properly and you don't loose function of your hip.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Sat Mar 15, 2008 9:38 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Cannot bend wrist outward?
content: Hello, I would not expect more than 90 degrees' on this, but if you're saying you just don't flex back as much as desired for guitar, I would concentrate on learning to adapt.  People with limited resources are able to accomplish great and even unexpected things when they are determined to find a way.  If you find you just can't make it work (though my experience is that the wrist moving inward to reach the frets and strings is more important), you could consider learning to play the dobro - similar to a guitar and used more frequently in country and bluegrass music.  I don't know what style of guitar you want to use but I do believe you can make it work with desire and determination.  You could also see an orthopedic or hand specialist to see if there is anything to be done to improve your range of motion.  Genetics appear to be a big part of your problem, but often there is some improvement to be made with physical therapy.  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Fingers blue and numb
content: Hello, While this could be some type of temporary musculoskeletal condition, it is also possible it could be Reynaud's disease which causes a narrowing of the arteries that carry blood to the extremities or other body parts such as ears.  If this is the case, your friend could get helpful treatment.    Self care includes:  No smoking, regular exercise to improve circulation, avoid caffeine, reduce stress (something you have identified), take care of hands and feet, using protective coverings against cold and environment to avoid additional injury.  Thank you for looking out for your friend who is busy looking out for others.  Please encourage her to take care of herself as well.    Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Bruise turned into permanent lump
content: Hello BarbaraBecher,  The lump may be a calcified area in the muscle.  Occasionally bruises can induce calcium deposition that can remain for extended periods of time, if not permanently.  There really isn't a lot to prevent this from happening.  You can try heating pads, etc. to help the bruise resolve but there is no guarantee that this will help.  These calcifications aren't dangerous.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: carpal coalition
content: Hello SusieQ1,  Carpal coalition is a condition where two of the carpal bones did not properly separate and remain fused.  The carpal bones are found in the hand, though.  There is a similar condition called Tarsal coalition that affects the tarsal bones of the feet.  Tarsal coalition is present from birth since it is a developmental problem that occurs while the baby is developing.  Generally, it does not present with problems until the bones begin to mature (usually around puberty time).  The symptoms range from no symptoms at all to very severe pain when walking or standing.  Management is basically determined by symptoms.  Those that are asymptomatic do not need treatment.  For those with pain, often orthotic devices (shoe inserts) and anti-inflammatories are tried.  In severe cases where medical management is unsuccessful, surgical repair of the fused bones may be necessary.  If there is concern about this, seeing an orthopedic specialist would be appropriate.  Best wishes.

title: Teen looking at Hip Osteotomy
content: I'm a active and fit fifteen year old female high school student with a family history of hip problems.  My aunt has had six hip replacements and has severely shallow sockets.  Although I was checked as a child, this issue did not arise in me until around a year ago.  I dismissed my pain for a year, but i recently had it checked at an orthopedic and fracture clinic.  X-rays were taken that show my left hip socket has about 25 degrees of coverage and my right has 15.  (My doctor said between 20 and 40 is normal).  He told my that eventually an Osteotomy will be necessary, but he has no idea when.  I've been told its my decision when this needs to be done but it will be obvious when I'm having "more bad than good days".  Since going to the doctor my symptoms have increased, although its only been a few weeks.  I understand a lot of this is my focus on the problem and it is a mental issue.  I accept that I will live with pain and discomfort (and have sadly learned this probably wont change after the operation) and decreased flexibility.  I have also noticed that my hip is weaker.  Moving my leg backward and directly out to this side in a standing position is comfortable, however i can hardly gather the strength to lift my leg straight in front of me while standing.  I also notice this when i try to cross my legs (as i usually have to assist the motion with my arm strength).  I also have lost the strength to push things with my leg or kick.  Is this muscle loss something that goes hand-in-hand with my pain and decreased flexibility?  Am I also facing a hip replacement in my lifetime?  Is it possible that because of my young age and my active lifestyle that my recovery will be closer to 6 months than a year and will i possibly have better results and decreased pain after the surgery because of this?  Can some doctors do horizontal incisions rather than vertical across the crease in my groin to avoid an obvious and unpleasant scar?    I really appreciate your time seeing as in office visits are hard to schedule and there are often time limits.  I understand the questions I've asked have a large range of answers that are hard to predict, but a ballpark estimate would really help me understand what I'm looking at.    thanks again

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: soreness/dull pain in shoulders, arms, upper back
content: It is not unusual for musculo-skeletal disorders to last 6 weeks, or 6 months, or 6 years.... Sometimes the doctor is able to diagnose a particular problem such as osteoarthritis, tendonitis, or fibromyalgia, in which case there could be helpful treatments, but often because of the transient nature of such disorders, there may never be a name for it.  I suspect this is why your doctor responded as he/she did.  It is important to rule out underlying problems that could be serious and could lead to other problems so that is probably what was done with blood work.  They were able to rule out something that might put your life in danger even though they do not have an actual explanation for your symptoms.    As time goes by I would recommend you keep a diary or journal of your symptoms.  Along with the time of day, and date, describe what you were doing near that time.  If you were sleeping, what position were you in, if there were other symptoms also, what were they.  If they were exacerbated by anything, what helped; what didn't.  By noting a pattern, you may be able to eventually get the answers you seek.  Best wishes to you.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: My arms are very sensative.
content: The Thalamus is the gland that is called the brain's relay station.  When we experience a sensation, our nervous system sends the message and the message is interpreted.  We respond accordingly.  People exhibit a vast array of responses to pain and other stimulus.  Some have a much higher pain tolerance than others, for instance.    If you have a hypersensitive response to a painful stimulus such as you describe (what should feel like a light bump is experienced as excruciating pain) it could possibly be Thalamic Syndrome, sometimes called Dejerine-Roussy or a number of other names, a rare neurological disorder resulting from damage to the thalamus.   I do not know if you have this condition, but it is one possible cause of symptoms such as yours.  If so, this falls in the category of neurological disorders as you search for treatment.  Neurotransmitters can also play a role in pain sensation and various central nervous system disorders could be at play here as well.  This system is very complex so a neurologist would be the right doctor to consult with.  Good luck.  Best wishes to you.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Body Asymmetry
content: Hi Sunset429,  What you are describing sounds like hemihypertrophy.  Hemihypertrophy is an asymmetry in the body when comparing the right to the left with one side being larger than the other.  It can range from only involving one hand or arm to involving the entire side of the body, including internal organs.  It can occur as an isolated finding or can be associated with other syndromes, such as Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome, Klippel-Trenauney syndrome and neurofibromatosis.  Most of these are associated with other symptoms that would have made the syndrome obvious before age 18.  The one possible exception would be neurofibromatosis, although this is commonly diagnosed in childhood as well.  Determining which specialist to see for this can be difficult.  I would suggest that you see a dermatologist for further evaluation.  Seeing a geneticist is also a good idea to see if there may be any underlying genetic issues that may help to determine the cause.  Best wishes.

author: Sandy Tracy RN  Nurse Posts: 60 Joined: Wed Nov 07, 2007 6:57 pm
title: Re: Extreme Long Distance Walking
content: Hi Zenbob,  It takes about 18-20 minutes to walk 1 mile.  If you are planning on doing 40 miles a day it will take 12-14 hours.  This is if it is done at a leisurly pace.  So yes it can be done.   Obviously a great pair of walking shoes are essential.  This will keep your feet comfortable and free of blisters or rubbing.  You may need more than 1 pair.  Some of the medical issues that may arise from long distant walking is knee and hip pain.  Knees and hips are areas that can get bursitis.  Bursitis is caused by the repetative motion.  The bursa of the joint becomes inflammed from the friction.  Another issue is dehydration, be sure to drink plenty of water.  As far as the time I would plan on taking a few rest days to enjoy the scenery, and if weather is an issue.  Good Luck  Sandy Tracy RN
posted_time: Post  by Sandy Tracy RN » Wed Jan 16, 2008 11:54 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Knee Injury
content: Hello, Don't underestimate the damage and pain associated with a sprain.  You have injured soft tissue which can be just as painful as injuring a bone.  It also takes quite a while to heal and there is danger of reinjury with a sprain since you are not casted.  You must give it several weeks to heal but it certainly doesn't hurt to be in touch with your doctor.  Some fractures do not show on x-ray right away but may be apparent later.  Good luck.

posted_time: Post  by MechRocket » Wed Dec 26, 2007 12:14 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Cartilage erosion
content: I doubt you will regenerate cartilage if it has eroded.  This is what happens in osteroarthritis.   There are some new techniques to help this condition surgically and the synovial fluid can be improved to cushion and lubricate the joint.  Your prognosis at this point is hard to predict since it will rely on newer and better techniques that may be available in the future but are not at the current time.  I would suggest getting a consultation with an orthopedic specialist or rheumatologist to see what can be done.  Good luck.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: MULTIPLE JOINT PAIN
content: Hi Paul,  There are a few things that may be going on.  The pain and numbness may indicate that you are having some nerve problems.  It sounds like you have had back trouble in the past so it is possible that you are having some pain due to some compression of the spinal nerves.  You may also be developing some arthritis in your joints.  This may be simply from "wear and tear" of the joints or it may be due to a condition such as rheumatoid arthritis.  The joint distribution is less consistent with rheumatoid arthritis, though.  Seeing your primary care doctor is probably a good place to start.  From there, if needed, you can see an orthopedic specialist, a neurologist or possibly a rheumatologist.  Best wishes.

title: would tylenol 3 or lortab be stronger then the darvacet?
content: Hello, i just have a quick question before my appointment with my doctor tomorrow.   My doctor dosnt prescribe vicodin anymore for pain so he is trying me on darvacet and tramadol.  It is not really helping much for the pain plus it is making me sick/dizzy.   My question is (ive had suggestions)  would tylenol 3 or lortab (is it the same thing?) be stronger then the darvacet?   If not what would be a good medication to try besides the darvacet while still being close to as strong as vicodin.  ( im going to have surgery in a few weeks and need some pain releif close to what the vidodin would give.)   ty for your time and suggestions!!  lms
posted_time: Post  by lms » Thu Dec 27, 2007 7:33 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: would tylenol 3 or lortab be stronger then the darvacet?
content: Hello, As you have learned, people do respond differently to medications.  While one pain reliever is very strong for one person, the same may not be effective for the next.  It is also possible to develop a tolerance if these are used frequently.  This makes it hard to say what would be stronger for you but the Lortab should be the same as Vicodin.  Tylenol 3 is similar but it is with codeine, whereas Vicodin and Lortab both combine hydrocodone with acetaminophen (generic equivalent to Tylenol).  The combinations with acetaminophen or Tylenol and a narcotic pain reliever seem to work better than the single ingredient alone for most people.  Percocet would also be considered on a par with Vicodin and Lortab for strength and it combines the acetaminophen with oxycodone as the narcotic analgesic.    Often the decision is made based on which the patient tolerates without side effects and trying one or another is about the only way to know how you will do with it.  After surgery most doctors prescribe a couple of options so if one does not do the trick, an alternate can be tried.    Good luck with your upcoming surgery.

title: Re: Painful lump on wrist diagonal from thumb
content: My first thought on this would be that it is a ganglion cyst.  These are harmless except as they interfere with your activities or cause you discomfort.   These cysts tend to come and go and you may not need any treatment.  Surgically removing them is possible but they can return.  This is my best guess based on your description.  Best wishes.

author: misspuppychow  Guest Posts: 9 Joined: Sun Dec 02, 2007 11:07 pm
title: Rotator Cuff Tear?
content: I am a 21 year old female who use to be a competitive gymnast.  I had an injury on the bars where I was swinging around them and injured my left shoulder.  I went to an orthopaedic surgeon who did an MRI and wanted to do surgery to tighten up the muscles.  I was 16 and didn't want surgery, so I opted out of it.  I instead quit gymnastics and did extensive physical therapy.  No luck.  The should has had zero improvement and has been giving me increasing problems.  I have to wash my hair one handed because I cannot keep my other arm raised above my head that long.  I also can only drive with my right arm.  A few weeks ago I did a few tumbling passes out of curiosity and was thrilled when my shoulder only had mild pain and decent weakness afterwards.  However, the next day I was in so much pain I couldn't move my arm for two days.  Simple tasks with my arm always lead to a strong burning sensation around the part that rotates and a very very weak feeling.  My shoulder muscles leading up to my neck and around the upper part of my shoulder blade are always sore/tight and have many knots.  I can pop my shoulder around, but it never comes completely out of socket.  I also cannot raise my arm straight out in front of me above 45 degrees without popping it and then continuing up.  Does this sound like I have since torn the rotator cuff or is it possible it is still just stretched?  Could it be something else?   I really wanted to avoid surgery but I am afraid this is going to affect me caring for my children someday and having a health care career.  Also, if I have to have surgery, how long is the recovery? I am a full time college student who plans to graduate in 2009 and head straight to graduate school for 3-4 years.  It is really hard to find much time off school to have a surgery!  Thank you!
posted_time: Post  by misspuppychow » Sun Dec 02, 2007 11:54 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Misspuppychow,  The initial MRI that was done should have gotten a good look at your rotator cuff.  If you are able to get the report of it it may tell you that there is or is not a tear in the cuff.  The rotator cuff is made of several different muscles, tendons and ligaments so if one of them is torn it can cause your symptoms.  If surgery is needed, recovery time is variable but will most likely involve several months of physical therapy.  The answer to this really depends on how extensive the surgery needs to be.  I would recommend you see an orthopedic surgeon again to have your shoulder evaluated.  If there is a tear needing surgery, having surgery sooner rather than later is likely to improve success and decrease recovery time.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Mon Dec 03, 2007 7:02 pm

content: iam 27 female and i have a herniated extruded disc in midline and to the left at c5 - c6 with mild cord compression my left arm is very sore it has  been numb with tingling in my fingers for about 6 week now. i was just woundering what yr thoughts were on this .
posted_time: Post  by ash79 » Sat Sep 22, 2007 4:24 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Ash79,  You may want to talk with a neurosurgeon about this.  They would be best able to give you all the risks/benefits of surgery for your disk.  In general, I recommend avoiding spine surgery unless there is no other option.  Recovery from spinal surgery is long and there are often many complications.  Occasionally, the surgery ends up not improving the initial symptoms or simply exchanges them for other problems.  That being said, there are spinal surgeons because there are cases where surgery is an appropriate option.  I believe most surgeons would agree with me that surgery of the spine is not something to rush into so be sure to get all the information so you can make an educated decision.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by AngelTurtle » Fri Nov 16, 2007 8:10 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Angelturtle,  I suspect that the x-ray will again be normal.  They are often not particularly helpful for knee problems because most of the issues are with the cartilage of the knee, which doesn't show up on an x-ray.  However, it is a good first step since it is fast and easy.  If something does show up the MRI may not be necessary.  Most likely the MRI will be the best thing to answer the questions.  These lumps may be cysts although it seems a bit unlikely that all the areas are cysts.  They may also be small areas of scar tissue that have formed from the original injury.  The MRI should clear this up.  Seeing an orthopedic specialist may also be very beneficial.  Your knee giving out may or may not be related to this but there is a decent chance that it is at least partially connected.  Regarding the scoliosis, x-rays are fairly precise way to follow the scoliosis since the actual angle of curvature can be assessed objectively.  The physical examination may not pick up a slight scoliosis.  These are unlikely to progress much but it is worthwhile keeping an eye on periodically just to be sure.  Follow up with your doctor is important.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Fri Nov 16, 2007 10:46 pm

Over the past two months, I have had an X-ray and an MRI. I have seen my orthopedic doctor 3 times, and he referred me to another doctor to do an EMG. This doctor said there is not a severe problem with the nerve, but there is a problem.  My orthopedic doctor said the next step would probably be to see a hand surgeon (depending on the results of the EMG).  I teach middle school students with multiple disabilities, and I am really nervous about the thought of having surgery and having a substitute teacher with them. How long would the recovery process be, so that I could return to work? Any advice would be greatly appreciated!!! Thank you!

Seeing the hand surgeon will be helpful to give you all the information about treatment options.  Best wishes.

title: Hand pain in index finger tendon

author: Chrisgcma  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Sep 23, 2007 4:24 pm
title: Sudden onset of hip/groin pain
content: MY mother, who will be 70 in 12/07, had episode of severe left hip/groin pain upon getting out of bed...no history of a fall. The pain was so severe she could not put weight on her left leg or move/bend at the hip. Her doctor sent her for xrays suspecting a hip fx based on his exam.  Xrays were normal, sent her home with a pain med and muscle relaxer.  Two days later, she still has pain but is now able to walk.  The doctor has told me if does not get better he will order and MRI and look for vascular capuslitis.  Are there any other possibilities for this sudden onset of pain?  She does have a history of arthritis is multiple joints, HTN, Gerd, and is a heavy smoker.  Currently on Tylenol#3, Parafon Forte (new RXs), Toprol XL, Exforge, celebrex, prilosec, enablex, and lexapro.  She has never had surgery or previous injury to either hip.  She does have a history of herniated discs and a crushed disc in her lower back.
posted_time: Post  by Chrisgcma » Sun Sep 23, 2007 4:46 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Chrisgcma,  There are a few possibilities.  A stress fracture is possible and may not initially show up on x-rays.  If, after a week, her pain continues I would recommend a repeat x-ray.  At that point it is likely that a fracture may show up.  An MRI is also a good idea if the pain persists.  Other possibilities include a pulled muscle or a tendonitis/sinovitis.  The MRI can help look for these last two.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Fri Sep 28, 2007 3:22 pm

title: Severe hip pain upon awakening
content: I am 59 years old, female, and have been awakened on many occasions by severe pain in my left hip. I manage to sleep at least five hours and then the pain wakes me up. The strange thing about this is that when I get up and walk a short distance, ie the bathroom, and then get back into bed, the pain has subsided. I do not get the pain during the day when I am active, only early in the morning. I am sleeping on a new mattress so I don't think that would be the cause. I was quite active in sports when I was in college and walked alot well into my 40's.I have had no fractures and am in good health otherwise. Could this be arthritis or something else? I currently take 50 mg. Cozaar daily and 150 mg Armour thyroid for Hashimoto's.

author: dacubster  Guest Posts: 19 Joined: Sat Jan 13, 2007 9:56 pm
title: Reoccurent Shoulder Injury Problem
content: I am a 24 yr. old female with a history of asthma, hyperthroidism, inappropriate sinus tachycardia.    Seven years ago, I worked at a restaurant and a co-worker accidently tripped and dropped a 50 pound box on my left shoulder.  The weight of the box landed directly on top of my shoulder and the corner of the box went into the back of my shoulder blade.  I was in immediate pain and could not hold the arm up at all.  I went to the doctor the following morning, and an xray was normal.  He prescribed me pain killers, and told me to let it get better.  The pain was bad for almost a month and I could hardly move the affected arm.  Anyways, since that time the shoulder has been known to pop while moving.  It happened every once in a while over the years and it was more of a strange occurance than a nuisance.  However, within the last 7 months, it is popping constantly and being extremely sore for most of the day.  There is no one activity or movement I do that induces it.  In fact I can move it on my own and pop it numerous times.  I mentioned this to my primary care doctor who referred me for xrays (again normal) and then to an orthopedic surgeon.  THey also tried a round of steriods and then anti-inflammatories (which made my asthma flare up)  The interns who examined me were able to pop it numerous times just by pushing my shoulder back or turning my arm in a pitching type motion.  When the regular doctor examined me he was able to pop in a completely different place.  His initial thoughts were that there was a labral tear and a possible second injury related to the shoulder/neck.  He referred me for an MRI.  That day I was horribly achy from the repeated popping and it continued into the following morning.  While at work, I turned in one direction and that should snapped (loudly enough for my coworkers to hear) and I was in immediate pain.  I went back to my regular doctor who examined it, put me in a sling and ordered x-rays.  The x-rays again came back normal, and he suggested that my shoulder was just inflammed from the repeated motions from the orthopedic visit, and that I should wear the sling for a day or two and let it heal.  It's now been a week, and the pain seems to be increasing.  Not only is the shoulder completely sore, but I get almost a radiating pain in my bicep and forearm region.  It varies with intensity, but basically I am still not able to extend my arm at all without severe pain.    I am not scheduled for the MRI and follow-up ortho. appt. until next month, and I am wondering if possibly something is missing here?  Any suggestions?  Also, is there a usual cause for a shoulder to pop (it feels like it goes out of place/but the doctor said it's not dislocated), and is the usual treatment for this kind of injury surgery?  Thank you in advance.
posted_time: Post  by dacubster » Sat Nov 10, 2007 6:57 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Dacubster,  Often, shoulder popping is due to a tendon slipping over part of the shoulder.  In your case, there may be some scar tissue or bony spurs that have formed from the original trauma that are now causing pain.  The MRI will be very helpful.  If your pain continues to get worse I would suggest you see your doctor for a follow up.  It may be possible to expedite the work up for you.    Treatment often will not require surgery but may.  Many times, rest and physical therapy can be helpful.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Sat Nov 10, 2007 10:40 pm

author: xyzp  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Sep 01, 2007 6:07 pm
title: Pain and twinging feeling in wrist
content: I'm a 30 year-old male. In December of last year, I hit my wrist really hard against a wooden desk. I hit the knobby part on the outer side of the wrist. I went to a doctor who did x-rays and said nothing was broken or fractured. He said that a nerve runs right along the place where I hit my wrist, but that any injury I might have would get better on its own.  I didn't have much of a problem until around July of this year. I noticed a dull pain in my wrist and an odd twinging feeling, as if my fingers were about to move on their own. Also my wrist got sore easily, sometimes with a burning sensation, when doing something like using a computer mouse. I saw another doctor at the same office, who told me my wrist was just sore and that I should wear a splint. That was about three weeks ago. I wore the splint all the time for a little over two weeks, and I've been still wearing it most of the time.  I think the splint might have helped the soreness, but it doesn't seem to have cured the twinging feeling, which may be worse than before. I feel pain specifically at the same part of my wrist, and the twinging feeling in my fingers. I don't feel it much when I wear the splint, but when it's off and I use that hand, the feeling comes back. However, I think sometimes the splint intensifies the feeling because it presses against that part of my wrist. Sometimes I have a hard time getting to sleep because I can't find a position for my arm that doesn't cause my wrist to hurt. I don't know if the splint is helping or hurting overall.  I'm not sure what to do. I'm not in constant unbearable pain, but something isn't right.
posted_time: Post  by xyzp » Fri Sep 14, 2007 12:07 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Xyzp,  It is possible that there initially was a very small fracture that was missed on the first x-rays.  This can happen when the fracture is small and is not out of place.  In this case, it may be that a callous has formed where the fracture was that is now pressing in the nerve.  Depending on where your tingling is, carpal tunnel syndrome or another over-use type syndrome is also possible and may be unrelated to the initial trauma.  This seems less likely given the pain is in the same area as the trauma.  Seeing an orthopedic surgeon again is probably the best thing for you at this point.  You may need some repeat x-rays or an MRI of the area to help figure out why you are having these symptoms.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Thu Oct 25, 2007 5:34 pm

title: [no title]
content: Hi Providence210,  Some GI issues such as Crohn's disease can present with arthritis but the issues you are describing are unlikely to be related to a GI problem. author: eddywolf  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Oct 22, 2007 11:45 am
title: Spinal column fusion(at end of puberty)
content: I'm not certain if this is the correct place to be posting my question, but this is the closest i could find.  I went through puberty at a later than usual age(17), and i was wondering if i will continue to grow to my genetic natural  height, or, because puberty happened relatively late, my growth will be lessened.    I heard that around the age of 20 the spinal column fuses. Will this limit my growth or is it, only at the end of puberty the fusion takes place? Thanks.
posted_time: Post  by eddywolf » Mon Oct 22, 2007 12:10 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Eddywolf,  Actually, those who go through puberty later than others tend to be taller than average.  The reason for this that the bones grow more before hitting their growth spurt during puberty.  Once puberty is over the growth plates of the bones close essentially ending growth.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Wed Oct 24, 2007 11:28 pm

author: Layla  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Sat Sep 01, 2007 10:56 am
title: Anterior angulation of the acromion
content: I hope I'm posting this in the right category - I asked a question last week regarding blood tests from ER visit for a shoulder problem and this one relates  to the MRI report from the shoulder, I didn't think it should go in the same thread - sorry if I should have posted there....  One month ago I awoke with acute L shoulder pain, went to PCM, ordered xrays and MRI, sent me home with vicadin.  About 24 hours later, I went to ER due to horrific pain, ROM of 2 degrees, was given IV anti-inflammatories and morphine.   The sharp pain continued for the next couple of weeks and was unable to move my arm.  A couple weeks after initial onset, I accidently put weight on the shoulder and felt a pop, shortly thereafter, the sharp pain subsided (still had achy pain) and I was able to move my arm again, with limited ROM due to pain.    I received my MRI report today at my (first) visit with the Ortho and was told everything looked fine, that he wasn't sure what has caused the problem, but listed off several possibilities.  Was told to continue Naproxen for one month (been on it for one month so far), take muscle relaxers 2x daily for a month (my muscles are spasming and I have lumps in two areas), and continue physical therapy.  However, once I got home and read the report, one sentence stood out.  Everything else on report was normal.  "On coronal images, there is anterior angulation of the acromion with mild impingement on the suprapinatous tendon."  I understand the impingement, but what is the anterior angulation?  Also, my xrays, taken on 8-5, show calcium deopsit in bursa v. tendon, but do not show on MRI, taken 8-23.  Doc says the MRI did not show this view?  and that possibly the "pop" was dislodging the calcium and it moved down my arm, hence the pain there.......Does this make sense?  I'm feeling somewhat uneasy with this Doc as I was the one who pointed out the calcium and impingement in the first place after he said there was nothing on the MRI, and he never even looked at the xray until I urged him...I am just looking for a little reassurance.  Thank You.
posted_time: Post  by Layla » Wed Sep 05, 2007 6:22 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Layla,  Unfortunately, this is not my area of expertise so I'll basically need to say that I would recommend you see an orthopedic specialist for a second opinion if you are still concerned.  Anterior angulation means the joint is angled towards the front of the body.  This may have been due to a mild dislocation (but, again, this is not my specialty so this is a bit of a speculation).  I cannot comment on the possibility of dislodging the calcium deposit in the tendon.  Sorry I can't be of more help to you.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: I don't know of specific techniques or products for flattening your shoulders, but low back pain often responds to toning of the abdominal muscles which support the back.  If I were you that is where I would concentrate my initial efforts.  Exercises such as situps can help.    Also, you may want to wear one of the elastic support belts people often use when lifting heavy objects.  It can really help protect your back when you labor.  If you get accustomed to wearing one of those whenever you work, you may find it to be helpful.    For posture, it is really just a matter of committing yourself to being conscious of this problem and working at doing better. I don't know of any special products for it.  A determined effort to sit up straight at all times and not slump over when sitting, standing, walking, etc. should help over time.  At your age, you can probably make a difference this way.  Be sure you are also getting enough calcium and vitamin D for your bone health.  If you use dairy products, this can usually be obtained that way.    Best wishes.

title: Numbness & Pain in side of foot
content: I'm 22, female, no known foot injuries in the past, no surgeries or family history that is foot related, am on birth control.    Well, The other day I stood up, apparently stood up wrong because I felt something pop in my right foot.  There has been pain in my foot, Below the protruding part of your ankle on the OUTSIDE of my foot.  I figured I just pulled it or sprained it, but then last night I noticed my pinkie toe & top of my foot were numb.  Could this have to do with what I did to my ankle/foot?  Is there any reason to see a doctor or can I just wear an ace bandage and make sure I stay off my foot?
posted_time: Post  by lindzyb » Thu Oct 18, 2007 11:17 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Lindzyb,  When you stepped wrong you may have stretched a nerve causing your pain and numbness.  If it is just a stretched nerve it is likely to get better.  If, by chance, the nerve was severed it needs to be addressed as soon as possible to see if the nerve can be repaired.    I'd suggest that you have this evaluated to get a better sense of the possible nerve damage.  It is much more likely that this is simply a stretched nerve but its best to be sure.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Thu Oct 18, 2007 10:37 pm

author: peabody  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Sep 22, 2007 3:01 am
title: WEIRD: Change in height after sex
content: I'm 29/M and my wife is a 25/F. I'm typically about 1.5 cm taller than my wife, but in the last month we've noticed that shortly after sex, the height difference is diminished or reversed. Typically she ends up being about half a centimeter taller than me. We find it rather amusing, but I'm left wondering: "am I shrinking or is she getting taller?" I've never heard of anything like this before, and within a matter of hours, our heights are back to normal. Any ideas?
posted_time: Post  by peabody » Sat Sep 22, 2007 3:10 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Peabody,  This is a bit interesting.  Perhaps it has to do with your or your wifes musculature being relaxed causing some changes in the positioning  of the way you are standing.  You may want to measure yourselves before and after to see who is "changing" height.  I've never heard of this happening before but it may all be related to muscle tension changes.  For example, if the muscles of the body are more relaxed it may be that your wife is standing taller rather than hunching slightly if she does hunch.  It may also be that your muscles are tightening a bit causing you to hunch slightly more than usual.  I can't say this is a definite cause but it's about the only theory I can come up with.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Sat Oct 06, 2007 2:10 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi DavidHam,  Your pain may be due to a chronic overuse type syndrome.  These can be particularly exacerbated by doing a lot of walking on hard floors without adequate cushioning.  You may want to see a sports medicine doctor or an orthopedic surgeon for an evaluation.  (Probably the sports med. doc will be of more help, if possible.)  Also, be sure you have quality, cushioned shoes for work.    Best wishes.

title: [no title]
content: Hi Duluv2dance76,  Your pain sounds like it may be nerve related.  I don't think it is sciatica specifically as this would generally give leg pain also. title: [no title]
content: Hi CVish,  What you are seeing may be a lipoma, a non-cancer fat cell tumor that generally is harmless.  Occasionally they can become large or cause pain due to being irritated.
