author: Carol59  Guest Posts: 9 Joined: Sat Aug 11, 2007 2:18 pm
title: Muscle Atrophy
content: I noticed awhile back that I had a slight indentation to the left of my right shin (I think it's called tibialis anterior) and now it seems to have gotten a little deeper and longer in length.  I don't know if I always had this and just never noticed but it does seem to have expanded.  I don't have any pain or weakness, just this indentation.  I have been very inactive the last two years but I don't know what exercises affect the front of your calf anyway.  I plan on seeing a doctor but don't know where to begin - orthopedist? neurologist? internist?  Do you have any ideas on what it could be?  Thank you very much.
posted_time: Post  by Carol59 » Tue Sep 18, 2007 4:49 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Carol59,  You may be noticing an area of local atrophy (or shrinking) in the muscle or, more likely, the subcutaneous tissues (fat, etc.).  This is actually a fairly common occurrence.  It can be induced by trauma to the area.  It may be that some time ago you hit your leg in that area and it subsequently caused the atrophy to develop.  These areas are rarely symptomatic and are basically incidental findings.  If you notice that it is getting bigger at a fast rate or much bigger in size you should have it evaluated sooner.  Otherwise it is fine to wait until your next check up and ask your doctor to take a look.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Wed Sep 19, 2007 1:24 am

author: lolabelle  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Mon Aug 20, 2007 7:50 am
title: After foot surgery -- how long to build back muscle in leg?
content: Hello everyone,  I'm a 22-year-old female who just had bunion surgery (osteotomy) on her right foot five days ago.  Since then, my foot's been in a cast. It'll stay in this cast until I reach the two-week mark (i.e. 11 more days). For the third week following, I'll be in a walking cast with a "negative heel" that puts all weight on my heel (i.e. not on my former bunion). At the start of the fourth week, I can start using oversized shoes to start walking/waddling around.  Starting that fourth week, my surgeon says, I can also start swimming for an hour every day, to start to re-build muscle strength in my leg and to re-habilitate my foot.  Here's my question -- today, just 5 days following my surgery, I can already feel that the muscle in my right leg has altered completely (when compared to my left leg which I am using normally) -- it has lost shape and strength. My legs are among the few body parts I am pleased with, and would like to know how long I can expect it to take until my right leg will look like my left leg again. Assuming that I will be swimming every day for an hour after having not used it for three weeks, and, of course, walking around like usual. And how soon can I start other forms of exercise (say, weight-training or yoga)?  Thank you!
posted_time: Post  by lolabelle » Mon Aug 20, 2007 8:57 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Lolabelle,  It will probably take several weeks to get your muscle strength back after the cast is removed.  Start exercising gradually and don't over do it so you don't end up with a muscle strain.  I am not sure how long your doctor will recommend waiting before beginning more complex exercises such as weight training and yoga.  I would recommend asking your surgeon about this.  Best wishes.

author: xXcenobiteXx  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Sep 10, 2007 12:06 am
title: Hip/leg pain
content: Hey there.  I'm a 19 (almost 20) year old female.  I know nothing of my family history on my mom's side (she was adopted), but I haven't found anyone on my dad's side that has had the same problem as me.  About 3 months ago I woke up and couldn't move because my hip was in a lot of pain, and it's been ongoing since then.  I can't do any of my normal activities, because it hurts almost 24/7.  I went to a doctor, and he thought I had pulled my groin, which I didn't agree with, so I went to a chiropractor, and she had suggested hip cancer. The pain starts in my hip joint and pulses down my leg.  When it pulses down my leg, the pain is emphasized in my knee, ankle, and naturally, my hip.  I've had x-rays and ultrasounds done, but nothing has showed up so far.  The only medications I'm taking is Ventilin and Minovral.  This is very frustrating and I'd love a couple opinions!
posted_time: Post  by xXcenobiteXx » Mon Sep 10, 2007 12:29 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi  xXcenobiteXx,  There are a few possibilities for your pain.  First, cancer of the hip is possible but much, much less likely than some of the other things.  It is possible that you may have a stress fracture or some arthritis of the hip, although it would be unusual to wake up suddenly with these.  It may also be that you have a compressed nerve in your back causing the hip and leg pain.  The pulsing pain you describe shooting down your leg is pretty consistent with nerve type pain.  Another possibility is that you have some pulled ligaments or tendons in the hip joint although it would be unusual for this pain to continue for 3 months.  I would recommend you see an orthopedic surgeon for an evaluation.  These are the muscle/bone experts and are likely to be able to help you get answers.  You may also need better imaging of the hip joint with an MRI.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Mon Sep 10, 2007 8:14 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Volleyballinjury,  Am I correct that she is having pain in both legs?  If so, this may be a lower back problem, potentially aggravated by the jumping and activity.  it may also be an overuse injury lower in the legs that is causing problems (particularly if she has grown a lot fast).  I would recommend she see her doctor for an evaluation of this.  If there is a sports medicine specialist in the area this really would be an excellent resource to help determine what is going on.  One note, sometimes athletes will take some pain medicine then go out and exercise or play sports.  This can actually make the issue worse because the problem is still there but the pain is taken away so the player doesn't realize the injury is getting worse.  Try to avoid having her do this.  If the team has a trainer or physical therapist it is also going to be helpful for her to really stretch the areas well before and after practice/activity.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by Matt7723 » Sun Aug 19, 2007 8:43 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Matt7723,  In some people, some of the ribs can stick out more than others.  This is considered a normal variation and, as long as there are no symptoms from it, no treatment is needed.  It likely is mostly genetic in terms of a cause.  The bump at the bottom of the sternum you are seeing may be the xiphoid process.  It is a small bone attached to the end of the sternum.  In some people it can be angled forward away from the spine.  Again, this is a normal thing and does not cause problems.  In some people this can be quite significant causing some cosmetic issues as you are describing.  There really isn't a great treatment for this issue.  Best wishes.

author: Mutant1981  Guest Posts: 16 Joined: Tue May 15, 2007 1:36 pm
title: Bone cracking and popping
content: 25/M Every so often it feels like I need to crack my neck, ankles by swirling them until I feel it. My knuckles sometimes. Of course a lot of people do this! Is it a bone tension build up on those certain areas from veryday activities and you just need to crack it for a more relaxed feeling, what exactly is happening when you crack, pop a bone/joint?
posted_time: Post  by Mutant1981 » Mon Aug 06, 2007 12:03 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Scientists say that synovial fluid containing oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon dioxide is present in your joints and acts as a lubricant. When you pop or crack a joint, you stretch the joint capsule, causing a rapid release of gas which forms bubbles. It's the bursting of these bubbles that causes the popping sound.  In order to crack the same knuckle again, you have to wait until the gases return to the synovial fluid (25 to 30 minutes).  Another cause of  this "cracking" is the movement of joints, tendons and ligaments: When a joint moves, the tendon’s position changes and moves slightly out of place. You may hear a snapping sound as the tendon returns to its original position.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Sat Aug 18, 2007 6:43 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Mikem,  It sounds like you need to visit a doctor.  It is very likely that you again have shin splints or a stress fracture.  You may need to see a sports medicine physician or an orthopedic surgeon for further evaluation on how to best prevent this from happening.  Your doctor can also help control the pain.  Here's the key with pain medicine and these types of injuries: often the people who get these injuries are driven to play sports or exercise.  When the pain is made better by medicine, they go out and exercise hard again.  This only worsens the injury.  When you take pain meds for such an injury it is important to rest during that time to avoid worsening the injury while the pain is masked.  Best wishes.

Xray shows nothing.  Dr. stated originally Patella Femoral.  PT sent me back to Dr. because of pain, locking of left knee and swelling.  Had an MRI.  MRI states:  degenerative fissuring involving the articular surface of the medial femoral condyle with minimal focal underlying subchondral edema.  Focal cartilage defect invoves the far posterior medial femoral condyle with a small osteophyte. Intrasubstance degenerative signal withing both anterior and posterior horns of the lateral meniscus.  Can you please explain what exactly this means in layman's terms?  Thank you so very much
posted_time: Post  by kzak4151 » Tue Jul 24, 2007 4:04 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Kzak4151,  It appears that the cartilage in your knee is wearing down.  On the inner side there is an area that is wearing probably due to a small bone spur.  On the outerside (the lateral meniscus) appears to be breaking down also.  I suspect this is probably the beginnings of osteoarthritis.  Cartilage can wear out overtime, especially if there is repeated trauma to the area.  I would recommend you see an orthopedic surgeon for an evaluation of your knee and MRI to see if there are treatments that might help.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: HI Kelz1986,  Sometimes pain as you are describing is related to muscle tightness that pulls on the knee and its attachments all day long.  The pain is often worse at night because you are resting and all the activity of the day catches up.  Occasionally it is actually the other leg that has the problem and the pain is coming from the good leg trying to compensate for the muscle tightness of the other leg.  I would recommend you see a sports medicine physician.  If one is not available in your area you may want to see an orthopedic surgeon.  These are the muscle/bone experts.  Best wishes.

author: softballer  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sun Jul 22, 2007 4:01 pm
title: Finger pain in female fastpitch pitcher
content: I am a 22-year-old fastpitch softball pitcher and am experiencing pain in the pointer finger of my pitching hand. The middle knuckle of this finger is noticeably swollen, especially on the side of the knuckle closest to my middle finger. The outer side of the knuckle is also swollen, though not as much. The finger is stiff and I have less range of motion in it than in my other pointer finger--I cannot bend it all the way. The knuckle is also tender to the touch. It seems to be more painful as I am warming up to pitch, after games, and the day after I pitch a game.   Are there any ideas as to what this might be or what I could do to make it better? (I have tried icing and ibuprofen.) I have 4-5 weeks left in my season, and cannot afford to take time off. However, I do not want to risk doing permanent damage to my finger. Any ideas would be greatly appreciated.
posted_time: Post  by softballer » Sun Jul 22, 2007 4:24 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Softballer,  There are several possibilities for your pain.  It is possible that you have "jammed" your knuckle which really means you've hyperextended or somehow otherwise overused the joint.  Another possibility would be a stress fracture.    The best management strategy really depends on what actually caused the pain/swelling.  Given you are continually using the finger to pitch a stress fracture is quite possible.  I would recommend you have an x-ray done to look for this.  No matter what the cause, a big part of getting your finger better is going to be resting it as much as you can.    I would recommend you see a doctor for an evaluation of your finger to get the best recommendations about how to treat it.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Mon Jul 23, 2007 1:01 am

The pain is something that has developed over the course of the season. I did have a period of about 2-3 weeks of time off. When I started practicing and playing again, the finger pain was still there.  If this were a stress fracture, would I still be able to use the finger to pitch, as I am now? Also, the swelling that I mentioned on the side of my knuckle closest to my middle finger is hard; it's not like the soft fluid build-up one would have with a sprained ankle, for example. I know you can't make a diagnosis without actually examining the finger, but I am just trying to determine the likelihood of a stress fracture. Thanks again!
posted_time: Post  by softballer » Mon Jul 23, 2007 4:24 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi again,  I agree that if you had jammed it you would remember.  It's hard to miss something like that.  It may still be that you have a stress fracture, though.  Having a fracture would not necessarily limit you so you were unable to pitch with it.  Continuing to pitch with a stress fracture may cause the fracture to get worse to the point where the pain is too much to pitch, however.  I think your finger is in need of an x-ray.  If it is positive, you can get proper treatment.  If it is negative your doctor can pursue what may be going on.  Best wishes.

content: Hi Holistic-lady,  Do you have joint stiffness also?  And, does it get better throughout the day?  I ask because your symptoms make me very suspicious of rheumatoid arthritis.  If you have a skin condition known as psoriasis there is a related condition known as psoriatic arthritis that may also be causing your pain.  In a small number of cases, the rheumatoid factor may be negative.  I would also recommend testing your ESR and CRP (markers of inflammation).  X-rays can be done to look for osteoarthritis if they did not look for this on the initial x-rays.  I would recommend you continue to follow up with your primary care doctor.  Perhaps your doctor can discuss your case over the phone with a rheumatologist to get some more advice while you are waiting to see the specialist.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by momofkneepain » Mon Jul 09, 2007 8:39 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I think the key to being able to answer your question regarding how best to treat this lies in what actually is causing your pain.  If you have a torn meniscus (cartilage pad) in the knee this can cause significant pain and a "catching" sensation.  Scar tissue may also be a factor.  These things may be more treatable with surgery.  If the problem is due to some arthritis of the knee (quite common after injury) surgery is likely to do more harm than good.    I'm a little surprised that the MRI didn't show anything.  You may want to consider seeing a sports medicine doctor to see if there are some muscular components to your pain.  Getting a second opinion from another surgeon is always reasonable simply as a fresh look at the case.  I do understand your surgeon's hesitancy to do more surgery since each surgery adds to the chances of scar tissue or complications developing.  I hope you are able to get some relief.  Best wishes.

author: dixie05  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Wed Mar 07, 2007 8:56 pm
title: Bunionectomy post-surgery swelling
content: I am a 57-yr old female who had bunionectomy with 1 hammertoe correction on 5/14/07. I returned to work on 07/02/07 where I must be on my feet 8-9 hours a day. I am wearing a surgical stocking and good sneaker, but my ankle and calf swell a lot during the day. After I get home I use ice packs and elevate the foot. By the next morning it is okay. Is there anything I can do to aleviate this problem?
posted_time: Post  by dixie05 » Sun Jul 08, 2007 7:02 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: What you are describing is known as dependent edema.  If it is occuring in both feet I would strongly recommend you see your doctor to have your heart checked out to make sure it is doing OK.  Sometimes when the heart is not pumping well it can lead to dependent edema.  If it only involves the leg that the surgery was on it is a little more complicated.  It may be that the area still has some inflammation in it preventing normal circulation and uptake of the lymphatic fluid (fluid that normally leaks out of the blood vessels into the soft tissue that subsequently is picked up by the lymphatic tissue).  It is also possible that during the surgery one or more of the larger lymphatic vessels was cut.  Both these issues should resolve over time.  If it is not improving (at least slowly but steadily) I would recommend you follow up with your surgeon for an evaluation.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Wed Jul 18, 2007 4:50 pm

title: infection over titanium plate?
content: Hi everyone   About 4 months ago I broke my clavicle in 4 places.I then had the clavicle plated with 9 screws to hold everything together.The bone is almost completely healed and I got released to go back to work.                                                                        For several weeks I had "bruised looking ,thin skined area"on my surgical scar. I was swimming with the kids for a couple of hours and when I dried off a small hole appeared in my "bruised area".I could see my titanium plate clearly.Needless to say I went to the doctor ASAP.My doctor called it skin breakdown,I call it skin breakdown due to infection.     His procedure was to cut the infected area out(about the size of a penny)and stretch the skin and sew me back up.My concern is another surgeon told me this procedure wouldnt work.Any input would be extremely appreciated.
posted_time: Post  by steve f » Thu Jul 12, 2007 3:45 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I am not particularly knowledgeable about this subject but I'll offer what I know.  If you have any other signs of infection, such as redness, tenderness, discharge or swelling you will most likely need to take antibiotics to help clear up the infection.  If none of these are present it may be that the skin was not actually infected but simply was not strong enough to heal well.  In this case, removing the weakened area and reclosing the incision may be enough.  I would recommend close follow up with your surgeon and watch for any signs of infection.  If it appears that infection is developing I would recommend you see your doctor for an evaluation and antibiotics as soon as you are able to prevent the infection from getting bad.  Best wishes.

title: Rotator Cuff:  Surgery vs. Rehabilitation?
content: Hello,  I am a 24 year old female.  Recently I went in for family doctor visit and complained of left shoulder pain that radiates down my left arm, and into my back and chest areas.  Because of my previous problems with tachycardia they ruled out it being hurt related.  THe doctor performed a brief exam.  Pressure forced onto that arm was painful.  Rotating the arm the full length around led to considerable pain and continuous clicking/popping sounds in the region.  My guess at cause for the pain was an injury occurring 8 yrs earlier.  A co-worker dropped a 25 pound box onto the shoulder and the corner of the box went into the back of my shoulder blade.  A clinic doctor x-rayed it and said he didn't see anything (a MRI was not performed).  Instead I was put in a sling, given painkillers, and painfully went through the next couple of months.  My current doctor thinks the original injury tore something, but wasn't seen because I was not given an MRI.  Furthermore, from his assessment, he thinks that my rotator cuff may completely torn.  He didn't offer many suggestions, but suggested I talk with an orthopedic surgeon and get an MRI.  My question is how do they usually decide who is a better candidate for surgery, versus strictly going through rehabilitation exercises for the injury.  I am wondering if the long time frame (8 years) will have any effect on what type of treatment options I may have?  Thanks for any advice.
posted_time: Post  by dacubster » Fri Jul 13, 2007 8:32 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I would agree that you need to see an orthopedic surgeon and have an MRI done of your shoulder.    In deciding how to proceed with treatment (surgery vs. conservative therapy) many factors are taken into account.  These include: what is damaged and how badly is it damaged?  Is there potential for worsening illness if it is not repaired or will it heal well?  What will the future activity levels be for the patient and will these activities be putting significant stress on the rotator cuff or not?  In the end it comes down to a decision that must be made between you and your surgeon.  Best wishes.

title: Waking up becaus of neck pain
content: 34 Male with reverse curvature in neck. No family history (adoption) and not on any meds other than ibuprofen or asprin when needed. Past surgeries shoulder and knee (rotator cup and cartlidge tear).  I wake up in the middle of the night and I can not seem to move my neck for a short amount of time. It is not like a stiff neck where there is muscle soreness,because after a minute or so I have full range of motion again and I am fine after that. It happens frequently and disrupts my sleep frequently. My head is usually turned one way or another when I sleep and I use a tempurpedic pillow. I know I have what they call "military neck" or reverse curvature and I have had it for years and I work with my chiropractor on that issue, but as of recent the waking up because I can't move my neck is getting worse.
posted_time: Post  by rennikcks » Thu May 31, 2007 3:39 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I suspect it may be related to muscle pain when you are sleeping that causes stiffness in the muscle.  It may also be related to the curvature of your spine getting into a position that is causing difficulty moving.  I would recommend you see an orthopedic surgeon for an evaluation.  They are the bone and muscle specialists and would probably be most qualified to figure out what is going on with your neck.  The other option would be to see a sports medicine specialist.  Best wishes.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Pandi999, Sometimes the pain we experience can have a root in simple physics.  Without being able to assess you in person, it is difficult to determine exactly what part of your body "under your collarbone" hurts as you describe. But I would like to throw out a possibility for you to consider.  You state you have been having this problem for about 3-4 years, which means they began as far as you remember when you were about 15 or 16 years old.  Young women who may be "late bloomers" with accelerated breast development in their mid and late teens, need to use special bras when playing competitive sports - especially ones in which running plays a large part. "Well-endowed" women are particularly at risk. There can be a strain on the pectoral muscles with the movement of the breast tissue without adequate support.  You may wish to consider investing in a good sports bra and see if that helps.

author: smile23  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri May 18, 2007 3:07 am
title: Chronic Arm Pain
content: I am a 23 year old male. I have no past surgical medical history nor am I on any medication. I am posting here because I cannot post in the sports medicine forum. For the last couple of years I have experienced excrutiating pain in my throwing arm after throwing. It does not always occur but most often occurs when I throw several days in sucession. It is like my arm does not recover. Often if I do not throw for a couple days the arm feels fresh and strong when I resume throwing.The pain often sets in after I am done throwing and the arm hangs at my side. It is a slow, pulsating pain that is often nauseating. The pain is annoying across the medial side of the elbow(from the inner forearm to the inner tricep) and extreme in the laterall head of the tricep(long head) which ties into the elbow. My arm goes extremley cold, my forearm, triceps, and bicep become extremley soft, my arm shakes violentley, and the velocity at which I can throw the baseball is extremley reduced. It is hard for me to grab things. I am right handed but structuraly my right arm feels unstable, the area surronding my right elbow also seems to be smaller and have less muscle surronding it compared to my left arm. My right tricep is not as defined as left especialy where it ties into the elbow. At this point there seems to be a hard mass covering the area where the tricep ties into the elbow. Oddly enough my arm strength has steadily been improving. Latley I have had the feeling that my arm has died I am not getting the same carry or velocity on the ball as I have been. Also the pain is not as extreme as it has been in the past. I do not pitch. I will be seeing a specialist on the 24th but I have the feeling that they are going to simply tel me to use the R.I.C.E. method. As I live in a country with public medicine they reserve things such as MRI's for emergency situations. I know this is a lengthy post and I also realize that sports medicine may not be your field but i'm hoping that you may be able to provide some ideas as to what the orgin of the pain my be. Thank you for your time.
posted_time: Post  by smile23 » Fri May 18, 2007 3:58 am

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Smile23, Have you discussed lateral epicondylitis (more commonly known as "tennis elbow") with your primary care doctor?  The mechanism if injury is in keeping with your passion for pitching.  The concern is that if it is indeed lateral epicondylitis, it may be a degenerative process that is exacerbated (made worse) by your continuing the repetitive throwing movements that may have caused the original injury.  The fact that you experience some relief when you rest the arm, and that it starts to "act up" when you actively use it again, seems to support this supposition. You may need to see if extended rest may allow the tendons to heal.  You may also want to consider that if your passion is contributing to your problem, you may need to find another passion.

title: Opposite of trigger finger?
content: I am a 55 year old female with Hairy Cell Leukemia (treated in 2005) and osteoarthritis.  Recently, upon waking, my middle finger of my right hand feels swollen and is bent down in a closed hand position.  I have to consciously release it and then it will stick again a few more times until I have opened and closed my hand several times.  I have pain in my shoulders, arms and hands which seemed to increase after chemo with Cladribine, but this finger phenomenon is new.  I read about trigger finger, but my situation seems opposite.  Any ideas?
posted_time: Post  by edcarta » Tue Jun 26, 2007 8:03 am

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear edcarta, Osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis are two different manifestations of arthritis (inflammation in the joints).  The interesting thing about them is that there is a generalized way to differentiate them from a lay person's perspective.  Osteoarthritis is one where there is pain and limitations in movement when beginning activity from a rest, which gets better when the affected limb is loosened up. In other words, the condition is worsened by rest and alleviated/improved by movement. Rheumatoid arthritis, oppositely, is worsened by movement and improved by rest.  What you are describing, coupled with your statement that you already have been diagnosed with osteoarthritis, seems to strongly lean toward this "finger" phenomenon being a flare up of your arthritis. The fact that you are able to release the "frozen" joint with first passive then active range of motion, certainly strengthens my supposition.  The best thing to do is keep active, keep all your joints mobile, maybe explore some of the OTC (over the counter) joint support neutraceuticals, and be sure to let your doctor know that your symptoms seem to be getting a little more complex, and aggravating.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am

content: Dear JayC55, Muscles begin to atrophy as quickly as within 12 hours of inactivity. Since you indicated you had nearly 2 and 1/2 months of inactivity I am not surprised that you notice a smaller Left Leg than Right and have also discovered how easily these atrophied limbs can be injured! A strong commitment to recovering your pre-injury strength and flexibility is the best key to achieving our goal!

author: femalehelpinghand  Guest Posts: 6 Joined: Tue Feb 28, 2006 9:55 pm
title: Carpal Tunnel
content: I have just found out I have carpal tunnel in my right hand.  I am using the wrist supports as I have been told to use.  If I wear these all the time will this possibly help heal this?  I am 70 years old and question if this surgery could help me at his age.  Any information on this would be appreciated.
posted_time: Post  by femalehelpinghand » Sun Jun 17, 2007 10:36 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  The median nerve which innervates muscles of the hand runs from the forearm into the hand crossing over the wrist joint.  When the nerve is squeezed at the wrist, numbness and pain in the muscles supplied by the nerve occur, a condition known as Carpal tunnel syndrome.  Carpal tunnel syndrome is usually due to increased pressure on the median nerve and tendons in the carpal tunnel and not due to an injury in the nerve itself.  The carpal tunnel is smaller in some people leading to congenital predisposition to the syndrome.   Factors involved in the disorder include: -  Direct trauma or injury to the wrist resulting in swelling that adds pressure on the median nerve. -  Swellings due to hormonal disturbances like pituitary gland hyperactivity; hypothyroidism; rheumatoid arthritis; -  Work stress, repetitive movement can cause tendonitis. -  Fluid retention due to hormonal changes  - In some cases there is no apparent cause.    Treatments for carpal tunnel syndrome are preferred to start as early as possible. Underlying causes should be treated first.    General measures include: - Rest of the affected hand and wrist for at least 2 weeks and immobilizing the wrist in a splint to avoid further damage from twisting or bending.   - Medications like NSAID - Finally surgery is recommended to complicated persistent cases for 6 month after conservative measures.  In the majority of cases rest through immobilization using a splint and other conservative measures will alleviate symptoms.  Age per se is not a contraindication for this type of operation if the general condition allows. Surgery however, is a decision taken by the neurosurgeon after complete physical examination and proper investigations to confirm the underlying cause and to exclude any contraindication for surgery.  I advise you to follow with your doctor. Keep us updated, Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Mon Jun 18, 2007 12:30 pm

content: It sounds as if you have a hematoma under the skin.  A hematoma is a collection of blood that then clots.  Most likely, the blow to your leg was just right to cause a blood vessel to break resulting in the hematoma formation.  These are not dangerous and will eventually go away.  If the pain is not improving you should see your doctor to verify that there isn't something more going on, such as a small fracture.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  This could be Posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) palsy.  This is due to injury of a branch of the radial nerve that supply muscles of the hand on the dorsal surface that result in motor dysfunction. It is uncommon but seen after trauma or iatrogenic during fixation of fractures ordeep traumatic injuries ( nearby the tendon of the biceps).  Traumatic PIN palsy have three types:  of them Type I complete PIN palsy affects extension of the wrist ,at the metacarpo-phalangeal joints of all the fingers and the thumb, and weak abduction of the thumb.  Type II the xtension of the little and ring fingers are lost sparing the index, thumb and middle fingers.  Type III  the index and the thumb extension is lost and loss of abduction of the thumb sparing the other fingers. (as in your case)  Radiographs to detect  forearm fractures, dislocations or instabilities and EMGs (3 weeks after damage may become abnormal) are helpful in the diagnosis.  A 6- to 12-week waiting period is followed by some doctors,if there is no recover of function, exploration of the nerve is indicated.  Exploration and primary or delayed primary repair or nerve grafting is performed if complete nerve damage occur. The results depend on the nature of the wound and the extent of nerve injury.   Keep us updated. Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Thu Dec 21, 2006 6:07 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  In fact, distal rupture of the biceps tendon may be disabling (the traumatic injury or the surgical trauma).  Successful surgery mandates an attention for possible complications like nerve injury and ectopic bone formation.   Single-incision technique is one of the approaches aiming to avoid as possible fixation damage, avoids PIN injury, and minimal ectopic bone formation although injury of the radial nerve is still of consideration.  I hope, it is just a mild injury and you will recover soon. Keep us updated. Best regards.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Nerve axonal regeneration takes place in 4 phases. Only in the third phase, the axons elongate beyond the site of injury till the distal peripheral target with restoration of function.  Thus direction of regeneration goes from site of injury to periphery till complete recovery of conduction.  The duration ranges from 6-18 months, according to the nerve length as well as the site of the lesion.  Keep us updated. Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Sun Jan 21, 2007 4:57 pm

content: It may be that one of the blood vessels in your knuckle burst.  This causes bleeding beneath the skin and subsequent bruising. title: Knee clicking and grinding with no pain
content: I am a 32 year old dancer. I have been dancing for 14 years. In my early 20s I had severe knee pain with swelling. I went to an orthopedic surgeon...I believe he said (it was very long ago!) I had torn tendons or ligaments under the knee cap and recommended I stop dancing or always wear a brace. Instead of listening to his advice I went with acupuncture. I have had no swelling or pain since except sometimes when I kneel and I experience a sharp horrible pain that seems to come from under my kneecap. Recently my knees would be achy after dancing so to protect my knees, since I kneel  a lot during a routine, I have been wearing a compression brace. I have also started going to the gym to build the muscles around my knee. Since the gym and the brace, I have been  experiencing popping, clicking and grinding  whenever I move my leg back and forth. The clicking is in both knees. I am worried this is something serious!! Any advice would be greatly appreciated...I have no insurance so getting to a doctor is difficult unless its absolutely necessary! Thanks!
posted_time: Post  by shesupsidedown » Thu Apr 26, 2007 12:33 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: It is hard to say without examining you what is going on.  There are several possibilities.  It may be simply a normally tight knee although with your pain this is less likely.    It is also possible that you have some arthritis in your knees (where the cartilage is worn down and the bone is scraping bone).  This is very common in dancers and other athletes over time.  Strengthening exercises are generally helpful but if they are causing pain you should be cautious.  If your pain is worsening or not improving I would recommend that you see a doctor.  There are often clinics that offer reduced fee schedules for those that have no insurance.  Your local health department can help point you to them if needed.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Your complaint could be due to one of the following causes:  - Gout :in which there is an increase in the serum uric acid concentration in the blood and its precipitation in the joint, usually it is bilateral and affects the big toe, but other forms of presentations are possible. Swelling around the affected joint occur in severe inflammation.  -  Sprain: it is an injury to a ligament   -  Tendinitis and arthritis due to inflammation of the tendon or the joint. Fluid collection and joint effusion forming swelling around my occur.  -  Rheumatoid arthritis , usually it affects the small joints, bilateral and morning stiffness is common (the pain resolves gradually with movement).  Direct clinical examination is essential. I advise you to seek orthopedic consultation. Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Mon Feb 05, 2007 2:10 pm

author: Dr. Paula Fontaine  Podiatrist Posts: 11 Joined: Wed Jan 24, 2007 4:55 pm
title: ankle pain
content: Limitation of ankle joint range of motion could be due to  osteophyte (bone spur) formation at the front of your ankle joint. This would retrict your ability to dorsiflex the foot on the ankle.  Another possibility is talar dome fracture although normally I would expect this to be associated with some trauma to the foot/ankle and you did not mention any.  If this were the case however, it is possible for a fragment of the talus bone to be loose in the anke joint.  Tight posterior leg muscles can restrict ankle joint dorsiflexion though it sounds more like you feel its an issue at the front of your ankle.  I agree an orthopedic exam would be important. Some plain radiographs may be very helpful, CT scan more helpful still. Good luck!
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Paula Fontaine » Thu Feb 08, 2007 5:18 pm

author: Dr. Paula Fontaine  Podiatrist Posts: 11 Joined: Wed Jan 24, 2007 4:55 pm
title: talar leson
content: Hello- A talar lesion would refer to fracture (where a chip of bone has been chipped off the  top of the talus (or 'talar dome')  following trauma)  or a small  compressed area  on the top of the talus bone. If you have a chip of bone loose it may stay right in the place it sat before the trauma, or it may break loose and float in the ankle joint causing pain.  In either case the problem is treatable although the surgeon may want to scope the ankle to remove any floating pieces.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Paula Fontaine » Sat Mar 03, 2007 5:32 pm

author: Dr. Paula Fontaine  Podiatrist Posts: 11 Joined: Wed Jan 24, 2007 4:55 pm
title: osteochondral lesion
content: Hi, I am passing along two links  that I hope will be helpful to you.  http://www.myfootshop.com/detail.asp?Co ... 20Fracture  http://www.emedicine.com/orthoped/topic638.htm  Both of these links give a fairly detailed overview of  talar dome lesions (which can also be associated with tibial lesions). It sounds like your surgeon wants to get in with the scope (arthroscopy)  to better appreciate the extent of the damageto both talus and tibia  before deciding on a treatment plan. Treatment plans do vary depending on the size of the lesion. If there is a loose body (bone and/or cartilage fragment) floating around it would need to be removed or fixated at your surgeon's discretion.  Sometimes a procedure called subchondral drilling is performed to help reestablish blood supply to the damaged area of the bone.  Other lesions of thistype could be treated with a bone graft. Again, the size and extent of the damage will determine which treatment would be necessary.   Hope this helps.  PAF

title: ankle
content: Hi-   I absolutely would recommend wrapping the ankle when you are working to get you through the next couple of weeks. This could be a simple ace wrap or elastic ankle support.  I am also  a fan of Sweedo braces (if you're not familiar its kind of a canvas lace up support that you can wear inside a regular shoe). I know after a visit with my chiropractor  I can expect pain that escalates over the 48 hours or so following the visit ( and THEN I finally start to feel the benefits of the treatment). author: Dr. Paula Fontaine  Podiatrist Posts: 11 Joined: Wed Jan 24, 2007 4:55 pm
title: ankle surgery
content: Ryann, I would absolutely tell your surgeon if you are experiencing any unusual symptoms. It is possible that your illness is unrelated to your surgery, however your symptoms could be a sign of a post-op complication. Are you taking antibiotics? Diarrhea can be sometimes be associated with  taking antibiotics as well.  I tell my patients to always call me if they have any unusual symptoms. In the worst case scenario you will be making an unnecessary phone call. In the best scenario you will be 'heading off' what could turn into a more serious post op complication- I am sure your doctor would prefer the unnecessary phone call over the latter :-) Good luck and let me know how it turns out!  Dr. Paula Fontaine

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Eleo1, What you are describing could very well be a misalignment in your spine.  An active person as yourself can still have a problem with the alignment.  When a misalignment occurs, you may feel exactly the symptoms you are describing.  I would recommend you see a D.O. (Dr. of Osteopathy)  who specializes in whole body medicine, and the relationship of the spine health to the health of the whole body. Or, you may wish to consult with a chiropractor or chiropractic physician who can also advise you on the state of health of your spine, and if indicated, treat it with adjustments and teach you exercises to prevent the problem from re-occurring.  Many times the retraining of your body for safe moves will enable you to become pain free, and stay pain free.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Your symptoms are suspicious for a condition called "claudication".  This is basically where there is poor blood circulation to the feet and legs.  When exercising the feet/legs need more blood flow and can't get it so pain occurs.  This condition can be associated with high blood pressure and is due to peripheral artery disease.  It is fairly rare before the age of 50 but can occur.  I would recommend you see your doctor for an evaluation of this.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Wed May 02, 2007 2:24 pm

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Chartsmalm, There are a variety of foot ailments that could be what you are referring to, and without a personal assessment of your feet, I can only offer general descriptions of a couple in hopes of helping you.  What kind of shoe did the podiatrist recommend?  I appreciate your comment that you had already explored the use of OTC innersoles, however, not all innersoles are the same.  An orthotics specialist may have an answer for you if returning to the podiatrist is not an option, especially since it sounds like you did not appreciate the lack of information from the one you saw. Your city should have several orthotic/prosthesis companies.  There are also a number of "foot" stores available in many large cities that specialize in custom or nearly custom inserts to correct stance, gait, and bone structure abnormalities.  Some abnormalities are actually normal for age and wear and tear on the feet: callus formation as an example.  Changes in the impact velocity on the metatarsals also occurs as we age, causing variations in where the foot contact to the ground is made.  Both of these examples can cause the sensation you are describing.  I suggest you consult an orthotics company, or even do some research online into companies such as HappyFeet who may give you insight into the top of the line specialty shoe manufacturers who strive to provide footwear for "happy feet".
posted_time: Post  by Marceline F, RN » Sun Apr 22, 2007 1:26 am

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Chartsmalm, Again by not being able to assess your feet directly, I am limited in my suggestions and must be somewhat  "potential", "possible", and general  in my phrasing. With that in mind:  If we consider the possibility that the perception of coolness is indeed related to the above scenarios - then it could be that the nerve endings interpreting the topographic changes in your feet as soft marbles, may also interpret ambient temperatures differently than sensors in the rest of your body.  It is also possible that other factors may be at play - for instance an undiagnosed peripheral neuropathy, a misalignment in your spine, and even simply a natural tendency to over-read symptoms when trying to discover cause for an existing concern.   If the problem persists, and becomes a serious concern to you, it would be a good idea to bring it to the attention of your primary care physician.  Thank your for your feedback, and for using Doctors Lounge.

title: [no title]
content: I've not personally heard of this treatment but it sounds reasonable.  The corset will help keep the rib from protruding.  This may or may not ultimately result in a permanent remodeling of the rib.  Should you choose to try the corset, you should make sure that it is not too tight and compromising your ability to breathe or be painful.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by tsg295 » Fri Apr 13, 2007 9:39 pm

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Tanner, Sounds like you may have a bout of TMD - temporomandibular joint disorder - more commonly referred to as TMJ - which is the name of the associated joint.  The most common cause of associated pain is myofascial pain dysfunction syndrome, which is noticeable mostly when chewing or as you indicated whenever you have your mouth open for a while.  It seems that whenever the joint "popped" it did not remain displaced, but it will be sore for a while. You did not mention if you are still having problems masticating.  If so, or if the soreness persists, you would be wise to check it out with your doctor - who may - in severe cases cross-refer you to an Dentist to explore why the problem occurred to begin with, and what needs to be done to fix it.  If the joint is not now displaced, warm compresses may help the pain and discomfort, and increase circulation to the area to speed healing.  I would be cautious about chewing hard food for a while!

content: i am a 39 year old female and i started suffering from health anxiety and panic attacks just over a year ago. at around the same time, i started suffering with bad achiness pain in my rib/breast/shoulder area. with suffering from health anxiety i convinced myself that i had breast cancer.(no lumps or changes found) my doctor did reassure me this was unlikely. he suggested i needed to do stretching exercises. i was also diagnoised early last year with acid reflux and i'm currently on omeprozole 20mg. my doctor did send me for a c reactive protien blood test and he also did me a blood test for bone density. all he told me was they were normal. he never really explained what these tests can show. i daren't google about them because with being a health anxiety sufferer i would look for the worse case scenario.  someone did say i could possible have costrochondrities, but my doctor didn't seem bothered when i mentioned this. he just perscribed me some co codomol.  please could some one give me some idea or pointers as sometimes i sit and fret that i do have breast/bone cancer.  thankyou
posted_time: Post  by pinkpenny1uk » Sun Apr 15, 2007 11:59 am

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear PinkPenny1uk, Sometimes the best way to handle an anxiety issue is to face it square on - have you considered getting a mammogram?  Did your doctor suggest that?  That is the number one way for you to eliminate breast cancer as a possible situation.  It is recommended at about your age that you get a baseline mammogram anyway.  From a health anxiety perspective, or panic attacks, please remember, we can always handle what we know we have a lot easier than the giant monsters of problems our fertile minds are able to create!  Then after having faced that scary question head on, you can lay that fear to rest.  Bone density is done to determine if the bones have become affected by any disease that attacks bone.  If your doctor tells you these tests were fine, it implies that you do not have reason at this time to be overly concerned.  CRP (c-reactive protein) is a test to see if an inflammatory process is at work in your body.  Again, if this test is "fine", it implies you do not have anything serious at this time to worry about. You did not mention if you smoke.  Smoking will aggravate a panic disorder, and can cause pain with breathing.  Panic itself can cause physical pain, and this pain can lead to more panic and a vicious cycle begins.  Are you taking your antianxiety meds as prescribed?  They should help you be in control enough to calmly pursue a mammogram as suggested above, and to keep the giant monsters of your mind at bay.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: It's likely that you have injured your wrist during your daily work, possibly without even noticing it.    The acronim RICE provides good treatment for these injuries: Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation.  Rest your wrist and be self limited in terms of using it.  If it causes pain, don't do it.  Ice is good initially, not as helpful after a few days.  Wearing a compression type brace or bandage can be helpful to provide some extra support.  Elevation helps keep the pressure of gravity and the rest of the body off the injury until it heals.  If your wrist isn't getting better in a few days (not totally better but getting better) you should have it examined.  Best wishes.

title: KNEE SWELLING/MEDS
content: IM 39 YEARS OLD WHITE MALE I'M ON METHADONE MAINT. MY KNEE HAS SWOLLEN UP AND HURTS IF I GO TO THE DOCTOR WHAT CAN HE GIVE ME FOR PAIN
posted_time: Post  by kpdog68 » Thu Mar 29, 2007 5:35 pm

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear kpdog68, I surmise that you are attempting to fight a previous drug addiction through  your methadone program.  I commend you for your effort.  You did not mention if you had injured your knee, or if you ever had knee swelling in the past.  If your knee is swollen due to trauma, such as a fall, the swelling is the body's natural defense to injury, and sometimes rest and propping your leg up on pillows will help to reduce the swelling,  I am concerned that you may feel the over the counter pain medications available at your local pharmacy are not going to be effective due to your high "tolerance".  The method of action of NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), as its name implies, is to reduce inflammation. This swelling may be the source of your discomfort, and helping it to go down should give you pain relief.  The medications work independent of your body's pain receptors.  If you have already tried the OTC meds, and you still have pain and swelling, it would be a good idea to go to your doctor or clinic, and ask them to both evaluate your problem, as well as tell you what will be the best medication in your specific case to help.  Other diseases ("dis-ease") can present with similar symptoms, and your doctor is the best one to help you determine what is wrong.

content: Your symptoms are interesting.  I cannot fully explain them.  It is possible that you have some compression of the nerves that feed the muscles of your rib cage. I have had x-rays and MRI. X-rays didn't show anything. MRI showed small rotator cuff tear. I have horrible pain in my right shoulder.. the only way that I can describe it is like a giant absess toothache pain in my shoulder.  Sometimes it's a dull ache, but usually an awful deep ache with sharp shooting pains at times. I have pain raising and just in general moving my arm and shoulder.  At night especially I will wake up crying out with the pain... laying half on my stomach on my left side with a pillow shoved tightly up into my RT armpit seems to help a little. When I bring my arm down from a raised position.. and move it in certain ways  it will catch and feel as if it's sliding out. My O.T therapist does not believe that I have a frozen shoulder that doc is saying it is.  She says it's anterior shoulder instability. When I do the arm raises with her she will grip my humeral and push in hard while I bring my arm down and this helps with the catching. She has done ultrasound treatment on shoulder 1x and it hurt! posted_time: Post  by zippy » Sun Mar 25, 2007 5:11 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: The term frozen shoulder essentially means limitation of shoulder movement for reasons that cannot be explained by a torn tendon, etc.  In these cases, the shoulder isn't really "frozen" as it would work fine if the muscle were attached to the bone to allow proper pulling on the bone.    A frozen shoulder may occur for no known reason, or from trauma.  Often, physical therapy is helpful although surgery may be needed in refractory cases.  "Cure" of a frozen shoulder is a long process and may take several years to fully get mobility back.  Anterior instability results when the ligaments/tendons are damaged in such a way that the head of the humerus wants to slip forward out of the shoulder joint when the right stress is placed on it (movement similar to pitching a ball with the arm drawn back and rotated some).  Anterior instability may need surgical repair as well.  If the issue is minor, often strengthening of the rotator cuff muscles can help overcome this laxity and protect the shoulder joint.  If you are beginning to experience limitation in your joint mobility you may be seeing the beginnings of a frozen shoulder.  Continuing with physical therapy and range of motion exercises will likely help.  Continued follow up with your orthopedist is important.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Sun Mar 25, 2007 7:34 pm

title: [no title]
content: Seeing your primary care doctor first is the right course of action for you.  At that point you may be referred to an orthopedic specialist. posted_time: Post  by Benny » Thu Feb 08, 2007 10:54 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: While I am far from a specialist in this area I'll give you my two cents worth.    If you are loosing muscle mass this may be due to one of two main problems.  First, you may have nerve damage.  If the nerves are not stimulating the muscle properly the muscle begins to shrink.  The nerves that may be involved start in the neck at the spine.  A careful neurological exam should be done to isolate any nerve type signs.  Second, the muscle may be becoming smaller due to lack of use.  The injury you have may be limiting your ability to exercise the muscle.  Muscles require adequate use to maintain bulk.  I would recommend you continue to follow up with your orthopedic surgeon and discuss your symptoms.  Also, it is within your rights to request a second opinion if needed.  Best wishes.  I hope this helps a little.

content: Pain is an indication that something is wrong in the body.  Burning type pain often is representative of nerve pain.  It may be that you have a pinched nerve in the area of your shoulder blades or neck.  I would recommend that you be evaluated by your doctor.  Along with diagnosing the problem, you can also get a referral to physical therapy which sometimes can be helpful with muscle related pains.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by pattycake » Tue Jan 16, 2007 12:45 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Chronic low back pain is a common and difficult problem to manage from a physician point of view.  Diagnosing the actual cause can be quite difficult as well.  It sounds as if you've seen all the right people and had the right tests done.  I have found that what ever the initial cause of the pain, the pain is almost always added to by muscle pain.  This is because the muscles of the back are always tensed up trying to protect the back from moving and causing pain.  This, in turn, causes the muscles to begin to hurt.  Physical therapy can be helpful.  Back strengthening exercises may help some.  Keep following up with your doctor.  If you've not seen a neurosurgeon this may be another avenue to pursue.  Generally, back surgery should be a last resort because it can sometimes cause more problems but in some cases it is necessary.  Best wishes.  Hang in there, back pain can be very difficult to deal with.

title: knee injury while skiing
content: hi! im an almost 17 Y O female. i love playing sport, working (i am a swimming teacher) and being active.  about 4 months ago i was skiing and i stacked. i think my ski turned inwards and i felt my knee. i was able to ski straight (no side to side) to the bottom, got on the chairlift and sat in the chalet. as much as i wanted to i couldnt keep going. i tried!!   i thought nothing of it as i have had knee problems forever ( bursitis, patella maltracking and unknown problems that have disappeared in the last year).   driving down the mountain i had to hold it going around the corners as it hurt too much, in the outside and inside.  back home, i waited about 2 weeks before seeing the physio, he said a slight sprain on the medial ligament and bit of rest and come back.  a few days later i was in huge amounts of pain, i rang my mum and asked her to pick me up from school, rang work, told them i couldnt. we then got an appointment with a sports medecine guy and he straight away said i had torn the ligament on the outside of my knee. the lateral colateral ligament. I had an MRI and this was confirmed that i had a high grade level 2 tear. i was put in a brace for 4 weeks. until mid november  it still sometimes bugs me and causes pain, especially in the cold. i am aiming to be back playing sport in 1 month. should i go and see the Dr again, or go to see an ortho surgeon. i really want it fixed as my last netball season was full of injury, and i have worked hard, then my knee. i just want to be able to play!!  thanks for taking the time to read it, sorry its so long!!  ERM
posted_time: Post  by erm » Wed Jan 10, 2007 12:51 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I apologize for the delayed response.   The knee has several ligaments that hold it together.  Often with a tear the treatment is rest.  If it is severe, surgery can be done.  Sometimes, surgery is not needed as the knee can often do OK without one of the ligaments intact.  Generally repair is recommended for those that are very active.  You may consider visiting an orthopedic surgeon to discuss possible treatment options for you.  Physical therapy is also likely to be of some help to ensure that the leg muscles are strengthened to help protect the knee.  Best wishes.

author: griffinlead  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Mar 11, 2007 5:03 am
title: Sharp muscle pain while coughing
content: I've had a chronic cough for about 9 days and am currently under a doctor’s care.  I have been prescribed antibiotics, decongestant, and an expectorant.  Last night while coughing, I felt a pop and a sharp pain in my right side, below the rib cage.  Is it possible I gave myself a hernia?  There is no swelling in the area, only a dull pain and I sharp pain if I cough too hard.
posted_time: Post  by griffinlead » Sun Mar 11, 2007 5:15 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: There are a few possible causes of your pain.  Commonly with respiratory illnesses, the lining of the lungs (called pleura) become inflamed.  This can cause intense pain that is typically referred to as sharp and stabbing.  Another possibility is that you have strained a rib muscle with coughing.  These muscle strains heal similar to other muscle strains-slowly.  Ibuprofen is good for this pain as it helps relieve inflammation.  I suspect this is what has occurred in your case.  While it theoretically is possible to induce a hernia with coughing, it would be very rare and one would likely need to have some underlying predisposition for this to happen.  If your pain is not improving over then next few days I recommend you see your doctor.  Best wishes.

title: Big Toe Problem
content: 3 Months ago I went on the balls of my feet. I felt a pain in my right foot. I was unable to move any of my toes and my foot swelled up and went an odd colour as well as feeling very cold. It stayed like this for quite sometime. I have had two lots of x-rays and an MRI scan no injury shows up. I couldn't put any pressure on the ball of my foot and after 2 months most symptoms went when I raised my leg. I was able to move my toes as long as I kept my foot up in the air!!!!!! I am still not able to walk properly as I am left with a pain on the underside of my big toe. I did have a bad varicose vain in my leg which has just disappeared after 14 years since doing this and I am told there is no connection. I have been diagnosed with complex pain syndrome and told I have to overcome the pain and walk properly!!! Please can anyone suggest what I might have done because this is driving me potty.  I was quite a fit and healthy 42 year old female!!!
posted_time: Post  by Janet-hopefull » Sat Mar 10, 2007 10:07 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: There are a few possibilities.  You may have had a severe strain of the muscles causing the pain/swelling.  These can take a long time to go away.  The MRI would most likely have seen any tendon damage, bone fractures or ligament damage making these less likely.  Also you may have some nerve damage.  These can be very painful.  Diagnosis is mainly clinical unless one wants to do nerve conduction studies that are somewhat painful and difficult to do.  Peripheral nerves do regenerate but it is a long process.  Reflex sympathetic dystrophy is a syndrome of pain that occurs after an initial injury happens.  The injury heals but pain persists and can be quite severe.  It sounds as if you may have this.  Treatment is a little painful as it basically requires that the injured part be moved and stretched to allow the nerves to "reset" back to normal.  Physical therapy may be helpful for you.  (This is a bit of a simplified explanation of this syndrome.)  You may consider being evaluated by a sports medicine specialist.  They are the specialists that deal with muscle injuries, sprains, etc. and may be able to give you some help.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  This could be due to a muscle spasm. Muscle spasm alone can cause this pain which can be an unidentified cause but in many cases is the result of inappropriate posture for long time like traveling, driving and certain types of work. Arthritic changes in the shoulder region may result in muscle spasm as a protective mechanism to avoid joint movement.  In these cases, self care and avoiding the precipitating cause will lead to a gradual but clear improvement in the pain. Home treatment includes the use of analgesics, cold or hot therapy. Rest for maximum two days is also beneficial.  Plain X ray or MRI on the shoulder may be requested to exclude other causes which result from bone and joint changes.  Direct clinical examination is essential. Keep us updated. Best regards.

author: Dr. Paula Fontaine  Podiatrist Posts: 11 Joined: Wed Jan 24, 2007 4:55 pm
title: short 4th toe
content: There is a way to lengthen the toe although it is not an easy process. If you have a short metatarsal bone that is making your toe look shorter than its neighbors, the metatarsal bone can be lengthened with a technique called callus distraction. Basically  the metatarsal bone is cut in half surgically  and an external device is attached to each end of the cut metatarsal with pins. The surgical incision is closed and you would be left with an external fixator device on the outside of your foot (usually made of metal bars with a "key" for you to turn daily that will gradually pull the two ends of the cut bone apart from each other.The space that is being created between the two ends of the cut bone as you turn the key ( a little each day) will fill in with new bone.  Over a period of weeks (perhaps 10 weeks or so) your metatarsal bone will be lengthened to a more normal length and your small toe will be pushed out so that it looks much more normal. You will likely  be required to be non-weight bearing during healing so as not to disrupt the new bone formation. A podiatric surgeon or orthopedic surgeon could perform this operation.    Good luck!
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Paula Fontaine » Thu Feb 08, 2007 5:29 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Pain in the toe can arise from different causes ranging from accidental trauma to neurological and vascular conditions.  -Gouty arthritis, although affects mainly the big toe, it can start with any other joint. The signs and symptoms of gout are almost always acute, occurring suddenly often at night and without warning.  -Ingrown nails :patients have a painful, swollen, and tender toe.  Other unlikely causes include: -Osteoarthritis affects mainly big toe and in older age. -Raynaud's phenomenon:is a vasospastic disorder causing discoloration of the fingers, toes, and occasionally other extremities  -Erythromelalgia is a rare disorder that affects the extremities and especially in the feet, in which blood vessels blocked and inflamed, causing a painful burning and throbbing sensation and red skin and tend to be worse in summer.  Direct clinical examination is essential. Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Tue Dec 19, 2006 3:50 pm

author: Dr. Paula Fontaine  Podiatrist Posts: 11 Joined: Wed Jan 24, 2007 4:55 pm
title: small toe pain
content: Hello Pain in the small toe could results from a number of issues: Do you have any new lesions on the toe (corns or calluses?). You said you have not switched shoes recently but do the shoes you have squeeze your toes at all? Occasionally nerve damage can result from ill-fitted shoes and can last for weeks or months after the offending shoes have been discarded.   Another possibility could be arthritis in the toe. Xrays would help to determine if there is arthritis , fracture, or other problems with the bones in your toe that could be causing pain.  Although gout is not out of the question, its unusual to find it only in a small toe.  Symptoms of gout are a red, hot , swollen toe that is extremely tender (some patients cannot stand even the bedsheet to touch the area).  Hope this helps. Good luck! PAF

I went to the hospital and they did and xray and said it wasn't broken.  They just wrapped it and told me to stay off it for 6 weeks.  Well, I twisted it 2 more times in the following month, and my doctor wouldn't have it xrayed again.  It has been over 6 months now and it stays swollen on both sides of my ankle. posted_time: Post  by ronirains » Fri Feb 02, 2007 7:25 am

author: Dr. Paula Fontaine  Podiatrist Posts: 11 Joined: Wed Jan 24, 2007 4:55 pm
title: sprained ankle
content: ronirains- I would definitely recommend a follow up Xray and MRI. It is possible that you did not break a bone but you may have severly sprained or torn one or more ligaments in the ankle.  Once the ligaments (which hold the foot and leg together) become torn or severly stretched it becomes more likely that you will have a repeat of the same injury. An MRI would be a good way to image the soft tisses (ligaments and tendons)  around your ankle to see if they have been damaged.  Some such injuries can be treated with formal physical therapy and /or supportive devices placed in the shoes.  More serious injuried may be best managed with surgery to repair the torn structures. A podiatrist or orthopedic surgeon could help you diagnose and treat an ankle injury.  Left untreated, such an injury could be come a chronic issue.  Good luck,  PAF

posted_time: Post  by alliekat » Sat Dec 09, 2006 6:42 pm

author: Dr. Paula Fontaine  Podiatrist Posts: 11 Joined: Wed Jan 24, 2007 4:55 pm
title: achilles tendon
content: Hello alliecat- Once an achilles tendon has become very inflammed it can be difficult to get relief as it is stretched with every step you take. It is certainly possible to rupture an achilles tendon, particularly one that has become chronically inflammed over a long period of time.  In many instances the treatment of choice might be immobilization of the foot to reduce further trauma to the tendon and allow healing to occur.  Immobilization might mean a cast with crutches or a pneumatic walking boot depending on your doctor's preference and the severity of your symptoms. Once the tendon has had a chance to 'settle down' your doctor may then have your return to formal physical therapy (as you return to a normal shoe) to help gradually rehabilitate the foot and leg.  Depending on how quickly your tendon responds to immobilization you may need to be in a cast or pneumatic walking boot for a number of weeks followed by several weeks of therapy.    Oral antiinflammatory medications and daily icing are often part of the treatment for tendonitis as well.  Good luck!
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Paula Fontaine » Wed Jan 24, 2007 5:45 pm

author: tthoney  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Wed Dec 13, 2006 10:24 am Location: PA
title: Sesamoiditis
content: I am a 28 year old active female.  I had surgery to remove a sesamoid bone from one of my feet 2 years ago.  Is it possible to have the same thing happen in the other foot because I am having the same pains now in the other one.  Is this common?  Thanks
posted_time: Post  by tthoney » Wed Jan 17, 2007 12:03 pm

author: Dr. Paula Fontaine  Podiatrist Posts: 11 Joined: Wed Jan 24, 2007 4:55 pm
title: sesamoiditis both feet
content: Hello tthoney- You can definitely get sesamoiditis in both feet. This problem can occur as a result of activity or job which causes undue stress on the ball of the foot. Examples of this might be ballet or a job requiring many hours of squatting while on the balls of the feet.  It can also occur in patients who have very high arched feet since often these patients have excessive pressures on the balls of their feet (and heels) just during normal ambulation.   I would be sure you have the foot xrayed to be certain the sesamoid is not fractured. If there is no fracture but the area has become inflammed and irritated, a non-surgical approach to treatment might involve special pads (called Dancer's pads) worn short (or long) term to reduce pressure under the sesamoid bones.  Also icing the area can help reduce pain and inflammation.   A short course of oral antiiflammatory medication prescribed by your doctor in conjuction with the icing and pads may reduce or even eliminate your sesamoid pain withour surgery.  Good luck.

title: [no title]
content: This is suspicious for osteoarthritis.  If you are unable to walk on your knee I would recommend urgent evaluation to ensure that there is not an infection in the knee.  However, if the pain has been slowly worsening for 3 months, an infection is incredibly unlikely.    There are a few other possibilities so evaluation is important.  With a family history of knee problems there is a possibility of a rheumatologic process as well.  There are some treatments for osteoarthritis to hopefully avoid a knee replacement if possible.  Hope this helps.

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Zena,  Any joint in our body is surrounded by a capsule...what seperates the capsule from the bone itself is a special fluid called (synovial fluid) it resesmbles and feels like the egg white,very slimy to help the bone glide easily and there would be no friction in movements.The bursae are small sacs of these fluids that help with this process as well.  Imagine that this fluid or the capsule surrounding the joint is inflammed for any reason,and has not been treated properly! The body's defensive mechanism will attack vigorously and causes alot of immune complexes (cells) to be deposited in these small spaces, that inturn will adhere and impair the movements.  To prevent that,proper management of bursitis or capsulitis should be obtained...and if for any reason it has been neglected /misdiagnosed/ mistreated, the patient should be put on nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicaction and after resolution of the symptoms he is  encouraged to do physiotherapy which aims to tear the adhesions and regain the  shoulder's maximum movement range (ofcourse it will be painful during exercises) I hope that has helped, and we are here for you if you have further questions. Best regards,

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Two major problems that affect tendons: tendonitis and tenosynovitis.  Tendonitis, inflammation of a tendon and most commonly seen in the wrist and fingers.   Tenosynovitis is the inflammation of the lining sheath of the tendon.  Causes include strain, overuse (writing), injury, or excessive exercise.  Carpal Tunnel syndrome gives also a similar clinical picture and is due to repetitive,strong motion with the wrist bent for long periods.  Symptoms are mainly in the form of Parasthesia in thumb, index and middle fingers, and the thumb side of your ring finger and never the little finger. Weakness and loss of sensation may develop.  A neurological examination and certain test can help in the diagnosis. Treatments include  activity modification like intermittent rest, avoid  bending your wrist and to keep it relaxed, do not overuse or do a hard gripping.   Direct clinical examination is essential. Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Wed Dec 27, 2006 7:20 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  This is what we call bruises, or ecchymoses that occur due to the leakage of blood from an injured blood vessel into the tissues which may become swollen.  Healthy people might develop bruises due to any injury that without causing skin break. Vigorous exercise may cause bruises.  Bleeding tendency is commonly seen in individuals taking NSAID drugs. Advil is one of these drugs that increase bleeding tendency and make bleeding easier.  Usually, It doe not need treatment after one to two days, the color will change gradually till fades  at about day six.   Local measure include  the use of ice packs during the first 24,  after that, heat, or warm packs to increase the circulation and fasten the healing of the injured tissues.  Best regards.

The Dr that performed the test said that he is "pretty certain" that it is Ulnar nerve entrapment at the elbow.   My questions are: 1.  Because the muscles are "wasting away"  does that pretty much mean I should have the surgery?  2.  What happens after the surgery?  Everything that I have read says that the pain is horrible.   3.
