author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Dear Momof,  I would suggest you should have the surgery.  The ulnar nerve is being irritated, or put under pressure as it winds behind the inside of the elbow.  The symptoms are of two kinds...those related to the irritation, and those related to loss of function.  Irritant sysmptoms are pins and needles and pain.  Loss of function is numbness and weakness.  If the numbness stops being transient and the weakness leads to muscle wasting, then it implies that the neorons are bit by bit being knocked off.   Decompression involves releasing the nerve from structures trapping it and rerouting to the front of the elbow (so that the nerve isn't stretched when you flex the arm)  Surgery itself is not painful, but often the elbow feels sore for as much as 6 weeks afterwards, and the area remains sensitive.  Irritant sysmptoms disappear immediately usually, but function recovery depends on how much of the nerve and how badly it has been damaged and it may be incomplete.    Different surgeons use different techniques, many apply a removable splint or a  cast afterwards, but some do little more than a bandage.  This usually is for a couple of weeks...again this depends on the surgeon doing the operation.  Usually it is  done as a day case with most people going home the same day.  The wound has to be kept clean and dry until healed, as with any operation.  Restrictions are minimal, but you will probaly find that picking things up is quiet uncomfortable, as the nerve is often re-routed through a muscle in front of the elbow.  pain is what determines your level of function.  Treatments can also involve the use of night extension splints, occassionally local steroid injection...but in your case I would suggest surgery may be what is required, if you are having muscle wasting and sustained numbness.  Regards  saif

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Dear Benjamin BenjaminLok wrote:1. Will my ulnar nerve recover if I continue to do my physical activities? Or must I stop them until my nerve gets better?  Depends on the activity.  Rrepeated impact or sustained pressure over the ulnar nerve will make this worse.  Breakdancing causing damage to the ulnar nerve is perhaps more likely to be at a different point to that of the previous poster.  This may cause entrapment or damage at Guyon's canal at the base of your hand, near your wrist.  Paradoxically although less of the nerve is damaged, the contracture (clawing) is greater. BenjaminLok wrote:2. Will it recover even though it has been this way for over a year now? If you are developing clawing, Ii do not recommend waiting any longer before consulting a specialist. The recovery is variable, and depends on many factors I have already alluded to in the previous post. BenjaminLok wrote:3. Do I need surgery?Thanks. Possibly...hard to say without examining you formally  Saif

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,   The ulnar nerve is one of three main nerves that innervate  the hand. The nerve goes down the forearm, divide across the palm then pass into the little and ring fingers.   Ulnar tunnel syndrome is mainly due to pressure on the nerve. Excessive pressure on this nerve can result in a loss of feeling and/or muscle weakness in the hand.  Sometimes the cause of pressure is difficult to be diagnosed but some swellings, like cysts in the elbow region are found.  General measures include: Rest of the arm and avoid keeping the elbow bent for longe time. Keep the elbow straight at night when you are sleeping  - Use of cool to reduce swellings if any is present.  - medications like NSAID - Finally surgery is recommended to complicated persistent cases after conservative measures or to remove any possible cause of pressure like cysts.

author: mtstanley  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Sat Nov 18, 2006 8:17 am
title: OSD
content: Spensaid003; As you know, this disease occurs in young boys who are typically in thier growth spurts.  Typically 10-14 years of age.  While its not common for a six year old, as you now know its not impossible.  As far as treating it, we use anti-inflammatory drugs, usually ibuprofen in someone age 6, along with ice and rest.    I would look into some physical therapy to get the legs stronger especially the quads and hamstrings, and then discontinue whatever is causing the pain until the knee(s) settle down.    As far as "how long will it affect him?"  If properly managed, it can be managed effectively so that it doesn't affect him.  If ignored, it can spell lifelong knee troubles.  It sounds like you are doing everything right.  Do not let him "play through" the pain, or try to talk you into doing activities that you do not feel he should.  In a few months he should be able to resume all activities and not notice any problems.  I'm not sure I told you anything new, but I hope its reassuring.  MStanley, MD, Orthopaedic surgery. FACOS/AAOS

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Each disc is formed of a central gel-like inside (nucleus pulposus), surrounded by an outer ring (annulus fibrosus).   When this softer component ruptures (herniates) through the outer ring it can press directly on nerve roots and irritate adjacent nervous tissue.   Your MRI report (according to what you mentioned)  informs that you have disc herniation at the level of the Thoracic vertebrae Between T6-7. Since I did not personally review your MRI, I cannot be so accurate to confirm that it showed no clear nerve root compression although it is touching the sac that protects the nerve roots (thecal sac).  These conditions can be treated in the majority of cases with medical and conservative treatment (non surgical).   Non surgical treatment includes, physical therapy, certain exercises, weight reduction, epidural steroid injections, non-steroidal Anti-inflammatory medications, and decreased daily activities. The pain usually improves faster than the numbness and the weakness if present.   Surgery for disc herniation is only considered if symptoms are not controlled after at least one month (6 weeks) of medical and conservative treatment, or in very complicated cases with serious symptoms.   A spinal physician is the one able to determine if surgery is the best treatment for the patient.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Fri Aug 18, 2006 3:08 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Wrist pain is a very common complaint. The presence of other symptoms and signs can help in the diagnosis. History of recent infection or trauma is important. Past diagnoses of systemic diseases and surgeries are of great value in the diagnosis.  Common causes of wrist pain  include:  - Tendonitis (inflammation of the tendon sheath) : a common problem which result in wrist pain and swelling.   - Carpal tunnel syndrome : the nerves in the wrist are compressed by swellings. The pinched nerves cause pain and numbness in palm and  fingers (thumb). Pain and numbness increase with wrist movement.  -The condition could e due to repetitive use of the wrist like typing on a computer keyboard, using a computer mouse or due to other systemic and local diseases.  - Wrist sprains are common injuries to the ligaments around the wrist joint.  - Arthritis results in wrist pain, swelling, and stiffness, in RA it is usually bilateral.

author: pt_i_am  Guest Posts: 13 Joined: Mon Jul 25, 2005 6:53 pm Location: Kansas City
title: Avascular Necrosis
content: I am a 40 yr old female who has been on prednisone for the past year due to pulmonary problems. The average dosage is about 40 mg/day. I began having hip pain about 2 weeks ago and had an MRI which showed Stage I AVN of the femoral head. I have read quite a bit on AVN and want to make sure I am understanding what I read.  Is it true that since I am on prednisone and there is no end in site right now, that the AVN will not get better but get worse? The doctor has started me on Fosomax, which may help somewhat. I am currently full weight bearing. Should I be using crutches? Is it true that more than likely, my other hip will become affected?  FYI... I was started on Immuran to help assist with decreasing the steroid use, however my liver enzymes have increased, so I am on hold right now from taking that medication.
posted_time: Post  by pt_i_am » Wed Jun 28, 2006 11:50 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi pt_i_am, If you have researched Avascular Necrosis then you are probably aware that it is also known as Osteonecrosis.  Avascular Necrosis is essentially a disease that causes death of the femoral head due to interruption of blood flow. Avascular Necrosis in the earliest stages are typically not detected on xray, and usually found during a MRI. Very small lesions may resolve but larger lesions, generally speaking, progress until there is collapse of the femoral head. There are four stages of Avascular Necrosis. Careful attention and monitoring should also be done of the unaffected hip as there of course is a risk that it may become affected as well. There are a variety of causative factors increasing the risk of this condition, one of which is long term corticosteroid use. Nonsurgical intervention may include partial weight bearing for a period of approximately six weeks and then re-evaluation but in many cases progression of the disease, noted with larger lesion, may ultimately result in total hip replacement (Total Hip Arthroplasty). Discuss with your physician regarding available treatment options as mentioned above including, for example, core decompression, etc. so that you will be making informed decisions regarding treatment. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  I would like to emphasize that MRI results are very important in the diagnosis of vertebral changes, but the clinical picture, I mean your complaints and the physical examination are more important in determine the management.  Muscle spasm alone can cause this pain which can be an unidentified cause but in many cases it is secondary to spinal or bone problems.  In these cases, self care and avoiding the precipitating cause will lead to a gradual but clear improvement in the pain. Home treatment includes the use of analgesics, cold or hot therapy.  Non surgical treatment includes also, physical therapy, certain exercises, weight reduction, Stretching, non-steroidal Anti-inflammatory medications, and decreased daily activities. The pain usually improves faster than the numbness and the weakness if present.   Surgery for disc herniation is only considered if symptoms are not controlled after at least one month (6 weeks) of medical and conservative treatment, or in very complicated cases with serious symptoms.  A spinal physician is the one able to determine if surgery is the best treatment for the patient.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear bridg12,  This sounds like muscle pain and spasm as it is related to certain posture. Muscle spasm is a body reaction to injury in tissues  Causes of muscle injury include: Muscle fatigue, wrong posture Heavy exercise Flu Trauma Metabolic abnormalities like low Magnesium level and Hypocalcemia Hypoparathyroidism  The correct diagnosis is easier when other symptoms exist.  Self care and avoiding the precipitating cause will lead to a gradual but clear improvement in the pain. Home treatment includes the use of analgesics, cold or hot therapy. Proper posture is important.   If the condition is progressing or other symptoms like numbness of upper limb exists, more investigations should be done to exclude cervical problems.  Follow up with your doctor is essential. Hope you find this information useful.  Best regards,

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Ladysmith52,  Scoliosis in many cases does not cause pain.  Severe scoliosis on the other hand results in many complications especially if it starts early in life.  These complications include:  Lung and heart damage: Curvature of 70 degrees of  or more make the lungs and heart are pressed by the rib cage and their movements become restricted. Recurrent Lung infections are common.   Back problems: chronic back pain and arthritis of the spine.    In general the treatment depends on the degree of curvature and the age.  At your age with mild scoliosis, severe complications are less likely to happen although regular checkup is important.   I advise you to follow conservative measures like electrical stimulation of muscles, chiropractic manipulation and exercise as it will improve your overall health.  Follow up with your doctor is essential. Only by complete history and physical examination, the correct diagnosis can be reached.   Hope you find this information useful. Best regards,

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Joelle07,  It is essential to diagnose the cause of pain accurately. Pain generated from a herniated disc that causes nerve compression is treated differently from that of a muscle strain. Thus complete history,clinical examination as well as investigations are critical in the management of pain.   In most of the cases with back pain, strain of the back muscles and ligaments, is the primary cause. This usually results from wrong or heavy lifting, or following a sudden improper movement. Muscle spasm alone can cause the back pain which can be an unidentified cause.  Pain due to Disc prolapse is usually associated with numbness and weakness.  These conditions can be treated in the majority of cases with medical and conservative treatment (non surgical). Non surgical treatment include, physical therapy, certain exercises, weight reduction, epidural steroid injections, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications, and decreased daily activities. The pain usually improves faster than the numbness and the weakness if present.   Surgery for cervical disc herniation is only considered if symptoms are not controlled after at least one month (6 weeks) of medical and conservative treatment, or in very complicated cases with serious symptoms.  Follow up with your doctor, and keep us updated. Hope you find this information useful.  Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Fri Aug 04, 2006 5:46 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear pawprints,  Numbness in the lower limb with or without lower back pain that is centered in the lower spine and radiates down to both legs is most probably due to compressed nerves in the lumbosacral area.  If the same problem is felt in the upper part of the body (neck and upper limbs), the compressed nerves are those in the cervical region.  Nerve compression can be due to many reasons, including herniated disc, spondylosis, arthritis, spinal stenosis etc.  These conditions can be diagnosed by imaging studies like MRI (of choice).   Your condition needs follow up, please continue to update your doctor on your condition.  Best regards,

title: Back/arm/rib pain-what to do?
content: I am a 24 year old male in reasonably good health, I quit smoking around 6 months ago (had smoked for about 5 years), and the only illness in my family history is heart disease.  No current meds, one surgery 8 years ago to correct a perforated eardrum.  For about three years now I've had a sometimes aching and sometimes stabbing pain which seems to emenate from under my middle left rib cage, between my spine and left shoulder blade, and down the back of my left arm to my elbow.  These pains came and went in the past, but now they seem to always be there although they vary in intensity.  The pain in my arm seems to worsen when I do the following:  Lie on my left side and breathe in deeply  Turn my head to the extreme left in any position  Cough (I actually have a bad cold right now)  I also have developed an aching sternum pain as of about a year and a half to two years ago.  This is aggravated by certain movements such as pushing or pulling against resistance across my chest (like working out on a butterfly machine), or lying a certain way.  Sometimes (especially when first waking up) I can "crack" my chest by reaching backwards as far as possible.  I can hear and feel the crack which seems to alleviate the pain temporarily as well as feel very satisfying almost as if I am relieving tension.    I saw a doctor for the first time about this last year and he did an EKG to rule out heart problems.  He basically told me to take aspirin when I had pain and that the pain was due to an inflammation of the connective tissue of the ribcage (Costochondritis?), but at this point I don't want to live on aspirin every day.    I've been through countless websites which attribute rib/shoulder pain to everything from metastisized cancer to heart attack, but I think its safe to say that at my age those diagnoses are probably remote.  What can I do to alleviate this pain?  Can I modify my sleeping position, see a chiropractor, etc...?  Thanks,  Matthew

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Badfish740, Have you had any diagnostic studies/labwork, ie., sedimentation rate, c-reactive protein test? These studies would assist in identification of the causative factor. Costochondritis may involve factors such as trauma, recent illness, or may be indicative of other disorders such as psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, fibromyalgia, reactive arthritis, inflammatory bowel disorders, etc. etc. Treatment typically consists of minimization of stressing activities that seem to aggravate the condition, anti-inflammatory medications, and in some cases physical therapy. If there has been no diagnostic studies to identify the causative factor, I would suggest that you inquire with your physician regarding this matter. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi leamea, A MRI is an excellent diagnostic tool for identifying a torn meniscus. Chronic knee problems may be treated with physical therapy and anti-inflammatory medications but the risk of course may be enlargement of the tear if left surgically untreated. When symptoms arise surgical treatment (Arthroscopic) is the preferrable method. Small incisions are made to allow visualization of the joint by inserting a very small camera. This allows the surgeon to identify the tear and treat accordingly. If you had a negative experience with the epidural and general anesthesia was the recommended choice, then listen to their advice. Generally speaking, prior to the surgery, an EKG, chest xray, standard labwork, are all preoperative tests. After the surgery, pain medications are administered. Instructions regarding signs or symptoms of infection/complications are given, ie, increased pain, redness, swelling, fever >101, any unusual symptoms to alert the physician too. Crutches are typically given for at least the first couple of days and then weight bearing (along with the assistance of the crutches) is added a small amount at a time. Depending on the severity of the tear, would indicate the length of time needed for recovery. In smaller tears, normal activities are permitted after a few days. Of course these are certainly questions you want to ask prior to the procedure so that you will have a general idea and you will go into this informed. Also, make sure you have a friend or family memeber accompany you (this will be necessary anyway with general anesthesia in particular) because you will not be able to drive, or make any improtant decisions for the next 24 hrs). The person accompanying you will also be able to listen to the post operative instructions and help you remember appointments etc. because most likely you will be somewhat "groggy" after the procedure. I hope this has been somewhat helpful. Good luck and best wishes! Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: lump on sternum
content: Hello Erigirl,  It may be one of your parasternal lymph nodes that is a little out of place. They are lymph nodes that are normally located next to the sternum in the intercostals space, between the ribs. Did you notice it because it was sore or because it was a bump? Lymph nodes are sometimes hard to see on X-rays but when they are swollen, they’re doing their job. Try not to bother it for a week or so and see if the soreness goes away. If you don’t feel like it’s getting any better you can request bloodwork be done to see if you have inflammation or infection – C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, fibrogen levels, CBC, etc. If you still feel like you have something wrong you can request your Physician do a biopsy of the bump. Before any poking starts happening, try not to touch it and see if it will go down on its own.

author: txjessy  Guest Posts: 10 Joined: Tue May 31, 2005 4:26 pm Location: Texas
title: Sudden Generalized Joint Pain in 28yr old
content: I'm not certain if this should be in the orthopedic topics or not...but that's where it started...so I'll start here.   About three weeks ago, I began having sorness and tingling in my left foot and calf.  My big toe and across the top of my foot was very sore, and the outside edge and the two smallest toes on the same foot went from tingling (like when your foot falls asleep), to being numb. This went on for about a week. I thought I must have done something, and figured with some advil and a few days it would get better.  But, instead of getting better..it started up in the right leg and foot as well.  Then it got to be both feet, legs, and my lower back.  Although I couldn't think of anything I had done...I still figured I must have hurt my back somehow, and it was probably just a pinched nerve or something, and that with taking it easy and some time it would get better.  Then on Saturday I woke up and every joint in my body was sore and stiff.  I felt like I had the flu x 10...but I haven't had any other flu like symptoms (no fever, head or chest congestion, etc.).  The joint pain and stiffness seems worse in the morning, and gradually over the day will get a little better.  I've had arthritis in my wrists from an old injury for years, but they usually only bother my in really cold weather, or when I've done something repetitive and over-used them. Then they will swell and be stiff and sore.  All my joints feel like that right now, but there doens't seem to be any swelling, redness, and no previous injuries. So, I don't know what's going on.  If I wake up tomorrow and it's as bad as it was this morning, I'm going to call and see if I can make an appointment with my doctor.  I'm just wondering if anyone has any idea what this might be?  I've had family/friends suggest lyme disease (haven't been near any woods or animals...haven't seen any ticks), flu (no other flu symptoms, and it's been going on for 3 weeks), rhematoid arthritis (don't know much about this...so couldn't say), and multiple sclerosis (only because my aunt was diagnosed 2 years ago, and hers began with numbess in her feet and legs).   I thought maybe it was just a virus or infection...but it's been going on for 3 weeks now...and besides the joint pain and not sleeping well...I haven't had any other symptoms.   Thanks for your time and help! J

content: Dear, I think that u must takeyour complain in a serious way.all your suggestions must be considered so you must have some investigations first before we can decide. i think we must start with some simple blood test first then accordingly we can procced. these tests are: -ESR ( erythrocyte sedimintation rate). -CRP -CBC -serum uric acid. -Rhuematoid factor. -ANA ( antinuclear antibody). -urine analysis.  All types of autoimmune disease must be considered and also low back problems also must be taken in consedration but i think that systemic disease is more important.  Till you have these blood test you may take some non steroidal anitinflamatory drugs like diclofenac ( cataflam or voltaren). or any other similar drugs.  waiting for new data  thank you. title: I feel your pain!
content: I feel your pain Txjessy!  I too am experiencing unexplained migrating joint pain.  I just turned 29 in May and about a month ago I woke up with some minor pain in my ankles but couldn't for the life of me figure out what I did to make them hurt.  About a week later, my left ankle started to swell on the lower part and on the inside only.  Then the area that was swelling started turning pink and felt sort of warm.  About a week into that, the right ankle started swelling too.  My primary care doc did the usual blood work, all of which was normal.  He sent me to an ortho specialist who ordered more labs.    In the meantime, I am hurting!!!!  The very next day after I went to the ortho specialist for my initial consultation, I woke up with every joint in my body hurting like crazy!  And it's been that way ever since.  It's only been a few weeks but it feels like an eternity.  I've been taking Naproxen but it's not really helping.  I feel like I am stuck in an 80 year old's body!  I assume, based on my labs, that I probably don't have lupus or RA, but that I probably have some sort of infection or immflamation in my body.  It's wondering what kind of infection that is bothering me this weekend - other than the pain!!!  My mom was diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis a few years ago and another family member (not first line though) has Myasthenia Gravis.  I know some researchers think these autoimmune diseases are hereditary, but some don't.  Who knows!  I don't have any anwers for you, but I thought I'd share my story and let you know that you are not alone.  I know when I found this website it was because I was searching online for answers and I felt like I was the only young adult who had this problem.    Let me know further progress and I'll keep you posted on my diagnosis too if you'd like. author: txjessy  Guest Posts: 10 Joined: Tue May 31, 2005 4:26 pm Location: Texas
title: Lab Results
content: We got the lab results back.  They did a "CBC with Differential / Platelet", "Comp. Metabolic Panel", "Rheumatiod Arthritis Factor", "Antinuclear Antibodies Direct", and "Sedimentation Rate".  The doctor says that although there are some items elevated,  there isn't anything  that conclusively tells him what is causing the joint and muscle pain.  So, he wants to refer me to a Rheumatologist.  I called and can't get an appointment until July 25th.   So, for now I wait...and keep wondering.  There were 4 things in my lab results that showed to be elevated.    White Blood Cell Count 11.3 H x10E3/uL Limits 4.0-10.5  RDW 16.0 H % Limits 11.7-15.0  Neutrophils (Absolute) 8.2 H x10E3/uL Limits 1.8-7.8  ALT (SGPT) 46 H IU/L Limits 0-40  None of these seem to be very high over the limits.  But, in February, before all this started, I had a complete physical, and all these were within the normal range. So, it is quite a change in 4 months. Not sure if it means anything, or helps to figure out what's going on.  The RA Factor, ANA, and sed-rate, all seem ok (see below).  Rhematiod Arthritis Factor - RA Latex Turbid. 6.6 IU/mL Limits 0.0-13.9  Antinuclear Antibodies Direct 33 U/mL Limits: Negative <100   Sedimentation Rate - Westergren 15 mm/hr Limits 0-20  Antistreptolysin O Antibodies 31.6 IU/mL Limits 0.0-200.0  Does any of this help to give a clue as to what's going on?    I also asked my doctor about "Cat Scratch" disease/fever.  Several months ago my nephew (he's 7) began complaining of his leg hurting. At first his parents just thought he pulled something playing rough or jumping on the trampoline. But when he kept on talking about it, they got him down and realized the lymph nodes in his leg/groin area were very swollen and hard. They took him to the doctor, who did lots of tests, and an MRI. They could see that something had many of the lymph nodes in his leg swollen, and his WBC was elevated on his lab results, but they couldn't figure out what was causing it. They tried two rounds of anti-biotics, with no improvement. They finally sent him to a Children's Hospital to see an oncologist.  The oncologist first wanted to take some blood and do a culture for "Cat Scratch" fever.  It took 9 days to get it back, but it was positive.  They gave him a different kind of anti-biotic and he recovered quickly and has been great since then.  As I said, I asked my doctor about this, because I had also been around my nephew's new kitten, but the doctor doesn't seem to think this could be a possibility.  Granted, I don't remember getting scratched...but neither did my nephew, and they could never find a scratch on him.  I even called back to the doctors office Friday morning, and asked that since we have to wait a month for me to get in to see the Rheumotologist, could we go ahead and test for the "cat scratch" just to be sure.  The nurse said she would ask the doctor, and someone would call me back.  It's Tuesday night, and so far no one has called back.    I'm not sure what to do at this point......

author: sweetsugrbriches  Guest Posts: 12 Joined: Mon May 30, 2005 7:31 pm Location: Texas
title: got a few answers from my doc
content: Hi Tx!  Good to hear you are hanging in there.  How's your pain?  Are you taking an OTC anti-inflammatory or did your doc prescribe one for you?  I was taking Naproxen (Aleve), about 600 mg a day, but it didn't help me any.    When my ortho doc finally came into the office to review my labwork (this was last Monday afternoon), he had his nurse call me and schedule an appointment for the following Thursday and his office called in a prescription of steroids for me to start the next morning.  I think it was Methylprednisolone or something like that.  It was one of those six day packs that you take six the first day, five the next, four then next, etc.  They were a God-send!!  Within two days, almost all my pain was gone from everywhere.  My ankles were still a little stiff but for the most part, my body was pain free!  The swelling in my ankles was starting to go away and I couldn't have been happier!  Well, except for the fact that I've been on prescription diet pills for the past six months and I've lost 35 pounds so far - WOO HOO for me! - - and while on the steroids I had to stop the diet pills and I was soooooooo hungry!  Thankfullly I only gained two pounds while on the steroids last week and this past Monday I started my diet pills again and hopefully I can drop at least five pounds this week.  But anyways...  I went in to see my ortho doc last Thursday, after having been on the steroids since the Tuesday prior, and told him that my pain was gone and the swelling was going away.  I'm not sure if I mentioned in my previous posts that I also had some discoloration to my skin where the swelling was but it started out pink then turned more purple and even a little grayish.  Even though the swelling was going away, there was still some discoloration.  Just a little though.  My ortho doc was happy that the steroids were working and he wrote me a prescription for Mobic.  Mobic is supposed to be the newest anti-inflammatory on the market, and he gave me 7.5 mg a day.  He told me that since my Sed rate and CRP was elevated, he believed that my problem was something systemic.  I think the discoloration on my swollen ankles was an indicator too.  He told me to take the Mobic daily and to let him know if it controls my symptoms.  If it does, we'll continue with that and if not, or if I have "breakthrough symptoms", he said he could refer me to a Rheumatologist for further workup.    He couldn't give me a specific diagnosis but right now we're going with Unspecified Polyarthritis.  He hasn't ruled out an autoimmune disease but my ANA screening was negative and my RF was normal so it's probably not lupus or RA, but since my doc is an ortho doc and not a Rheumatologist he really couldn't diagnose an autoimmune disease.  So, Monday I woke up feelin' great and took my Mobic and my diet pill.  This morning, same thing.  But by about 6 pm, my ankles started feeling a little achy.  I carefully examined my ankles and low and behold...swelling!!!!  It's not bad like it was before, but it is starting again.  I don't have any joint pain and my ankles don't hurt really bad, but I am getting worried now that the swelling is starting again.    I took another Mobic this evening around 7 pm and we'll see if it helps with the swelling at all this evening.  I am going to call my ortho doc in the morning and ask if he wants me to continue with two Mobic a day or just go to a Rheumatologist.  I don't even know of any Rheumatologists in my town!!!  I'm sure I'll have the same problem as you and have to wait for a month or so just to be seen and then have to drive for 1/2 an hour just to get to the doctor's office!  I assume none of your labs came back elevated/low since your doc said he couldn't give you any clear answers, right?  I wonder what your CRP level was because mine was 15.4 and it's not supposed to be over 3 or 5 or something like that.  I just assumed that 15.4 was extremely high based on the normal range but I don't really know what extremely high would be.  Have you had any other symptoms other than joint/muscle pain?  Like dry eye or mouth ulcers?  What about fatigue?  And I know this is probably too personal and none of my business but have you noticed any decrease in your sex drive?  I'm not sure what to make of my symptoms.  Are they all unrelated?  Could they all be related to some systemic disorder and I just never connected them before?  It's all so confusing and I am getting so frustrated with not knowing what is wrong with me or how to prevent any of my symptoms.  Good luck and I hope you find some anwers...and some pain relief!!

author: sweetsugrbriches  Guest Posts: 12 Joined: Mon May 30, 2005 7:31 pm Location: Texas
title: just read your post
content: Hi there again Tx!  I guess I responded too soon because after I submitted my reply, I noticed that you posted again.  I too thought about Cat Scratch Fever because I have  cats.  My mom and I rescue cats and between the two of us we have 13 cats so I get scratched all the time.  I used to be a vet tech so I have a little bit of knowledge about Cat Scratch Fever, but not much.  I even thought about Toxoplasmosis but I don't think I have that either.  Here are my labs:  Blood chemistry was all within normal limits (electrolytes, blood sugar & kidney function was all normal). My liver function was normal too - - ALT was 12 (range is <45) and AST was 20 (range is <45).  TSH was normal (1.835 with a range of 0.35 - 5.50).  Red Blood Cell count was normal.  RDW was 13.9 with a range of 11.5 - 14.5.  White Blood Cell count was also normal at 5.2 with a range of 4.0 - 11.0.  However, my Neutrophils were lowered at 40% with a range of 42% - 77%.  But my Lymphocytes were elevated at 46% with a range of 16% - 43%.    My RF was within limits at 25 (range is <43).  ANA Screen just said Negative.  No range given.  Sed rate was elevated at 29 with range of 0-20.  My CRP was elevated at 15.4 with a range of <=5.0.  What was your Antistreptolysin O Antibodies test for?  Sounds like they were testing for strep, is that right?  I also considered that maybe I had a staph infection but I don't know where I would have gotten it from as I don't have any open wounds but I guess I could have gotten it from bad food or just airborne.  My ortho doc definitely thinks my problem is something systemic but he doesn't know what.  This is so frustrating!!!

author: Stephy123  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Thu Aug 11, 2005 3:52 pm Location: Erie, PA
title: Experiencing Sore Muscle and Joint Pain Too!
content: I'm so glad that I found this page. I'm experiencing many of the same symptoms as stated above. My systoms started in January. My pain started with a pulled groin muscle. Then, it happened a few weeks later on the other side. Then the pain jumped to my arm muscle. Then, a few weeks later, I experienced pain in my shoulder. During the past few months, the pain seemed to jump all over my body but it wasn't too frequent (about once every 3 or 4 weeks). Lately, the pain is occuring every week! I can't stand it!  The past few weeks, the pain has been primarily in my legs and on top of my foot. I have also noticed some discoloration! I finally went for a physical and visited a great nurse practictioner. She sent me for some blood work.  My ESR rate was very elevated (42H). My Cardio CRP was also elevated (29.9). My Uric Acid rate was high (4.9). My Glocose reate was in the normal range (97). My Rheumatoid Factor was in the normal range also (13).  My blood work did not help my nurse practicioner to diagonise anything. I've been on two rounds of antibotics (just in case I have a staff infection), i'm also taking Flexeril (muscle relaxor - helps me to sleep when I'm in serious pain) and Tramadol (Prescribed Acetaminophen) which does help somewhat. I've recently just started taking Mobic too - which if I take it right on the onset of the pain, it does seem to help.  Anyway, I have an appointment with a rheumatoidolist on Aug. 16 (took over a month to get this appointment)! I hope I can get some answers.  Again, I'm so glad that I found these postings. I explain my pain to friends and family, but I'm only 35 years old and I think they think I'm going nuts (and at times, I do feel this way). I will pray for all of you - I hope you all feel better. Please feel free to contact me or to keep in touch with me regarding your diagnosis.  Best of Luck to You All, Stephanie
posted_time: Post  by Stephy123 » Thu Aug 11, 2005 4:08 pm

author: sweetsugrbriches  Guest Posts: 12 Joined: Mon May 30, 2005 7:31 pm Location: Texas
title: glad you found us
content: Hi Stephy123 -   I understand what you mean about trying to explain your pain to friends and family.  I feel like maybe I am becoming a hypochondriac with all the symptoms I try to explain to others.  I truly feel like I may go insane somedays.  My pain has subsided for the most part.  I last saw my doctor at the end of June and he told me to discontinue the Mobic and just take Naproxen (400 mg twice daily).  All anti-inflammatories can cause some water retention but everyone reacts differently to each different drug.  He thought maybe the Mobic was causing me to retain more water than Naproxen and since we got everything under control with the steroid pack, he thought maybe Naproxen would keep everything in check.  It took several weeks, but finally the swelling and discoloration started to go away.  I haven't had any other joint pains and the swelling in my ankles hasn't come back yet but they hurt everyday.  They aren't just horribly painful but they ache everyday.  Being on my feet a lot and when my feet get cold seems to make it worse.  The pain isn't bad but it's really annoying.   So I take 400 mg of Naproxen twice daily and just pray that it keeps the strong pains away.  It's all my other minor symptoms that keep me frustrated.  I did a lot of research on autoimmune disease and I know that a lot of them share symptoms.  I just hate not knowing what is wrong with me.  Right now, my biggest problem is dry eye.  I never really noticed it before but when I tried to wear contacts for the first time in March, it became really bothersome.  I tried so many different brands of contacts and finally gave up at the end of June.  I scheduled an appointment with an opthamologist and he tested me for dry eye.  The tests came back that I had mild dry eye, more so in my left than in my right eye.  He prescribed Restasis but told me that it would take at least 6 to 8 weeks before I noticed anything.  I've only been taking it for about a month so my eyes still bother me, even though I'm not wearing my contacts again yet.  Hopefully I'll be able to try contacts again in a few more months.    I've also been getting a lot of mouth ulcers lately.  Just one after another for the past few months.  They are REALLY annoying!  And I have ZERO sex drive!  My poor husband is really frustrated with that!  I am only 29 years old - I'm not supposed to feel like this!  I just feel like it's one thing after another and I'm too young for all this!  I wish you luck and hope it all works out for you.

author: Stephy123  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Thu Aug 11, 2005 3:52 pm Location: Erie, PA
title: [no title]
content: Hi sweetsugrbriches,  Thanks for the quick reply. I'm glad to hear that Naproxen is helping you. I may ask the specialist if it may help me too. I'm hoping that the specialist won't put me on the steriods because I hear too many bad things about that kind of treatment (I have a friend who has been on steroids for years and can't get off the drug, which has destroyed her adreanal gland and more).  Today, woke up with a pulled muscle in my arm. I'm so sick of this. My aunt is worried that my symptoms sounds like Muscluar Dystropy (MS). Frankly, I'm a bit worried too although I have no family history of this disease. But, for the most part, my pain has been in muscles versus joints. I have some joint pain now and then, but not compared to the pulled muscles all over my body.  I'm beginning to feel crippled. It's hurting just to type this so I'm going to cut this short...  Oh yeah, about the cold thing. Heat does really help me. I have a gym membership that I'm totally not using, however, I have gone just to sit in the whirlpool. It really helps! Perhaps you may try that when you're in a lot of pain.  As for the dry eye, I just resently had my eye doctor try 5 different contacts on me! I finally settled with Bausch & Lomb SofLens. I also use Bausch & Lomb Renu with Moisture Loc. Perhaps you might try different lens? The thin, scratchy ones really aggreviate dry eyes. I hope this helps...  Have you seen a specialist or just a family doctor? I hope that you continue to feel better. How long does the doctor want you to continue to take the prescriptions for your pain?  Again, thanks for letting me know that I'm not going insane. Your letter made me feel better!  Take Care, Stephanie

author: another_stoopid_patient  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Feb 12, 2006 10:20 pm
title: [no title]
content: I will be as "polite" as I can to reading such a reply to someone's problem.  The problem should not go "UN-NOTED"!!??  No wonder people put off going to the doctor and are so cynical towards the medical professions.  I believe the problem should not go UN-CURED!  Your reply sounds like this person should go to the doctor so in case they DIE from their affliction, then the doctor at least had a note of the problem (which would be a good malpractice suit it seems).   We are more often as not fed cookie-cutter solutions to our (often times life-threatening or altering) medical problems...  the doctor listens to us for about 60 seconds, checks pulse, breathing, blood pressure, etc., and then puts the patient into whichever category allows them to prescribe the newest drug they learned of on  their last pharmacutically-paid trip to hawaii.  Then if this doesn't fix the problem, oh well, no biggie, cuz the patient gets to come back for multiple visits and tests and the doctor can bill the insurance out the ass and buy another porche.  I'm sick of it.    And yes, there are a FEW good doctors out there who actually shun pharmacutical manipulation and care about their patients... but the vast majority are giving the entire profession a bad name.  And if you don't have insurance, plan on not getting better, since you can't afford all the tests and doctor visits they don't bother with you.  Gotta love the HIPPOCR-I-TIC oath.

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Oops! Sorry about that.  I see that you have had opioids to the level of tolerance. Has your doctor tried meds for neuropathic pain? Neuropathic pains don't respond to opioids usually.  Neuropathic pains respond to antiepileptic and antidepressant medications. Regional anesthesia or block may be required if all fails. It would be best to discuss regarding these with your doctor.  Hope this helps.  Warm regards,  Bill

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  When I mentioned the antidepressant/antiepileptic usage for neuropathic pain, do not be misled by the terms used to describe these medicines. Eventhough the terms imply its usual indication in depression or epilepsy, there can be more than one use for a single drug. And the dosage used for its antidepressant action or antiepileptic action is different from that when used for its analgesic action.   Another fear among the medical profession as well as the society is the addiction potential of analgesic drugs like opioids. It would be enlightening to note that there is no ceiling effect for the use of morphine, as long as pain ramains. Multiple studies have indicated that because of this common 'fear,' such medicines are underprescribed, leaving patients to suffer pain at the expense of an unrealistic addiction potential.   As for your doctor's reluctance to anesthesia, I would presume it to be medicolegally founded. Risk exists even in prescribing tylenol, let alone surgical procedures.  I hope the experts in V.A. figure out some way to release you from the pain you suffer.  Warm regards,  bill

author: R. Zein, Pharm D  Pharmacist Posts: 157 Joined: Tue Jul 12, 2005 9:16 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Dear Pianist  Initial treatment of carpal tunnel syndrome generally involves resting the affected hand and wrist for at least 2 weeks, avoiding activities that may worsen symptoms, and immobilizing the wrist in a splint to avoid further damage from twisting or bending.     Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, such as aspirin, ibuprofen, and other nonprescription pain relievers, may ease pain.     Also , cool (ice) packs and prednisone (taken by mouth) or lidocaine (injected directly into the wrist) can relieve swelling and pressure on the median nerve and provide immediate, temporary relief.      If symptoms last for 6 months or more, doctors may recommend surgery to sever the band of tissue around the wrist and reduce the pressure.  The good news is that recurrence of carpal tunnel syndrome after surgery is rare.  At the meantime, you may want to use Advil to ease the pain, or have something prescribed by your doctor for the same purpose.  Thank you very much , and all the best in your concerts..
posted_time: Post  by R. Zein, Pharm D » Sat Feb 04, 2006 12:32 pm

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: Re: Need some advice...Ulnar Nerve issues.
content: Hi there DD,  I'll try and answer... Ulnar neuritis sysmptoms are partly due to irritation of the nerve (pins and needles and pain), and partly due to loss of function of the nerve function (numbness, weakness).  If the loss of function is established, then this is a result of nerve damage, and recovery is based on how damaged the nerve actually is.  Indications of the severity of the damage may be a) whether the numbness is persistent or just transient b) whether there is muscle wasting or not c) whether there is clawing of the fingers or not. DreamDragoninNY wrote:1.  Should I get both compressions done at once? Depends on the findings of the conduction tests...if only the elbow is done, then sometimes the clawing gets worse...called the "ulnar paradox" DreamDragoninNY wrote:2.  How much does this complicate the surgery, and the recovery process.? The extra procedure, if done, will not greatly complicate the surgery except in that with two operations, you have twice as many sites for wound related problems. DreamDragoninNY wrote:3.  My life is my hands...what are the negatives of this surgery, the real risks?  Apart from wound related problems, there is I guess nerve damage during the procedure.  The most significant complication is that the nerve function may not fully recover...particularly likely as the problem has been around for a few years. DreamDragoninNY wrote:4.  I have read recovery times from 2 months to a year and a half...can any one give me more concrete answers on this, as my business will be completely shut down during recovery. Nope, crystal ball not working today  DreamDragoninNY wrote:5.  If the surgery is not successful, what is my worst case scenerio here? Worst case is that nerve does not recover, you have clawed, hand with numb little and ring fingers, and reduced ability to do fine movements of the hand.  Despite this, ulnar nerve problems may be resonably well tolerated.  Best case...you recover full function, in record time, and win the lottery...  Hope this helps  Saif

author: LADYMARINE  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Dec 10, 2005 1:17 am
title: UNDIAGNOSED FOOT PAIN HELP??
content: Hello,  I am a 38 year old female that has had progressively worsening foot pain for the past 10 years. It has gotten so bad that it hurts to walk for any period of time. The pain always starts in the 3rd through 5th toes and the pads of my feet. It starts as a burning/stinging sensation then with increased aggrevation from any weight bearing it starts a painful numbing sensation and eventually almost total numbing in the toes and pads. Sometimes it will move to the entire outside of my feet and if I continue the agrevating activity my entire foot will go numb. It started about 10 years ago and was initially mild with symptoms only occurring when I ran or stood in place for long periods. It has progressed over the years to occurring eveyday with any prolonged walking, standing and rapid increased symptoms with running, elitical machines, or any althletic activity. I have seen several specialist and no one seems to be able to diagnose. (Thought it was mortons nueromas at one point and went through injections and the only result was painful muscle spasms 8-10 times per day). X-rays show nothing, MRI's in 2002 showed bone marrow edema (unknown why since I had no activity for several months due to the nueroma traeatments, second opiniion resulted in MRA that showed no nueromas) Currently ortho thinks maybe tarsal tunnel syndrom, new MRI show nothing. EMG shows no nerve reaction in the bottom of either foot in the outside nerves on bottom of feet, but nerve reaction in legs and top of feet are normal. Just sitting here right now, my feet aare partially numb, a stinging/throbbing/ numbing sensation if that makes any sense.  I've invested hundreds of dollars in different shoes, orthodics, and everything I can think of to relieve the pain.       This posses a real problem for me because I am a US Marine with 17 years of active service. I have built up a pain tolerance to get by, but it is becoming increasingly more difficult. I have to keep physically fit to continue serving to be able to retire, but I really getting worried as this condition worsens that I will be able to continue passing my physical fittness test. It has gotten to the point that it is sheer will to get through the pain when I have to run 3 miles, stand in long formations or wear my dress unforms because of the shoes. I can no longer wear any kind of heels without a great deal of pain. I buy all my civilian shoes a size bigger and wider. I must have a lot of padding on my feet. walking barefoot on hard floors triggers pain a numbing within a few minutes.  Military docs can't figure it out. I also have pain in lower back, but MRI's show slight bulding within normal range.    I'm concerned if it continues to worsen sooner or later I may not be able to walk. I have three kids, I want to be a good mom and be able to do normal activities with my kids.   If you can offer any suggestions, I would be greatful.  LADYMARINE

author: Peterug13  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Dec 29, 2004 11:58 pm Location: Newport RI USA
title: Chest Wall/shoulder/neck pain
content: Hello!  Thanks in advance for taking the time to read and answer my legnthy post. I will try to be as brief as possible.  I am a 38 year old male in relatively good health. I have been having a constant problem with a fullness and sensation of pressure in my chest and epigastric area as well as neck sorenes, tenderness, pain in my left shoulder and arm as well as tenderness to touch in these areas. Occasionally I feel light headed and have a sensation of not getting enough air or a choking sensation in my neck. This all came on suddenly about 6 months ago while I was at work lifting a heavy object over my head. I went to the ER and was hospitalized for observation and further testing. The following were performed, multiple EKG's, chest x ray. cardiac enzymes and an Echo Stress all were negative and ruled out cardiac cause. Tidal volume and PulseOx are good even with the tightness in my chest (100% on room air) I have also had an MRI of my thoracic and cervical spine with the exception of a slight "bulge" at T-1 it was normal. I have also had a normalhead CT w/contrast.   the pain in the chest is the most bothersome. When I do something that moves my left shoulder back it is the worst. The pain occurs just adjacent to the edge of my breastbone a little ways out from where the ribs meet itand starts at my collar bone and goes down to just below my left nipple. The tightness sensation is mostly in the left side of my chest and covers most of the left chest from the shoulder to just below the last rib. My neck pain varies in intensity and is mostly a vague stifness. There are points in my chest and neck that are sore to touch and sometimes even a light breeze on my chest feels like a lot more pressure than it should. It is better when I lay down but it is always there. The soreness and stiffness in my chest is definitly worse first thing in the morning and gets a little better with some gentle stretching and moist heat from the shower. It is the fullness and tightness that really concern me. I should also mention that there are activities that bring on a numbness sensation in my back just below the left shoulder blade. Doing dishes and driving are activities that make that prevalent. There is also one spot in my left chest near my shoulder that is very sore, feels like a knot and when I press on it I get severe pain down the legnth of my left arm. I also have the sensation sometimes that the end of a rib near the sternum is pushing out against my skin although I cant actually feel a lump or obvious end of a rib poking out there. Sharp pains between ribs in varying locations front and back and sometimes sharp pain in the middle of my back just below the shoulder blades.   My PCP keeps saying its a pulled muscle in my chest wall but the amount of time this has been going on (6 months) makes me wonder. He says the other pains are part of getting older and have nothng to do with the chest pain. I have been going to physical therapy for four months now and there is NO improvement. I would appreciate your opinion.   THANKS!!!

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Pballgrl,  Sorry to hear about your knee problem...I will try to help.  It is difficult to assess on-line as it were, but let's have a go anyway.  There are several features of your symptoms that suggest possibilities as to what the the cause of your pain is.  If I can just decribe the knee joint to you first as a way of explanation.  The end of Femur (thigh bone) artculates with the top of Tibia (main bone of your lower leg).  On the front  of your femur, is the knee cap, the patella, and this moves up and down as you flex and extend your knee, travelling in a groove in the femur.  Between the femur and the tibia are two cresent shaped bits of cartilage (the menisci) which act something like cushions.  Twisting injuries can lead to injuries of the menisci, and typically these cause intermittent pains, aching in the knee, periodic swelling and locking of the knee...although none of these are absolute.  What is more likely in your knee, from what you describe is something called Chondromalacia Patellae.  It is a poorly understood condition, and orthopaedic surgeons themselves oten disagree as the significance of thsi sometimes.  Essentially the problem is due to some damage of "softening undeneath your knee cap.  What this does is cause pain when the pressure is maximal between the patella and femur is greatest,  typically, when load is applied to a bent knee.  This occurs when you go up and downstairs, get up from a chair or from the floor, squat, kneel etc.   This seems to be what you are describing.  Why this occurs is difficult to explain in a short space, it is more frequent in young women. There are several therapeutic options,  the simplest initial treatment is to exercise your quads, in particular your VMOs (Vastus Medialis Obliquus).  What you do is lie in bed, legs straight out.  Turn you foot outwards, and lift your legs up and down.  You should feel some tightening of the muscles on the inner side of your thigh.  Do this twice a day, for about 10 minutes.  It taks a while to settle down, and sometimes needs more drastic action...  Try these, I am happy to discuss further, but if I carried on I have no doubt you'd fall asleep with boredom...and this is no substitute for face to face contact...  Best wishes  Saif

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Rose,  Difficult to say, without examining you, and indeed often the cause is not clear even even you are examined by a specialist.  CMP can also cause these symptoms,  and typically occurs on both knees, and in women more often than men.  Other causes such as meniscal problems (cartilage tears) rarely affect both knoees simultaneously.  Some orthopeadic surgeons feels a fold in the knee, called a plica can also cause these symptoms, but plicae are also found in normal asymptomaatic individuals.  Saif

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: I will just list a few of the more important medical conditions that could be associated with foot pain.  Arthritic Conditions. Arthritic conditions, particularly osteoarthritis and gout, can cause foot pain. Although rheumatoid arthritis almost always develops in the hand, the ball of the foot can also be affected.   Diabetes. Diabetes is an important cause of serious foot disorders. It is discussed in a separate section.  Diseases That Affect Muscle and Motor Control. Diseases that affect muscle and motor control, such as Parkinson's disease, can cause foot problems.  High Blood Pressure. High blood pressure can cause fluid build-up and swollen feet. The effects of high blood pressure on the nervous and circulatory systems can cause pain, loss of sensation, and tingling in the feet, and can increase the susceptibility for infection and foot ulcers.  Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis, in which bone loss occurs, can cause foot pain.  Of note is the fact that you have a family history of both diabetes and parkinson's disease. However, I would doubt that these diseases would present with foot pain. I would take a careful look at the possibility of arthritis or osteoporosis.  A calcaneal spur is another condition which leads to intense pain which generally originates from the heal but could be felt in the sole of the foot as well. All 3 conditions (arthritis, osteoporosis, spur) can be excluded by an x-ray.  Best wishes,

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Dear Veronica,  The vast majority of clicky knees are not associated with any significant pathology within the knee.  Occassionally torn menisci, damage to the joint surface, or a fold within the knee (called a plica) can cause the clicks. These are worth treating if they are associated with pain, swelling or instability (the knee giving way).  You clearly are atheletic, and do enough activity to sustain any of these injuries, but as I say the vast majority of such clicks are completely harmless, and without the above features would not warrant any further investigation or treatment.  Regards   Saif
posted_time: Post  by Dr. A. Saif » Sat Mar 19, 2005 11:10 am

author: woodsskier3  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Dec 03, 2005 11:15 am Location: Maine
title: [no title]
content: You have the classic symptoms of an ulnar nerve entrapment.  This is usually caused by damage to the ulnar nerve, usually at elbow or hand.  Do you rembember hitting your funny bone or have you hurt your wrist on the pinky side recently from a bang?  Do you lean on your elbow much? If the problem is with your elbow, try to adjust your sleeping posture.  You may need to keep from sleeping with your elbow bent.  I would see a doctor and ask for a nerve conduction test called EMG - this is not expensive.  See someone about this even if it doesnt go away, because it might come back to haunt you later.  If you think you have a circulation problem, there are easy ways a doctor can check your blood flow.  If the problem is with your hand and you cant wait, search the net for "Allen Test" this is an easy way to check for a curculation issue.  Make sure: any diagnosis a doctor gives you is solidly backed up with diagnostic testing proof; Don't just take their word.  Ulnar nerve problems can lead to permanent wasting of the hand muscles if left untreated, making it hard to use your hands for finer movements.

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Nikki,  By the number of replies you have had, (and really quite helpful advice, I might add), you will see that it is a fairly common accident, and as you have experienced, fairly painful too!  Typically, the person doing this has caught the little toe against a door, or a table leg, running in barefeet.  The toe is often broken, but it doesn't need to be to be painful, and strapping to its buddy is the most commonly recommended treatment.  Bruising and swelling is also very common, and sometimes causes more concern, but even then the problem is not too bad. You say there has been some bleeding...this is not so common.  A cut to the skin technically makes this an open injury, and often orthpaedic surgeons tend to be a bit more aggressive managing such injuries.  If you are worried let me know.    Apart from strapping it, the toe should be kept elevated, and ice packs applied.  The healing process effectively starts the moment you injure it, and steadily improves over the next few weeks(!). By about 4 weeks the bulk of the pain is gone...in the meantime some painkillers and open shoes should  make life a little easier...Sadly you will now find out exactly how often one  knocks one's little toes throughout the day!  It is very rare for these fractures not to heal (if that is what you have), but it can happen...I would suggest DaveT is rather unfortunate in this regard.  "Buddy strapping" should prevent a little toe fracture  healing in an angulated fashion, non union is extremely rare.

content: Three + weeks ago I was out to dinner with some coworkers and on my way out I did not see a short step.  I fell forward with both my knee's taking most of the blow.  It hurt but I got up and was able to walk.  At that point I think my ego was more damaged than my knees.  When I got home I iced them both and continued to ice them for about 2 days, once or twice a day.  The ice seemed to help but my left knee seemed to be sorer than my right.  This was a great relief since I had ACL reconstruction and two other knee surgeries on that knee awhile back.  There was some bruising on both knee's but not all that bad and I expected them to be sore for at lest a week or so. But now for the last 3 weeks I have been having pain in the outer side of the L knee when I go from sitting at my desk for a few hours to standing up.  It feels sharp and it is more of a bone pain.  The knee is stable, it does not "go out" and I can twist and turn, and bend it with no problem.  There really has not been much if any swelling.  The bruising is gone now and all I have now is the pain.  It could be that I bruised the bone and it is just taking a long time to heal.  I hope I don't have a fracture or did some ligament damage. author: ouchie  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Fri Aug 22, 2003 12:49 am Location: Washington
title: What should I expect from my doctor?
content: Hello! I am a 28  year old female with some questions for my doctor.  I have just moved, and am going to him for the second time.  I'm a little unsure of him. My history: I pulled muscles in my lower back about 6 months ago while lifting my 10 month old.  It only took about a week to completely heal.  When we made a cross country drive 4 months after, I started having ALOT of back pain.  I dealt with it, but the pain became so bad I had to see a doc.  He told me I had 3 pinched nerves, and spasms in my lower back on the right side.  He gave me some at home stretching/conditioning exercises, told me to get good insoles, and sent me on my way.  Since then, the pain hasn't gone away.  Some days are better than others.  I have been under ALOT of stress lately.  I have been feeling a little depressed.  The pain has gotten ALOT worse with this stress also (new job/BIG pressure).  My pain is mostly lower back/with tingling all up the left side of my back.  Tingling from my left shoulder to mid back, where my pinched nerve is. I made an appt with him, and started to go through my medical history.  I did a little research on line, and was wondering if I should bring all this to his attention.  On top of the above mentioned pain, I have been extremely fatigued.  I sleep approx. 6 hours during the night.  It takes all my energy to get out of bed and get myself and two children ready and out the door.  I fight looking at the bed, in fear that I will fall back asleep.  I am exhaused when I get to work, and my back pain flares!  I have a very hard time concentrating.  I forget what I'm doing about 25% of the time.  I lose concentration halfway through a conversation, like my mind shuts down (which isn't good when you're in sales!)  I sit about 50% of the day, stand the rest. I have previously been diagnosed with Psoriasis, Raynoynds (sp?) syndrome, meniere's disease (which I personally think was misdiagnosed), and vertigo.  The vertigo is under control (disappeared when I became pregnant in 2001).  My inner ear still aches from time to time.  My legs have stared to ache, along with my upper arms.  I have had a mild headached for 4 days now (taking Aleve).  I have also been getting painfully bloated stomachaches for the last 4 years.  I have ignored it, and just thought gas.  This happens about 3 times a week.  My husband saw a commercial about IBS medication, and said I should get checked for it....he said my symptoms are very similar. I know I should bring all this up to my doctor.  My question is:  what should be his next step?  Rheumatologist? Chiropractor? Physical Therapy? Psychologist? What could be going on with me? Do you think this is all stress realted? Thank you so much for you time.  I appreciate you reading this and taking the time to reply.  My appointment is this coming Tues, and would like to go to my doc somewhat knowledgeable about what to expect next!
posted_time: Post  by ouchie » Fri Aug 22, 2003 1:08 am

author: Shadowydreamer  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Fri Aug 22, 2003 12:46 am Location: Vancouver'ish, Canada  Contact:   Contact Shadowydreamer       ICQ   Website   Yahoo Messenger   AOL
title: [no title]
content: Wow, your back problems sound so similar to mine. I'm not a doctor, so take what I say as a fellow suffer and nothing more.   It sounds like you have soft tissue damage, so going to a chiropracter may actually make the problem worse. What you want to demand is a CT scan of your back. This will identify any bulging disc that are pinching the nerve, or bone growths that are pushing on them, etc. I, personally, find it unlikely you have three pinched nerves, but it's not impossible.  If you do indeed have pinched nerves, these can be fixed with surgery. (I  think it's like 80% success rate with herniated discs)  That's the good news.  I've found Ortho Surgeons a mucn friendlier breed than Neurosurgeons. (They seem to have spent so much time learning what they do with such amazing ability that they didn't have time to realize they're dealing with a feeling (often scared) person.   A great help for the backpain (so you can sit in chairs and do things that help you) is an electric blanket. Of course, you probably can't bring of one of those into work, so I'd suggest a heating pad. It won't mean you aren't in pain, but it keeps it minimal for *me* until I finish doing what I want to do.   As far as the headaches, its probably very very understandable stress headaches. I've found sinus headache medication works miracles in getting rid of them, but again, just my experience.  I offer you heaps of sympathy. I have massive back woes but don't have any children and so can only imagine the nightmare of pain and suffering your life has become in trying to keep up.  And if you aren't comfortable with your new doctor, find another. Sometimes doctors-patients just don't work well together, finding a second one is often a good idea. Things will work better for *you*.  Hope some of this helped!  -Shady.
posted_time: Post  by Shadowydreamer » Fri Aug 22, 2003 1:24 am

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: What should I expect from my doctor?
content: Dear Ouchie,  Having psoriasis is associated with the presence of arthritis in lots of patiens and this might present as back pain or arthritis of the fingers of the hands as well.  Does the alleve that you take for your headaches make your back pain better? Have you tried any thing else for the back pain? A heating pad is a good idea, you might want to try it.  See your doctor on tuesday and then he will decide whether it is necessary to have a ct scan of your back or not because if you do not have any signs of herniated discs clinically then the ct scan will be unrevealing. You can raise your concerns during that appointment and ask him if he could refer you to an orthopedic surgeon if whatever treatment he offers you does not improve your condition within a certain period of time.  Most of the back pain that people experience is most probably due to unhealthy sitting habits (especially if you are using a computer in your job as this will put more stress on your neck vertebrae) and may be bad mattresses. So always try to sit straight and try to get enough sleep because to some people 6 hours of sleep are not enough.  Once more, thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Yasser Mokhtar » Fri Aug 22, 2003 6:14 am

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: What should I expect from my doctor?
content: Dear Ouchie,  It sounds that you are a tense person or under a lot of pressure at your new job or simply one of those perfectionistics that are never satisfied with what they did because you should have done better. This is not going to help your back.  Not being able to sleep at night could be related to a thyroid disorder in addition to the usual insomnia.  When you see you doctor ask him about the possibility of this being a thyroid disorder and tell him about your insomnia and see what he thinks about a sleep aid for you may be that's the problem.   Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: julie5914  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Wed May 18, 2005 11:32 am Location: Athens, Ga
title: Have the same problem
content: Hi there, I have similar trouble, but I wanted to alert you to Celiac disease. It is an intolerance to gluten and is not caused by stress or tenseness - it is an autoimmune disease that is treatable. It has many symptoms and can be hard to pin point, but there are blood tests available. I would encourage you to get these if you have low back pain, tiredness, and stomach troubles. Celiac will cause muscle aches, nutritional deficiencies constipation, big D and stomach pain.

author: fearuvhorses  Guest Posts: 13 Joined: Tue Jun 10, 2003 7:57 pm Location: Alberta, Canada
title: Scaphoid Fracture in Youth
content: My 15 yr old son was injured in a quadding accident last week.  He says he felt and "heard" a snap.  He has no side-to-side rotation of his wrist and has been in such extreme pain that he has passed out 3 times in the shower.  Initial diagnosis on Saturday by the emergeny physician was "a bad sprain".  My son has had multiple sports injuries, including fractures and sprains and tried to tell the doctor "I felt it break.  I know its broken."  The doctor said nothing showed on the x-rays.  My son was in so much pain that I took him back yesterday.  He saw a different ER doc who did some simple "try to do this, try to do that, does this hurt? does that hurt?"  Then the doctor said that it appeared to be a "Scaphoid Fracture" but he would do some new x-rays with different views from the last time.  Sure enough, the bone is broken right across about mid-line.  My son was put into a thumb spica cast to his elbow.  The ER doc gave us this list of possible outcomes, none of which sounded so great.  What I don't understand is that there is not a great chance of this type of injury healing without surgical intervention.  Also, what I have been able to learn about it is that there should not be so much pain as my son is experiencing.  He is a very active athlete (hence all the injuries) and he has broken this wrist three other times so is quite concerned that if things are not done properly that he will not be able to have full use.  So, my questions: 1.  Is an orthoepoedic consult recommended? 2.  Is surgery advisable sooner rather than as a "last ditch attempt". 3.  Does severe pain indicate other trauma (to ligaments, muscle, etc.)?  Thank you.  B.
posted_time: Post  by fearuvhorses » Tue Jul 20, 2004 12:15 pm

author: DeLWolcott  Guest Posts: 293 Joined: Fri Jun 24, 2005 5:47 pm Location: Texas
title: [no title]
content: This answer is quite late, but yes, an orthopedic consultation should have been given at the time of injury by the ER physician.  That much pain should have been addressed more aggressively in my opinion.    But, as you, I'm a parent and I only want the absolute best for my children.  I do hope that a consultation was received eventually and everything was done to make sure that your son recovered as much movement and as little pain as possible.

content: I'm 18 years old, and my hands are constantly cold and clammy. i guess i have bad circulation or something...but thats not what concerns me the most.   for awhile now my fingers have been periodically swelling. my mother is a nurse and she thought perhaps it was because of my hands constantly being in water or maybe from the chemicals i use at work, so i kept my hands clear of water and chemicals as best i could for awhile and the swelling kept coming back.  its not my whole finger that swells,  its always from my middle joint to my nail/tip of my finger, and when you press down on the swollen area its kinda harder and lumpy. my fingers are red, itchy and obviously swollen, you can tell just by looking theyre obviously inflamed. they hurt too!    its only my fingers that swell, my toes are fine, and its only a small part of my fingers too.  i havent been bit by any animals, i don't have any nail infections, nothing is broken, no insect bites, skin allergies or anything that could cause this.  its really starting to worry me. ..could this be serious? please help
posted_time: Post  by Zonda » Sat Feb 12, 2005 1:46 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Zonda, Generally speaking when I hear a complaint of cold hands with swollen painful joints,  the first things that come to mind is Raynaud's syndrome/phenomenon  and arthritis. With Raynaud's there is an over reacted constriction on the blood vessels which cause the feeling of coldness. The affected areas turn white, then may become dusky. Upon warming the affected area the skin may turn red, throb, or swell. Raynaud's may be the initial sign of Rheumatoid arthritis among other things. Sincerely, Rntdj
posted_time: Post  by Theresa Jones, RN » Mon Feb 14, 2005 9:28 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi KristineE, Ulnar Tunnel Syndrome/Ulnar Nerve Entrapment/Cubital Tunnel Syndrome, typically affects the "ring and pinky" fingers. This generally causes numbness of these two fingers. Repetative motions do not likely cause this disorder as it does in carpal tunnel syndrome. You should call your physician for an evaluation. Sincerely, Rntdj
