author: Bandolph  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Tue Sep 20, 2005 9:16 am Location: Pittsburgh
title: Elbow troubles.
content: Hi, I am a 48 year old male. I am dealing with a number of orthopedic problems but one has become an overwhelming concern.  I had a multiple fracture of my left elbow at the age of 7. The joint was rebuilt from the remains of the growth plates. It was a good job by the doctor considering what he had to work with. The joint never again had more than half of the normal range of motion.  The wrist was only able to rotate about 40 degrees. The ulna cap was removed in 1996 to relieve pain.  I have been on Celebrex for years and I have been using Ultram daily for the last couple years. However the pain has been intense and getting worse over the last year.  My family doctor tried steroids but they  made me too jittery, they did cut the pain and swelling. I saw a notable orthopedic here in Pittsburgh and his first reaction to my X-rays  was disbelief. He could not believe my elbow was that bad. He noted to me that arthritis that bad is not usually seen in someone my age. He stated that the best alternative for me would be Joint replacement but that it was unethical to do at my age.  I understand his points, yet I still have my problem. He did give me a shot of cortisone but it only made it worse. As a funny aside the Doctor had his PA give me the shot with a resident watching. As the fluid went into the joint my arm muscles started to spasm.  I thought the resident was going to freak. His eyes got real big.  My job entails me having to be exposed to great temperature and moisture changes ( I have to examine the fresh produce in the coolers) about 20 times each morning then I have to type my report into a database. Even the typing is getting to be painful.  Upon rising in the morning I feel great. It only takes about an hour though until my arm starts to ache. I carry my arm in my coat pocket as it acts like a sling and that helps a little. The pain is mostly in the muscles around the joint and inside the joint.  So what do I do now? I feel like my family doc is unsure about what to do and the impression I got from the Ortho was to call him when I get older.  I am worried about muscular damage because the arm responds with swelling every time I exercise.  What should I do next?
posted_time: Post  by Bandolph » Tue Sep 20, 2005 9:49 am

author: DeLWolcott  Guest Posts: 293 Joined: Fri Jun 24, 2005 5:47 pm Location: Texas
title: [no title]
content: Joint replacement may be unethical in a male your age with no previous history in the joint to be replaced, but I do believe that you fall into special circumstances.    Ask for a referral to an orthopedic physician or rheumatologist, who should have the final word on surgery.  Good luck!

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi crimsondynamics, Poorly fitting shoes cause blisters, bunions, among other foot problems. Normal walking is heel to toe gait. In children toe walking is typically only for a short period of time, approximately two-three months. Persistence after this time frame should be evaluated by a physician to assure that no anomalies are present. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: JenevaRN  Guest Posts: 16 Joined: Wed Aug 31, 2005 4:50 pm Location: Northern NJ
title: [no title]
content: It sounds from your description like it may be one of your lymph nodes that is troubling you.  The lymph nodes "absorb" some of the toxins of a near by infection, inflammation or injury to help the body heal quicker.  You may feel the lymph node as swollen or tender and not be able to pinpoint why.  I realize that this reply has come late in relation to your question, but give it a few days and see if it improves, if not you should follow up with your GP to determine if it is sometnigh more serious.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi indrajitkuri, Bone spurs may cause significant pain while walking if the location of these are in the heels. A xray should assist in diagnosis of this disorder and I would suggest that another set be completed. Treatment for bone spurs may include anti-inflammatory medications, orthotic devices/or padding in shoes, coticosteroid injections to relieve pain and surgical intervention, etc. Again I would suggest a re-evaluation. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: JustDionne  Guest Posts: 6 Joined: Wed Jun 29, 2005 2:14 pm Location: Prattville, AL
title: Pediatric knee problem
content: My daughter who is now 9 years old has been able to "pop" the bone in her shin where it attaches to the knee in and out at will since she was 3 years old.  Our family doctor insisted that the knee didn't require any intervention.  He said that children often have "soft" bones and ligament connections don't always tighten until they are much older.  As the ability to do this knee thing didn't seem to be causing her pain, he insisted we leave it alone and evaluate it later if it began to bother her.  Granted, it didn't seem to bother her so we did leave it alone, but I've insisted that she quit popping it in and out just for the fun of it.  Now, she seems to be having lots of problems with her knee.  She complains of pain in it constantly - sometimes worse than others.  When she is on it for a prolonged period, she actually retains quite a bit of fluid on it.  And now I notice that occassionally the knee just seems to give out on her making her fall.  I've taken her back to the family doctor for the problem, but he says that it is Austen-Schlatters (sp?) and there really isn't anything to do but exercise it regularly and take motrin for the pain.  That just doesn't seem right.  She is quite active already and given being on it for a long period makes it retain fluid and really hurt, I just don't think this is the best advice.  I am afraid that we've waited too long to treat this correctly.  I am afraid to take her to a regular orthopedic doctor, but can't get an appointment with a pediatric orthopedic doctor for many months.  Any suggestions what this might be?  And should I give in a take her to a regular orthopedic doctor instead of waiting for the pediatric ortho at Children's Hospital?  Thanks.
posted_time: Post  by JustDionne » Wed Jun 29, 2005 2:38 pm

author: Dr. Heba Ismail  Medical Doctor Posts: 328 Joined: Tue Sep 21, 2004 4:08 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear JustDionne,  Osgood-Schlatter disease occurs in children and adolescent athletes where repetitive extension of the knee causes inflammation and injury of the tibial tubercle (of the bone itself).  The tibial tubercle is the protuberant knob on the front of the tibia, a couple of inches below the knee, where the patellar tendon attaches. This pain is typically worse when extending the leg. The tibial tubercle is painful and tender to touch and over time begins to protrude more because the chronic inflammation stimulates the bone to grow.  This is a self-limited condition that usually resolves as the bone stops growing with the end of adolescence (at about age 17 years in males and age 15 years in females). Treatment includes PRICE therapy, which stands for:  PROTECT the knee from further trauma which can be done with knee padding.  REST the knee.  ICE the knee. Use an icebag placed on the knee 2-3 times a day for 20-30 minutes each time.  COMPRESS the knee with a knee brace or wrap.  ELEVATE the knee.  Over-the-counter pain control medications such as naproxen (Aleve or Naprosyn) and ibuprofen (Advil or Motrin) also play a role in treatment.  In severe cases, splinting the knee for a few weeks may help reduce the pain and halt the inflammation cycle.  My advice is: give the PRICE therapy together with medication one week, and if no improvemnt, go see an orthopedic doctor, as this usually points to some other underlying condition.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Heba Ismail » Fri Jul 01, 2005 3:40 am

author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: Do you notice a correlation between the flare ups of pain and high impact physical activity? Is there swelling or heat associated with the pain?  Your knees shouldn't hurt just to bend; you really do need to see a doctor.  If you have been active in sports for several years, you may have possibly strained the ligament(s) in your knees.  I assume from your name that you are active in sports.  If you are doing high impact activities (sports), that may be aggravating the problem.  Call your doctor, or if you don't have a regular doctor, ask someone at your health center about taking some antiinflammatories like ibuprofen (Advil) to reduce the inflammation/pain, and refrain from anymore strenuous activity until you can be seen.

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: INJURY TO TOE
content: Have you had an Xray to determine if there is bony injury? A dislocation or fracture can only be diagnosed by radiological investigation and  the mode of treatment is dependent on Xray findings. Subjecting a bruised and grossly swollen toe to more strain will be more damaging. Get that injured toe examined urgently so that treatment and healing can begin.   Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM

title: [no title]
content: Hi jill, Yes 3 days should be sufficient time for you to tell if it is exercise related. When you begin exercising again try doing a couple of your different ones at a time over a couple days before adding additional ones. If the pain exhibits itself after new exercices are added it would be easier to determine which ones to maybe avoid. This way you will know if the pain is related to overextending or something else. author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi joanne_1960, Actually your mom is correct especially if there is any redness or swelling that accompanies the pain. Gout is a form of rheumatic disease (one of the most painful) and it results from the formation of crystals of uric acid in connective tissue , joint space between 2 bones etc. Although drinking to much alcohol is a contributing factor, family history, being overweight, eating foods rich in purines, etc., are also contributing factors. Sincerely, Rntdj

title: Achilles tendon release surgery question?
content: Hi,   I'm not sure if I am posting this in the correct section or not, I was lookng for a neurologist section but couldn't find one. Anyway,  I have mild spastic Cererbral Palsy and use crutches to move around. Due to my CP my balance isn't too great and I am not able to move my right foot that well on my own.  Around 6 months ago I began to notice that my ankles were stiffer then usual and so I went to my family doctor and he said that I was beginning to get "frozen ankles" and my right foot is inverted some and getting worse. Recently I noticed my muscles getting really tight and uncomfortable. When I first seen a podiatrist he reccomended doing surgery to have the tendons released again.( I had this done already once when I was 3.) I was researching online and I read that having the surgery makes the muscles weaker and I was just wondering if I have it a second time would my ankles be too weak to support me?  Also Would anyone be able to give me more information on what the surgery involves and if there are any other options out there? I did recently get AFO's but  I don't see how they help stretch the muscles they seem to just hold my foot in the proper position. Thanks for the information in advance I appreciate it. Holly
posted_time: Post  by Hollyberry19 » Thu Apr 28, 2005 5:12 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Hollyberry19, The Achilles tendon is the largest/strongest tendon in the body and seems to cause significant problems in people suffering from Cerebral Palsy. Conservative treatment measures are stretching and casting but this offers limited success. To my knowledge surgical interventions involve essentially dividing the tendon, making incisions (cuts) in such a fashion that permits lengthening of the tendon.Tthe tendon is  then sutured into place, and a walking cast is placed for approximately 6 weeks, usually followed by physical therapy. As for muscle weakness involving the extended use of braces etc. this is found to be more common when surgical intervention is used to release spastic muscles verses tendons. Prior to any type of  surgical procedure, make sure you discuss the procedure, what to expect after a procedure, and expected outcomes with your physician so that you are well informed prior to an intervention.  I hope this information is somewhat useful.  Sincerely, Rntdj

Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM   Yes, there is a total absence of both phalanges of one thumb. posted_time: Post  by lefty » Sat Apr 16, 2005 10:23 pm

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: POUCE FLOTTANT THUMB
content: A thumb which is absent, rudimentary or without bones is generally described as a hypoplastic thumb.  If the thumb is present but has no bones  (phalanges), it is specifically known as a  POUCE FLOTTANT THUMB.   Dr Anthony Solomon MB BS DTM&H DIP.VEN FRSM  Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Anthony Solomon » Wed Apr 20, 2005 5:25 pm

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: POUCE FLOTTANT THUMB
content: I thought you may be interested to know how the term is derived:  flottant --  french word for floating pouce  --  french word for thumb  Therefore, the term literally means a floating thumb.   Dr Anthony Solomon

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: nodularis chronica
content: Hello,  Chondrodermatitis nodularis chronica helices is also known as Winkler’s disease.  This is a small, painful, scaly, nodular lesion on the helix (upper, outer cartilage rim) of the ear, colored skin color, grayish, or translucent; multiple lesions may occur along the rim of the ear. It can be caused from sleeping on one side, more common on the right side, can be surgically removed but may return. Very painful for your cousin to deal with, relief may be found with lidocaine ointment until it can be seen by a Physician. I can't find any information on a pillow made especially for this condition.
posted_time: Post  by Rhonda P, CEP » Mon Apr 04, 2005 5:41 pm

author: MACtools_2  Guest Posts: 11 Joined: Tue Feb 15, 2005 1:16 pm Location: Massachusetts
title: Pinched Nerve, or Something Worse?
content: I'll just give you my rundown of symptoms, please tell me what you think may be going on here (note: I am already in contact with my doctor, just waiting for him to open the office in 1/2-hour and call me back):   1. Been having upper back soreness lately (I KNOW this is from bad posture at my desk at work).  2. Last week, I had a sensation of "an explosion of tingliness" in the back of my head, it radiated down my arms and then my fingers felt tingly. Went away in just seconds.  3. Friday I woke up with a sore right shoulder muscle, but nothing to stop me from going about my normal daily activities.  4. Saturday I woke up with that same shoulder pain so BAD that it was debilitating. I called my MD, who gave me a muscle relaxer and an anti-inflammatory (we both figured it was another pinched nerve, as I had one about a year ago in the same spot). The meds didn't seem to do anything, not even make me tired, and the pain was UNBEARABLE, so I called him again, and he prescribed Vicodin. I took two of those, and went to bed a few hours later.  5. Easter Sunday - I wake up with still a little bit of soreness in the shoulder, but like Friday, nothing so bad as to stop me from normal activities. The vicodin was like my Easter miracle. I take one anti-inflammatory pill, as prescribed, NO vicodin, and NO muscle relaxer, and go to visit my parents for Easter.  6. Easter, while at my parents house, I get the sensation of "an explosion of tingliness" in my head again. author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Cervical spine compression
content: Hello,  If you have a Cervical spine compression you will probably be referred to a Neurologist by your Physician. A Neurologist is a doctor who specializes in diagnosing and treatment of nervous system disorders, including diseases of the brain, spinal cord, nerves and muscles that are shorting out because of nerve problems. The nervous system basically consists of the brain and its components, spinal cord, all nerves coming off the spinal cord and all nerves coming off of those nerves. The explanation of Neurological is real long, it is anything to do with the nervous system, the disorders of and functions of.   The Cervical spine is the vertebrae that make up your neck. Cervical spinal compression happens when something causes a narrowing of the canal or tube where the spinal cord runs through it. This can be caused by (to name a few) trauma, posture, or disease. This narrowing starts to irritate and squeeze the spinal cord and slows the flow of cerebrospinal fluid down that goes around the cord which adds to the irritation. All of this starts a variety of symptoms like tingling, numbness, weakness, severe pain, paralysis, and can eventually cause injury to the spinal cord, cervical discs and bones.

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Joanna,  Unusual to damage a calf muscle with a twisting mechanism, but the tender muscle on the backside of the calf, in the middle of your lower leg would be your gastrocnemius.  Apart from local tenderness, going on tip toes causes the pain to worsen.  Pain settles down eventually,  with ice, elevation and gentle exercises.    Sometimes people sustaining an injury to the gastrocnemius describe a sensation that someone hit then from behind.   A similar sensation can be associated with an Achilles tendon injury, and this would need susrgery.  Ankles can be sprained after a twisting injury, and this can affect the collateral ligaments on either side of the ankle or (more commonly) the anterior talofibular ligament, slightly in front and to the outer side of the ankle. Treatment is again is as you have doing, with rest, ice, elevation, compression, then gentle exercise.   This would not cause a pain in the calf.  However if the pain in the calf developed after a days from the injury, then the possibility of a Deep Vein Thrombosis needs to be excluded.  More common in females, in smokers and those on the oral contraceptive  pill, this is potentially serious compliavtion of lower limb injuries.  DVTs are assocaites with hardness, swelling and redness of the calf.  Moving the foot upwards may make the pain worse, but sometimes the problem is difficult to disctinguish from the less serious, but painful gastrocnemius injury.  If there is any doubt, I would consult a doc...distasteful creatures though we are   Saif

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Ken,  Flat feet (pes planus in doctors gobbledee Greek), is often associated with pains on the dorsum (top) of the foot.  This is said to be due to the fact that an arch to the foot is said to act like a spring and absorb some of the shocks of walking.  With falttened feet this shock is transmitted more to the joints between the tarsal bones, and the tarsometametatarsal joints.  This leads to arthritis here, and pain associated with this.  The holes in the bones probably represent degenerate subchondral cysts associated with this arthritis. Untreated this may progress to the extent that your feet migrates outwards, so that more and more pressure goes on the instep, with a callosity affecting the underside of the instep over time.  Treatment is with medial arch supports...uncomfortable to begin but useful if you persist with them in the first instance.  Gel ones are nice, custom ones are often better.  If very advanced the choice is between accommodative shoes or surgery...which has variable success rate.  regards  Saif  saif

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi there F Boy,  The lump you have could be an epitrochlear lymph node.  This can be enlarged due to viral infections. Some infection of the hand and forearm will cause this gland to become enlarged.  Lymph nodes can be enlarged for a variety of reasons, and many of them quite harmless, but it is worth checking it out with your doc, to find out whether there is something you should worry about or not.  Lipomas and neuromas and other-omas can also produce similar lumps.  Pulsatile lumps are usually vascular.  Sebaceous cysts are usually adherent to skin but not underlying tissue.  There are many to choose from, but as i say, get it checked out with your doc  Saif

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi ltlpeasmom, A "hot spot" on a bone scan is an abnormal finding. Some of the abnormalities that may be identified on a bone scan are fractures, bone infections, degenerative bone diseases, bone tumors, tumors that have spread from other parts of the body to the bone (metastatic disease) etc. A "pop" such as a fracture would be evident on this particular scan. Probably the reason for a repeat study in six months is to verify the cause. In my opinion, 6 months is not an unusual range, and I would consider it necessary. Sincerely, Rntdj

title: Rheumatoid Arthritis???
content: I injured my back in 97 working as a CNA.  I saw an orthopedic and trama specialist nearly a year later because my back and hips felt like they were burning. He did blood test.  It indicated I had the HLA B27 gene, and he recommended I see a rheumatogist.  He suggested he thought I had rheumatoid arthritis.  I don't have insurance, so I haven't gotten this checked, but as the years go by, and I now have kids, I really worry I will end up like other people I know with RA.  Am I being paranoid, or is this gene always and indicator for RA?  I posted this post before w/out a reponse, but like I said I have no insurance, so I don't want to spend money at a rheumatologist for nothing.  Please respond.  Thanks,  Nikky
posted_time: Post  by NikkyLeClair » Sat Jan 29, 2005 7:26 pm

author: Kathy C, RN  Nurse Posts: 84 Joined: Tue Jan 25, 2005 5:57 am Location: Titusville Florida
title: [no title]
content: Hi Nikky, You never did mention if you are having any symptoms or not now. I did some research on this and this is what I found:  HLA B27 is an inherited gene marker associated with a number of related rheumatic diseases. They share in common, features such as spinal and peripheral arthritis, skin and GI disorders, anterior chamber eye disease, and psoriasis like skin lesions. This gene is found with highest prevalence in patients with ankylosing spondylosis (>90%), reactive arthritis (80%), and patients with the combination of peripheral arthritis and either psoriasis or inflammatory bowel disease (50%). Statistics are, however, sometimes misleading. Although it is true that patients with classic disease will show the presence of the HLA B27 gene between 50 and 90+% of the time, if you randomly take 100 persons with the gene marker, you may find evidence of disease in only 25% of the study group. This suggests that most patients with the gene never develop any clinical rheumatic symptoms of t (Answer provided by the late Dr. Raymond Federman, aka Dr. Bones, who passed away on September 2, 2003. The care of his patients even in retirement was always his joy.)  Here is another one Using the new genetic testing methods, not all HLA-B27 genes are associated with an increased risk of developing ankylosing spondylitis (for example, HLA-B*2706 has not been shown to have an association). It is important to note that this test does not predict the development of autoimmune disease, and should not be used for this purpose.

title: joint pain and swollen hands
content: I'm 37 years old with two boys, 3 and 5.  I am still in the habit of picking them up and carrying them (i.e. when they are sick or asleep or when we are playing).  I have just started to experience pain in my joints in my ankles, knees, wrists and shoulders.  If I stop picking my boys up so much, could the pain subside, or could this be something more?
posted_time: Post  by quince » Wed Jan 19, 2005 10:16 am

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Dear Quince,  Certainly joint pains can be caused by excessive loaded activity, but I wouldn't ragrd picking up you 3 and 5 year old on odd occassions too much.  I would suggest that if the problem affects multiple joints, and is associated with swelling in these joints, there might be an inflammatory component to your predicament. This is then more a problem of your body reacting against your joints, rather than due to wear and tear, or mechanical stress.  Your doctor, may be able to advise better than I, but other symptoms may include redness and warmth in your joints with the swelling, lumps around your joints that do not subside competely when the swelling goes down, feeling unwell, having good weeks and bad weeks, morning stiffness, dry eyes, etc.  Regards  Saif

author: SportsDad  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Jan 19, 2005 7:34 am Location: Michigan
title: Swollen Elbow
content: My 13 year old son has been practicing with his baseball team and throwing an awful lot. We noticed that after practice a couple of days ago that his right elbow was swollen and he was unable to fully extend his arm. There is no pain and he has full range of motion with the exception of not being able to extend the arm straight out. We have iced the elbow, given him motrin for the inflamation and the swelling has subsided; however, he is still unable to fully extend the arm.  Is this a case of over working the elbow or something more serious? It does not appear to be an issue with the bursa because it does not appear to be your typical "Popeye" swelling.  Thanks for your assistance.
posted_time: Post  by SportsDad » Wed Jan 19, 2005 7:46 am

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Dear Sportsdad,  Sorry to here about your son...baseball has a lot to answer for; cricket on the other hand is a REAL sport  .  In cricket, bowlers have to keep the elbow straight you see.  This sounds like a repeated stess injury.  Bursitis typically starts on the tip of the elbow, doesnot involve mechanical structures directly, is more related to leaning on the elbows rather than sporting activities, and the "popeye arm" your describe are related to secondary inflammation, usually in adults, occassionally related to gout.  The injury that your son sustained may be more related to the common flexor origin (at a guess...).  This is the part ofthe inner side the elbow, where the bulk of the muscles that flex your wrist insert.  Try flexing your wrist, and feel on the inner side of the elbow...if the swelling your son has corresponds to the location of the bulge that appears on your elbow when you flex your wrist, then this is undoubtedly the case.  The treatment you have started is absolutely right, and you may a forearm support for future along with some reduction in the amount of throwing he does for some time.  That doesn't however explain why he is not able to fully extend his elbow.  This perhaps may related to some bicipital tendinitis.  The biceps tendon attached to the forearm in front of the elbow and is the cord like structure directly infront of your elbow.  If this is the area of tenderness or swelling, this may be the cause and may acccount for the limitation in extension.  Other non-specific problems can cause similar symptoms...for most scenarios the treament you have insituted would work very well.  Delay in resturn of full extension can be caused by swelling itself, if it is the joint, by local fibrosis, or rarely by myositis ossificans.  This last is a rare condition, and I wouldn't worry about this right now...suffice it to say that the treatment for this is said to be "masterly neglect"...i.e. the less you do to treat it, the better it gets.  Cheers  Saif
posted_time: Post  by Dr. A. Saif » Fri Jan 21, 2005 10:34 am

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi jay,  As always, it is difficult to comment without having you in front of me, but I will try to help.    The fall that you describe could have injured your ankle; you don't specify if you saw a doctor, or had any treatment.  This can lead to post traumatic arthritis, and while this can be evaluated and partly relieved by arthroscopic management, it is unlikely that this procedure will reverse  any damage that has already occured.  This arthritis is a progressive irreversible damage to your joint.  Physio can help, as can arthroscopic surgery and debridement.  If this fails paliative measures include local injections of steroids.  Other treatments include the use of rocker bottomed boots, and if all these fail more radical surgery like arthoplasty or even fusion can be considered as a last resort.  These surgical procedures can have significant complications.  Another problem that can happen  is an injury to your subtalar joint. The injury mechanism that you describe is a way that the os calcis (your heel bone) can be fractured.  This can lead to pain coming from the subtalar joint...a joint below the true ankle joint, that would not be addressed during an arthroscopy.  Problems here are again difficult to treat, and typically give pain more when walking on uneven ground.   You orthopedic surgeon would be best able to identify which is the best joint to address, and I am sure the relevent investigations will indicate the best mode of treatment.    If on the other hand there is no degenerative arthritis, and there is no reasonable explanation for the pain (as your note seems also to suggest), it is possible that you may have something like Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy (RSD, also called  algodystrophy, or complex regional pain syndrome).  This is extremely difficult to treat, and sometimes a pain specialist can help.    Yet another problem that can also be a source of pain is the tarsal tunnel syndrome, and i won't go through a convoluted description of this...a better resource is found at http://www.podiatrychannel.com/tarsaltunnelsyndrome/  The superficial peroneal nerve can be bruised or damaged during arthroscopic surgery, its anatomy is variable, so not always possible to avoid, and it is possible this is the cause of your numbness in your foot...for a detailed study of the various paths see http://www.med.ub.es/~aprats/sae/EJA/EJA_V7_S1_03.pdf.  The upshot of this is that while the nerve is infrequently injured using the normal portals, it can be damaged if it takes an unusual path.  If it hasn't recovered by now, it is probably unlikely to.  hope this helps  Regards  Saif[/url]
posted_time: Post  by Dr. A. Saif » Sun Jan 16, 2005 12:33 pm

content: Dear MojoGirl,  From your description this sounds like this is most probably, a mild inflammation of the membrane sourrounding the lungs, a condition called pleurisy. author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Mak,  Having never heard of prolotherapy before, I looked it up on the web. This site was enlightening http://www.physsportsmed.com/issues/2000/08_00/news.htm, as was this article from "quackwatch.com" http://www.quackwatch.org/01QuackeryRel ... prolo.html.  Both these are quite old (4 years), so unless new evidence has demonstrated efficacy, I would consider this treatment dubious. There are plenty of sites promoting this suggesting that it is pretty good, most of these are sites that offer this kind of treatment.  Logic would suggest that if your do have a complete tear of the suprspinatus tendon, then injection of sugar will not help.  Steroid injections can sometimes alleviate some symptoms.  If it is a partial tear, injection of sclerosants may help in theory, but there is also probably the risk of converting a partial tear to a complete tear (in deed this is what we warn all our patients before injecting steroids).  I would suggest seeking a second opinion...but as I say, I have no experience of this therapeutic option.  Regards  Saif

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Dear Over,  It is difficult to comment on foot problems without having you in front of me.  However I will try to help.  Metatarsalgia has many causes, and is common in ladies.  You description of the pain is a bit confusing for my brain...as I am myself rather aged you see.  you say "going laterally"...does this mean on the lateral (outer) side of the feet, or starting on the inner side and heading laterally across your metatarsals?  Most commonly patients present with pain at the balls of the feet when walking as if walking on marbles, there may be thickened skin here, and treatment is initially the use of insoles that raise the transverse arch and abstaining from high heeled shoes for a while.  More drastic treatments exist of course.  A different problem, Morton's metaratarsalgia, is pain actually cause by a pseudo neuroma in between usually the 3rd and 4rth Metatarsals, but occassionally the 2nd and 3rd.  Typically patients say that the feet feel better when walking barefoot than with closed in shoes.  This too can be helped by the insoles I described.  There is no substitue for a doctor examining you and reaching the appropriate diagnosis but i hope this helps  Saif

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi there Ms Cobra,  Lots of posibilities from you description, I guess...and if it is swollen after ten days and you still have pain, it certainly is wrth getting further attention to it.  If you can weight bear and lift your leg straight up in the airwhile lying flat, it is unlikely to be serious.  You say you can't straighten it...sometimes fluid in the knee joint can cause this.  It can also be caused by a damaged menscus, although unlikely with your description of the mechanism. A locked knee is one that is stuck at around 20 degrees or so and you can not extend it any further...loose bodies within your knee or a torn meniscus can cause this...as i say unlikely in your case. You say the swelling is on the inside of the knee...does this mean the inner side (on the side nearest the other side), or within the knee the knee joint itself? A sprined medial collateral can cause pain on the inner side of the knee, but again is unlikely with a direct impact injury to the knee.  Most common problem that people get after landing directly on the knee cap, is bruising to the undersurface of the patella.  This causes pain, particularly when going up and downstairs, getting up out of a chair, or kneeling.  It seems not so painful walking, in this situation and patients often walk stiff legged.  Ice packs and gentle quads strengthening exercise help.    As I say if it is not getting better after 10 days, then i would recommend a consultation with your doc would be appropriate.  Regards  Saif

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: If I understand you correctly what you are describing is called "snapping hip syndrome". The internal snapping hip is most commonly associated with an audible and painful displacement of the iliopsoas tendon over bony pelvic or femoral prominences.  Surgical treatment consists of lengthening the iliopsoas tendon.  The pain associated with the disorder is generally believed to be due to the sharp movement of the iliopsoas tendon over the pelvic pectineal eminence, femoral head, or lesser trochanter. Usually two weeks after surgery 14 days after surgery full weightbearing and physical therapy is initiated. Therapy includes stretching of the iliopsoas tendon (hip extension) and progressive, concentric resistive exercises of all the muscles around the hip. Aquatic therapy can also be used. Anti-inflammatory medication is used to help reduce the inflammation and subsequent pain. There are some studies out to show that botox injections into the muscles surrounding the area have helped to alleviate the pain when no other interventions have been effective. Chronic pain in certainly both physically and mentally debilitating and that is why there is now a specialty for doctors to go into that is called "Chronic Pain Management"  Seeing a doctor who specializes in pain management might be of benefit also.  I suggest you discuss these  possibilities with your physician and that you ask for a referral to a Chronic Pain Management physician. Best regards, Carolyn

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Flower,  I am sorry to hear about your problems with your ankle.  I see that you have already had an ankle ligament repair in the past.  The swelling on the side of the ankle occurs after strains and sprains of the lateral colateral and the anterior talo-fibular ligament, and as someone suffering from chronic instability you are I guess vulneranble to these.  Three components of any joint determine stability, the bony architecture, the ligaments between the bones, and the muscles that cross the joint.   Instabilty can be due to deficiencies in one or more of these.  In fact is is possible to compensate for the deficiency in one, by augmenting the contribution from another component.  For example, if your ligaments are inherently weak, in theory, by improving muscle power, one can improve the stability of the joint.  Bony deficiencies can be only treated with surgery Acute ligament deficiencies (e.g. due to recent injury) have some limited capacity for healing, but require rest and stabilisation for this.  Longstanding ligament deficiency, or that due generalised joint hypermobility will not respond to this.  Rest and stabilisation however weaken the muscles. Muscle contribution to stability is improved by exercise, but may (possibly) compromise the healing of some of the structures.  Here is the dilemma...do we rest and splint the joint to allow the tissues to heal, but risk the muscles going weak, or do we exercise the muscles to improve their contribution to stability...but risk losing the potential stability gains from the healing of the damaged ligaments.  I would suggest that in the acute phase...shortly after the injury and while the ankle is still sore, we rest and splint the joint (e.g. wear boots, ice, elevate, and avoid high impact activity etc)...this should be limited to say a maximum of 6 weeks.  Then we start building up muscle power, again avoiding high impact activities, and avoiding stretching exercises.  Why avoiding stretching exercises?  Because stiffness is, in your situation, better than instability.   We can focus on range of motion once everything is settled.  Flower, there is no simple solution, I am afraid, and I would suggest tailoring your therapy to your response. I hope this helps,  and hope you have a good Xmas and new year.  yours sincerely  Saif

title: i don't know what to call it
content: im not sure if im posting in the right forum but here it goes my left leg is extremely smaller than the right-ive been diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome since a young child-im now 25-  its the whole left leg from the waist down including the buttocks-occassionally i have sharp pains in the leg and i the knee and its only the left leg-because of this i don't sit up straight, i sit like on a slant because the muscles in my buttocks seemed to deteriorate-i have no muscle definition-no hardness to the muscle. i  also walk with a limp    any help or advice

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Bleu,  Will try to help, if I can, it is difficult without having you in front of me.  I would like to focus on three possibilities...but we need to be clear whether this is a global shortening of the limb, and apparent shortening of the limb or a shortening due to a focal pathology.  Global shortening are usually due to something that affects the leg development as a child, often due to a vascular problems.  Similar problems (vascular malformations such as AV fistulas can make a limb abnormally bigger than the other).  Other causes are polio etc. Vascular problems are associated with nephrotic syndrome, but global shortening is not common, in my experience.  Apparent shortening is due to the tilting of your pelvis, perhaps due to a spinal problem.  The tilted pelvis makes one leg appear longer than the other when standing, but when sitting, with the pelvis level and the legs in the same position, the legs look the same length.  This is possible in patients with renal pathology, and perhaps patients who have high dose steroids on multiple occassions in the past.  The scoliosis (curvature of the spine)  may also explain why you sit on a tilt.  Another possibility, and the most common is a focal apthology in the hip.  This can be due to Avascular Necrosis (AVN) of the Femoral Head.  This would give you stiffness and pain in you hip, pain being in the groin, occassionally referred to your knee.  This reduces the length of your leg, (further exaggerated if you have a fixed adduction deformity i.e. if you cannot move your leg outwards).  If you have a fixed flexion deformity associated wih this you may also find that you are having to adopt a tilt to sit properly...  Bleu, these are a ew things to consider...if you have any more questions please do not hesitate to ask...but in the mean time have a merry Xmas, and a happy new year  Saif

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Dear Rizanno,  It may be difficult for a doctor to address the issue of you computer avidity .  It is true that slouching in front of a computer aint good for your back.  There is two comments I would make in the light of your story...(you don't say how you have been "disabled for the last 5-6years", it may be relevant but lets ignore that for now). There are stools designed to improve posture when you sit in front of the computer, and a recliner may not be the best piece of furniture, but it may be the most comfortable with your disability.  Comment 1) Tilting to one side, and the appearance on one side of the chest being hiher than the other, may suggest a scoliosis...a curvature of the spine.  treatment is the treament of the cause for scolisis...if it is longstanding then it becomes tricky to treat...if it is progressive at your age, then this needs investigation and treatment.  Comment 2) While nerves can be pinched by the ribs the intercostal nerves only supply a thin strip of skin allong your chest wall  not down your arm.  This would imply a problem elsewhere, perhaps in your neck (although rarely a cervical rib...an extra rib  can cause trapping of nerves in your arm)   Hope this helps...  Saif

title: Tendonitis?
content: Dear Doctor,  I have recently been having problems with pain in my achilles tendon bilaterally.  It seems to be worse after walking/being on my feet for a long time, and hurts the most when I flex my feet (walking), and especially after I have been sitting for a long while and when I wake up in the morning.  I wear birkenstock clogs alot with no strap in the back and lots of slide on type shoes, could my shoes be the culprit of my pain?  How can I treat the pain?  Thanks in advance.
posted_time: Post  by Kady » Thu Dec 09, 2004 6:56 pm

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Kady,  I guess you could have achilles tendinitis.  The tendon itself becomes tender in this situation and "taking off" becomes uncomfortable.   Another possibilty is paratendinitis which is an inflammation of the lining of the tendon.  If the tendon looks swollen and the normal  concavity on either side looks as if it is no longer concave then paratndinitis is more likely.  Tis latter condition is associated with other system inflammatory pathologies, like Rheumatoid Arthritis,  I ahve not heard of it being associated with inflammatory bowel pathology which you seem to have...but i guess that is possible.  Assuming that it is tendinitis rather than paratendinitis, then the cause is said to be mechanical.  The solution is usually interferential treatment such as warm packs, and conversely ice packs and rest.  Anti inflammtories help.  Another thing worth trying is shock absorbent heel cushions that you can get in sports shops.  These reduce the shock of the impact of walking and help to some extent.  Unusually, it is also a condition that seems to be relieved by having a slightly higher heel in the shoe.  Paratendinitis is less common and again can respond to the above treatments...however this is perhaps better addressed in conjunction with the underlying systemic process (if there is one)  Hope this helps  Saif

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Chelle,  Poor Brian...sounds like he does need help (if not being hog tied and dragged to the doctor!) . Falling down a 6-foot hole can give you a lot of potential causes of the pains you describe in your husband. So first we need to be certain that we are looking at the right area of the problem.  Can you describe any bruising? Does it hurt anywhere to press? Is the knee, hip or ankle tender or swollen? Does movement of these joints cause pain? If the answer to all of these is no, then perhaps a prolapsed disc is the problem...as always it is difficult to diagnose with the limited examination that can be done over the internet icon_sad.gif  A "disc" is like a bag of jelly that sits between the bones of your spine (the vertebrae). The vertebrae form a channel (called the spinal canal) for the spinal cord and nerves that take signals between your brain and the rest of your body. A prolapsed disc is when the bag of jelly bursts or bulges and presses on the nerves or the cord in the canal. This affects the function of the nerve, so 1) there may be pain in the area where the nerve takes pain signals from (not in the back, but somewhere say in the leg) 2) there may be numbness in parts where the nerve supplies touch sensation to. There may be pins and needles in this area 3) there may be weakness in the muscle groups supplied by the nerve  If the weakness involves the sphincter muscles then there may be difficulty in passing or controling urination, or feeling when urine is apssed. This is an emergency and should be dealt with IMMEDIATELY. If the weekness leads to a foot drop, again this is another criteria for early treatment.  Associated back pain may exist, however, there does not need to be any back pain, although the problem is indeed in the back.  Hope this helps, 'Chelle and hope your hubby gets better, and an Orthopaedic Surgeon is the kind of doctor you (rather your hog-tied husband) needs...  Saif  _________________ thinking, thinking, thing.... nope, no good, I give up.

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Dear Rhoda,  Along with a number of conditions yes, damaged discs can cause numbness in the feet.  More likely if the numbness is spreading from the feet up, then the causes are more likely to be some peripherial neuropathy, including conditions like diabetes.  Numbness caused by discs, or more often in your age group, spinal stenosis secondary to degenerative disease of the spine, can happen, though.  Symptoms include burning pain, aggravated by exercise, helped by leaning forward, weakness in the lower legs. Treatment is dependant on the severity of the disease, but most often it is conservative (i.e. non-operative, with physio etc.)  But I would strongly suggest that other causes of neuropathy are eliminated before committing to this diagnosis.  Regards  Saif

content: i have 2 fingers that stay numb on right hand and have had an mri of my wrist and it shows a torn cartilage.will it heal? and a nerve study was done and the diagnosis was cubital tunnel.will this get better without surgury?i had a debridement on my elbow and the pain is still the same and i have a doctor who says i am released to my full recovery and i feel nothing is better.

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi there Dsssatcom,  Seems like you have a couple of "problems".  You say you have had debridement of the elbow.  Why diod you need it Was this in relation to arthritis of the elbow, or a wound?  Which bit of the elbow was involved?     1) Cubital Tunnel Syndrome produces ulnar nerve compression or irritation leading to the numbness in the little finger, and it is said, half your ring finger (there may be some variation), pins and needles in this area, weakness in some of the small muscles of the hand and on occassion, when severe, "clawing" of the hand.  The nerve is trapped as it travels around the elbow on its way to the hand...it is the "funny bone" nerve.   There are two components to the problem...one is the caused by the nerve being irritated (the pins and needles and pain), and the other caused by actual nerve loss of function (weakness and numbness).  Incidentally, ulnar nerve symptoms can be caused by cubital syndrome, or direct injury to the nerve.  Symptoms may also arise from problems in the neck or in the wrist.  Cubital tunnel syndrome can be treated surgically, but other measures exist.  Night splints that extend the elbow can help reduce symptoms.  Occassionally a local steroid injection may help.  If there is confirmed cubital tunnel syndrome, then the only reason for not doing something is when the conduction study suggests the nerve damage is so extensive that recovery is unlikely.  After a surgical decompression, the irritation symptoms should recover.  The function recovers to a variable extent and sometimes incompletely depending on the amount of damage that has occured already.   If the recovery is incomplete, there is no guarantee that you will get back full recovery, the nerve regeneration rate is said to be one mm a day, so may take months before you notice benefit.  2) The cartilage tear in the wrist I presume refers to the "triangular fibro-cartlilage" (TFC), in the wrist joint.  This a small bit of tissue that lies in the wrist joint only the "pinky" side of your wrist.  In most people the tears do not cause any symptoms.  In those that do, the symptoms are usually of twinges of pain on certain specific maneouvres, clicking and rarely locking.  The tear does not heal usually, but usually becomes smaller and less problematic, but modern surgical techniques exist to help those in whom it causes sustained problems.  This is usually in the form a arthroscopic debridement ("key hole surgery") of  the wrist.  I hope this helps.  It is difficult to be specific without having you in front of me, please let me know if you need any more questions answered   Regards  Saif

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi David,  I have to confess I have very little experience with chest wall  problems which are normall dealt with Paediatric Surgeons in the UK.  However I will try to help.  It does sound though that you have significant problems and it is certainly very important that you consult with a specialist, as the respiratory performance is compromised in your case.     You are right of course that Marfan's is associated with chest wall abnormalities, along with a host of other problems, some of which you mention.  It is genetic, and you do not mention if any of your relatives have these features and have been diagnosed with Marfan's...although spontaneous cases (without a family history) do occur.  Both Pectus excavatum (depression in the chest wall) and pectus carinatum, (pointy out chest wall) can occur. It is difficult for me diagnose this in you on-line.  The one feature that sticks out in your description is the fact that the chest wall problem is assymetrical (one side affected, the other side not).  Two things come to mind (barring the causes due to surgery or trauma) from my medical school days.  Most common cause of chest wall assymetry is scoliosis (curvature of the spine), and then there is the rarer Poland syndrome when the muscles and the skeleton on one side do not develop properly.  Several other conditions exist in between...not least of which is idiopathic.  David, I firmly believe that you should be seeking at least a consultation with a Surgeon to advise your further, as your breathing is affected...the treatment unfortunately is surgical, and there is, as far as I know no conservative solution.  I have for your information, included a few references from the web, that may be of interest to you, and apologise for my lack of expertise in this field  regards  saif   http://www.hmc.psu.edu/childrens/health ... stwall.htm  http://www.pectusdeformity.com/  http://www.emedicine.com/plastic/topic458.htm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello, Shin splints is the name given to pain at the front of the lower leg. The most common cause is inflammation of the periostium of the tibia (sheath surrounding the bone). The injury is an overuse injury and can be caused by running on hard surfaces, running on tip toes and sports where a lot of jumping is involved. If you over pronate then you are also more susceptible to this injury.   In its earliest stages, because it is an overuse injury, rest is mandatory. Applying ice may help if it is very painful. An anti-inflammatory medication may also be required.  In your case since it has been going on for some time I would advise:   Wearing shock absorbing insoles in shoes.  Maintaining fitness with other non weight bearing exercises.  Applying heat and use a heat retainer after the initial acute stage, particularly before training.  If the symptoms should continue still, then you should see a sports injury specialist who as you may need a brief rehabilitation program. He can also help analyse running style for over pronation.   Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Sat Aug 28, 2004 12:57 pm

author: surfergirl  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Wed Sep 01, 2004 12:27 am Location: Philippines
title: [no title]
content: Shin splints.... How I hate them too.    You really have to have a good pair ofrunning shoes  Also, before doing a sport or any activity that involves the legs, try to stretch your tibialis anterior muscles, the muscles attached to your shin by pulling down your foot as if making a tip-toe.  Hold the stretch for at least 30 seconds until you feel some "stretch" on the front side of your leg.  Repeat that several times.  Then stretch your calf muscles.  After a sprint or any running activity, apply ice directly on the painful site for 10 minutes.  Do this with and wothout pain.      Ciao!

title: Proper Procedure
content: Lets say a patient comes in claiming he injured his shoulder, maybe even thinks he dislocated it. What is proper procedure for Dr to do? Does he leave and tells nurse to administer medication, or does he examine the injured area by placing his hands on it, or does he just walk away and allows meds to be administered? title: Neck Injury
content: Ok, so I was at a party and happened to be in a fight. Yes, I'am not one who gets in fights but for some reason it happened. I was talking to a friend and a kid from my right back side punched me in the side of the throat. I think it might have been an uppercut becuase it also grazed my jaw bone. Anyways that is the injury. I have soreness in the right side of my neck and jaw, I noticed 3 red dots in the center of my neck and I' am not sure what those are from. They are very small and placed in a v kind of, but are spaced apart about a half a centimeter. Anyways I see no external bruising, but I assume there is brusing because it is sore.   My concern is not my neck bones or jaw ect.. My concern is internal bleeding. I have worked myself up over this I'am sure but for some reason I needed to look up symptoms of internal bleeding and I saw the red dots (well this was under a subcategory of brusing, may be it was just a sign of a small bruise) Anyways, my question is, could a punch to the neck cause internal bleeding? If so how could I tell without seeing a doctor (which I most likely will be). Would I be cold? This happened Tuesday night at around 12 a.m. If it were a very small cut would I notice anything? Any information or ideas would help thanks.

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  I see that you have the Phantom's punch mark, which could be a big scoop! Check out the ID of the boy who hit you!  Anyways, jokes apart, internal bleeding if long enough or large enough would cause you to be hypotensive, which means your blood pressure may go down making you dizzy and causing loss of consciousness. If you're reading this message right now, then know that nothing of the sort has happened to you. So, relax! But be careful to spar and block them punches!  Hope this helps,  bill

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  By 'the hole above your collar bone,' do you mean the one centrally located at the lower end of your neck, or the ones on either sides of the neck, i.e., between the neck and the shoulder tips?  The central 'hole' below the neck is called the 'suprasternal notch.' The depressions above the collar bones on either sides of the neck are called the right/left 'supraclavicular fossa' [clavicle=collar bones].  bill
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Russell M » Fri May 21, 2004 10:48 am

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  I would think it best to get yourself examined by your doctor. Costochondritis [the inflammation of the joints between the ribs and the breast bone] is what comes to my mind, but I could be wrong. If that is the case, analgesics should help. Reduced stomach ulcer disease is noted during pregnancy due to reduced acid secretion by stomach. If there is relief for your pain with antacids, it is a pointer to stomach acidity/ulcers.  Hope this helps.  Warm regards,  -Bill
